headline: STATE SAVINGS BANKS HEALTHIER
abstract: Savings banks in New York State showed considerable improvement in the second quarter, although more than half of them continued to report operating losses, according to the state banking department.    Operating losses were cut dramatically, to a total of $55.1 million, from $269.9 million in the second quarter of 1982, and from $116 million in the first quarter of this year.   As a result, the sense of impending doom within the industry has lifted. It has become far less likely that Federal and state regulatory authorities will force mergers of failing institutions into stronger ones.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Sale of Gold By Lisbon Seen    LISBON, Sept. 6 (AP) - Portugal may have to sell about 30 tons of gold, worth about $404 million, to repay a $300 million loan from the Bank of International Settlements, banking sources said today.   Portugal's central bank deposited 36 tons of gold in March to back a $400 million loan, and deposited 30 tons in May for a $300 million credit with the settlements bank.

headline: 'Smear' Seen On I.M.F. Bill
abstract: Democrats in the House of Representatives told President Reagan today that a ''smear campaign'' by a Republican committee might jeopardize his chances for gaining final approval of increased support for the International Monetary Fund.   A vote on a House-Senate compromise version is due this fall.

headline: Pope Says All Possible Steps Are Being Taken to Free Girl
abstract: Pope John Paul II said today that he was doing ''all that is humanly possible'' to help free a 15-year-old girl apparently being held as a hostage for the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who shot the Pope.   The Pope told 30,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square, ''Once again, as last Sunday, I want to recommend to your prayers Emanuela Orlandi, for whom I and all of us together with the afflicted family, wait with anxiety for the return.''

headline: Petrobras in Talks With Oil Concerns
abstract: Petrobras, the Brazilian state oil company, has opened talks with three multinational oil companies aimed at importing part of the country's oil needs under favorable terms, officials said.   Carlos Santanna, the company's commercial director, said at a news conference that the talks had begun in London and New York between Petrobras and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Exxon and Atlantic Richfield.   Brazil is attempting to import oil from the three companies with payment deferred for 180 days. Mr. Santanna indicated that companies that did not comply would receive less favorable terms for their operations in Brazil.

headline: KOHL PARTY SUFFERS SETBACK IN STATE VOTE
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party suffered a sharp reverse today in a closely watched election in the industrial state of Hesse, where the national opposition party, the Social Democrats, emerged as the largest single group but fell short of a governing majority.   In a day of voting seen as the first significant test of opinion on the one- year-old Kohl Government, the Social Democrats also strengthened their majority in the legislature of the small northern state of Bremen, which has the highest level of unemployment in the country.   Both states are traditional Social Democratic strongholds, and politicians were reluctant to draw sweeping conclusions about national politics from the two regional elections. But the conservative Kohl Government, now confronting difficult foreign and economic policy decisions, was hardly bolstered by the results.

headline: LOPSIDED ECONOMIC RECOVERY
abstract: The Western industrialized world is entering a period of lopsided economic recovery with the United States and Japanese economies likely to perform significantly better during the next 18 months than those of Western Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its semiannual forecast released today.   ''Evidence that recovery is under way is now quite clear in the U.S., and detectable - though less so and with some important differences among countries - elsewhere in the O.E.C.D.,'' Sylvia Ostry, the organization's chief economist, told a news conference when she introduced the new forecasts. The projections were contained in The Economic Outlook, the group's semiannual review of Western economic policy.   But the O.E.C.D. warned that the uneven recovery now beginning in the West was still vulnerable to high American interest rates and weak demand that threaten to choke off the revival of industrial investment that is necessary if the recovery is to become selfsustaining.

headline: CHINESE MOBILIZE FOR NEW FLOODING
abstract: China's heartland is bracing for potentially serious flooding along the Yangtze River after torrential rains last week that inundated the industrial city of Wuhan.   More than a million Chinese have been mobilized to patrol along the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze day and night to to prevent it from bursting its banks and covering the surrounding countryside, the New China News Agency quoted a spokesman from the central flood control headquarters as saying.   They include 43,000 soldiers and civilians working on the dikes, which were reinforced several years ago at a cost of about $10 million. The water level is said to be the second highest at Wuhan and downriver in 29 years.

headline: STREET URCHINS IN BRAZIL FIND A TOWN THAT CARES
abstract: In most respects, this town of 20,000 inhabitants on Brazil's vast tableland is like thousands of other towns across Latin America.   A jouncing 50-mile ride along a dirt road from the nearest highway brings you to a community that is centered on a plaza dominated by a scrubbed white church, with its steeple rising over clusters of terra-cotta roofs.   Donkey carts rattle over cobblestone streets alongside pickups whose wheels and fenders are layered with red dust. Old men pass the morning in desultory conversation on concrete benches bearing the names of past mayors in lordly script.

headline: Dutch Jobless
abstract: Dutch unemployment rose to a postwar record of 810,400 in June from 793,300 in May, the Social Affairs Ministry reported today. In June 1982, seasonally adjusted unemployment stood at 655,500.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS JET CONTRACT
abstract: In a major victory for the General Dynamics Corporation, the Turkish Ministry of Defense said yesterday that it would buy the F-16 jet fighter, made by General Dynamics, to modernize its air force. Turkish military sources said that the Government would buy some 160 planes for an estimated $4 billion over 10 years.   It was the first time since the mid 1970's that General Dynamics' F-16 had won an international competition over the F-18, made jointly by the Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.   In St. Louis, General Dynamics said that while it had not yet been told officially, it understood that it had won and that negotiations between the United States and Turkey would be held over the next three months.

headline: IN COMMAND IN GUATEMALA
abstract: Brig. Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, who became the provisional President of Guatemala today, is a career army officer with a reputation for devotion to the military and to its hard-line solutions to the country's problems.  His ascension to power is expected to result in a change less in substance than in the style of the Government, which has been run for the last 17 months by Brig.Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, whose moralistic attitude had increasingly angered military officers, businessmen and politicians.   What are not expected to change under General Mejia Victores are policies that have been bitterly attacked by human rights organizations. As Defense Minister, General Mejia Victores helped preside over a campaign against leftist guerrillas that has drawn criticism for causing the deaths of thousands of civilians and for routing hundreds of thousands from their homes.

headline: BISHOPS WITHDRAW SHARP CRITICISM OF MARCOS
abstract: The Roman Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines announced today that a pastoral letter sharply criticizing President Ferdinand E. Marcos was withdrawn Friday after Mr. Marcos decreed the repeal or modification of his powers to arrest suspected rebels and subversives.    The bishops' letter, titled ''A Message to the People of God,'' condemned as immoral the President's power to have people imprisoned without the right of appeal to any court.   Msgr. Dexter H. Irisari, a spokesman for the 109-member Bishops' Conference, said the letter was withdrawn several hours after the presidential palace announced that the ''presidential commitment order'' had been abolished.

headline: Airlines Serving Moscow
abstract: Following is a list of Western European airlines and other non-Soviet bloc carriers and the flights they operate in and out of Moscow: British Airways - Four flights a week, and a weekly London- Moscow-Tokyo service. Air France - Five weekly flights and a weekly Paris-Moscow-Tokyo flight, returning via New Delhi and Moscow.

headline: Highest Soviet Award Is Given to Jaruzelski
abstract: The Soviet Union today bestowed its highest award, the Order of Lenin, on the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.  The award marked General Jaruzelski's 60th birthday, and Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported that it was made ''in recognition of his services in the development of the fraternal friendship and cooperation'' between Poland and the Soviet Union.

headline: 25,000 IN ARGENTINA PROTEST MILITARY'S PLAN FOR AMNESTY
abstract: More than 25,000 Argentines marched here today to protest a proposed amnesty that would protect the military against prosecution for the disappearances, deaths and tortures that occurred in the antiterrorist campaign in the 1970's.   The march, called by the country's eight major human rights groups, was boisterous but peaceful as it crawled the 12 blocks from a downtown corner to Congress.   The junta of three service chiefs is reportedly on the verge of declaring the amnesty, which is widely seen as the single most explosive issue in the path of the country's promised return to democracy.

headline: Advertising; A New Ad Medium For TV
abstract: TELEVISION syndication, which has been a factor in the business as long as stations have needed programming, has moved into a bright new day as a major advertising medium that might some day challenge the three commercial networks.   Some in the business, like Henry Siegel, chairman of Lexington Broadcast Services, and Robert L. Turner, president, think that time is close at hand.   ''And, if we are successful,'' said Mr. Turner, ''the advertisers will have to ask, 'Why do we need the networks?' Producers will have to ask, 'Are there other places I can go if I can't get a satisfactory deal?' ''   You might call Mr. Turner a recent convert expressing all of the usually strong convictions of a convert, since he joined Mr. Siegel at the Grey Advertising subsidiary only a year ago from the sinking CBS Cable, where he was vice president and general manager. And he recently also became president of the newly formed Advertiser Syndicate Television Association, with 15 members, going on 30. Its function, he explained, ''is to get advertisers to think about syndication and help educate the agencies about it.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: British Name Railroad Chief    LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) - The Government today named Bob Reid, a veteran railroad executive, as chairman of British Rail, Britain's state-run railways, for the next three years.

headline: IN CONGRESS, BITTER WORDS AND DEMAND FOR SANCTIONS
abstract: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders jointly introduced a resolution today ''condemning the brutal behavior'' of the Soviet Union in destroying Korean Air Lines Flight 7, but many liberals and conservatives in both houses pressed for action stronger than words.   The leaders of the House, meanwhile, worked on a similar resolution amid a rising call for sanctions against the Soviet Government. The House resolution is expected to be introduced on Tuesday. Votes in both houses are planned for Wednesday.

headline: COURT TO SELECT TRUSTEE FOR HUGHES INTERESTS
abstract: The question of who will run the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, and thereby control the Hughes Aircraft Company, a leading aerospace and military contractor, has been placed in the hands of a Delaware Chancery Court judge.   In a suit filed in 1978 and heard Monday, the state charged that two long-time aides to Howard R. Hughes - F. William Gay, his chauffeur, and Chester Davis, a lawyer - usurped control of the nonprofit institute after the billionaire's death in 1976. According to the suit, the two men improperly changed the bylaws of the institute in 1971 to allow them to gain control after Hughes died.  Hughes put the aircraft company under the institute's control in 1953, for tax purposes.

headline: Heileman's Net Up 32%
abstract: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said today that second-quarter earnings rose 32 percent, to $19.6 million.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Creditors Back Hyatt Braniff Plan    FORT WORTH, Aug. 30 (AP) - Creditors of the Braniff International Corporation have approved a reorganization plan that would put 30 planes and 2,000 employees back to work this winter, attorneys for the airline told United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers today.   Judge Flowers was asked to give final court approval to a plan under which the Hyatt Corporation would invest $70 million in exchange for 80 percent of the stock in the new company. He tentatively approved the vote and continued the court hearing until Wednesday.

headline: WARSAW PRESSING DRIVE ON DISSENT
abstract: Despite public hints that martial law restrictions may soon be lifted after the visit of Pope John Paul II, the Polish authorities are continuing, and in some ways intensifying, a crackdown on dissent.   The major targets of the campaign are intellectuals, writers and artists, largely supportive of the banned Solidarity union, who have steadfastly refused to give allegiance to the Government of Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski.   Polish intellectuals were taken aback by two recent articles in the Communist Party daily newspaper, Trybuna Ludu, which attacked virtually every important living Polish writer by name.   ''Anyone who escaped mention is very upset, of course,'' a Polish journalist said, ''because everyone else will think less of him.''

headline: Northwest Air Reports Profit
abstract: Northwest Airlines yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $14.4 million, or 66 cents a share, on revenues of $537.5 million.

headline: DRUSE PREVENT REOPENING OF BEIRUT'S AIRPORT
abstract: The Druse militia threatened today to take military action if the Lebanese Government went ahead with a plan to reopen the Beirut International Airport. Hours later, the Government announced it would put off opening the airport.   The threat from the Druse militia forces and the Government's response came as representatives of the Government and warring political factions met for the first tiome today to discuss ways of enforcing the cease-fire agreement that took effect on Monday, ending a month of warfare.

headline: TELEPHONE COSTS WILL BE INCREASED UNDER F.C.C. PLAN
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission approved a plan yesterday that would add $2 a month to the cost of a residential telephone line, and $6 a month to the cost of business lines, starting in January.   The commission's decision, which could be overridden by Congress, is designed to end the nearly 50-year-old practice of using the revenues from long-distance service to subsidize local telephone service, so that its rates could be kept low enough to be affordable by nearly everyone.   Growing competition in providing long-distance telephone service, and the coming breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has made the subsidy an obstacle to lower rates for the competing long-distance carriers. The F.C.C. ruling yesterday orders that the subsidies be phased out after the first of the year. The new line charges, in effect, would convert the subsidies into higher local rates.

headline: INTEREST RATES DROP SLIGHTLY
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as credit market participants remained uncertain about the longevity of recent declines in overnight interest rates.    The uncertainty centers on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market - the most closely watched interest rate in the United States financial markets.   When the funds rate falls, as it has in the last week, it could be a sign that the Federal Reserve is easing monetary policy and making funds more available to the banking system. A higher funds rate could indicate a tighter monetary policy.

headline: Economic Scene; 'Expectations' And 'Reality'
abstract: THE second half of 1983 begins with economists voicing increasing confidence about the strength of the recovery and investment advisers expressing growing concern about the outlook for the stock market.   How can the disparity be explained? One key factor may be the way the two professions perceive ''reality.'' The economists, seeking to be ''scientific,'' focus on existing data, such as the latest figures on gross national product or industrial production, and try to build realistic models on the basis of those data. But the investment advisers, seeking to make money, not science, focus on ''expectations,'' that is, the expectations and moods of the market, however difficult these may be to measure or incorporate in systematic models.

headline: No Headline
abstract: In an attempt to mollify trade unions, the French Government announced today that it had raised to 6 percent from 5 percent its goal for average wage increases next year.

headline: Alaska's Native Corporations
abstract: There is a roller-coaster quality to the collective business performance of the native-owned corporations that were created 12 years ago by the Alaska Native Claim Settlement Act.   Blessed by huge grants of natural resources and endowed by huge injections of Federal and state cash, these corporations have run through almost the full gamut of American business experience over the years. Some have established solid earnings records; others have come perilously close to bankruptcy.   In some instances the Eskimo, Aleut and Indian shareholders brought in outside executives to run their affairs. Sometimes the outsiders have done well, sometimes not.

headline: Giscard Received by Reagan For Talk on the Missile Issue
abstract: Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France told President Reagan today that the Atlantic allies must keep pressing for arms control after new medium-range missiles are deployed in Western Europe later this year.

headline: MEXICANS TIE CRIME SURGE TO ECONOMY
abstract: Shortly before midnight one evening last week, three men raided a restaurant in a quiet Mexico City neighborhood, searching the patrons for watches, wallets and jewelry. When one of the diners resisted and ran for the door to call the police, he was shot and killed.   A holdup in this city of 15 million people, the nation's center of poverty and wealth, is no longer unusual. But the victim in this case was Alberto Raurell, a well-known American curator of a leading Mexican art museum. His death has added to the accounts over the current surge of crime in the Mexican capital.

headline: BACKBONE OF ALLEGHANY IS THE I.D.S. FUND GROUP
abstract: Beginning in 1940, salesmen from Investors Diversified Services Inc. fanned out through America, urging people to save for their future by buying mutual funds. The pitch worked, and through the 1960's and early 1970's the company was the nation's largest mutual fund group.   I.D.S., the main subsidiary of the Alleghany Corporation, ultimately lost that distinction when it failed to keep pace in a rapidly evolving financial world. But now the American Express Company, in buying Alleghany's businesses, is adding a financial services concern that some analysts think has successfully diversified into insurance and may be on the rebound.

headline: BONN TAKES NEW LOOK ARMS EXPORT CURBS
abstract: West Germany's conservative Government is under growing pressure, both at home and from its allies, to loosen its restrictive policy toward arms exports. Some analysts believe the Government is cautiously moving to do just that.    The rewards of arms exports were brought home this summer, when the Swiss Government ordered 210 advanced Leopard 2 tanks, for $1.17 billion, from Krauss-Maffei, a company controlled by the Friedrich Flick group. The sole competitor was the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis.

headline: U.S. STEEL SAYS IT LOST $112 MILLION
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, struggling to emerge from one of the worst recessions in steelmaking history, reported yesterday that it lost $112 million in the quarter ended June 30.   The losses came despite the profitability of U.S. Steel's Marathon Oil Company subsidiary, whose revenue of $2.3 billion accounted for more than half of U.S. Steel's total revenue of $4.4 billion in the quarter. Marathon had $290 million in earnings in the quarter, up from $266 million in last year's period.   This year's $112 million second-quarter loss for U.S. Steel compares with a profit in last year's second quarter of $4 million, or 5 cents a share, on revenue of $5.1 billion. In this year's first quarter, the company lost $118 million.

headline: GUIDE TO COMMITTEES
abstract: Finance ministers and central bank governors from nearly 150 countries have gathered here for the 38th annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, or World Bank. Since their establishment in 1945, a number of other bodies have been set up to coordinate economic policy. Here are some of these others and what they do:   Development Assistance Committee: A specialized committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development that coordinates development assistance to poor countries.

headline: SALES RATIO FALLS
abstract: The nation's businesses increased their inventories by three-tenths of 1 percent in May, but sales rose a strong 3.3 percent, the biggest month-to-month jump in four years, the Commerce Department reported today.   Because of the strong sales, the closely watched inventory-to-sales ratio fell to 1.39 - a record low -from 1.44 in April. The ratio measures the number of months needed to liquidate inventories at the current month's sales pace. May's unusually low ratio was an indication of the strength of the economic recovery that began in December, analysts said.

headline: BONN CONTRITE OVER ACTIVIST WHO SPILLED BLOOD ON GENERAL
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher apologized to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today for the behavior Wednesday of a Green Party regional deputy who spilled blood on an American general.   In a protest against the projected stationing of American medium-range missiles in West Germany and the Reagan Administration's Central American policies, the regional deputy, Frank Schwalba-Hoth, a member of the Hesse legislature, poured a glass of his blood on the chest of Lieut. Gen. Paul S. Williams Jr. at a reception for American commanders.   The action drew a storm of condemnation from newspapers and mainstream politicians today. In a telegram to his American counterpart, Mr. Genscher asserted that President Reagan's firm commitment to disarmament ''should put to shame those involved in this inexcusable and unworthy behavior toward General Williams.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Victor's New Video Unit    TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters) - The Victor Company of Japan said today that it had developed an integrated video camera/recorder unit, the world's lightest video camera/ recorder combination, weighing only a little more than four pounds without battery.

headline: Soviet Production Up
abstract: Industrial production in the Soviet Union rose 4.2 percent in the first half of this year, mostly because of better worker discipline, less absenteeism and greater efficiency, the Government's Central Statistical Board said Friday. Output of natural gas - a key earner of Western currency - rose 7 percent, coal stayed even at 363 million tons and oil rose 1 percent, to 307 million tons.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Foreclosures Off in Quarter    WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) - The number of American homeowners involved in mortgage foreclosures fell during the second quarter, marking the first quarterly decline in two years, a mortgage lending group said today.   The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said the rate of loans in the process of foreclosure was 0.66 percent in the April-June period, down from 0.71 percent in the first quarter.

headline: SOVIET SAYS 747 USED 'TRICKS' LIKE SPY PLANE
abstract: The Soviet armed forces added new details today to earlier assertions that the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet jet fighter was spying.   Krasnaya Zvezda, the Defense Ministry newspaper, said the Korean captain and the pilot of an American RC-135 reconnaissance plane that was in the area on the night of the downing both used the typical maneuvering ''tricks'' of American spy planes in a bid to frustrate Soviet air defenses.   The paper said the Korean 747 had lowered its flaps at a critical moment of the pursuit, trying to make a Soviet fighter overshoot and allow the airliner to ''slip away.'' The paper also said an RC-135 had dived below radar cover off the Kamchatka Peninsula to distract air-defense crews and enable the 747 to enter Soviet airspace undetected.

headline: Australian Incentives
abstract: The Australian Government plans to encourage high-risk technological ventures with federal tax incentives, the Industry and Commerce Minister, John Button, said today.

headline: AN ARCHITECT-SAILOR'S L.I. PROJECT CONTAINS BOAT SHIPS
abstract: Several years ago, Stephen Shilowitz, an architect by vocation and an avid sailor by avocation, was confronted with a problem most people would love to have: finding a berth for his 36-foot-long sloop, a family heirloom custom-built for his late father.   Mr. Shilowitz, who had berthed the boat at a shipyard here since he began sailing in the 1960's, wanted to moor it where he could work on it himself, something the fire insurance policies of most shipyards would prevent.   And he wanted to stay in the Greenport area, which he considers one of the Northeast's finest harbors because of its proximity to and protection from the sea.   He was stumped until, doodling one day in his kitchen, he hit upon a solution: combine the needs of his sloop with his family's desire for a second home. It was a way, as he put it during a tour of the area, to resolve ''the dilemma of owning a leisure home remote from my commitment to sailing.'' And, he felt, it was a solution that could be attractive to others.

headline: REVIVAL OF JAPANESE EXPORTS
abstract: Japanese exports, after sputtering for more than a year, are starting to revive.  The turnaround began to take shape in the last few months, as overseas demand for such products as office equipment, video cassette recorders, semiconductors, ships and automobiles picked up.   The Japanese Government recently reported that total Japanese exports in May climbed above the level in the same month a year earlier. It was the first year-to-year monthly increase in 16 months.

headline: G.E.'s Hybrid Test Car: Manager's Role Is Cited
abstract: One might suppose that the head of a team assigned to build a new type of complex experimental automobile -one that operates on gasoline as well as electricity - would need an extensive technical background. Mechanical or electrical engineering, perhaps.   Not so, says Michael F. Ciccarelli, 36, who received his undergraduate degree in biology at Siena College near Albany. Good management, Mr. Ciccarelli said, is the key to bringing off a project like the one just completed at General Electric's Research and Development Center in Schenectady, N.Y.

headline: Goodyear Closure
abstract: The Goodyear Tire Company said it would close its factory in Northern Ireland in three months, a move that would put about 750 people out of work. Goodyear-Great Britain, the British subsidiary of the American company, said the plant is losing as much as $1 million a month. The Goodyear factory at Craigavon, south of Belfast, was opened in 1967 to make conveyer belts, fan belts, hoses and other rubber products.

headline: Flxible Sale
abstract: The General Automotive Corporation, Ann Arbor, Mich., said it had completed the acquisition of the assets of the Grumman Corporation's Flxible bus subsidiary for an undisclosed amount of cash, notes and preferred stock.

headline: Plunge in Colombia Kills 7
abstract: A truck driving peasants and food to the eastern Colombian town of Betulia plunged 500 feet into a ravine today, killing 7 of the passengers and injuring 10 others.  The police said the accident, which took place 160 miles from Bogota, was caused by mechanical trouble with the truck.

headline: French Prices Rise
abstract: French retail prices rose five-tenths to six-tenths of 1 percent in August after an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Statistics Institute said today. The figures show that for the 12 months to August prices rose 9.6 to 9.7 percent after a rise of 9.4 percent for the 12 months to July.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 28, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: ALEXANDER IS SUING IN HOWDEN AUDIT
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the United States insurance broker that took big write-offs against earnings because of troubles at its Alexander Howden Group subsidiary in Britain, said today that it had sued the firms that audited Howden before it was acquired in 1982.   Alexander & Alexander's suit charged that the Howden financial statements audited by the firms did not accurately reflect Howden's condition.

headline: PATENTS; An Elevated Station For Outlying Areas
abstract: A space engineer who has done much research on overhead railway systems received a patent this week for an elevated passenger station. It is to have a waiting room at the ground level, two elevators and no stairs.

headline: Australian Reports K.G.B. Recruiting Effort
abstract: The K.G.B. tried to recruit a lobbyist with close connections to the ruling Labor Party, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today at a hearing on Australia's security services.   Mr. Hawke also said he had warned two Canberra men not to form a business partnership with the lobbyist, David Combe, the Labor Party's former national secretary. The Soviet agent, Valery Ivanov, was expelled in April after the Australian Security Intelligence Organization monitored meetings and telephone calls between him and Mr. Combe.

headline: ZIMBABWE AIR FORCE TRIAL EMBITTERS WHITES
abstract: Until a year ago, Zimbabwe's Air Force was an elite, white bastion, little affected by the country's black majority rule. But such isolation ended with explosions at its main base, Thornhill, on July 25, 1982, that wrecked 13 jet fighters, or more than half of Zimbabwe's combat planes.   Since then, six of its top officers, all whites, have been tried on charges of contributing to the attack by infiltrating three South African saboteurs onto the base. The nine-week trial ended Friday, and verdicts are expected at the end of next month.

headline: Harvester Nissan Kits
abstract: The International Harvester Company has said it will start assembling truck kits imported from Australia for midsize Nissan trucks and reselling them under the Harvester name beginning in the fall.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: A 'FLEA MARKET' FOR AUTO FANCIERS
abstract: Terry Ehrich, an auto buff with an informal manner and easy smile, runs an $8 million-a-year magazine business. Next year, for the first time, he plans to draw up a budget.   Mr. Ehrich, 42 years old, is publisher of Hemmings Motor News, a monthly resource for more than 225,000 enthusiasts of old automobiles. He also publishes two, smaller magazines, one on old automobiles, the other on small boats, plus an annual directory that lists old-car hobbyists.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Eyelab Inc., to Herman & Rosner Enterprises.

headline: REACTIONS TO KREMLIN: HOW IT SEES ITSELF AND THE WORLD
abstract: Unlike Afghanistan, Poland or the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the downing of a Korean Air Lines 747 presented the Kremlin with a crisis for which it had no explanation or rationale worked out in advance.  Soviet leaders were forced to respond fast, and their reflexes - their claims, evasions, charges and disclosures - may have revealed more about their system than about what led to the decision to destroy a civilian airliner, resulting in the deaths of 269 people.   From all that has been said here in defense of the action, it seems as if the Kremlin dismissed from the outset the option of accepting responsibility or apologizing, thus buttressing the image presented by diplomatic and other experts on the Soviet Union both here and abroad of a state incapable of admitting error.   Throughout all their explanations, the Soviet leaders have weaved in the notion that the West would surely have done what the Soviet Union did.   Those leaders may be aware that Americans might have acted differently. But in their efforts to field a version of the incident that absolves them of blame and in their notion that the mysteries surrounding the flight would arouse universal suspicion, the leaders seemed to share in the presumption that the world outside is essentially like their world.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 20, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Preparatory Commtttee for the In- ternational Conference on the Ques- tion of Palestinians - 10:30 A.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: National Steel Sees 1983 Profit
abstract: The chairman of the National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, said yesterday that there was a good chance the company would post an operating profit for 1983.   Howard M. Love, the chairman, added, however, that National Steel would have a net loss for all of 1983 after taking a $368 million pretax write-off for the sale of its Weirton, W. Va., steel division to its employees before the end of the year.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Leona Sills, associate publisher-director of creative services of Conde- Nast's Bride's magazine, is setting up her own consulting firm at 7 East 75th Street.

headline: BIG NAME ON WALL STREET MOVES ACROSS THE TABLE
abstract: WHEN Maryann N. Keller was offered a job analyzing the automobile industry, she did not even know that the DeSoto had long been pulled from the market or that the Bentley was a car for the very rich.   She took the job anyway.   Mrs. Keller, it seems, has always had confidence in her ability to swim to the top. So much so, in fact, that she recently abdicated her post as Wall Street's premier auto analyst for a different type of job at a little- known money management firm paying her half as much.   The move surprised many on Wall Street, given Mrs. Keller's status and salary at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., where she analyzed the automobile industry and its stocks, making buy and sell recommendations to clients in hopes of winning orders and commissions for the investment house.

headline: STUDYING CANADA'S ECONOMY
abstract: A high-level inquiry into Canada's economic problems that opened here last week heard charges that the federal Government is sacrificing workers to win its battle against inflation.   The British Columbia Federation of Labor blamed Canada's economic troubles on the federal Government for following the tight money policies of the United States and Britain. In its testimony the labor federation said the battle against inflation was being fought at the expense of those who could least afford it.

headline: Singer Posts Profit
abstract: The Singer Company, a diversified high-technology company based in Stamford, Conn., reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter ended June 30 climbed to $5.8 million, or 26 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends, compared with $400,000, or a loss of 5 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Key Soviet Official Arrives in Peking
abstract: The first high- ranking official of the Soviet Union to be invited here on a state visit in more than two decades arrived today for a week of talks with Chinese officials.   The Soviet visitor, Mikhail S. Kapitsa, is Deputy Foreign Minister in charge of East Asian and Southeast Asian Affairs.

headline: REVIVAL IN STEEL ORDERS STALLS
abstract: After their worst year in more than two decades, steel manufacturers were suddenly deluged with new orders in February and March. Certain that the worst was over, manufacturers restarted dormant blast furnaces and expressed confidence that 1983 would be the year of steel's comeback.    Now it appears that reports of steel's revival were greatly exaggerated. Since April, orders in most sectors of the industry have tapered off, and capacity utilization for raw steel has fallen steadily.

headline: Maoists in Peru Set Off 25 Bombs in One City
abstract: Guerrillas simultaneously set off more than 25 bombs in Ayacucho on Monday night, and shortly afterward about 45 rebels attacked a civil guard post outside the city.

headline: Lesotho Asks for Food
abstract: Lesotho has asked other countries in the Commonwealth to increase their food aid to prevent mass starvation in areas of the country where drought has devastated the cattle and crops, the Tanzanian Government newspaper Daily News reported today. The request came at the opening session of a Commonwealth conference being held in northern Tanzania.

headline: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASED IN JULY BY MODERATE 0.4%
abstract: Consumer prices rose a moderate four- tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today. Economists predicted that inflation would continue at about this rate, almost 5 percent a year, for the near future.   There was a slight decline in food prices, with consumers paying less for some cuts of beef and pork and some fruits and vegetables than they did a year ago. But all the other major categories in the Consumer Price Index showed small increases.

headline: CSX-Texas Gas
abstract: The CSX Corporation said it plans to resume its $1.07 billion tender offer for Texas Gas Resources Corporation. Yesterday a Washington Federal appeals court lifted an injunction yesterday blocking the merger and later, Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. refused to delay the CSX tender offer. A spokesman for CSX said the company has extended its $52-a-share offer for the remaining Texas Gas issues until midnight tonight. CSX has already bought 18.9 million of the 20.6 million outstanding Texas Gas shares, he said, and will give 0.684 share of its common stock for each Texas Gas share not tendered already.

headline: Brazil Debt Talks Held
abstract: Brazil's major private creditors completed two days of meetings in New York yesterday, amid indications that by the middle of next week the International Monetary Fund might sign a letter of intent with the debt-ridden country agreeing to a new set of economic measures.   Carlos Langoni, governor of the central bank of Brazil, attended yesterday's session after meeting with Federal Reserve officials in Washington, banking sources said.   Mr. Langoni had been expected in New York on Tuesday, but was delayed in Paris following discussions with officials of the Paris Club of Western creditor nations over rescheduling payments on $7 billion to $8 billion the Brazil owes member governments.

headline: Indian Crowd Panics; 53 Worshipers Killed
abstract: At least 53 people, including 19 women and 11 children, were trampled to death when thousands of Hindu worshipers visiting a shrine in northern India stampeded in panic after a hillside market collapsed, local officials said today.   Rescue officials said the market stalls may have collapsed because recent monsoon rains undermined their foundations.

headline: 6 From Fidelity Union Join Carteret Thrift Unit
abstract: Robert J. Mueller prefers the word ''transition'' in describing the sudden move that brought him and five other Fidelity Union Bank officers to the Carteret Savings and Loan Association last month.  Others call it corporate raiding; most agree there will be more of it in the savings and loan industry.   Mr. Mueller, who is 41, joined Carteret on June 22 as senior officer of the association's new corporate banking division - primarily, he said, because ''the idea of starting an enterprise from scratch was a very intriguing challenge.'' He was formerly executive vice president and head of the corporate banking division at Newarkbased Fidelity, New Jersey's largest commercial bank, and once held management positions at the Bank of New York.

headline: Changes at Ogilvy
abstract: Henry P. Bernhard, 55-year-old vice chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, who has been running the Chicago office, is returning to the New York office after seven successful years out there. He is turning management of the office, which has annual billings of about $102 million, over to the three-man team headed by William E. Whitney, 50, already managing director; Curvin O'Reilly, 41, already executive director, and Wim Slootweg, 39, a Hollander and Procter & Gamble alumnus, who has worked for Ogilvy in a number of countries. He will now be senior vice president and general manager.

headline: GUATEMALAN ARMY TOPPLES PRESIDENT IN A BRIEF BATTLE
abstract: The Guatemalan military overthrew the Government of Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt today in Guatemala's second coup in 17 months.   Brig. Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, the Defense Minister, was sworn in this afternoon to succeed General Rios Montt.   The fate of General Rios Montt, whose evangelical beliefs and promotion of young army officers irritated traditional military men, was not known.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF SOVIET OFFICIAL'S STATEMENT AND EXCERPTS FROM NEWS SESSION MARSHAL CALLS FLIGHT 7 A 'PROVOCATION PERPETRATED BY U.S. SECRET SERVICES'
abstract: Following are a full transcript of an opening statement and excerpts from the questions at a news conference in the Foreign Ministry Press Center in Moscow yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. The conference was held by Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, with Viktor Litvinsky translating from the Russian.   OPENING STATEMENT    The nature of the provocation perpetrated by the U.S. secret services in the Soviet Far East on the night of Sept. 1 and the character of the actions taken in this connection by the Soviet Air Defense Forces were presented with utmost clarity in the statement of the Soviet Government on Sept. 6 and in a Tass report made earlier on instructions from the Government.

headline: Canada Trade Surplus
abstract: Canada's current account balance of payments surplus rose to $1.1 billion in the second quarter, seasonally adjusted, from an upward revised $253 million in the first quarter and a $965 million surplus in the second quarter last year, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The surplus resulted from a sharp increase in merchandise exports, which brought the trade surplus to a new quarterly high.

headline: Sega Shifts to Dailey From Della Femina
abstract: Dailey & Associates of Los Angeles, which will officially become a subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies in about a week, last week got a promising piece of business from the entertainment industry - Sega Enterprises, a video games creator that is part of the Paramount Pictures division of Gulf & Western.   Phillip Jounou, Dailey president, said that the account has been billing about $8 million and will probably be at $10 million next year.

headline: S.E.C.'s Rules On Bank Data
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday voted to require more information from bank holding companies about their foreign lending and their potentially risky domestic loans.   In most respects, the new disclosure rules, which take effect with reports filed after Dec. 31, echo the bank disclosure requirements of the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

headline: MARKETS AWAIT FED DECISIONS
abstract: The financial markets are expected to remain edgy this week despite the welcomed $3 billion drop in the money supply that was announced Friday by the Federal Reserve System.   While that decline eased pressure on the Fed to tighten credit and possibly drive up interest rates, and while it reduced the possibility of a sharp clash between the central bank and the Reagan Administration, which has been warning the Fed against a tightening of credit, the short-term outlook for monetary policy remains highly uncertain.   That is because the money supply has grown to levels far above the Fed's target rate in a period when the economic recovery has been stronger than most economists and officials had expected. As a result, while there is less concern that a tightening of credit will abort the recovery, there is increasing concern that an excessively rapid increase in the money supply will rekindle inflation.   The markets thus are focusing their attention on this week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the arm of the Federal Reserve System that sets monetary policy.

headline: Becker Group Gets General Manager
abstract: Michael J. Kugler, chairman of Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., has been named general manager of the fixed-income group at A. G. Becker Paribas Inc., the securities and investment banking firm. He has also been named a managing director of the firm.

headline: G.I.'S DIG IN FOR HONDURAS MANEUVERS
abstract: American G.I.'s are digging ditches and stringing communications lines under the bright sun at this dusty military post as American C-130's land and take off.    The Honduran air base here has become the American headquarters for the military exercise called Big Pine II that began two weeks ago and will last for about eight months.   There are touches of home. A sign says ''Boston 1,548 miles,'' and there are cases of Olympia beer and Unsinger's Sausage.

headline: People
abstract: *  Linda P. Spikol has been elected a senior vice president of Kalish & Rice Inc., Philadelphia.     *  Sally Willis Rogers named senior vice president/director of marketing services at Richardson, Myers & Donofrio Inc., Baltimore.

headline: 64 KILLED IN BLAST AT SOUTH AFRICAN COAL MINE
abstract: A methane gas explosion at a coal mine in Natal Province killed 64 miners and seriously injured 4 others today.   The explosion at the Hlobane coal mine occurred as 80 miners were working two sections of a horizontal seam cut four miles into a mountainside, according to Jurie Blom, manager of the mine 200 miles southeast of Johannesburg. Mr. Blom said all but three of the victims were blacks, most of them Zulu contract workers.   ''Our people are investigating,'' Mr. Blom said, ''but it will be hard to pinpoint the cause because the explosion has burned everything.''

headline: Coldwell Banker
abstract: Coldwell Banker, the real-estate subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, won a court injunction giving the company the right to offer its customers retail discounts for home merchandise at Sears. The injunction blocks the Illinois Department of Registration and Education from preventing Coldwell Banker's discount program for customers who buy or sell their homes through the company.

headline: ARGENTINES FEAR LABOR UNREST MAY IMPERIL ELECTIONS
abstract: A spree of Argentine wildcat strikes resulting from inflation and falling living standards has raised fears of a social explosion that could interrupt elections scheduled for Oct. 30.   An unpopular amnesty freeing the military and the police from prosecution for the thousands of deaths and disappearances during an antisubversion campaign has added to the tension.   But the economic squeeze is the most immediate cause. Inflation has risen from 335 percent in the past year to annual rates of 444 percent for the last quarter and 571 percent last month.

headline: Guyana Loans Canceled
abstract: The United States Government has canceled two loans to Guyana because it defaulted on the conditions, a United States Embassy spokesman said yesterday. The spokesman gave no details.

headline: Advertising; Ice Cream With Some 'Romance'
abstract: AT the heart of every Custom Creamery Flavor Factory is a machine.  And while the concept of these compact, in-store franchise locations beginning to blossom in the land is new, the machine that makes possible the promise of ''over 2,000 ice cream fantasies'' is old.   In fact, it has been around for more than 30 years, according to Robert White, vice president-marketing of Mateer-Burt, a Wayne, Pa., subsidiary of the Berwind Corporation, which makes auger fillers.   The particular auger filler that magically changes vanilla ice cream into exotic, or not-so-exotic, flavors has found its way into various locations in this country and Canada over the years but has never really been sold properly, Mr. White believes.

headline: AT THE CHAD FRONT: WAR IN AN ANCIENT WASTELAND
abstract: This remote desert crossroads does not look like a prize worthy of the worry of diplomats in Paris and Washington or the lives of soldiers from half a dozen countries.   There is very little here - an old adobe fortress, built by the French in colonial times, now abandoned and crumbling; two whitewashed buildings marked with red crosses, also abandoned, and the carcasses of several vehicles, rusting in the relentless heat of the sub-Saharan sun.   Nearby, there is the merest hint of green grass, some stunted trees and thorny bushes, the mud-brick and straw huts of a few nomadic goat herders and two pale stones marking the unpaved routes to the northern Chadian settlements of Fada and Faya-Largeau.   Yet this desolate landscape has become the focus of the conflict in Chad, the one place where, in recent days, the forces of President Hissen Habre have continued to battle with the Libyan- supported rebel troops of former President Goukouni Oueddei.

headline: P.L.O. CHIEFS URGE CEASE-FIRE
abstract: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization called today for a cease-fire between rival Palestinian factions in eastern Lebanon and decided to send a mediation team to talk to all sides in the dispute.   The team will also visit Syria to try to heal the rift between President Hafez al-Assad and Yasir Arafat, leader of the P.L.O.  The decisions were announced at the end of a two-day meeting of the P.L.O. Executive Committee in Tunis to discuss the mutiny against Mr. Arafat within Al Fatah, the largest of the groups that make up the P.L.O.   Palestinian sources said the Executive Committee decided to send 10 of its 14 members to Syria in an effort to end the feud within Al Fatah and the dispute between Mr. Arafat and the Syrian President. Communique Is Issued   Wafa, the Palestinian press agency, quoted a communique from the meeting as saying, ''The Executive Committee calls on all brothers to stop fighting immediately and to preserve the principle of democratic dialogue.

headline: BROKER RATE RISES
abstract: The U.S. Trust Company yesterday raised its broker loan rate to 10 1/4 percent, from 9 3/4 percent. The level at most other major banks is 10 percent.

headline: 5 Years' Jail for Having Gun
abstract: A black mechanic was sentenced to five years' imprisonment today for possessing a Soviet-made pistol that he said had been sent to him by members of the banned African National Congress in Mozambique. Moses Langa, 38 years old, told the Johannesburg regional court that the pistol had been smuggled to him after he met members of the nationalist group while visiting Mozambique, where he was born. He gave the gun away to a friend.

headline: Philippine Police Blame Leftists for Clashes
abstract: The police blamed leftists today for the street fighting Wednesday night in which one person was killed and 18 were hurt after the funeral of the slain opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

headline: NICARAGUANS HOPE FOR AID IN DEFENSE
abstract: High-ranking Nicaraguan officials say they are hopeful that this weekend's meeting of four regional presidents in Mexico will forestall what they believe are United States plans for a major stepping up of hostilities against their Government.   Top Sandinista officials linked the meeting of the Presidents of Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela, which began today in the Mexican resort of Cancun, with what they said were sudden private warnings from France and Spain that the Reagan Administration had decided to take drastic steps, including military action involving the Honduran Army, to overthrow the Sandinistas.   Nicaragua announced Friday for the first time that universal military service would soon become law. At a military ceremony, Defense Minister Humberto Ortega said conscription would permit the ''massive defense'' needed for the revolution.

headline: Court Seeks Data About DeLorean
abstract: A judge has ordered the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government organizations to hand over any documents they have on John Z. DeLorean, the car maker, for the court's private inspection, sources at the court said.   The order follows defense contentions that the British Government had plotted with the United States Government to bring about the downfall of Mr. DeLorean and his sports car factory in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Clairol, a subsidiary of Bristol-Myers, has appointed Michael E.  DeGennaro president of the professional products division.   * Island Creek Coal Co., Lexington, Ky., a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum, has named Stonie Barker Jr. chairman.

headline: ANOTHER LIGHT WEEK FOR DEBT ISSUES
abstract: For the third consecutive week, analysts are reporting an unusually light debt calendar. Higher interest rates are keeping many corporations out of the bond market, and many municipalities have slowed their borrowing because of the elimination of bearer, or nonregistered, bonds, analysts said.   The Treasury, however, will continue to borrow heavily, albeit no heavier than in recent weeks. Today, the Government is expected to borrow $6.2 billion in three-month bills and another $6.2 billion in six-month bills. Of the $12.4 billion total, about $11.8 billion will be used to retire maturing debt, the remainder being additions to the Government's debt.

headline: Seoul Says Spy Ship Was Forced to Flee
abstract: South Korean military officials, who said Friday that they had sunk a North Korean spy ship, reported today that a second spy vessel escaped during that incident.   Four commandos were killed when the small spy boat was sunk during a South Korean air-sea operation near the southeastern coastal town of Wolsong, South Korean Defense Ministry officials said.

headline: Belgian Civil Servants Protest Austerity Plan
abstract: Civil servants across Belgium went on strike today to protest a Government austerity plan. The wildcat walkout halted or sharply curtailed services ranging from public transport to weather reports.

headline: Upjohn Expansion
abstract: Puerto Rico announced that the Upjohn Company plans to invest $40 million over the next three years to expand its pharmaceutical operation in Arecibo, following a new tax exemption agreement extending through 1998. The investment will bring to $130 million the total Upjohn spending on the complex.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan A Comeback For Aluminum    ALL of the major aluminum producers lost money last year. The industry itself, suffering from extreme price competition and weak demand caused by the recession, was considered to be in its poorest shape since the 1930's.   Stock prices of aluminum companies dropped precipitously from early 1981 until they turned upward in the summer of 1982, when equities in general began to rally strongly.   This week, against the background of an erratic stock market, the recovery in aluminum shares looks especially dramatic.

headline: SECRETIVE BRENNINKMEYERS
abstract: In an unassuming building in Amsterdam's trim Weesper Straat, 50 or so executives meet four times a year to discuss the affairs of what is, by most standards, one of the world's most secretive business operations.    The executives, all men, are members of the Brenninkmeyer clan, and they run what has been described as the world's largest retail clothing group. It is believed that some 200 family members, all bearing the Brenninkmeyer name - some use the Dutch form, Brenninkmeijer - operate in a dozen countries.   Yet no one knows for sure. So secretive is the family that no one knows for certain how many stores it owns, how much clothing it sells or how much money it earns. None have ever granted an interview.

headline: ASPARTAME BUILDS A MARKET
abstract: Aspartame, the new low-calorie sweetener, has opened up a vast new consumer market.    Since last spring, when aspartame became nationally available in cereal, milk shake mix and diet colas, it has become an alternative to both saccharin and sugar. ''It is the first real substitute for sugar,'' said Kenneth Defren, a spokesman for the General Foods Corporation.   Already, the new sweetener, discovered accidentally in 1965 by a chemist at G. D. Searle & Company, is being used by an increasing number of companies, including Borden Inc., General Foods, H. J. Heinz, Quaker Oats and Coca-Cola.

headline: Thousands Join Vigil For Argentine Missing
abstract: Thousands of protesters held a 24-hour vigil outside the national palace today to demand the military regime account for the more than 6,000 people who vanished during antileftist repression in the 1970's.   The vigil was called by the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, who for six and a half years have held weekly silent marches in front of the palace to press the military junta for information on their missing relatives.

headline: Federal Express Named An Esquire Sponsor
abstract: The folks at Esquire, intent on making the 50th anniversary issue ''a media event'' - like ''Roots'' or the Olympics, according to Alan Greenberg, the publisher - went out looking for corporate sponsors and came up with Federal Express.   And the country's biggest air express company will do what it does best.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Charter Co. agreed to offer a 10-year, $22.5 million subordinated loan to W .R. Berkley Corp., bearing interest four points below the prime rate but not lower than 8 percent.   * Empire Of Carolina Inc. reduced the conversion price of its 17 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures to $4 a common share, from $4.625, during the period July 28 through Aug. 19.   * Newmont Mining Corp. called for redemption on Sept. 15, at $100 a share, of all its shares outstanding of series A $4.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock $5 par value.

headline: CHEMICAL, ISELIN PUSH DEBT TALKS
abstract: The Chemical Bank yesterday intensified its efforts to obtain repayment of a $25 million delinquent loan to a garment company that has been accused by another major commercial banking organization of having committed a $15 million fraud.   Representatives of Chemical and the other banking concern, the William Iselin unit of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, met yesterday with representatives of Irwin Feiner, the head of the TJK Sportswear Company. Mr. Feiner's lawyer said they had agreed to a further restructuring of the Chemical loan.   A lawyer for Chemical said the bank had already previously restructured outstanding obligations of TJK. The bank attorney, Henry Goodman, a partner in the New York law firm of Zalkin, Rodin & Goodman, said that that agreement had been ''guaranteed'' by Mr. Feiner.

headline: Continental Group
abstract: The Continental Group announced the sale of six plants that manufacture plastic soft-drink bottles to the Tricoast Holding Corporation for about $32 million. The transaction will not have a material impact on earnings, it said. The plants, in California, Washington, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Texas, make two-liter, oneliter and half-liter containers.

headline: WITH FLOWERS AND CRIES OF GRIEF, JAPANESE HONOR THOSE WHO DIED
abstract: It was a day for chrysanthemums upon the waters.    Relatives of Japanese passengers presumably killed in last Thursday's Korean Air Lines incident chartered a ferryboat today and tried to get close to their loved ones once more.   Forty-eight people from 14 families, including six Koreans, set off in the northern Sea of Japan, where Flight 7 is believed to have gone down after a missile attack by a Soviet fighter plane. Twenty-eight Japanese were among the 269 people on board.

headline: Tend Your Economies, U.N. Chief Tells Poor
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today urged third-world nations to improve their own economies before seeking help from the rich.   His remarks at a press luncheon were unusual for the United Nations, where more than 100 of the 157 members are from the developing world.

headline: Honeywell Contract
abstract: Honeywell Inc. won a $500.1 million Navy contract for engineering development of the X-50 advance lightweight torpedo, including design, building of prototypes and testing, the Defense Department said today. It also said Pan American World Airways Inc. had received $42.5 million from the Air Force for Civil Reserve Air Fleet enhancement to modify wide-body 747 passenger aircraft.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, SEPT. 12, 1983
abstract: Companies   Major companies are asking employees to pay more of the medical costs traditionally paid through company-provided insurance plans. Among the corporations finding that insurance costs are eroding profits are A.T.& T., Ford, Chrysler, W. R. Grace and Citibank. Unions are resisting the companies' demands. (Page A1.)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Champion Products Inc., Rochester, N.Y., has elected J. Jay Cassen to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer.     * Damson Oil Corp.  has named Lee Adams vice president of acquisitions.     * Doric Foods Corp.  has named James F. Pomroy president.

headline: G.M. Shutdown
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it would close its southeast Baltimore assembly plant for 20 weeks, starting at the end of next March, to prepare for production of a new type of vehicle that G.M. has not identified. G.M. had announced the shutdown previously, but had not said when it would start or how long it would last. The shutdown is to allow for completion of a $270 million renovation of the nearly 50- year-old plant.

headline: Walesa Pledges Lawsuit To Keep His Job
abstract: Lech Walesa defied Poland's authorities today, refusing to end his unauthorized vacation and vowing a court battle to keep his job.

headline: MOSCOW STEPS UP ATTACK ON U.S. OVER DOWNING KOREAN AIRLINER
abstract: The Soviet Union stepped up its charges today that the United States was ultimately responsible for the fate of the South Korean airliner that was downed over Soviet Far Eastern airspace.   It accused the White House of waging a ''worldwide, rabid anti-Soviet campaign'' over the incident.   An account carried by the Soviet press agency Tass and read on Soviet television tonight continued to avoid any admission that the Korean Air Lines 747 with 269 people aboard had been shot down by Soviet interceptors. But the report went beyond previous Soviet statements in acknowledging that the aircraft, previously identified only as an ''intruder plane,'' was in fact the Korean airliner.

headline: American General Net
abstract: The American General Corporation, a holding company based in Houston with interests in life and property-casualty insurance, said net income in the second quarter rose 81.9 percent, to $86.6 million, or 92 cents a share, from $47.6 million, or 62 cents a share, a year before. Operating earnings rose 51.3 percent, to $72.3 million, or 76 cents a share, from $47.8 million, or 62 cents a share.

headline: DEVELOPER IN MANHATTAN PLANS SALES, THEN BUILDS
abstract: On the 25,000-square-foot parcel at the southeast corner of First Avenue and East 70th Street in Manhattan, the city zoning code would have let Bruce Eichner, the developer, construct a 27-story building with 10,000 square feet on each floor.   But the apartment tower that he chose to build, now nearing completion, is significantly thinner than that. The 210-unit building, a condominium called the Kingsley, covers just over half the site and has a per- floor area of 6,750 square feet. Also it will have a 1,000-square-foot plaza.

headline: Market Place; The Parts Of A.T.& T.
abstract: JOHN L. CLENDENIN is among a corps of telephone company executives poised to march into a competitive new world next Jan. 1. That is the breakup date set for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, an event in which its 3.2 million stockholders also hold a stake.   On Wednesday, A.T.& T. and the Justice Department agreed to final changes in their antitrust settlement as called for by Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene. This effectively cleared the way for the biggest corporate splitup ever.

headline: Foes of Whaling Say Colleagues Will Be Freed
abstract: The Soviet Union has agreed to hand over at sea seven Greenpeace activists arrested at a Siberian whaling station on Monday, a spokesman for the environmentalist group said here today.

headline: Bank Rates Are Steady
abstract: Interest rates by major banks for money market deposit accounts remained at the same level as last week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.   The Monitor's nationwide average this week was 8.67 percent.

headline: 'No Shortage of Food,' Secretary Block Says
abstract: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that there was no world shortage of food, but that there was a major problem in moving food donations to the poor in developing countries.   Mr. Block told a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing that the problem, especially in Africa and Asia, was not lack of food but of money to pay for transportation and storage.

headline: CHRYSLER SEEN RETIRING LOANS EARLY
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation plans to repay the entire $800 million remaining of its federally guaranteed debt by the end of this year, sources in the auto industry and in the financial community said today.   The announcement is expected to be made by Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, in a speech tomorrow before the National Press Club in Washington. Chrysler officials refused to confirm the reports but, pointedly, did not deny them.

headline: 'ONE NATION!' IS THE CRY FOR NIGERIANS ON THE STUMP
abstract: In the surprisingly cool air of morning, a caravan of Mercedes and Peugeot sedans wends its way through the streets of this state capital, a jumble of cinder-block buildings and corrugated metal shacks insinuated into a lushly verdant tropical forest.   The caravan arrives at a stage set up at the municipal stadium. Workers begin testing microphones and amplifiers while VIP's ensconce themselves in upholstered chairs under a canvas awning.   When all is ready and a crowd of several thousand has gathered around, the master of ceremonies struts downstage. He wears a yellow babanriga, the flowing embroidered linen robe of the Nigerian north, and the tall rigid cap known as a dipcharima.

headline: EX-TYPIST FOR WACHTELL ACCUSED OF INSIDER TIPS
abstract: A former typist at a New York law firm that is one of the nation's specialists in corporate mergers was accused today of illegally passing tips about pending mergers to friends and relatives who were said to have used the information to make $2.7 million in the stock market.   The Securities and Exchange Commission brought the charge principally against Manohar Lal Madan, 48 years old, who joined Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz in the 1970's as a typist, a job he held until his dismissal last November.   The commission said, in effect, that Mr. Lal Madan passed information about planned mergers that he came across as he typed.  The S.E.C. also filed charges against the friends and relatives.   The friends and relatives, using this information, were able to buy stocks in companies soon to be the targets of takeover bids, the S.E.C. said. When the bids were announced, the stocks of these companies rose in price and Mr. Lal Madan's group sold at a profit, the commission charged. They traded in the stocks of 29 companies this way and earned the $2.7 million over five years, the S.E.C.  said.

headline: Advertising; Thomas's Muffin Campaign
abstract: HOW many of you insular New Yorkers realize that for almost a century, while you and your kind were enjoying the melted butter in the nooks and crannies, the rest of your country was doing without Thomas's English muffins.   Equal muffin opportunity did not begin to come to the land of the free and the home of the brave until after CPC International purchased S. B. Thomas Inc. That was in 1976, when there was a single bakery serving metropolitan New York. Now there are four - with a fifth opening any moment near Chicago - and the ''original English muffin'' is available to 53 percent of the United States population.

headline: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Osborne, Financially Shaky, Seeks Investor
abstract: The Osborne Computer Corporation, which laid off all but 80 of its employees last Friday, is scrambling to find a new source of investment or a possible acquirer to stave off financial failure.   Company officials did not return phone calls yesterday seeking a response to reports that the company was talking to the ITT Corporation and others about being acquired.

headline: Careers; High-Rise Specialists Developing
abstract: MOST people, at one time or another, have run their eyes up the full height of a skyscraper and had the odd feeling that the structure is swaying in the wind. Many people, too, worry about the stability of elevators in high-rise buildings. And others get uneasy looking out the window of a tall building.   A new group of professionals has made these sensory or psychological reactions to tall buildings their special subject of study. They are interested, in particular, in high-rise safety, livability, engineering, economics and environmental impact.

headline: Plato Software By Control Data
abstract: The Control Data Corporation said that it would introduce a software package that would enable users of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer to gain access to a data base containing Plato, a popular instructional computer program used primarily in elementary schools.

headline: NOT SINCE 30'S HAS BRITISH COLUMBIA BEEN SO RILED
abstract: Flush with an election victory, the government of this Pacific Coast province is proposing a barrage of actions whose cumulative effect is far more radical than anything Canada has ever experienced.    At a time of severe economic crisis, Premier William Bennett announced plans to dismiss or otherwise remove a quarter of the provincial government's employees, about 11,000 people. Among other things, he wants to abolish the Human Rights Commission, take tenure away from college professors, abolish rent controls as well as the office for resolving tenant complaints and partly privatize public medical insurance.   Not since the unemployed rioted in Vancouver streets during the Depression have emotions been so strident. The government rails about the irresponsibility of its ''socialist'' opponents, while its opponents call the ruling party ''Nazis'' and worse.

headline: CHOICES FOR THE ALLIES
abstract: MilitaryAnalysis     Despite assurances from their governments that the Marines and other members of the four-nation peacekeeping force in Beirut will remain on the defensive, American and other allied officers are confident that the troops jointly have the weapons, the training and the experience to mount an attack, if they were ordered, against the Shiite Moslem guerrillas who have shelled their positions and sniped at their transport.   Troops of all four contingents came under fire yesterday, and United States and British sources said there was little chance that the Lebanese Army would be able to find and destroy the Shiite guerrillas in the hills.   The retention of the peacekeeping force in its present defense positions under fire and without being able to do much about it, one source said, is bound to raise morale problems among the troops.   The marines, who number 1,200, do not appear to have sufficient strength to mount offensive actions on their own. Aside from their helicopter gunships and 155-millimeter artillery, which were used Monday and Tuesday against Shiite positions, they have a limited ability to hit back at mortar batteries, machine-gun nests and snipers. The other units in the multinational force do not have heavy weapons.

headline: REAGAN AVOIDS DRAMATIC IN RESPONSE TO SHOOTING
abstract: News  Analysis    WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 - On the recommendation of his key advisers, President Reagan decided not to impose any new, dramatic sanctions against the Soviet Union for the downing of the Korean airliner.  He agreed not to do so, his aides said tonight, because it would be too damaging to the Administration if he took such steps as suspending the arms control negotiations or halting the trade in grain and nonstrategic goods.   Several conservative organizations and public figures had urged the President to use the outrage generated over the airliner incident to sever relations effectively with Moscow. He was advised by the publication Conservative Digest, for instance, to halt the arms control talks, end all trade, and cut diplomatic relations to a bare minimum.

headline: Pipeline Offering
abstract: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation's $100 million of 12 3/4 percent debentures due in 2008 were offered at 99 5/8 to yield 12.80 percent, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. When the price was set, the pipeline company's debentures, rated A-2, yielded about 1 1/4 percentage points more than outstanding 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013.

headline: DRUSE BESIEGE CHRISTIANS IN MOUNTAINS OUTSIDE BEIRUT
abstract: Druse militiamen laid siege to Christian enclaves in the Shuf Mountains east and south of here today as efforts to achieve a cease-fire faltered on the seventh day of Lebanon's renewed civil war.   While shelling in the Beirut area, and against members of the multinational peacekeeping forces, diminished today, Christian and Druse militias continued to shell each other in their scramble for position in the Shuf mountains.   Although Beirut had its most peaceful day in two weeks, American jets, apparently on reconnaissance missions, were seen streaking over the city this afternoon and into the mountains to the east.   Positions held by the Lebanese Army in a defensive perimeter it has established around Beirut came under fire from Druse batteries today, the state radio said. The radio also reported that, as the war rages in the Shuf, there had been reports of villages destroyed, of increasing numbers of refugees and atrocities against civilians.

headline: Monfort Files Suit
abstract: Monfort of Colorado has filed suit in Federal court to stop what it says is an attempt by another meatpacker to monopolize the beef industry.

headline: Chrysler Callback
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would call back 1,500 laid-off auto workers to reactivate a second shift at a suburban truck plant in Warren, Mich. The new shift, which begins Oct. 3, also means means jobs for about 100 additional salaried workers at the Warren facility, said Stephan Sharf, Chrysler's executive vice president of manufacturing.

headline: Shah's Widow in Cairo
abstract: Former Empress Farah of Iran was reported today to have arrived in Cairo to pay respects at the burial place of her husband, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, on the third anniversary of his death.

headline: BATTLE OVER CRUDE OIL FUTURES
abstract: For the first time since 1974, when gold futures were introduced, a New York futures exchange has beaten a Chicago exchange at trading the same new commodity contract. This year, in the first five months of competition, the New York Mercantile Exchange has leaped ahead of the Chicago Board of Trade to become the No. 1 trader in crude oil futures.  The race began on March 30. And the Chicago Board, the world's largest commodities exchange, quickly jumped in front in the first month, trading more than 30,000 contracts - against 14,000 for the New York Merc.

headline: Is Commodore Return Due for Kornhauser?
abstract: Rumblings coming in from east of Times Square have it that Commodore Business Machines, now that it has split with Ally & Gargano, one of the nation's outstanding advertising agencies, could be returning to Kornhauser & Calene, which had previously done the usual brief tour that a Commodore agency usually does.   The personal computer maker, whose sales have been booming, is part of Commodore International.

headline: Japan Consumer Prices
abstract: Japanese consumer prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent in July from June, the Government said today. July prices were up 2.2 percent from a year earlier. The figures are not seasonally adjusted.

headline: HOMELAND LEADER RECOUNTS A PLOT
abstract: Lennox L. Sebe, the President for Life of this nominally independent black homeland, chortles softly over reports that he was acting on a tip from the South African authorities when he jailed the top officers of his own security police, including his younger brother.    Until he was stripped of his powers, Lieut. Gen. Charles Sebe had been the strongman of Ciskei and probably the most powerful black in South Africa. A former sergeant in the South African security police, he had command of Ciskei's army, police and prisons.   He used the powers he amassed to wage a personal holy war against the underground African National Congress, which has been strong in the region.  But when he fell in July, there were reports from Pretoria that his South African sponsors had learned he planned a coup and alerted his brother to the danger.

headline: Mortage Rates Go Up
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that the average interest rate for new mortgages rose to 13.01 percent in early June, from 12.99 percent in early May, ending a decline from 17.23 percent last July. The average covers long-term, fixed-rate loans for newly built houses.

headline: SOVIET HARSHLY CRITICIZES REAGAN'S SPEECH AT U.N.
abstract: The official Soviet press agency Tass today reported President Reagan's speech to the United Nations General Assembly but omitted any mention of his new proposal for an agreement on medium- range nuclear weapons in Europe.   In a dispatch from New York, Tass used some of the harshest language it has applied to Mr. Reagan since he took office.
