It said that he had used ''gross distortions of generally known facts, demagoguery, disinformation and blatant lies'' in an attempt to disguise an ''aggressive, imperialist'' foreign policy as one of peace.   The report said nothing about Mr. Reagan's new proposals on medium- range weapons, which have been described as ''a mockery of common sense'' in Soviet news commentaries since they were outlined privately to Soviet negotiators in Geneva last week. There has been no authoritative pronouncement on the proposals by the Government.

headline: Equatorial Guinea Elects a Parliament
abstract: The tiny West African country of Equatorial Guinea held its first parliamentary elections in more than 10 years today, but exiled opposition groups criticized the vote as a sham.   An estimated 50,000 voters, about one-third of the residents, were electing 41 representatives to a new five- year National Assembly in accordance with the 1982 constitution.

headline: PHYSICIANS DEVELOPING STATEN ISLAND MEDICAL PROJECT
abstract: More than two years ago it became obvious to Dr. Thomas Costantino and Dr. Marie C. Rosati, who share a Staten Island practice in cardiology, that they would soon outgrow the small building they occupy on Seaview Avenue.   While they were thinking of building a new facility on that same street near the Staten Island Hospital, where they both serve on the staff, they were put in touch with two other Staten Island physicians, Dr. Charles Lomanto, an anesthesiologist, and Dr. Robert Cattani, a plastic surgeon and eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, who were also looking for office space in the area.   The four doctors formed a partnership - but not in a medical practice. Instead they are partners in a real estate development company that is building a 40,000-square-foot medical condominium. The building is going up at 500 Seaview Avenue, across the street from the new Staten Island Hospital and the state-run South Beach Psychiatric Center. The institutions are in the South Beach section of the borough.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 14, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Exercise of the Inalienable Rights of the Palestinian People - 3 P.M.

headline: Rates Up At Banks
abstract: Interest rates on banks' money market accounts continued to rise in the week ended Wednesday, both in New York and around the country, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.   The nationwide average, based on a survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, rose to 8.38 percent, from 8.34 percent last week and 8.2 percent the week before.

headline: ADIEU TO SERVICE WITH A SMILE
abstract: When business is bad, you expect service to be better than usual. But where gas stations are concerned, that's not the case. In fact, the friendly attendant who cleans your windshield is being replaced, almost overnight, by the fully automated - and computerized - station.

headline: ZAMBIAN SAYS U.S. ASSISTS PRETORIA
abstract: President Kenneth D. Kaunda, expressing frustration over the diplomatic stalemate in southern Africa, is now accusing the Reagan Administration of being an accomplice of South Africa in Angola.   In an interview, the Zambian leader contended that Washington's approach to the tangled issue of the independence for South-West Africa, the disputed territory commonly known as Namibia, had ''allowed time'' for South Africa to bolster the Angolan rebel force led by Jonas Savimbi.   ''What the Reagan Administration is doing,'' the President said, ''is to enable Savimbi to build up his forces with the help of South Africa.''  Of the Cuban Withdrawal    It has been nearly five months since the last known negotiations between the United States and Angola over the withdrawal of an estimated 23,000 Cuban troops. In that time the Savimbi force, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, has markedly extended its area of operations and influence beyond its stronghold in southeastern Angola where it has access to South African supply lines.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Kinder-Care Learning Centers has agreed with Drexel Burnham Lambert, Merrill Lynch International and Alexander Brown & Sons to sell $50 million of 6.25 percent convertible subordinated guaranteed debentures of its Netherlands Antilles unit.      Debt Ratings     *  Moody's Investors Service raised to B-1, from B-3, its rating on $70 million of subordinated debentures of Arrow Electronics and assigned a B-1 rating to a newly registered issue of $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Oil Depletion Is Estimated LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -   The world's supply of conventional crude oil, used at the current rate, could run out in about   63 years, an American geologist said today. Charles D. Masters of the   United States Geological Survey told oil industry officials at   the World Petroleum Congress   that known reserves of conventional crude oil stand at about   103 billion metric tons, or approximately 720 billion barrels.

headline: SOVIET RUNAWAY TEEN-AGER CREATES WASHINGTON MYSTERY
abstract: The 16- year-old son of a Soviet diplomat here took his parents' car and ran away from home Wednesday because, according to a letter signed with the boy's name, ''I hate my country and it's rules and I love your country.''   By the time the boy had returned to his home in a Washington suburb less than 24 hours later, he had created a diplomatic incident, involving the State Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and police officials in several jurisdictions.    Some aspects of his disappearance remained - and may remain - a mystery. It was not clear whether Government authorities, at the time they ordered the search, understood that the boy's departure might involve a possible defection.

headline: 2 Killed in Sikh Clash in India
abstract: Two people died in an exchange of gunfire in a clash today between rival Sikh sects over control of a temple in the city of Chandigarh in the northern Indian state of Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported. The police said the dead were members of a Sikh sect known as Nihangs, who guard Sikh temples and traditionally carry swords or spears. The police said 31 members of the sect were arrested on various charges including murder, rioting and possession of illegal weapons.

headline: Advertising; Glamour Magazine's Relevance
abstract: Our company is the best-kept secret in the business.'' That is one of the most familiar complaints among ad agency chief executives who feel that their non-news events are not getting the proper coverage.   But that doesn't mean that a publishing type can't feel similarly neglected. On Friday E. Louis Holtermann Jr. said he did. He is the publisher of Glamour Magazine, one of Conde Nast's three entries in the female fashion field, and a fashion plate himself.

headline: Headaches
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Paul Harper of the American Association of Advertising Agencies suggests that the Federal Trade Commission forget its request for accountability in analgesics advertising, and leave it to the Better Business Bureau and the National Advertising Review Board to protect the public's interest in such matters (Business Forum, July 31).    These two self-policing groups take no positive action to set standards of honesty or accountability in advertising. They simply wait for someone to complain about a specific advertisement, then they field the complaint.   In recent years their major activity has been not to protect the public's interest, but to referee competitive hair-pulling matches between Product A and Product B.   LIONEL M. KAUFMAN Scarsdale, N.Y., July 31

headline: PILOT WHO SHOT DOWN KOREAN JET IS INTERVIEWED ON SOVIET TELEVISION
abstract: Soviet television broadcast an interview tonight with a Soviet fighter pilot who was identified as having shot down the Korean Air Lines 747 jetliner last week.   The pilot, who appeared to be about 45 years old, with graying, tousled hair, a rugged face and a raspy voice, was not named or identified by rank.   ''I had a specific task assigned me,'' he said, ''and I tried to accomplish it as well as possible - a military task, which is the meaning of my entire life.''   He sat slouched in an easy chair, dressed in a brown leather jacket, blue cotton pants and blue shirt as he spoke to the interviewer, Aleksandr Tikhomirov of Soviet state television, on a base on Sakhalin island.   The pilot described his certainty that he was dealing with an ''enemy aircraft,'' and told how he had wagged the wings of his SU-15 and fired four bursts of tracer shells along the jetliner's route.  ''This in international code signifies that 'you're an intruder,' '' he said. ''He had to answer somehow that 'yes, I'm an intruding aircraft and in trouble,' and I would've helped him if he was in trouble, and if he was an intruder he could have landed on our airfield and we would have sorted it out.''

headline: BANKING'S CREDIT CARD LURES
abstract: With the bank credit card market saturated after 15 years, participants in the battle for customers have come to rely on one main weapon: marketing ingenuity.  Citibank gives holders of its Mastercard and Visa card ''Citidollar$'' toward catalogue merchandise discounts with every purchase made.  Manufacturers Hanover Trust recently ran a sweepstakes program, with card members ''entering'' each time they used the card.  And at Manufacturers and Traders Trust in Buffalo, members of eight upstate American Automobile Association clubs get reduced annual fees for Visa cards issued through the bank.

headline: Kuwait Cuts Gas Price
abstract: The state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corporation today reduced prices of its liquefied petroleum gas, mainly propane and butane, by 4.6 percent.

headline: LEBANON CHIEF SAYS OPPOSITION ALLIANCE PRESENTS NO THREAT
abstract: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon said today that a newly announced alliance formed to oppose his Government posed no threat to the country or his administration.   ''We have democracy in Lebanon,'' Mr. Gemayel said.

headline: Kaiser Steel Bids
abstract: A group of Tulsa investors, whose bid to acquire the Kaiser Steel Corporation was rejected, said they plan to submit a second offer soon.

headline: Palestinian Shot Dead By Gunmen in Athens
abstract: Two young men on a motorbicycle, their faces covered by crash helmets, today shot and killed a businessman identified by the Palestinian press service as a top lieutenant in Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah guerrilla group.   The Palestine Liberation Organization's mission in Athens said in a statement that the killing was ''the work of Israeli agents and part of Israel's general policy to exterminate the people of Palestine.''

headline: WALESA SPEECH PRINTED, APPARENTLY TO HURT HIM
abstract: Polish exiles adjust to U.S. Page 42.             WARSAW, Aug. 27 - The authorities today published and broadcast a speech by Lech Walesa, whom they have been calling for many months a ''private person'' of little public consequence despite his having founded Solidarity.   The Government appeared to be trying to show both that it was willing to meet with disgruntled workers and to discredit Mr. Walesa and his supporters, whom a high Government official described as a ''gang of thugs.''   The move came amid efforts by the Government to reduce tension for next Wednesday's anniversary of the signing of agreements with striking Gdansk shipyard workers that gave birth to the now-banned Solidarity labor union in 1980. For example, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, went to a Silesian mining and industrial area and met with members of the Government-sponsored unions.

headline: Airlines Review Commission
abstract: Three major airlines said yesterday that they would continue to pay full-service travel agents a 10 percent commission for the sale of air travel in United States markets.   Eastern Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines all declined to follow the lead last week of several airlines, including American Airlines, which reduced the commissions paid travel agents to 9 percent.

headline: SOUTH CYPRUS BOUNCES BACK FROM '74 WAR
abstract: For more than 400 years this was a drowsy farming village. Today it is the Mediterranean island's most popular seaside resort and a symbol of Greek Cypriot resilience.   ''We were not afraid to start from scratch,'' said Iacovos P. Iacovou, one of the 200,000 Greek Cypriot refugees who lost their homes and businesses when Turkish troops invaded and occupied the north in 1974. ''Success is possible with hard work. We are very hard workers.''

headline: Market Place; Price Swings in Dart Drug
abstract: LAST Friday, shares of the Dart Drug Corporation, a little-known but stellar performer in the current bull market, plunged 26 points, to 117 bid, in over-the-counter trading. Within the last 52 weeks, Dart's stock had soared more than tenfold - from a low of 14 1/2 to a record of 148.   After dropping 11 points Monday and rebounding 6 points on Tuesday, Dart's shares closed yesterday at 116 bid, up 4 points.  The success of Dart, which operates discount drugstores in the Washington area, reflects the confluence of two unusual forces: it was an ''overlooked'' issue in the chain drugstore industry that investors have favored recently, and it was a beneficiary of the hot new-issues market.

headline: THE K.G.B. GOES ON THE OFFENSIVE AND THE WEST BEGINS STRIKING BACK
abstract: The Soviet intelligence and security agency, the K.G.B., has entered a phase of aggressiveness in its activities in the West, according to allied officials. The upsurge is cited as the principal cause of a series of expulsions of Soviet agents from countries around the world since the start of 1983.   The number of Russians expelled for illegal intelligence-gathering so far this year has reached 90, according to the United States State Department. Six others, identified as spies, left on their own.  The total for all of 1982, according to United States Government records was 49; in 1981, it was 27.   The increased number of expulsions, including the French decision to order the departure of 47 Russians in April, is widely described as a function of the stepped-up K.G.B. effort, but not a result of a coordinated Western campaign.

headline: LEBANON TROOPS BATTLE MOSLEMS IN WEST BEIRUT
abstract: Lebanese Army units and Shiite Moslem militiamen clashed in the heart of Beirut today after Government security forces tried to evict Shiite squatters from an abandoned Jewish school.   The shootout began about 10 A.M., peaked at midday and continued into the night. It was the worst fighting in the capital since the army took control of the Greater Beirut area in September and early October, after the withdrawal of Israeli forces.   As news of the fighting spread the streets of West Beirut became largely deserted. People closeted themselves in their homes or listened to the fighting in small groups sitting on their balconies.  Most shopkeepers, fearing that the clashes might spread, rolled down their steel shutters and closed for the day.

headline: STATE SAVINGS BANKS HEALTHIER
abstract: Savings banks in New York State showed considerable improvement in the second quarter, although more than half of them continued to report operating losses, according to the state banking department.    Operating losses were cut dramatically, to a total of $55.1 million, from $269.9 million in the second quarter of 1982, and from $116 million in the first quarter of this year.   As a result, the sense of impending doom within the industry has lifted. It has become far less likely that Federal and state regulatory authorities will force mergers of failing institutions into stronger ones.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Sale of Gold By Lisbon Seen    LISBON, Sept. 6 (AP) - Portugal may have to sell about 30 tons of gold, worth about $404 million, to repay a $300 million loan from the Bank of International Settlements, banking sources said today.   Portugal's central bank deposited 36 tons of gold in March to back a $400 million loan, and deposited 30 tons in May for a $300 million credit with the settlements bank.

headline: 'Smear' Seen On I.M.F. Bill
abstract: Democrats in the House of Representatives told President Reagan today that a ''smear campaign'' by a Republican committee might jeopardize his chances for gaining final approval of increased support for the International Monetary Fund.   A vote on a House-Senate compromise version is due this fall.

headline: Pope Says All Possible Steps Are Being Taken to Free Girl
abstract: Pope John Paul II said today that he was doing ''all that is humanly possible'' to help free a 15-year-old girl apparently being held as a hostage for the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who shot the Pope.   The Pope told 30,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square, ''Once again, as last Sunday, I want to recommend to your prayers Emanuela Orlandi, for whom I and all of us together with the afflicted family, wait with anxiety for the return.''

headline: Petrobras in Talks With Oil Concerns
abstract: Petrobras, the Brazilian state oil company, has opened talks with three multinational oil companies aimed at importing part of the country's oil needs under favorable terms, officials said.   Carlos Santanna, the company's commercial director, said at a news conference that the talks had begun in London and New York between Petrobras and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Exxon and Atlantic Richfield.   Brazil is attempting to import oil from the three companies with payment deferred for 180 days. Mr. Santanna indicated that companies that did not comply would receive less favorable terms for their operations in Brazil.

headline: KOHL PARTY SUFFERS SETBACK IN STATE VOTE
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party suffered a sharp reverse today in a closely watched election in the industrial state of Hesse, where the national opposition party, the Social Democrats, emerged as the largest single group but fell short of a governing majority.   In a day of voting seen as the first significant test of opinion on the one- year-old Kohl Government, the Social Democrats also strengthened their majority in the legislature of the small northern state of Bremen, which has the highest level of unemployment in the country.   Both states are traditional Social Democratic strongholds, and politicians were reluctant to draw sweeping conclusions about national politics from the two regional elections. But the conservative Kohl Government, now confronting difficult foreign and economic policy decisions, was hardly bolstered by the results.

headline: LOPSIDED ECONOMIC RECOVERY
abstract: The Western industrialized world is entering a period of lopsided economic recovery with the United States and Japanese economies likely to perform significantly better during the next 18 months than those of Western Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its semiannual forecast released today.   ''Evidence that recovery is under way is now quite clear in the U.S., and detectable - though less so and with some important differences among countries - elsewhere in the O.E.C.D.,'' Sylvia Ostry, the organization's chief economist, told a news conference when she introduced the new forecasts. The projections were contained in The Economic Outlook, the group's semiannual review of Western economic policy.   But the O.E.C.D. warned that the uneven recovery now beginning in the West was still vulnerable to high American interest rates and weak demand that threaten to choke off the revival of industrial investment that is necessary if the recovery is to become selfsustaining.

headline: CHINESE MOBILIZE FOR NEW FLOODING
abstract: China's heartland is bracing for potentially serious flooding along the Yangtze River after torrential rains last week that inundated the industrial city of Wuhan.   More than a million Chinese have been mobilized to patrol along the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze day and night to to prevent it from bursting its banks and covering the surrounding countryside, the New China News Agency quoted a spokesman from the central flood control headquarters as saying.   They include 43,000 soldiers and civilians working on the dikes, which were reinforced several years ago at a cost of about $10 million. The water level is said to be the second highest at Wuhan and downriver in 29 years.

headline: STREET URCHINS IN BRAZIL FIND A TOWN THAT CARES
abstract: In most respects, this town of 20,000 inhabitants on Brazil's vast tableland is like thousands of other towns across Latin America.   A jouncing 50-mile ride along a dirt road from the nearest highway brings you to a community that is centered on a plaza dominated by a scrubbed white church, with its steeple rising over clusters of terra-cotta roofs.   Donkey carts rattle over cobblestone streets alongside pickups whose wheels and fenders are layered with red dust. Old men pass the morning in desultory conversation on concrete benches bearing the names of past mayors in lordly script.

headline: Dutch Jobless
abstract: Dutch unemployment rose to a postwar record of 810,400 in June from 793,300 in May, the Social Affairs Ministry reported today. In June 1982, seasonally adjusted unemployment stood at 655,500.

headline: Rival Palestinian Groups Again Battle in Bekaa
abstract: Heavy fighting erupted today between rival Palestinian guerrilla factions in the Bekaa, the eastern Lebanon valley, the Beirut radio reported.   It said the clashes broke out in villages near the crossroads town of Shtaura between supporters and opponents of Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Fatah guerrilla group.

headline: Quaker Oats Gets A New Chairman
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company, the big marketer of food, pet foods and toys, announced yesterday that its chairman, Robert D. Stuart Jr., would step down Nov. 9 at the company's annual meeting.   The announcement prompted several other changes. William D. Smithburg, the 45-year-old president and chief executive, was named chairman and chief executive. And Frank J. Morgan, 58, executive vice president for United States and Canadian grocery products, was named president and chief operating officer.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Carowinds regional theme park, owned by Taft Broadcasting, to W. B. Doner & Company, Southfield, Mich.     * Daisy Manufacturing Company, Tulsa, to Hood, Hope & Associates.

headline: Borrowing In Decline
abstract: New international borrowings fell 18 percent in August from July, reflecting, in part, greater caution among multinational banks, a study said today.   The total of new funds raised in the global capital markets fell to $8.6 billion, from $10.5 billion in July, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.

headline: LEADERS IN SENATE CRITICIZING SHULTZ
abstract: Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress today sharply criticized statements by Secretary of State George P. Shultz that the Reagan Administration would not feel bound by proposed legislation to invoke the War Powers Resolution and to authorize the presence of American Marines in Lebanon for 18 months.    Mr. Shultz's statements have become a major issue on Capitol Hill, where the Senate began considering a bill today to use the War Powers Resolution for the first time since its enactment 10 years ago. Many lawmakers said the Administration's position showed contempt for the law and the constitutional responsibility of Congress to share in decisions on war and peace.   ''The Administration wants our stamp of approval,'' Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, told the Senate, ''but it is unwilling to commit itself to our laws.''

headline: Bank Rates Off Again
abstract: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts continued to fall in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   The Monitor's nationwide average, based on a survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, dropped to 8.62 percent, from 8.64 percent a week ago.

headline: Hilton's Net Up 21.5%
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its second-quarter net income rose 21.5 percent to $28.3 million, or $1.05 a share, from $23.3 million, or 87 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Hilton said revenues for the 1983 quarter ended June 30 were $178.9 million, up 10.8 percent from $161.4 million a year earlier. Hilton credited higher occupancy levels at its hotels and improved casino earnings.

headline: Wang Net Rises 44%; Prime Computer Down
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc., the Lowell, Mass., manufacturer of electronic office equipment, reported sharp increases in earnings, revenue and new orders for the quarter ended June 30 and for its fiscal year.   But Prime Computer Inc., as expected, said earnings in its second quarter dropped 41.3 percent because of a sharp downturn in orders for its most profitable minicomputers. Prime also warned that thirdquarter results would be worse than those of a year earlier.

headline: Feldstein Rate View
abstract: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Martin S. Feldstein, said today that he expected no significant change in interest-rate levels in coming months, a view somewhat at odds with that of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who has been arguing that they would move downward for at least the rest of 1983. ''I don't see any reason to expect any major movement,'' Mr. Feldstein told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

headline: RUSSIA'S LONG FLIRTATION
abstract: Red Carpet, by Joseph Finder. A New Republic Book/Holt Rinehart & Winston, N.Y. 372 pages, $16.95.  IN the midst of a devastating famine in the 1930's, George Bernard Shaw visited Russia and was fed generously by his hosts.  ''Starvation?'' he remarked when he returned. ''Why, I've never eaten so wonderfully!''   Last year, having been chauffeured about the Soviet Union, the Rev. Billy Graham said that he had seen no evidence of religious oppression and added, ''In the United States you have to be a millionaire to have caviar, but I have had caviar with almost every meal.'' According to the author of this book, who is at Harvard's Russian Research Center, no one told Mr. Graham that caviar ''is a luxury available only to Russia's most privileged.''

headline: DEBRIS OF A PLANE FOUND, SOVIET SAYS
abstract: The Soviet Ambassador to Japan reported that debris from an aircraft had been found in waters where a South Korean passenger airliner was reported shot down Thursday by a Soviet fighter plane, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.    The Ambassador, Vladimir Y. Pavlov, did not specify that the plane fragments were from the missing Korean Air Lines jet, according to the Foreign Ministry. Nor did he comment on reports in the United States that Soviet searchers had recovered some bodies from the plane, which went down with 269 people aboard in the northern Sea of Japan west of Sakhalin island.   Nevertheless, it was the first Soviet statement that something had been discovered from what presumably was the Korean jet, a Boeing 747 on the Anchorage-to-Seoul leg of a flight that had begun in New York.

headline: CHANGES PROPOSED IN AIR NAVIGATION
abstract: The head of the Air Line Pilots Association suggested to a House panel today that a more foolproof system ought to be developed to make sure traffic-control centers on shore know the precise position of planes on oceanic routes.   The union official, Capt. Henry Duffy, called for a civil system that would use satellites to relay the positions calculated by the inertial navigation systems carried aboard the planes. Currently, with planes out of range of civil radar, the crew reports positions periodically by radio. Captain Duffy said an automatic satellite relay system should provide ''an independent verification of pilot position reports.''

headline: Bass-Bayly Tie
abstract: Bayly Martin & Fay International Inc. said the Bass Brothers, a group of investors, had purchased an interest in the company for an undisclosed cash sum.   Bayly Martin & Fay, a general insurance brokerage firm, was purchased by members of its senior management in December last year from its former parent company, the Baldwin-United Corporation.

headline: SPECIAL HEARING CALLED ON SEIZURE OF RICH FILES
abstract: A visibly angry Federal judge yesterday scheduled a special hearing for next Monday to determine whether Marc Rich & Company A.G., the giant Swiss-based commodities firm, and an affiliate are conspiring to resist his repeated orders to turn over subpoenaed documents.   Judge Leonard B. Sand said he intended to find out at the hearing, set for United States District Court in Manhattan, if the companies have been truthful in explaining their failure to turn over records subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury a year and a half ago.   If he determines that they have not, the judge warned, he could halt the company's multi-billion dollar trading operations in the United States.   Marc Rich, one of the world's biggest commodities trading firms, is being investigated by the grand jury on charges that it evaded United States income taxes on at least $20 million in profits. After a contempt- of-court citation and fines of $50,000 a day, the Swiss-based company agreed on Aug. 5 to turn over the documents by this Friday.

headline: Ariane Rocket Contracts
abstract: The European Space Agency, which is competing against the United States in the lucrative satellitelaunching market, today announced two new contracts for its Ariane rockets worth $130 million. One contract is for the launching of the European Telecommunications Satellite, Olympus, in 1986 and the other is for three European Meteosat weather satellites between 1987 and 1990.

headline: MALAWI'S ELITE ACADEMY: THE VERY MODEL OF ETON
abstract: The dirt road twists and turns through okra and arid bush, fringed with villages where wolen pound corn in large wooden mortars and the children are thin and ragged.   Then, suddenly, there is a tarred road, sprinklers on billiardsmooth lawns and, rising from the savannah, the crenelated and cloiste2ed ramparts of Kamuzu Academy, modeled on Eton and Marlborough schools in England, a monument to classical learning and to one man's monomania - the school the President built.   ''What,'' a teacher from England might ask a class of young Africans, ''did Archimedes shout when he discovered his principle in the bathtub? And write the answer in Greek.'' The pupils bow their heads over their exercise books and write ''Eureka,'' which means, ''I have found it.''

headline: 21 REMAIN AT LARGE AFTER ULSTER PRISON BREAK
abstract: Heavily armed policemen and British Army patrols searched today for 21 members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army still at large after having escaped from the maximum-security Maze Prison on Sunday.   Officials promised a full inquiry into the daylight escape by 38 prisoners from H-Block, the scene of the hunger strike by I.R.A. inmates two years ago that attracted international attention.    Protestant Unionist leaders expressed frustration and rage over what was apparently the ease with which weapons had been smuggled into the prison.   Fifteen fugitives were rounded up Sunday, and two were captured today. A prison guard died in the prison break and six others were hospitalized with wounds. Most of the guards were stabbed during a wild sequence when the prisoners drove a commandeered food truck through the prison's front gate.

headline: ISRAEL IS SENDING 2 HIGH OFFICIALS TO MEET REAGAN
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Arens and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir will fly to Washington Monday to consult with President Reagan on the deteriorating situation in Lebanon, the Cabinet announced today.   Israeli officials, emerging from the regular weekly Cabinet meeting, said the visit of the two ministers was in response to an invitation from Mr. Reagan contained in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin that arrived here this morning.   In Washington, the White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said the talks would center on a discussion of ''steps toward withdrawal of all foreign forces'' from Lebanon. Mr. Speakes said Mr. Reagan's invitation was ''based on the fact that he had seen President Gemayel,'' the Lebanese leader, ''and wanted a chance to talk to the Israelis and get the views of everybody affected.'' Visit by Begin Canceled   The visit of Israel's Defense and Foreign Ministers will apparently substitute for an official trip to the United States by Mr. Begin originally planned for this week. That visit was canceled by Mr. Begin, who cited ''personal reasons.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ACTS ON A CONSTITUTION
abstract: South Africa's white parliament completed action today on a newconstitution that would give nonwhites a role in the national Government for the first time in the country's history.   The constitution will now be presented to the white electorate in a referendum on Nov. 2. Its approval then is regarded as likely but something less than a foregone conclusion. If it is rejected, the governing National Party will have suffered its most severe setback in 35 years of uninterrupted rule.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: Ronald Reagan entered the White House promising substantial reductions in personal income taxes; with the arrival Friday of the third and final cut of his program, the President has delivered. Mr. Reagan also promised to fight inflation and to reduce the burden of Government regulation. There, too, he has delivered.   These initiatives - on taxes, inflation and regulation - are the tenets of Reaganomics, a contradictory blend of orthodox conservative ideology and little-tested theories of supply-side economics. Cutting income tax rates across the board was meant to encourage saving and investment, a cornerstone of supply-side theory, which holds that growth begins more with industrial expansion than through buoyant spending on the demand, or consumer, side.   Today the President can argue that Reaganomics works. In apparent testimony to his success, the economy of late has been bursting with the blossoms of even greater growth than Mr. Reagan had predicted.  Indeed, with prices stable and factory production, automobile sales, consumer spending and house building all on the rebound, the President this week had to raise his estimate for 1983 economic growth for the second time.

headline: MOSCOW CONCEDES A SOVIET FIGHTER DOWNED AIRLINER
abstract: The Soviet Government said today that a Soviet fighter was ordered ''to stop the flight'' of a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 on Sept. 1 over the island of Sakhalin after it had failed to obey the fighter's demands that it land at a Soviet airfield.    The Government statement was the first acknowledgment that the 747 was        Soviet statement, page A16.  shot down. But it said that the fighter pilots involved did not know they were dealing with a civilian airliner.   ''The Soviet pilots, in stopping the actions of the intruder plane, could not have known that it was a civilian aircraft,'' the statement said. ''It was flying without navigation lights, at the height of night, in conditions of bad visibility and was not answering signals.''

headline: Irish Detail Allegations In Russian Expulsions
abstract: Two Soviet diplomats and the wife of one of them had gotten in touch with the outlawed Irish Republican Army apparently in an attempt to trade arms for information before they were expelled from the Irish Republic, according to Irish security sources.   The Foreign Ministry cited ''unacceptable activities,'' which is common diplomatic language for spying, when it announced the expulsions of Gennadi Salin, a first secretary and press attache; Viktor Lipasov, a second secretary, and Mr. Lipasov's wife, Irina, on Sept. 9.

headline: Sales of Funds At $2.7 Billion
abstract: Sales of mutual funds continued to exceed redemptions by a wide margin in August, according to data compiled by the Investment Company Institute.

headline: TAKEOVER STIR AT BELL & HOWELL
abstract: The Bell & Howell Company, disclosing that it had been approached by a smaller company that wanted to acquire its vocational training business, announced a two-step plan yesterday to discourage takeover attempts.   Bell & Howell, an electronics, publishing and education company, said it had been approached by the National Education Corporation, a vocational education concern. It said National Education had expressed an interest in buying the Devry Institutes of Technology, which is a Bell & Howell subsidiary, or all of Bell & Howell.

headline: Mrs. Thatcher's Retina Is Surgically Repaired
abstract: The retina in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's right eye was repaired in an operation today, a spokesman announced tonight.

headline: CHINA'S WEST IS CHALLENGED BY ETHNIC MIX
abstract: A Han Chinese migrant to this western Chinese region said her husband once threw a pailful of dirty laundry water out the front door and nearly splashed a local Uighur, a Moslem who was going to the mosque to pray. Uighur neighbors came around to say they considered the practice offensive, and her husband apologized.   ''Uighurs are very particular about not throwing water out on the street,'' said the migrant, Zhou Songying, ''so we don't do that anymore.''   Mrs. Zhou, who speaks Uighur so well that she works as an interpreter for the Kashgar Grain Supply Bureau, said many newcomers to this region corrected their actions ''in time'' after finding out that they offended customs here. But the insensitivity of other members of China's Han majority who have moved to this far western region has contributed to frictions with the area's original inhabitants.

headline: California Magazine Sold
abstract: Alan Bennett and his backers, who are owners of four-year-old Savvy magazine, on Friday signed the papers to acquire California magazine from Mediatex, publishers of Texas Monthly.

headline: SRI LANKA CHARGES ALIENS STIR RIOTING
abstract: A Sri Lankan official charged today that rioting that swept the country this week was the result of a plot to overthrow the Government.   At the same time, the Government banned three Marxist parties in what appeared to be part of a crackdown on groups it suspects of contributing to the violence, which has taken at least 120 lives since last weekend.   The Minister of State for Information, Anandatissa De Alwis, said in a broadcast that plotters were seeking to cause the collapse of the armed forces by spreading division among the minority Hindu Tamils, majority Sinhalese, Moslems and Christians.   Mr. De Alwis said there was a pattern to the violence and asked: ''How can there be a pattern if there was no leadership, preplanning, instruction about what each group was to do?''

headline: Data Bank; July 10, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: EXCERPTS FROM 3 SPEECHES TO GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Following are excerpts from speeches to the General Assembly today by President Francois Mitterrand of France, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. The United Nations translated Mr. Mitterrand's remarks from the French and Mr. Mubarak's from the Arabic. Mitterrand's Remarks    Following a continuous escalation all across the European soil, a new situation has been created whereby the Soviet Union, and it alone, has a sizable intermediate-range nuclear force on our Continent, with triple- warhead missiles which are mobile and accurate and have a range of approximately 5,000 kilometers. Since they cannot cross the Atlantic, their only possible target is the nations of Western Europe.

headline: 112 ABOARD AIRLINER ARE KILLED IN CRASH IN PERSIAN GULF SHEIKDOM
abstract: A Gulf Air jetliner crashed and burned in the mountains of this desert sheikdom today and airline officials said all 112 people aboard were killed. The passengers inluded an American.   The Boeing 737, on its way from Karachi, Pakistan, to Dubai by way of Qatar on the Persian Gulf, lost contact with the Dubai airport 20 minutes before it was to have landed, airport sources said.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONE MARKETING; A.T.&T.; COURTS THE BUYERS
abstract: The court-ordered reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has galvanized the retail phone industry, prompting A.T.& T. to push sales of the telephones it had leased for so long and creating a free-for-all in the race to convert Americans to the joys of phone ownership.   In the last six years, since a Supreme Court ruling opened the floodgates for other manufacturers to sell telephones to the public, some 30 million Americans have bought their own phones. But that pace is now accelerating sharply as A.T.& T. gets more deeply into the game. Next year alone, according to Venture Development, a market research company, sales are expected to reach 24.8 million units, for a retail value of $1.75 billion, up from $1 billion this year.

headline: Argentine Nobel Winner Is Barred by Uruguay
abstract: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel Peace Prize winner, was denied entry to Uruguay by the military Government today, police sources said.

headline: Dome Debt Extension
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., Canada's largest and most indebted energy producer, announced yesterday that it had received an eight-week extension of its July 5 deadline for repayment of $2 billion of its $6.35 billion total debt. Dome came close to bankruptcy last year when it was unable to repay $1.35 billion of principal to four big Canadian banks.

headline: SHULTZ TELLS INDIA THAT U.S. WILL DROP REACTOR-PARTS BAN
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the Indian Government today that the United States would export nuclearreactor components to India if other suppliers could not be found.   Citing concern for the safety of operations at two American-built reactors in Tarapur, north of Bombay, a State Department spokesman said Mr. Shultz had informed Foreign Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao that the Reagan Administration ''is prepared to take the necessary actions to supply those parts which are not available from elsewhere.''   India asked the United States last year to supply spare parts for the Tarapur reactors, which, according to Americans, have developed serious radiation leaks in part because of a lack of spare parts. One of the reactors was shut down in May because of a ruptured seal.

headline: Closings by Toro
abstract: The Toro Company, a leading maker and marketer of lawn care and irrigation equipment, said it planned to close plants in the Minnesota communities of Willmar and Fairmont and transfer those operations to and transfer those operations to plants in Shakopee, Minn., and Tomah, Wis. ''This action is consistent with the company's two-year program to restore Toro to profitability by making the most effective use of its assets,'' said Toro's president, Kendrick B. Melrose.

headline: U.S. Aide Who Invited U.N. To Move Tried to Quit Earlier
abstract: The United States delegate who suggested that the Reagan Administration would not care if the United Nations left the country tried unsuccessfully to resign two weeks earlier, a White House spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, confirmed a report in the Washington Times newspaper that the delegate, Charles M. Lichenstein, wanted to resign in frustration over the United Nations bureaucracy and the United States Mission in New York.

headline: GLOBAL STOCK MARKETS STRONG
abstract: Stock prices on the world's major equity markets continued to climb in the second quarter, bolstered by signs that economic recovery in the United States was gathering momentum.   ''International markets are strongly dependent on there being no significant interruption in the American recovery,'' said Robert Stephens, senior portfolio manager for the Kemper International Fund in Glasgow, Scotland. ''As long as everybody believes that economic progress in the United States is proceeding, then international markets can be allowed to look ahead.''   Analysts at Rowe-Price Fleming International, a Baltimore investment advisory firm, estimate that the closely watched Capital International World Index was 8.2 percent higher on June 30 than on March 31. This index reflects prices on all major exchanges. Its advance during the second quarter was not due solely to the rise of American share prices; the gain abroad was about 8 percent, according to the Rowe-Price analysts.

headline: BEGINS TELLS AIDES HE IS DETERMINED TO QUIT AS PREMIER
abstract: Menachem Begin told his political colleagues today that he had exhausted his ability to function in his position and was determined to retire as Prime Minister and leader of the Herut Party.   He said he would submit his formal letter of resignation to President Chaim Herzog within the next few days, after which the law provides that he remain as Prime Minister until a new government can be formed.   ''I cannot continue,'' Mr. Begin was quoted as telling a meeting of his coalition leaders who had urged him to stay.  Foreign Minister a Favorite    Several hours after his decision, his party's eight Cabinet ministers met to start choosing a successor in an effort to hold together the governing coalition of right-wing and religious factions.

headline: 104 Missing After Boat Sinks Off Indonesia
abstract: An overloaded passenger boat sprang a leak and sank in the Java Sea, and 104 people were reported missing, authorities said today.

headline: Grain Accord Signing Is Set
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union plan to sign a new five-year grain agreement on Aug. 25 in Moscow, American officials said today.

headline: STATEMENT ON RUSSIAN YOUTH
abstract: Following is the text of a State Department statement on Andrei V. Berezhkov issued tonight at Dulles International Airport:    Andrei Berezhkov left this evening for Moscow with his parents.   Andrei's letters to President Reagan and the press raised reasonable doubt as to whether Andrei's travel would be voluntary.

headline: THURSDAY, JULY 14, 1983; International
abstract: Canada is violating world trade rules by imposing too many curbs on foreign investors, a GATT panel ruled. The decision, in response to complaints by the U.S., noted in particular Ottawa's requirement that foreign companies buy Canadian raw materials for their manufacturing. The ruling could permit the U.S. to take reciprocal actions against Canada. (Page A1.)   China and Britain ended two days of talks on Hong Kong. They said merely that more talks will be held in two weeks. (A4.)

headline: U.S. and Soviet Editors Adopt Exchange Plans
abstract: A group of New England and Soviet editors agreed today to an exchange of reporters who would work directly for publications in the other country.   The editors, meeting here, also drafted two other exchanges.

headline: Group Buys Stock In 21st Century
abstract: The 21st Century Distribution Corporation, which owns and distributes full-length motion pictures, announced that an investment group had agreed to buy one million common shares from Tom Ward, president of 21st Century.

headline: POLITICS AND PRAYERS MIX AT CATHEDRAL IN SALVADOR
abstract: The Metropolitan Cathedral of San Salvador has a look of anguish about it.  Steel reinforcement bars twist out of the walls, inside and outside. Thick plastic sheets cover the high, arched windows that in other churches would be radiantly mystical with stained glass.  Vertical neon tubes light the altar. The flowers always seem wilted, the plastic bouquets always dusty.   ''The ugliness of the cathedral is no different than the ugliness of this country,'' said a priest who works in the capital.  The Archdiocese, he said, has not had the money to finish rebuilding the cathedral since it was destroyed by a fire in 1951.  ''Its unfinished structure symbolizes the country's roughness,'' he added. ''But people come to the cathedral because they want to hear the truth about what is happening.''

headline: Belgian Jobless Rate Up
abstract: The Belgian Government said today that the number of jobless in the country rose by 19,824 in July, to almost 511,000, a record 12.3 percent of the workforce. Unemployment was 11.8 percent in June. The sharp rise in July reversed a four-month decline from a February peak of 510,000, or 12.2 percent, the Government said.

headline: SHULTZ REFUSES TO SET A LIMIT ON THE MARINES' STAY
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the mission of the United States marines and other Western forces should continue in Lebanon until there is stability in that country, which he indicated should include the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces.   Given the situation in Lebanon, a senior Administration official acknowledged that this could mean an indefinite commitment to remain because ''nobody knows if the Syrians will ever agree to pull out.'' Concern in Congress    Mr. Shultz's comments, in an interview over the Cable News Network, were expected to cause further concern in Congress. As he did when he testified on Wednesday before two Congressional committees, Mr. Shultz refused to guarantee that the marines now in Lebanon would be pulled out in 18 months or that the size of the contingent or its mission would not be changed.

headline: Manville Motion Filed by GAF
abstract: The GAF Corporation, a co-defendant in thousands of asbestos injury lawsuits filed against the Manville Corporation, said it had filed a motion to dismiss Manville's 13-month-old petition for bankruptcy protection.   Anthony J. Marchetta, a GAF attorney, said the company's motion charges that Manville's petition contradicts ''the entire rationale for the reorganization'' under bankruptcy protection.

headline: WORKERS IN BRAZIL PROTEST AUSTERITY
abstract: The head of the Bank for International Settlements said Brazil would not get an extension for a repayment due Friday. Page D7.   RIO DE JANIERO, July 11 - While a negotiating team from the International Monetary Fund is in Brasilia pressing Government leaders to adhere to a strict economic austerity program, workers around the country have been staging wildcat strikes to say they can stand no more.   Auto workers in Sao Paulo and metalworkers and oil workers in several cities ended a four-day walkout today in favor of a national day of protest on July 21 that is to take the form of a nationwide strike.

headline: TO THE VICTORS BELONG THE SMILES IN WEST BEIRUT
abstract: uf813        News  Analysis    BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1 - The Lebanese Army soldiers who took control of West Beirut from Moslem militiamen in an offensive Wednesday were clearly a happy group today. Throughout this battered, rubble- strewn city, platoons of soldiers, stationed at intersections or in front of buildings, smiled, embraced comrades and exchanged cheers with soldiers passing in Range-Rovers or armored personnel carriers.   The army's performance was a sign that the Government had enhanced its authority in at least the tiny part of the country in the vicinity of Beirut that it genuinely controls. But the disturbances that erupted last Sunday and resulted in a brief occupation of the western half of the city by armed and hooded gunmen also show how fragile and subject to attack that authority remains.

headline: 2 Million Elderly Chinese Replaced in Bureaucracy
abstract: Nearly two million elderly officials have been replaced at the national and provincial levels, with a major purge set for later this year, Peking Review said today.   The latest issue of the authoritative magazine also publicly reported one of China's open secrets - that Deng Xiaoping, China's leader, has a greater voice in major decisions than the head of the Communist Party or the Prime Minister.

headline: Uruguayans Bang Pots To Protest Army Rule
abstract: Uruguayans banged pots in the capital tonight as part of a nationwide protest against the 10-year-old military Government.

headline: ALLEGHANY DEAL'S 'STEPCHILD'
abstract: The day after the American Express Company announced that it had agreed to acquire most of the assets of the Alleghany Corporation it sent 10 executives to Minneapolis to meet with their counterparts at Alleghany's prized subsidiary, Investors Diversified Services.   But it was not until this afternoon, three days after the agreement was made public, that Wallace M. Scott Jr., the chairman at MSL Industries, heard from a single American Express official. MSL, based in Lincolnwood, Ill, a suburb north of Chicago, is Alleghany's struggling steel products division that American Express is also acquiring as part of its agreement with Alleghany.   In the call from American Express, Howard L. Clark Jr., an executive vice president, apologized for not getting in touch with Mr. Scott sooner and welcomed him to the family. American Express had said previously that it intended to keep MSL. But Mr. Clark also offered assurances today that there would be no management changes.

headline: Cyclotron Accord
abstract: The Cyclotron Corporation, operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since February, said it had agreed with the BankAmerica Corporation on interim financing during reorganization.

headline: TODAY, VOLCKER GETS HIS SAY
abstract: The heat is on Paul A. Volcker, the heat of a clammy Washington summer, and of television lights, and of politicians, businessmen, labor leaders and economists - few of whom believe he is doing his job quite right and none of whom professes to know how to do it much better.   There is such heat on Mr. Volcker right now because as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he wields more power over the turbulent domestic economy, and even the world economy, than anybody else.   Together with his six fellow governors of the reserve board and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, he can change the direction of much that matters in the American economy. In so doing, the central bank can influence the outcome of national elections.

headline: U.S. HAD NOTICED ACTIVITY BY SOVIET
abstract: American intelligence agencies were aware of heightened Soviet air-defense activity off the Siberian coast an hour before a Korean airliner was shot down in the area, but did not understand the significance of the Soviet actions until after the airliner had been attacked, senior intelligence officials said today.   The disclosure was the first time the Reagan Administration has revealed that United States intelligence agencies were in any way aware of the events that led to the downing of the Korean airliner while those events were unfolding.   Shielding Sources and Methods    Until now Administration officials, when commenting about the incident, have relied on information and tape recordings of Soviet pilots provided by Japan. The existence of independent American information about the attack had been shielded to protect United States intelligence sources and methods, Administration officials said. They added that the American information completely supported the version of events presented by President Reagan and other senior officials.

headline: SOUTH KOREA'S BANKING SHIFTS
abstract: Banking, it is said, is the art of gauging risk, deciding whether a client has plans or dreams and then approving or denying a loan.    In South Korea this fundamental bankers' art is not highly developed. The reason is that for the last two decades Korean banks have been essentially instruments of Government policy, funneling money into industries marked for rapid expansion.   ''Korean banks were public corporations without incentives to innovate and become more efficient,'' said Kim Mahn-je, president of the KorAm Bank. ''But things have changed. From now on, the banks will have to start acting more like banks.''

headline: Silver Futures Slide In New York Trading
abstract: All New York silver futures plunged the daily permissible limit of 50 cents an ounce yesterday, save the unrestricted spot October contract, which lost 53.5 cents at $11.29. The key December delivery closed at $11.412 on New York's Commodity Exchange.   The heavy selling, which intensified when stop-loss orders were set off, was directly linked to the record stocks of silver reported by the Comex after Wednesday's close - 128,437,423 ounces, up 2 million on the day. On Tuesday, 3.6 million ounces were added to Comex stocks.

headline: U.S. TRADE GAP WIDER
abstract: The United States merchandise trade deficit swelled to a record $7.19 billion in August as the economic expansion encouraged imports and the strong dollar restrained exports, the Commerce Department said today.   The August deficit compared with the previous monthly record of $6.91 billion, set in May, and with July's shortfall of $6.36 billion.

headline: German G.N.P. Rises
abstract: The Deutsche Bundesbank said today that the pace of West Germany's economic recovery doubled in the second quarter from first quarter and returned production to levels last seen in 1981. In its September report, the central bank said that seasonally and price-adjusted gross national product rose 1.5 percent in the second quarter from the preceding quarter, and was up 2 percent from the fourth quarter last year. It cited improved domestic demand, which increased manufacturing growth.

headline: Steel Chiefs' Merger Views
abstract: David Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, has told a Congressional committee that antitrust laws should be revised to encourage mergers and more efficient operations in the steel industry.   In testimony Friday, Mr. Roderick told the Senate Judiciary Committee that the nation's steel industry faces a crisis because of increased foreign competition and a need to rationalize its operations by shutting inefficient plants and modernizing others.

headline: BRITISH GROUP BUYS GRALLA PUBLICATIONS
abstract: United Newspapers of London said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Gralla Publications Inc. for $44 million.   Gralla, based in New York, publishes 15 national business and trade magazines.

headline: Offer of Shares In Enserch Corp.
abstract: An offering of four million shares of the Enserch Corporation is under way at $23.25 each through securities dealers led by Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*   9.62

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Texas-New Mexico Power Co.  filed an offering of $15 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds and 300,000 common shares, through Shearson/ American Express Inc.      Debt Ratings     *  Black Hills Power and Light Co.'s pollution control and industrial development revenue bonds were raised to A3 from Baa2 by Moody's Investors Service    *  Orbanco Financial Services Corp.'s commercial paper rating was lowered to B from A3 by Standard & Poor's, which also lowered the commercial paper ratings of the company's subsidiary, Northwest Acceptance Corp., to A3 from A2.      Common Stock     *  Aberford Resources Ltd.  said it had completed an initial public offering of 3.5 million shares and 1,750,000 warrants for an aggregate of $44.6 million.     *  Argonaut Energy Corp.  announced the closing of its exchange offer of common stock for various oil and gas interests in 28 properties owned by the company. The company received tender forms representing a 51 percent acceptance.

headline: Steel Output Declines
abstract: Last week's steel output was 1.58 million tons, down seven-tenths of 1 percent from 1.59 million tons the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: SALVADORANS DOUBT ELECTION CAN BE HELD BY END OF YEAR
abstract: El Salvador's political leaders are expressing increasing skepticism about the possibility of holding a presidential election by the end of this year, as the Reagan Administration has urged.   While the party leaders said they would like to hold elections ''as soon as possible,'' they added that the country's two million voters could not be registered by December.   In addition, the country has yet to approve a new constitution.  The Constituent Assembly will set an election date as part of a transition law that will be approved when the constitution is.

headline: TALES OF THE ECONOMIC RECOVERY
abstract: CHICAGO    THE economy's dramatic   recovery has been well   documented in the figures that have been pouring out of Washington since the beginning of the year. But the surge described by the statistics is just becoming apparent in the lives of many in the Middle West, the nation's economic heartland.   From the mountains of Western Pennsylvania to the prairies of the Great Plains, local communities are shaking off the legacy of three years of recession, or trying to. Some of the damage appears to be permanent.   ''Everything is not rosy by any means, but we're having a strong economic recovery in the region,'' says Nina Klarich, a First National Bank of Chicago economist. ''The numbers are finally starting to show up.''

headline: Politician Denied AccessTo Jailed I.R.A. Members
abstract: The British Government today barred an Ulster politician from visiting jailed members of the Irish Republican Army.   The decision came after reports that Gerry Adams, vice president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the outlawed I.R.A. Provisionals, would press for repatriation of Irish prisoners in English jails. Mr. Adams also said he would visit some of the prisoners - which he said was his right as a newly elected Member of Parliament from Northern Ireland, although he has refused to take the oath and his seat in Westminster.   But the Home Secretary, Leon Brittan, barred Mr. Adams from seeing Irish prisoners in England and Wales, saying Mr. Adams ''is a member of an organization which openly espouses the use of violence for political ends.''

headline: Wang Stock Deal
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it had sold 530,800 shares it owned of Tymshare Inc. stock and said it had canceled its previously announced plans to acquire more than $15 million worth of the stock. The shares sold, which represented about 4.3 percent of Tymshare stock, were worth about $10 million, Wang said. Analysts had suspected that Wang was interested in taking over Tymshare.

headline: Caesars World Loss
abstract: Narrows Caesars World Inc., citing a $10 million loss from a recent share exchange offer, yesterday reported a deficit of $8.4 million in the fourth quarter ended July 31, Nonetheless, the loss was narrower than its $14.1 million loss in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.   Revenues edged up 1.7 percent, to $151.2 million, from $148.7 million.

headline: Brouillard Is Chosen By Texas American
abstract: Texas American Bankshares, a Fort Worth-based bank holding company with 26 banks throughout the state, has retained Brouillard Communications as its ad agency.

headline: Irish Help Speed Plans For Hill, Holliday Office
abstract: The winning of the Irish Tourist Board account by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Coseopulos of Boston has speeded up the agency's planning for a New York office that was already in the works to service Wang Laboratories, the computer company.   The Irish business, which includes advertising in Canada, should have a budget of almost $2 million, according to Donal MacSullivan, vice president for North America of the Tourist Board.

headline: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Campaign Seeks Lift For Coffee
abstract: JANE CURTIN, the comedian;   Ken Anderson, the Cincinnati   Bengals quarterback; Joe Jackson, the singer; Allison Roe, the marathon runner; Cicely Tyson, the actress; Kurt Vonnegut, the author, and Ann Wilson and Nancy Wilson of the rock group Heart did not get to be top people in their fields by talent alone. They had to put in the hours.   Nobody gets through long, draining days without some kind of pick-me- up. What did it for these stars?

headline: SOVIET SEEMS UNWILLING TO BAR FUTURE DOWNING
abstract: The Soviet Union gave a strong indication today that that it would resist Western moves to obtain guarantees that civilian airliners intruding into its airspace would not in the future be shot down.   At the same time, the Kremlin announced a highly unusual appearance at a news conference here Friday of Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the general staff of the Soviet armed forces. There was speculation that the session may be devoted to the shooting down of a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 eight days ago.   The news conference will mark one of the very few occasions in recent years that a member of the Soviet military hierarchy has faced the Western press. It was believed to be the first time the 65-year-old Marshal Ogarkov had ever agreed to take part in such a session. Indications that there will be no Soviet guarantees against future attacks on straying airliners came in a series of commentaries in the official press that sought to reaffirm Moscow's legal basis for shooting down the jet and mocked Western demands for a new international code to prevent any recurrence.

headline: New Visa Cards
abstract: In an attempt to control counterfeiting losses that amounted to nearly $11 million last year, Visa International will redesign its cards, putting into effect several new security measures, the company said. The new design will include a border of microprinted bank identification codes, an embossed security symbol and a trademark of a dove in flight that can only be seen under an ultraviolet light. The new design will also include a hologram or lenticular print of the dove in a security panel that will cover the last several digits of the account number.  D.W. Hock, president of Visa International, said that would help prevent unauthorized changes in the account numbers.

headline: SHULTZ SUPPORTING COMPROMISE TERMS AT EAST-WEST TALK
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has decided to recommend to President Reagan that the United States agree to a compromise document on East-West human rights and security issues, Administration officials said today.   The Soviet Union has agreed informally to a compromise that would involve a meeting, as a follow-up to the East-West talks in Madrid, to deal with problems of Soviet-bloc emigration.   The officials also said that Mr. Shultz was ready to go to Madrid to sign a concluding document, along with representatives of Canada, 32 European states and the Vatican. While in Madrid, he would meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

headline: Penn Square Suit
abstract: More than 160 investors in 19 states have filed a Federal lawsuit contending that they were bilked out of more than $14.5 million in a conspiracy involving the defunct Penn Square Bank and others. The investors say the bank's holding company and directors, the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand and eight oil and gas drilling ventures headed by Carl W. Swan, a former Penn Square director, were part of the conspiracy.

headline: NCNB, Ellis In Merger Pact
abstract: The Ellis Banking Corporation, one of the few remaining large family-controlled banks in Florida, said it had agreed to merge with the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. NCNB said it would exchange 4 million of its shares for 4.1 million shares of Ellis stock owned by A.L. Ellis, the bank's 77-year-old chairman, and members of his family. Based on NCNB's current price of $26.50 a share, Mr. Ellis will receive stock worth an indicated $106 million.

headline: U.S. IS CONSIDERING STEPS FOR SHULTZ TO MEET GROMYKO
abstract: The Reagan Administration has recalled its chief negotiator at the East-West conference in Madrid to discuss a compromise that might lead to an early meeting of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, State Department officials said today.   Talks are scheduled here Monday between the negotiator, Max M.  Kampelman, and senior officials, including Mr. Shultz.  Officials said the discussions could decide whether the United States would go along with a compromise effort to conclude the Madrid meeting of 35 delegations, including the United States, Canada and the Vatican. The effort is being led by the neutral nations of Europe.

headline: HIGH COURT LIMITS TEXAS BANK TAX
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 6 to 2, that states may not levy a tax on a bank's assets without deducting the value of Federal notes and bonds that the bank holds.   Overturning a decision by a Texas court, the Court ruled that a Texas property tax on bank shares violated a Federal law by including a bank's holdings of Federal obligations in calculating the value of the shares. The 1959 Federal law exempts Federal notes, bonds, and other obligations from being taxed ''directly or indirectly'' by states or municipalities.

headline: Broad Shifts Made At Hanover Bank
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced a series of senior management changes yesterday, including the naming of two new vice chairmen.   The vice chairmen are John J. Evans, 54 years old, and Edward A. Farley, 59. Both had been executive vice presidents, Mr. Evans in charge of operations and Mr. Farley of metropolitan corporate banking.

headline: POLISH PARLIAMENT BROADENS REGIME'S POWERS
abstract: The Polish Parliament granted broad new powers to the Government today and acted to extend many martial law curbs for 18 months.   The actions were aimed at insuring Government controls after the expected formal lifting of military rule Friday, Poland's national day.   The new powers would allow the Government to impose a state of emergency, re-imprison dissidents or keep them and key leaders of the outlawed independent union Solidarity interned.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alabama Automated Clearing House Association, Birmingham, has elected A. W. Redmon president.     * AM International, Chicago, has appointed Marion G. Durk vice president-corporate relations.     * Biotechnica International Inc., Boston, has elected Winthrop Knowlton and Mark J. Millard to its board.

headline: MUSICAL CHAIRS
abstract: The technological developments that can make great waves in the market for robots are not the sort of breakthroughs that would interest the Nobel jurors for scientific achievement. But they are of compelling importance to Japanese industry.

headline: NICARAGUAN EXILES RESUMING FIGHTING
abstract: The forces of Eden Pastora Gomez, bolstered by newly acquired aid from within Latin America, are resuming their fight against his former Sandinista comrades in Nicaragua, according to leaders of Nicaraguan exile groups here.   ''We are planning a few surprises for the celebration next week,'' Alfonso Robelo Callejas, an exiled former member of the ruling Sandinista junta, said in a interview here Wednesday. Mr. Robelo, who is now allied with Mr. Pastora's Costa Rican-based armed opposition, was referring to the commemoration July 19 of the fourth anniversary of the overthrow of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle.   Mr. Robelo said Mr. Pastora never intended to give up the battle when he said last month that he was temporarily withdrawing from the field. He said Mr. Pastora only meant to postpone the fighting until aid could be found after a rush of unequipped volunteers bankrupted the force.   That aid, Mr. Robelo added, is now coming from sources in Latin America that he did not name.  ''We were not abandoning the fighting,'' he said. ''We never wanted to give that image. We were broke.'' At Mr. Pastora's headquarters here, a spokesman for the guerrilla force confirmed that the fighting had resumed in Nicaragua after a short pause.

headline: IN OKLAHOMA, A BANKER IS READY FOR EXPANSION
abstract: In anticipation of a change in Oklahoma law that will allow limited bank expansion, Dale Mitchell, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company in Oklahoma City, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Fidelity of Oklahoma Inc., a one-bank holding company.   He replaces Wilfred A. Clarke, who continues as president of the holding company.

headline: ROYAL CROWN GETS SEARLE'S ASPARTAME
abstract: G. D. Searle & Company said yesterday that it had reached agreement with the Royal Crown Companies to use the pharmaceutical company's low-calorie sweetener, aspartame, in Royal Crown's carbonated soft drinks.   The terms were not disclosed, but a spokesman for Royal Crown indicated that aspartame would be used in combination with saccharin, another low-calorie sweetener, in products very soon.

headline: VOLUME OFF
abstract: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday on news that inflation increased in July. Trading was slower.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, ended with a loss of 10.26 points, at 1,192.89. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that rose by more than 2 to 1.

headline: 'A TERRIBLE LOSS': LOVED ONES RECALL THE PASSENGERS ON KOREAN PLANE
abstract: Some were traveling in sorrow, to attend the funerals of loved ones. Others were bound for the Far East on missions of mercy, to sit at the bedsides of ailing relatives. Some were on business or vacation trips. One was returning to his Korean homeland to find a bride.    Mothers, fathers, children, people in trades and professions - these were among the 37 residents of New York's metropolitan area and upstate New York who died when a South Korean airliner carrying 269 people from New York to Seoul was reportedly struck by a Soviet missile and plunged into the Sea of Japan in the predawn darkness Thursday.

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT SHOWS STRONG RISE OF 1.8% FOR JULY
abstract: Industrial production jumped 1.8 percent in July, the Federal Reserve reported today. The increase was led by a sharp rise in auto output and demand for electricity for air conditioning.   The increase suggests that the recovery in the third quarter this year could be almost as strong as in the second quarter, when the gross national product soared at an annual rate of 8.7 percent after adjustment for inflation.   Most economists do not expect this rapid expansion of the economy to continue; indeed they would be concerned if it did. With sustained growth at the pace of the second quarter, the economy would likely begin to overheat, putting upward pressure on prices and reigniting inflation sometime in 1984.

headline: OSBORNE LAYS OFF BULK OF EMPLOYEES
abstract: The Osborne Computer Corporation, once one of the hottest stars in the personal computer field, laid off nearly all of its nonmanagement workers and some executives today.   Workers at the company's Hayward headquarters were called into meetings with managers and told that ''everyone was being laid off except for a few kept on to clean up,'' said Craig Moore an assembler for the past year.

headline: A MILLION FILIPINOS LINE THE AQUINO FUNERAL ROUTE
abstract: Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, was buried tonight after a 10-and- a-half-hour funeral procession that passed through crowds that the police said totaled a million people.    Despite the press of the mourners, there was no violence as the cortege made its way along a 19-mile route to a cemetery on the southern outskirts of Manila. But in the capital itself, several hundred youths, hurling rocks and crude bombs, rushed to within 500 yards of the presidential palace shortly after nightfall. They were repulsed by the police and Government troops, who turned water cannons on them, charged with riot sticks and fired what appeared to be warning shots.    (A 23-year-old student was fatally shot   and 18 people were wounded in the street fighting, police spokesmen reported, according to The Associated Press. At least eight of the wounded were said to be between 14 and 20 years old.)

headline: U.S. Says China Trade Dipped Sharply in May
abstract: Trade between the United States and China dipped to $238 million in May, the lowest monthly level since October 1979, the United States Embassy said today.   An embassy news release said United States exports totaled only $75.2 million for the month, the lowest level since August 1978.

headline: WHICH WAY INTEREST RATES?
abstract: Last August, the decline in interest rates helped ignite the stock market's most explosive rally ever. Nearly a year later, however, the pressure on those rates is upward and the market has turned jittery.   In recent days, long-term rates have hit their highest levels since last autumn, propelled in part by the nation's economic recovery and in part by the huge Federal budget deficit.   The dollar, meanwhile, has been pushed to new highs against many foreign currencies by investors anxious to take advantage of high interest yields in the United States.   All this activity is making interest rates and their direction one of the hottest topics in the financial community. The New York Times interviewed 10 of the nation's leading economists for their views.  Milton Friedman    Economist    Interest rates will rise as an inevitable consequence of the monetary explosion we've experienced over the past year.  So far as the economy is concerned, rising rates will in the short run have no impact, because the recovery will continue vigorously through 1983. But it will threaten the continuation of the recovery in 1984. There is nothing that can reverse that trend at the moment; it's all in the pipeline. And there's nothing good that can be done, only a choice among bad things.

headline: Sperry Venture
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board is allowing the Citicorp bank and the Sperry Corporation to operate a joint venture to finance farm equipment.

headline: Interest Rates Rise Modestly; New Issues Are Awaited
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday for short- and long-term issues, amid continued nervousness about investor demand for a heavy supply of Treasury issues expected for sale next week.   For more actively traded Treasury issues, prices fell about oneeighth point for those due in four years and less, while 10-year notes were down more than a quarter point, and long-term bonds were down about three-fourths of a point.   ''Most investors decided to stay on the sidelines and wait for the financing announcement,'' analysts at Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc. said in a commentary they publish daily.   While the Merrill Lynch analysts forecast a financing package of $6.75 billion of three-year notes, $5 billion of 10-year notes and $3.75 billion of 30-year bonds, other analysts said that the amount of any specific issue could vary by $250 million, up or down, from those estimates.
