headline: ANTILLES FIGHTS U.S. ASSERTIONS
abstract: Officials of the Netherlands Antilles have formally challenged charges that the islands are used to evade American taxes and that the Dutch colony does not cooperate fully with law enforcement officials in the United States.   The counterattack has led to a lively debate on the issue between a Congressional committee, the Netherlands Antilles and top officials of the Internal Revenue Service.   The debate has a direct bearing on deadlocked negotiations between the United States and the Netherlands Antilles on proposed changes in a tax treaty between the two. Changes in the 20-year-old treaty would affect not only the Antilles, but also more than 200 large American corporations that have raised tens of billions of dollars abroad by issuing Eurobonds through finance subsidiaries located in the Antilles.

headline: Ohio-Sealy to Add Stearns & Foster
abstract: The Ohio-Sealy Mattress Manufacturing Company announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Stearns & Foster Company, a Cincinnati-based bed manufacturer, in a stock and cash transaction valued at about $46 million.   Ohio-Sealy said Stearns & Foster shareholders would have the option of receiving $23.75 a share in Ohio-Sealy stock, or cash, or any combination up to a limit of $20.7 million in cash, but added that the transaction was still subject to a definitive agreement and approval by shareholders by both companies.   Stearns & Foster, which had sales of $95 million in the 1982 fiscal year, will continue to market products under its current name, and will also maintain its present facilities, work force and manner of operations after the acquisition, Ohio-Sealy said.

headline: Indonesian Volcano Erupts
abstract: Mount Calo, a 984-foot volcano on Una-Una, 1,625 miles northeast of here, erupted for the third straight day today. There were no reports of casualties. About 1,600 people on the beach waiting for ships to take them to Central Celebes, newspaper reports said.

headline: LIBERIAN ATTACKS LIBYAN AMBITION
abstract: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia said today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was sending bribes, terrorists and ammunition throughout Africa in an effort to overthrow governments and take over the continent.    ''Qaddafi is a man who, I think, would like to lead the whole continent of Africa, which is impossible to do,'' President Doe said in an interview. ''But he uses his marginal resources in terms of arms and ammunition, spreading explosives all over the continent.

headline: Home Resales Down 2.9%
abstract: Resales of single-family homes fell 2.9 percent in August because of a summer rise in mortgage rates, the National Association of Realtors said today.   It was the second consecutive monthly decline, but the drop in August was narrower than the 5.1 percent decline in July.

headline: MONDAY, JULY 18, 1983; Companies
abstract: Quaker Oats offered $77 a share for all of Stokely-Van Camp shares. The $208 million offer has been approved by directors of both food companies. Pillsbury had offered $62 for most of Stokely's shares, but Stokely rejected the offer. (Page D1.)

headline: Sri Lanka Confirms Report of Army Slayings
abstract: Sri Lankan Army troops pulled 20 civilians off a bus and executed them two weeks ago in retaliation for a Tamil guerrilla attack that killed 13 soldiers, a Government spokesman confirmed today.   The shootings were followed by two weeks of nationwide violence between the minority Tamils and the Sinhalese.

headline: Short-Term Rates Are Steady
abstract: Confusion over the near-term direction of interest rates sharply reduced activity in the credit market yesterday.  Dealers said that short-term Treasury discount rates were basically unchanged, while prices of long-term Treasury coupon issues closed moderately lower with attendant rises in yields after a late flurry of selling. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds closed off as much as a quarter point in in equally dull trading.   The confusion was heightened by warnings of further rises in short-term rates that were made yesterday by Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, before the Senate Banking Committee.

headline: Trading Active In Tymshare
abstract: Active trading in Tymshare Inc. was attributed by analysts and traders to reports that the company was an imminent takeover target.

headline: Article 147915 -- No Title
abstract: The World Wildlife Fund said today that it had donated $200,000 more to China's effort to save the endangered giant panda. A joint panda preservation project started in 1980 has received $2 million from China and a total of $1 million from the fund, which says that only about a thousand pandas remain in the wild in China.

headline: $100 Million Issue
abstract: A $100 dillion issue of the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation's floating rate, extendable notes due in 1998 were offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial interest rate for the issue will be announced Sept. 7 and will be adjusted weekly at three-fourths of a percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield at weekly sales of 91- day Treasury bills.

headline: Southern Hospitality Filing
abstract: The Southern Hospitality Corporation, Nashville, said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 2.2 million shares of common stock, including 1,114,675 to be offered by shareholders.   The company's part of the proceeds will be used to reduce bank debt, to help finance the construction of new restaurants, to acquire restaurants and for general corporate purposes.   The offering is to be underwritten by a syndicate managed by A.G.  Edwards & Son Inc. and Morgan Keegan & Company.

headline: Business Net Off in Japan
abstract: Recurrent profits of all Japanese corporations fell 6.1 percent, to 16,132 billion yen in the fiscal year 1982, which ended March 31, after a 12.8 percent decline in the fiscal year 1981 from 1980, according to the Finance Ministry.   The declines reflected the recession in Japan and abroad, it said.

headline: Japan-U.S.  Talks on Oil
abstract: Japan and the United States held discussions today on the possibility of shipping Alaskan oil across the Pacific to Asia, diplomatic sources said.   The talks were the latest in a series on energy cooperation between the countries following the visit to Washington earlier this year of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

headline: Clash in Chad Breaks Lull in Civil War
abstract: Chadian forces clashed with anti-Government rebels at the northeastern outpost of Fada today to break a weeklong lull in the civil war, Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia said.   But he told reporters that the engagement was ''not very violent'' and gave no indication of the outcome.

headline: THURSDAY, SEPT. 8, 1983
abstract: Companies   A group led by Lockheed and including Grumman won a contract to provide launching and landing services for future flights of the space shuttle. The award, perhaps worth billions, was a major upset for a group led by Rockwell International, which built the shuttle and until now has been its chief provider of services. NASA did not explain its choice. (Page D1.)    Turkey plans to buy the F-16 jet fighter from General Dynamics, a victory for the St. Louis military contractor. It is the first time the F-16 has beaten out the F-18 of Northrup and McDonnell Douglas in international competition. Turkey said it will buy some 160 of the F-16's for about $4 billion. (D1.) Boeing won a $640 million order for jetliners from Qantas Airways. (D4.)

headline: COALITION TALKS BACKED IN ISRAEL
abstract: The opposition Labor Party authorized its leader, Shimon Peres, today to explore the possibility of sharing power with the Likud bloc in a Government of national unity under Prime Minister-designate Yitzhak Shamir.   The decision was taken by the party's parliamentary caucus here.

headline: U.N. ROLE IN BIERUT REJECTED BY SYRIA
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has informed the United Nations that he opposes the use of United Nations observers to police the cease-fire in Lebanon, Western diplomats and United Nations officials said today.   They said Mr. Assad's strong refusal raises questions about Syrian intentions.   ''You have to assume the worst, given the history of cease-fires in Lebanon,'' a United Nations official said, ''and I have to assume in this case that Assad is looking to cause trouble. He probably looks upon the cease-fire as a pause in trying to overthrow Gemayel.''

headline: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Chrysler's New Fall Campaign
abstract: Come mid-September, we'll be seeing some of the first visible results of the huge restructuring of the Chrysler Corporation's marketing operations. That's when the first of some $200 million worth of advertising begins to appear.   And by that time the public - the TV-viewing public at least - will have been prepared for its coming by the reappearance on Sept. 9 of the mighty Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and corporate savior. He'll be back on the tube after an absence of about six months and with four new auto products as a backdrop. He'll note the repayment of Chrysler's Government-backed loans and comment on Chrysler's leadership in technology.

headline: BUSINESS TRAVELERS' HOTELS THRIVING AT WHITE PLAINS
abstract: A prediction that 2,500 hotel rooms would be needed in the next few years to accommodate visitors would seem overly optimistic for most suburban cities. But White Plains, which has evolved in the last decade from a somewhat seedy county seat into a major office and retail center, figures it may need that many rooms.   Through an aggressive urban renewal program, the city's residential communities were stabilized and its downtown was largely rebuilt. The success of that program, through which $100 million of public money has been spent, has been a magnet for commercial investment. Major corporations such as General Foods, I.B.M. and New York Telephone are situated in White Plains, and a dozen others are in the vicinity.

headline: THE U.N. AND THE CITY: OBLIGATION, OPPORTUNITY AND IRRITATION
abstract: With mutual suspicion, misunderstandings and occasional hostility, the United Nations and its host, New York City, have pursued an elusive goal of peaceful coexistence for 37 years. By all accounts, the results have been a mix of love, hate, tolerance and indifference.   As perceived by many New Yorkers, diplomatic immunity has meant a kind of license for United Nations personnel to park illegally, ignore bills and legal summonses, scoff at lawsuits, walk away from criminal charges and behave with haughty insensitivity.   As perceived by many United Nations diplomats, the cosmopolitan city has been surprisingly xenophobic, a place of noise, dirt, discourtesy, crime, outrageous prices and discrimination ranging from landlords who refuse rentals to racial slurs and bumper stickers proclaiming: ''Get the U.N. out of the U.S.''   But the city and its international diplomatic community have also brought each other mutual benefits whose loss, if the United Nations were to leave New York, would have a ''devastating impact,'' in the opinion of Gillian Martin Sorensen, who heads the New York City Commission for the United Nations.

headline: MONDAY, JULY 18, 1983; Companies
abstract: Quaker Oats offered $77 a share for all of Stokely-Van Camp shares. The $208 million offer has been approved by directors of both food companies. Pillsbury had offered $62 for most of Stokely's shares, but Stokely rejected the offer. (Page D1.)

headline: Sri Lanka Confirms Report of Army Slayings
abstract: Sri Lankan Army troops pulled 20 civilians off a bus and executed them two weeks ago in retaliation for a Tamil guerrilla attack that killed 13 soldiers, a Government spokesman confirmed today.   The shootings were followed by two weeks of nationwide violence between the minority Tamils and the Sinhalese.

headline: Short-Term Rates Are Steady
abstract: Confusion over the near-term direction of interest rates sharply reduced activity in the credit market yesterday.  Dealers said that short-term Treasury discount rates were basically unchanged, while prices of long-term Treasury coupon issues closed moderately lower with attendant rises in yields after a late flurry of selling. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds closed off as much as a quarter point in in equally dull trading.   The confusion was heightened by warnings of further rises in short-term rates that were made yesterday by Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, before the Senate Banking Committee.

headline: ;  Generating Bosses
abstract: To the Business Editor:   I cannot believe the situation is as simple as John Schreiner contends (''First Come the Bosses - Then the Jobs,'' Sept. 11). He asserts that there aren't enough jobs because there aren't enough entrepeneurs, and there aren't enough bosses because the tax system discourages them.

headline: Trading Active In Tymshare
abstract: Active trading in Tymshare Inc. was attributed by analysts and traders to reports that the company was an imminent takeover target.

headline: China Trade Rules Near
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that a new policy on China trade was nearly complete and could sharply increase technology exports to China.   Mr. Baldrige said that Government committees had nearly completed the so-called technological transfer guidelines and that the details would be made available after obtaining clearance from United States allies.

headline: Article 147915 -- No Title
abstract: The World Wildlife Fund said today that it had donated $200,000 more to China's effort to save the endangered giant panda. A joint panda preservation project started in 1980 has received $2 million from China and a total of $1 million from the fund, which says that only about a thousand pandas remain in the wild in China.

headline: South Africa Austerity
abstract: South Africa will introduce anti-inflation measures to back up its fiscal and monetary policy, Prime Minister P. W. Botha said today. He said said South Africa's inflation rate, running at 12 percent in July, higher than in major industralized nations, had to be brought closer to that of the country's trading partners if its manufacturing industry was to become more competitive.

headline: $100 Million Issue
abstract: A $100 dillion issue of the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation's floating rate, extendable notes due in 1998 were offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial interest rate for the issue will be announced Sept. 7 and will be adjusted weekly at three-fourths of a percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield at weekly sales of 91- day Treasury bills.

headline: Southern Hospitality Filing
abstract: The Southern Hospitality Corporation, Nashville, said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 2.2 million shares of common stock, including 1,114,675 to be offered by shareholders.   The company's part of the proceeds will be used to reduce bank debt, to help finance the construction of new restaurants, to acquire restaurants and for general corporate purposes.   The offering is to be underwritten by a syndicate managed by A.G.  Edwards & Son Inc. and Morgan Keegan & Company.

headline: General Cinema Forms Office of the Chairman
abstract: The General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest movie theater operator and a leading independent soft drink bottler, has established an office of the chairman, consisting of four senior executives.   Richard A. Smith, 57, continues to hold the office of chairman, president and chief executive. He said the decision to adopt a four-man office of the chairman had been made ''simply because we have grown to the point where the company's complexity is more than any one person can do justice.''

headline: Business Net Off in Japan
abstract: Recurrent profits of all Japanese corporations fell 6.1 percent, to 16,132 billion yen in the fiscal year 1982, which ended March 31, after a 12.8 percent decline in the fiscal year 1981 from 1980, according to the Finance Ministry.   The declines reflected the recession in Japan and abroad, it said.

headline: Japan-U.S.  Talks on Oil
abstract: Japan and the United States held discussions today on the possibility of shipping Alaskan oil across the Pacific to Asia, diplomatic sources said.   The talks were the latest in a series on energy cooperation between the countries following the visit to Washington earlier this year of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

headline: Clash in Chad Breaks Lull in Civil War
abstract: Chadian forces clashed with anti-Government rebels at the northeastern outpost of Fada today to break a weeklong lull in the civil war, Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia said.   But he told reporters that the engagement was ''not very violent'' and gave no indication of the outcome.

headline: AdvertisingPamela G. Hollie Renault's Encore Campaign
abstract: RENAULT, better known in France as Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, celebrated its minority ownership of the faltering American Motors Corporation last fall with the introduction of an American-made sedan called Alliance.   Renault's own alliance with America's fourth-largest car maker has been successful enough to encourage the company to try again, with a new car to be introduced next month - called, of course, Encore.   The sporty, European-style hatch- back will be accompanied by an all- out campaign designed by Grey Advertising Inc. and using the ''Star Wars'' touch of George Lucas. In three months of work in Mr. Lucas's California studios, Grey and R/ Greenberg Associates Inc., a New York production company, devised ways to bend, stretch and shrink an Encore to illustrate graphically in television commercials how the car handles around corners and over bumps and how little gas it uses.

headline: Monsanto Sees Silicon Demand
abstract: The Monsanto Company's Monsanto Electronic Materials unit said that a temporary shortage of silicon for microprocessors and computer memories may develop later this year because of an extremely sharp rise in demand.   George F. Moore, manager of marketing intelligence for Monsanto Electronics, said that in April and May shipments of semiconductor devices were up 10 percent from the first quarter, indicating strong third- and fourth-quarter production of electronic equipment.

headline: Marcos Repeals Decrees On Imprisoning Rebels
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos issued two decrees today repealing earlier orders under which many people suspected of being rebels have been imprisoned.   A third decree, also issued today, reaffirmed the President's power to imprison suspects in subversion cases and deny them access to the courts.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: The economic recovery in the United States is finally spreading to other countries and may help the world break out of its long period of economic stagnation. But officials, worried about interest rates, trade deficits and international debt problems, still face a summer of anxiety.   The recent conclusion of a series of international meetings - from the Williamsburg, Va., economic summit conference to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Belgrade, Yugoslavia - showed how much the world depends on what happens in the United States, the world's biggest market and producer of goods and services.   In the elegant banquet rooms of colonial Virginia and in the brand new Belgrade conference halls a few blocks from the Danube, delegates spoke about trends in the United States that influence interest rates, consumption, employment, trade policy, debt repayment and other critical factors in the rest of the world.

headline: Prudential-Bache To Buy Gelfand
abstract: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Gelfand, Quinn & Associates Inc., an investment advisory firm in Cleveland.

headline: DOZENS OF KEY BURMA OFFICIALS REPORTED PURGED
abstract: Ne Win, the former general who has ruled Burma almost single-handedly since seizing power in 1962, has reportedly dismissed dozens of senior officials in the last two months.   The reasons for the shake-up are not clear, although there have been rumors about corruption, gold-smuggling or a sudden reassertion of power by the regular army. Most informants say they doubt that Mr. Ne Win, the 72-year-old chairman of the ruling Burma Socialist Program Party, has ever been on the verge of losing control.   Western diplomats, who are among the few people here willing to discuss politics with foreign visitors, say the Government has been hard hit by the ouster of as many as 30 leading figures from the Cabinet, the intelligence services, the army and the diplomatic corps. Some diplomats here say they think the purge has not ended.

headline: No Martial Law, Marcos Says
abstract: While President Marcos threatened obliquely in addressing his people today to reimpose martial law, he said in a subsequent interview for American audiences that he was ''not thinking of that now.''   ''What I'm thinking of,'' he said by satellite to CBS News, ''is the radicals have attempted to exploit and manipulate the peaceful rallies here in Manila. There are no rallies, demonstrations or any incidents anywhere else.''

headline: House Passes Insider Curb
abstract: The House voted today to increase the Securities and Exchange Commission's powers over unscrupulous people using inside information for personal gain in financial markets.   ''Present sanctions available to the commission do not present an adequate deterrent when considering the enormous profits,'' said Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio.

headline: PEKING DEPLOYS A MISSILE-FIRING NUCLEAR SUB
abstract: China has developed a nuclear-powered submarine, the Xia, that can fire 16 nuclear missiles at targets 1,800 miles away while submerged, according to the latest edition of Jane's Fighting Ships.    The yearbook's editor, John Moore, said in the 1983-84 edition that at least one, possibly two, of the submarines are operational. They are believed to be the first of five that will join the Chinese Navy.

headline: Chrysler-VW Deal On Plant Is Set
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation disclosed in its 1983 second-quarter balance sheet that it had completed an agreement to purchase Volkswagen of America Inc.'s idle Michigan car plant for $192 million in cash.   The Chrysler statement said the deal also includes additional interest payments pegged at a 10 percent annual rate through March 31, 1995.   Earlier this year, Chrysler said it had agreed to buy the idle Sterling Heights plant from Volkswagen with an undisclosed amount of cash payments during a 12-year term.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A table last Sunday accompanying an article on the long-distance telephone industry mislabeled the columns for the number of cities and customers served.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: People
abstract: * Jerry Firestone named advertising director of Psychology Today magazine.     * J. Samuel Huey appointed publisher of Boating magazine.

headline: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Home Equity Line of Credit
abstract: THE most valuable asset of most American   families is their home. But this asset, which   can easily represent tens of thousands of dollars in stored value, has traditionally been a highly illiquid one that could be tapped only through sale or a costly second mortgage.   Some brokerage firms and banks, however, have recently developed what are generally referred to as home equity loans - a form of credit that allows individuals to use their homes quickly and simply as collateral when borrowing. While these variable-rate loans may be packaged as a revolving line of credit or in another legal format, they are secured by the borrower's home - and are thus similar to a second mortgage.

headline: British-U.S.  Trade Talks
abstract: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, flew to Washington today on a three-day trip in a bid to roll back United States trade restrictions on European steel and other products.   One of Sir Geoffrey's expected targets is the order issued by President Reagan last week imposing tariffs and import quotas on specialized steel to cushion American suppliers from foreign competition, which was denounced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

headline: Scali and Gianettino Attract Accounts
abstract: And now in the frenetic world of account movement, yesterday's action concerned Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Gianettino & Meredith.  The Heublein Spirits and Wine Company, now part of R.J. Reynolds Industries, has assigned Harvey's of Bristol, which is mostly Harvey's Bristol Cream Sherry, to Scali, an Ogilvy & Mather subsidiary.

headline: HEALTH INSURANCE AND THE OLDER WORKER
abstract: In the last few weeks, workers between the ages of 65 and 69 have been receiving a blizzard of paperwork from their employers notifying them of a major change in the way health insurance reimbursement programs will operate. The notices stem from legislation intended to cut the Government's Medicare bill. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, in amendments to the Age Discrimination in Employment Act and the Social Security Act, stipulates that Medicare will no longer be the insurer of first resort for older employees. Instead, private insurance plans of employers will pick up medical bills first and then Medicare will pay whatever remaining expenses qualify for coverage. The change, which is retroactive to Jan. 1, is expected to save the Government $1.48 billion through fiscal year 1985 by transferring the primary insurance bill to the private sector. Overall benefits for older employees who continue all of their existing coverage ''generally will not be reduced,'' said Herbert M. Pollock, an official at the Health Care Financing Administration, which administers Medicare. But older workers are now faced with key decisions about what health insurance they should carry. For some, the cost of their premiums may rise. The new law requires that employers of 20 or more persons must give older workers, and their spouses age 65 through 69, the option to select several different forms of health coverage. They can choose their employer's private health plan, Medicare Part B (the voluntary part of Medicare) or both.

headline: Careers; More Jobs For Middle Managers
abstract: THE outlook has begun to brighten for job-seeking middle managers, those business people who earn anywhere from $35,000 to $100,000 a year.   Jack Erdlen, executive director of the Employment Management Association, a group of personnel managers, says: ''Companies are coming back into the labor market cautiously, and the outlook for middle managers is hopeful. This is not a false alarm.''   During the recession, he noted last week, some managers were required to wear two hats, but now they intend to hire assistants.  Attrition was low, Mr. Erdlen said, resulting in relatively few openings as wary employees hung onto their jobs.

headline: STANDBY TAX PLAN RULED OUT
abstract: The Treasury Department's chief tax writer said today that the Reagan Administration's proposal for a contingency tax to reduce future budget deficits was ''dead for this year.''   It was unlikely, he added, that there would be any major tax increase approved until 1985.   In a speech here, John E. Chapoton, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, also ruled out Administration support at this time for any of the major revenue-raising options now being talked about in Congress or the Administration.   ''I would anticipate no major revenue-raiser this fall or next year,'' he said. ''It is possible but not likely.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In a speech here Tuesday summarizing the accomplishments of his 25 years in power, Fidel Castro seemed to play down Cuban ties to the Soviet Union. ''Not in the past, not now or ever have we made decisions at a cost to others or expected others to fight for us,'' the Cuban leader said.   A Cuban journalist, analyzing the remark later, suggested it was a message to those who believed that the Soviet Union, Cuba's economic underwriter, was also responsible for the defense of Cuba and its military involvement abroad.   The crowd listening to the President applauded most enthusiastically at such references to the country's self-reliance.  Mr. Castro dwelt on what he said was an ''atmosphere of terror'' the United States was trying to create around Nicaragua, asserting it was seeking to deploy troops in Central America through military maneuvers now beginning in the region. He made no direct reference to the role of the Soviet Union in Cuba's development until he came to a series of fraternal greetings at the end of his speech.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES RISE BIGGEST IN 7 MONTHS
abstract: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, pushed upward by soaring energy prices, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the biggest increase in seven months, the Government reported today.   Some private economists were uneasy about the jump, but the White House greeted the news as further evidence of moderating inflation.  Even with the increase, producer prices fell at an annual rate of 1 percent in the first half of the year. Those prices rose by 3.7 percent last year.

headline: RACE FOR EXCHANGE'S TOP JOB The 22-member board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange is starting to consider a replacement for William M. Batten, the exchange's 74- year-old chairman and chief executive whose contract expires next May.
abstract: Many people on Wall Street regard John J. Phelan Jr., the president and No. 2 man at the exchange, as a strong contender. But few are ready to say the race is over.   William Milfred Batten, nicknamed Mil, became the Big Board's second paid chairman in April 1976. His original five-year, $2 million contract was to have expired in May 1981 but was extended three years in recognition of his accomplishments.

headline: U.S. SHIPS ENTER LEBANON FIGHTING SHELLING HILL SITE
abstract: A United States warship shelled an artillery emplacement in hills southeast of this capital today after gunners, presumed to be Moslem Druse militiamen, fired at the Beirut airport area where American Marines are based.    In the first use of United States Navy firepower in the current Lebanon conflict, the frigate Bowen fired four 5-inch shells at the artillery battery in the hills. At about the same time, Marine gunners ashore fired six 155-millimeter shells at the emplacement.   ''We hit the target that we aimed at,'' a Marine spokesman, Warrant Officer Charles Rowe, said.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Kellogg Posts A 12.6% Gain
abstract: The Kellogg Company reported today that earnings in the second quarter rose 12.6 percent, to $64.2 million, or 84 cents a share, from $57 million, or 74 cents a share, in the period last year.   Sales in the quarter fell slightly, to $593.1 million, from $593.5 million.  Growth in international cereal sales remained strong in the quarter, but was offset by comparatively lower exchange rates, Kellogg said.

headline: Renault Model
abstract: The first 1984 Renault Encore hatchback rolled off the assembly line at the American Motors Corporation's Kenosha, Wis., plant to the cheers of A.M.C. autoworkers, the company said. The subcompact, to be introduced in showrooms this fall with a base price of $5,755, is built on the same platform as the No.4 United States auto maker's popular Renault Alliance subcompact, which was introduced last fall. The Alliance's appeal has brought A.M.C.'s United States car sales 117.6 percent ahead of 1982 levels.

headline: WRISTON SEES RATE RISE 'BLIP'
abstract: Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, said that he believed that short-term interest rates would rise in the next few weeks and that the prime rate might climb to 11 1/2 percent or 12 percent, from the current 10 1/2 percent.

headline: TRIES TO PROD QADDAFI TO NEGOTIATE
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand has expressed irritation at United States pressure on France to intervene in the war in Chad, and says he does not agree with what he sees as an American campaign against Libya.   He also says he sent French troops to Chad to encourage Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to reach a negotiated settlement of the war, believing that a military solution was impossible.   Mr. Mitterrand made his views known in an interview with Le Monde. French Troops Sent to Chad    Although the article carried no direct quotations and attributed its information to ''those who had the privilege of hearing the President privately,'' French officials confirmed tonight that Mr. Mitterrand had granted an interview to the newspaper and that the article accurately reflected his views. The officials also elaborated on several points made by the President in his first statements since French troops were sent to Chad last week.

headline: Freddie Mac's New Debentures
abstract: A $300 million issue of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 11.85 percent debentures due in 1991 is offered at a price of 100 by the corporation and various securities firms.   Although the corporation, known as Freddie Mac, was created by Congress, its securities are not backed by the Government. Proceeds of the debenture sale will be used to support the corporation's activity in the home mortgage market, where its major role is the purchase of loans that it packages and resells as securities.

headline: Computer Venture
abstract: The Mitsubishi Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Cosmos 80 Company said they had agreed to set up two joint ventures in Japan that would link computers using fiber optics. Under the agreement, one of the companies established by the three partners would develop the software needed for the communications system, and the other would develop both software and hardware. Mitsubishi and I.B.M.'s Japanese unit will each hold 34 percent of the new companies; Cosmo will hold 32 percent.

headline: NEW POOR IN BRAZIL TURN PEDDLING INTO PROFESSION
abstract: While Brazil's officials work for the country's economic survival in places like Brasilia, New York and Washington, Carlos Alberto Perez works for his in Rio de Janeiro.   A former sales director for a downtown company, the 45-year-old Mr. Perez now occupies an outdoor stand in a square near his old building, where he peddles ceramic handicrafts and satin sachets made by his wife.   For a while he delivered yellow page directories door to door, but a layoff cost him that job as another had his earlier executive post.  The Largo da Carioca where Mr. Perez mounts his wares these mornings has become a symbol of the Brazilian crisis.  Beneath the spacious plaza runs Rio's new subway, one of the large public projects built with foreign loans that have given the country the developing world's largest foreign debt and forced desperate leaders to seek a rescheduling.

headline: Acid Rain Study On Scandinavian Lakes
abstract: Leading scientists in Britain, Norway and Sweden announced today that they were starting a limited five-year study into the effects of acid rain on Scandinavian lakes.

headline: THE MAN BEHIND MARC RICH
abstract: It is the classic immigrant success story. Speaking only a foreign tongue, a young man flees war-torn Europe for America where, after an apprenticeship in a business run by other immigrants, he starts his own firm and becomes a multimillionaire.   It is the story of how Marc Rich - Belgian-born Jewish refugee, a low ''B'' student in high school and the son of a burlap bag maker - became head of one of the largest commodity trading firms in the world.   It is also a story shrouded in secrecy, and one that has begun to turn sour.   For much of his childhood, Mr. Rich did not even speak English, let alone the arcane language of commodities.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American States Insurance, Indianapolis, said it would acquire all the outstanding shares of its subsidiary, American States Life Insurance Co., that it does not currently own, for about $29.5 million.     * Brush Wellman Inc., Cleveland, said it had received a $14.3 million contract from the General Services Administration for 60,000 pounds of beryllium for the national defense stockpile.

headline: JAVITS, FRAIL BUT ELOQUENT, DEFENDS WAR POWERS ACT
abstract: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits returned today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing room to defend the War Powers Resolution, which he drafted 10 years ago as a member of the committee.   The 79-year-old New York Republican, who is suffering from a degenerative neurological disease, looked frail seated in a high-backed wheelchair before a battery of microphones.   But his voice was firm and his blue eyes were bright as he delivered to an attentive gathering of reporters a primer on the separation of powers between the Executive and Legislative branches of Government.

headline: U.N. Guidelines
abstract: To the Business Editor: Murray L. Weidenbaum's article, ''The U.N.'s Bid to Play Consumer Cop'' (June 26), makes a number of points based on misconceptions which could lead to confusion as to the role of the United Nations.   The United Nations draft consumer protection guidelines are about to be considered by governments in the Economic and Social Council.  This council, a principal organ of the United Nations composed of member states representing all regions of the world and different economic systems, requested the draft guidelines on consumer protection in 1981.

headline: PURCHASE OF U.S. GRAIN: SHIFR IN SOVIET STRATEGY
abstract: The Soviet decision to buy at least nine million metric tons of American grain a year between 1983 and 1988 reflected a shrewd assessment of domestic requirements, including a need to rebuild depleted reserves and to strengthen livestock herds, according to Western agricultural experts here.    The Soviet commitment to a new five-year pact with the United States, providing for purchases of 9 million to 12 million tons annually, was announced last week, and was widely viewed by these experts as a political gesture to the Reagan Administration.    But agricultural attaches at Western embassies here say that diplomatic considerations dovetailed with the needs of a Soviet economy that is only just beginning to recover from a disastrous succession of four bad harvests.   If the current Soviet harvest meets the United States Department of Agriculture estimate of 200 million tons, it will be the first reasonably good yield since the bumper year of 1978, when the Russians reported a total of 237 million tons.

headline: Economic SceneWilliam J. Baumol Competition Vs. Research
abstract: William J. Baumol is a professor of economics at Princeton and New York universities and has been a consultant to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and others. Leonard Silk is on vacation.  MANY economists advocate vigorous competition as the most effective means to get to consumers the mix of products they want at the lowest sustainable prices. Deregulation of transportation by air, trucks and railroads, for instance, has been promoted in the belief that most of these markets are now reasonably competitive, and that substitution of competition for regulation serves the public interest.   However, competition, like virtually all good things, incurs some social costs that are usually overlooked. If businesses are forced to vie with each other in charging the lowest possible prices for similar products, they will have nothing left over for nonbusiness-related expenditures.

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 17, 1983
abstract: The Economy    Industrial production rose a strong 1.8 percent during July, the Federal Reserve reported. The increase indicates that recovery in the third quarter may be almost as strong as in the second quarter, when the G.N.P.  soared 8.7 percent after adjustment for inflation. Most economists would be concerned if such rapid growth continues, fearing it might reignite inflation sometime in 1984. It remains unclear, however, how much the recovery may be slowed by tighter credit, higher interest rates and projections of continuing huge budget deficits. (Page A1.) As one sign of a possible slowdown, officials reported new housing construction fell 0.6 percent in July. (D6.)    The Government may be losing millions of dollars a year because the I.R.S. is not enforcing a ban on late corporate deposits of weekly payroll taxes. In one instance, a Norton Simon unit acknowledged having made late deposits for about three years before the I.R.S. asked it, a year ago, to obey the ban. (D1.)

headline: Bank Rates Show Rise
abstract: For the 10th consecutive week, interest rates for bank money market deposit accounts rose in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Interest rates in the New York area, however, declined slightly.

headline: CANCELED ACQUISITIONS: NOT ALL THAT UNUSUAL
abstract: The American Express Company is not the first would-be corporate suitor to get cold feet on its way to the altar.    The financial services conglomerate startled the business world earlier this week when it walked away from an agreement in principle to spend more than $1 billion for Investors Diversified Services, a division of the Alleghany Corporation.   ''These sorts of things happen reasonably often,'' said Brian D. Young, a vice president in the mergers and acquisitions department at the First Boston Corporation. ''But it is harder for a company to walk away from a big public deal than a smaller one. And most of the deals that fall apart are ultimately redone.''

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Herman and Rosner Get Express Telecom
abstract: Herman and Rosner Enterprises Inc., has been named the agency for Express Telecom, a company founded last year that provides low- cost, long-distance telephone service. Billings are estimated at $1 million for the first year.   The agency earlier signed up American Photographer Magazine, which is owned by CBS and will bill $500,000, as well as a second newcomer to advertising, Britton Development, a real estate development firm with billings estimated at $250,000 for the first half-year.

headline: FUN AND NOVELTY LIFT SALES OF BUBBLE GUM
abstract: Bubble gum is big business - ask Ada Cantavero.   ''We sell a lot of it,'' acknowledges the grandmotherly proprietor of Ada's, a neighborhood variety store in Riverside, Conn. ''We always have. It's something that never goes out of style.''   Indeed, bubble gum may be one of the nation's few truly recession-proof industries. Experts estimate that sales of the confection, in a variety of artificially colored sticks, wads, chunks, flakes, nuggets and powders, have probably tripled in the last decade, approaching $500 million last year.

headline: SALVADOR GUERRILLA UNITS ABANDON A USEFUL TACTIC
abstract: One of the most miltarily useful and innovative tactics to emerge from the guerrilla war in El Salvador has involved not pulling triggers.   From last October until recently, many of the leftist guerrilla units had adopted a policy of using sizable forces to overrun small Government garrisons and then releasing captured soldiers unharmed within 24 to 48 hours.   The tactic often eliminated soldiers from the war as effectively as would a bullet.  ''After they had surrendered and been released, they tended to lose their will to fight,'' an American adviser said. ''And their officers didn't trust them or want them any more.''

headline: FED TO LET BANKS SERVE AS DISCOUNT BROKERS
abstract: In yet another crack in the barriers separating the banking and securities industries, the Federal Reserve Board today added brokerage services to the list of activities that bank holding companies may engage in.    In a related action, the board authorized the Chase Manhattan Corporation of New York, the holding company of the Chase Manhattan Bank, to acquire Rose & Company Investment Brokers Inc. of Chicago. Rose's principal business is executing buy and sell orders for customers.   Earlier this year the board approved the acquisition of Charles Schwab & Company by the BankAmerica Corporation.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: U.S. Agents Once Held Barbie Son, Relative Says    PARIS, July 31 - American agents who sent Klaus Barbie on intelligence missions held his baby son as a ''hostage'' to insure that Mr. Barbie would return, according to an interview with Mr. Barbie's daughter-in-law published today.   Mr. Barbie, who was extradited to France from Bolivia in February, is awaiting trial for murders and deportations he is accused of having ordered when he was chief of the Gestapo in Lyons between 1942 and 1944.

headline: A FAMILY OF BUILDERS DEVELOPS ITS FARM
abstract: The progeny of Alfred Kaskel, one of the city's major builders of the postwar period, spent the happy summers of childhood surrounded by the beauties of Doral Farm, the Kaskel estate in Connecticut.   It is a 68-acre expanse of woodland and farmland with a four-acre pond, off Roxbury Road four miles north of downtown Stamford. Mr.  Kaskel bought it in 1944 from the Dodge estate. Until his death in 1968, the property was operated as a farm, but in more recent years it has lain fallow. In 1979, the main house burned down.

headline: SHAMIR IS INVITED TO FORM CABINET
abstract: President Chaim Herzog, after determining that Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir had the support of a majority in Parliament, asked him today to try to form a new government.   The President's decision, following the resignation of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, came after three days of consultations with all the political parties and factions in Parliament.   Since Mr. Begin first told his Cabinet on Aug. 28 that he intended to resign, he has been out of public view and barely functioning at Prime Minister. Because of what his aides describe as a skin ailment, he has not shaved in two weeks, and reports in the Israeli press portray him as withdrawn and unwilling to eat sufficiently.

headline: Charterhouse
abstract: Charterhouse Petroleum P.L.C. said it had agreed to terms for the disposal of its interest in two North Sea licenses, and part of another license interest held by an associated company, the Jubilee Oil Company, to Santa Fe Minerals Inc., a unit of the Santa Fe International Corporation. Financial details were not disclosed.

headline: Soldier From Bronx Is Killed In Joint War Games in Egypt
abstract: A United States soldier taking part in joint military exercises with Egyptian forces was killed when the jeep he was driving overturned on a road near Cairo, the Army said today.   A spokesman identified the man as Specialist 5 Julio Marcano, 25 years old, of the Bronx, a driver with the 44th Medical Brigade based in Fort Bragg, N.C. Specialist Marcano died in a Cairo hospital last Thursday, a day after the start of the joint exercises.   About 5,500 United States soldiers are taking part in the exercises, which will last through early September and include armor and infantry maneuvers, mock air raids by B-52 bombers and the use of Awacs radar planes.

headline: Diplomats Report Nicaragua Seeks U.S. Deal on Arms Aid
abstract: Nicaragua is prepared to send home its Cuban military advisers and halt the import of Soviet arms if the United States reduces its military presence in neighboring Honduras, diplomats here said today.   It is not clear though, the diplomats added, whether the Sandinistas would demand withdrawal of all American troops now in Honduras for maneuvers and an end to arms supplies to that country.   According to the diplomatic sources, the Cubans and Russians do not want to risk confrontation with the Reagan Administration in Central America.

headline: B.P. Block Goes on Sale
abstract: The British Government put some of its stake in the British Petroleum Company on sale today as part of its fight to control inflation and sustain national economic recovery.

headline: Texas Housing Bonds To Yield Up to 10 1/2%
abstract: An issue of single-family mortgage revenue bonds of the Texas Housing Finance Agency was increased to $238 million from $150 million yesterday and was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2011.   Officials at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead underwriter, said they expected the issue to be rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A or better by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.   The financing includes serial bonds yielding from 6.25 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 10 percent in 1996, 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 1998 at a price of 100 and 10 3/8 percent term bonds due in 2003 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield about 10.40 percent.

headline: KEY TOWN IN CHAD REPORTED TO FALL TO LIBYAN ASSAULT
abstract: Libyan troops and rebels backed by planes, armored vehicles and artillery were reported today to have overrun Chad's northern oasis of Faya-Largeau, forcing Government forces to retreat into the desert.   A Western source said that the battlefield situation meant that the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had ''abandoned all restraint'' in his support of former President Goukouni Oueddei, whom he is trying to return to power here.  (In Washington, President Reagan denounced Libya's military actions in Chad but said that as far as United States military involvement was concerned, ''It is not our primary sphere of influence; it is that of France.''    Article and transcript, page A6.)

headline: VOLCKER WARNS THAT RATES MAY RISE
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the forces that could lead to a new rise in interest rates were building in the economy.   In testimony before a Senate subcommittee, Mr. Volcker also indicated that he opposed efforts by some Congressmen to align the Fed's interest rate and money supply policies with the taxation and spending policies of Congress. The idea would be to aim monetary policy at achieving specified levels of economic growth, employment and inflation.

headline: Florida Bank Bid
abstract: Directors of Florida Coast Banks Inc. today rejected an unsolicited takeover bid from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. Barnett, the state's largest bank holding company with assets of $8.4 billion, Friday offered $22 a share in cash and stock for Florida Coast, which has its headquarters in Pompano Beach and reports assets of $562 million. Florida Coast said its board found Barnett's offer ''inadequate'' and ''not in the best interest of shareholders and customers.'' But Florida Coast directors ''authorized management to explore all appropriate alternatives.''

headline: Dry Pollination Season Pushes Corn Prices Up
abstract: Prices of corn futures covering the new crop continued to climb yesterday as the nation's major farm product entered its critical 10-day pollination period in mostly hot, dry weather.   The crop in the southern half of the main growing region of the Middle West has not received any significant rain this month, and none is forecast for the rest of this week.   As a result, prices for futures from September forward rose 5 cents to 6 cents a bushel; in the past six trading sessions, these prices have advanced about 25 cents. The old-crop corn futures closed yesterday with the July contract, which expires Wednesday, off 1 1/4 cents and the September basically unchanged. Each cent equals $50 on a contract of 5,000 bushels.

headline: HIGH TECH'S QUIET PUSH FOR LOWER TAXES
abstract: WASHINGTON IN a city fearful of deficits and    soured on giving a helping hand to   any but those most severely in need, the high-technology industry may prove to be the exception. In recent months, at least five major bills plus a Reagan plan have been proposed to facilitate joint ventures in research and development; three Congressional task forces are trying to educate legislators on high-tech concerns; the Administration has named Hewlett-Packard's chairman, John A. Young, to head a new commission on industrial competitiveness, and Japan has suddenly become a favorite travel spot for members of Congress seeking to find the Japanese secret to high tech.    The Atari Democrats - who have championed the cause of economic growth through extensive use of computer, robotic and semiconductor technology - are no longer alone. Their ranks have been enlarged by what could only be called Atari Republicans - led by President Reagan himself. Indeed, politicians now seem to be tripping over each other in the rush to assure the public that they are the great protectors of high-tech welfare.

headline: New Times Square Sign
abstract: The latest Times Square sign, between those of Canon and Citizen and surrounded by at least 18 other ads from Japanese manufacturers, is from Gold Star Electronics, a Korean company.

headline: AMONG LIFE INSURERS, LITTLE ONES SHINE
abstract: WHILE many of the big, lumbering life insurance companies have been lackluster performers in the stock market over the last year, a number of the smaller life insurers have recently come into favor among investors.    These small corporations, most of them traded over-the-counter, are not household names in the trillion-dollar life insurance business. (The best- known life insurers, such as Prudential Insurance, Metropolitan Life and Equitable Life Assurance, are mutual companies owned by their policyholders and are not publicly traded.) But in a business dominated by giants, smallness has been a strength.

headline: People
abstract: * Lawrence M. Rau has been appointed senior vice president and director of creative operations, Chevrolet creative, at the Campbell-Ewald Company.

headline: Viacom Joins Japanese Venture
abstract: Viacom World Wide Ltd. said it had joined a group of Japanese companies that includes the Mitsui Group, the Toshiba Corporation, the Odakyu Railways Company and Fujita Industry Ltd. to develop and operate the first two-way addressable cable television system in Japan.

headline: LEBANESE REOPEN BEIRUTS AIRPORT
abstract: Lebanon took its first tentative steps toward a return to relatively normal life today as Beirut International Airport reopened for the first time in more than a month.   The first red-and-white Middle East Airlines Boeing 707 touched down at 4:45 P.M., a few hours after a security committee representing Lebanon's various warring factions agreed there should be no more shelling of the airport so it could be reopened to civilian traffic. The airport, which is protected by American marines, had been closed by fighting since Aug. 28.   The jetliner had been on its way from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to Larnaca, Cyprus. About 45 minutes before it was due to land, the Beirut control tower radioed Capt. Adnan Chatila and told him to forget about Cyprus and to ''come home,'' the captain said.

headline: PURCHASERS CITE EASING OF GROWTH
abstract: The economy continued to grow in August, though at a slower rate, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report yesterday. Employment and industrial production, however, registered their best performances this year.   Though most economic indicators were up, a seasonally adjusted index of these indicators dropped, to 63.6 percent, from July's figure of 67.1 percent. Any reading above 50 means the economy is expanding, according to the purchasing group. Last November, the final month of the recession, the index stood at 37.3,

headline: Commodities; Exchange Celebrates 50th Year
abstract: TRADING in gold and silver futures on New York's Commodity Exchange will start one hour later than normal this morning, while the Comex copper market will be delayed 20 minutes. It will be the first time that the exchange intentionally delayed its openings.   The reason: the Comex will mark its 50th anniversary this morning, and the members of the largest metals futures exchange in the world wanted to start their 51st year at the precise time of day their market opened on July 5, 1933.   As a result, international precious and base metals dealers and brokers have been notified that, just for today, Comex's gold futures ring will open at 10 A.M.; silver, 10:05 A.M., and copper, 10:10 A.M.    While some members have noted that Comex grew out of a merger of the New York Metal Exchange, which opened in July 1883, the Rubber Exchange of New York, the National Raw Silk Exchange and the New York Hide Exchange, they decided to commemorate only the surviving exchange.

headline: Pole Seeks German Asylum
abstract: Waldemar Rzedkowski, the First Secretary at the Polish Embassy in West Germany, has asked for political asylum, Government officials said today.

headline: BOND DEFAULT
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Much of ''The Lessons of a Bond Failure'' (Aug. 14) is a balanced as well as an exhaustive review. But a very faulty impression is left by the uncritical acceptance of the Washington Supreme Court decision holding that public utility units in the state lacked authority to sign the ''take-or- pay'' contracts on which the security of Projects 4 and 5 bonds was based.   In our Federal system the highest state court, unfortunately in this instance, has the final power to rule on interpretation of the statutes of its state. As a result this decision is final, but that does not mean that it is ''right'' or ''correct.'' Accordingly I wish to take exception to the statement that the opinion of the New York law firm of Wood & Dawson, the supply system's legal counsel, upholding the authority of the major units to sign the ''take-or-pay'' contracts ''turned out to be wrong.''

headline: Market Place; Group Rotation And Moods
abstract: GROUP rotation continued to be the name of the game last week in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, meanwhile, finished at 1,225.71, down 14.03 points.   Indicative of the market's fast-changing mood, the industrial average on Monday moved from an early 20-point gain to a 10-point loss at the close, in the wake of rumors that the Federal Reserve had miscalculated its money supply numbers. That brought a denial from the Fed, but it failed to impart any sense of direction to what seemed essentially a market without a rudder.

headline: Vice President Out at Ashland
abstract: Bill E. McKay Jr., a vice president of the Ashland Oil Company who publicly disclosed a questionable payment that the company made to acquire foreign crude oil in 1981, was dismissed from his job this week, Ashland said yesterday. A spokesman for Ashland, the nation's largest independent oil refining company, said Mr. McKay was ''terminated from his job on Monday, effective immediately.'' The spokesman, Dan Lacy, added that the action was ''absolutely not related'' to Mr. McKay's role in the disclosure of the foreign payment. Mr. McKay could not be reached for comment despite repeated calls to his home in Ashland, Ky., where the company is situated.

headline: SALVADOR HEALTH CARE A VICTIM OF WAR
abstract: At times not even the roar of the traffic two stories below on the busy Calle Arce can drown out the crying in the sweltering nursery of this city's maternity hospital.   The hospital, part of a Government- supported health center called Centro Medico, does what it can for the poor. The hospital resembles, as much as anything, a squat blockhouse; it will be 30 years old next year but could easily pass for twice that age.  In the nursery, row after row of cribs hold infants who, for one reason or another, must be isolated. Many were born with skin infections or respiratory ailments or jaundice. Others, born prematurely, are placed in the 18 incubators that still work.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., has appointed Malcolm R. Lloyd group vice president responsible for the company's domestic consumer products divisions and Canadian operations.     *American Express has elected Joseph W. Brown Jr. and John F. Sellick senior vice presidents of its Fireman's Fund Insurance Company subsidiary.     *A. G. Becker Paribas Inc.  has named Leo J. Hindery chief financial officer and managing director.

headline: PHILIPPINES OPENS INQUIRY ON AQUINO
abstract: A Government commission formally began its inquiry today into the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., but its credibility was immediately challenged by supporters of the slain Philippine opposition leader.    Among those questioning the panel's impartiality was Mr. Aquino's widow, Corazon, who spent her first full day in the Philippines after three years of self-imposed exile in the United States that she had shared with her husband. All five commission members, she complained at a news conference, were ''Marcos men.''   Other opposition figures were especially troubled by President Ferdinand E. Marcos's selection of the Supreme Court Chief Justice, Enrique Fernando, to head the investigation. Justice Fernando is a Marcos appointee and loyalist, and critics accused him of having weakened the Supreme Court's independence during the several years he has directed it.

headline: EX-GENERAL DYNAMICS AIDES INDICTED
abstract: A Federal grand jury sitting in Manhattan indicted two former executives of the General Dynamics Corporation yesterday on charges they accepted $2.7 million in kickbacks, part of a $5 million embezzlement scheme involving General Dynamics and the now-defunct Frigitemp Corporation.    William M. Tendy, Acting United States Attorney, charged that they took the money in return for securing for Frigitemp more than $45 million of subcontracting work on tankers and submarines. The vessels were built at the General Dynamics shipyards in Quincy, Mass., and Groton, Conn.   Also indicted were two former executives of Frigitemp, who were charged with arranging and paying the kickbacks.

headline: AND NOW THERE'S EVEN PIZZA POPCORN
abstract: A scant two years ago, there was plain popcorn and buttered popcorn and caramel popcorn, and a few slightly more exotic flavors such as cinnamon for those who would dare.   Now, however, there is pizza-flavored popcorn, watermelon-flavored popcorn and taco-flavored popcorn, and the stores that sell them are called gourmet shops in the industry.   During the past two years, a wave of these stores, some selling as many as 60 flavors, has spread throughout the country, becoming the latest fast- food franchising trend.   In New York City there are nine such stores; two years ago there were none. ''Multiflavor is the biggest thing to hit the popcorn industry in my recollection,'' said Dave Evans, president of Gold Medal Products, a leading manufacturer of popcorn popping machines, ''and I've been in the business 35 years.''

headline: CHILEAN'S BID FOR A COMEBACK
abstract: For a man who presided over the most spectacular financial collapse in Chilean history, who is caught in a tangle of lawsuits and who owes hundreds of millions of dollars to foreign and domestic banks, Javier Vial seems remarkably relaxed and self-confident.   From his suite atop Santiago's tallest skyscraper, which he himself built just two years ago, Mr. Vial presides over a tottering empire of more than 50 mines, farms, paper mills, factories, fishing fleets, retail chains and other enterprises. The Government has taken over management of his bank and mutual funds, yet he remains certain that he will not only be able to stay out of jail, but that one day the group he forged will re-emerge as a powerful financial force.   ''If you were to liquidate our assets today, you would find that they would not produce enough money to pay off our $650 million in debts,'' the 49-year-old Mr. Vial conceded in an interview this week. ''But in a space of 3 to 10 years from now, we will be in a position to meet all our obligations and begin showing profits again.''

headline: Amnesty Group Charges Torture in Mauritania
abstract: Amnesty International charged Mauritania's military rulers today with torturing prisoners suspected of political opposition.

headline: Canadian Inflation Dips
abstract: Canada's annual inflation rate fell to 5.5 percent in July from 5.6 percent in June, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

headline: Iraq Says It Destroyed Four Iranian Vessels
abstract: Iraq said today that its ships and aircraft destroyed four large Iranian naval targets north of Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal in the Persian Gulf.

headline: COUNTERING FRENCH SOCIALSIM
abstract: When Francois Mitterrand took the reins of Government in 1981, he also took command of many French businesses by nationalizing key companies and banks.   The Socialists still hold control of the Government. But groups of smart investors have begun banding together to wrest back control of some businesses that were, in a sense, incompletely nationalized.   The latest raid on France's newly enlarged public sector was successfully completed late last month by a small but powerful group of French investors known as the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, so known on the French Bourse because of their lightning swoops into the market to purchase shares - a practice they plan to continue.

headline: F.D.I.C. TO CONSIDER LIMITING BANK POWERS
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in an apparent attempt to expand its regulatory powers, said today that it was considering the adoption of new rules on the services banks may offer.   William Isaac, chairman of the insurance agency, said the new regulations might apply to federally chartered, or national, banks in addition to state-chartered banks, which it normally supervises.   ''We're not trying to impose restrictions,'' Mr. Isaac said. But, he said, the agency is soliciting comment on whether or not it should limit the ability of banks to engage in real estate, insurance brokerage and underwriting, and travel services. Some states have authorized state-chartered banks to enter these lines of business.

headline: Pope Expresses Praise For Cardinal Cooke
abstract: Pope John Paul II expressed his sympathy today for Terence Cardinal Cooke of New York, who has announced he is terminally ill with leukemia, and extolled him as a ''faithful pastor and servant.''   ''As I take leave of you today,'' the Pope said in a speech to 25 United States Bishops at Castel Gandolfo, ''my thoughts turn once again to one who is a closer friend of many of us, your brother Bishop and mine, Cardinal Cooke.

headline: Kaypro Stock
abstract: The Kaypro Corporation, the portable computer manufacturer that had its intial public offering on Thursday when four million shares were sold at $10 each, closed yesterday at 10 1/4 bid, up 1/8, in over-the-counter trading.. The company's profits and sales have been booming this year.

headline: 2 FRENCH SOLDIERS KILLED AS SHELLS SLAM INTO BEIRUT
abstract: Artillery shells rained over West Beirut today, killing a French paratroop colonel and his driver. In response, the French sent two warplanes on warning flights over the city and Moslem Druse artillery positions in the nearby mountains.   Later, two fighter planes from the American aircraft carrier Eisenhower also swept over the city and the mountains on reconnaissance and warning flights. Tonight United States Marine positions near Beirut International Airport came under artillery fire, and the marines responded with six 155-millimeter artillery rounds. A Marine spokesman said there were no casualties.

headline: Port Authority Job For William S. Doyle
abstract: William S. Doyle, who was deputy state commerce commissioner and takes credit for the ''I Love New York'' campaign, just as former Governor Hugh L. Carey does, has just won an assignment for his agency, William S. Doyle & Company, from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.   If research shows that consumers bound for the States or from the States to Europe might be interested in travel packages that would give them inexpensive layovers in the two states, the agency will go ahead and develop them. The agency will be working on a $165,000 contract.

headline: Soviet Output Rises by 4.1%
abstract: Soviet industrial production grew by 4.1 percent in the first six months of this year compared with a 2.7 percent rise in the first half of 1982, according to a Government report issued today by Tass, the Soviet press agency.   The increase was almost a percentage point over the Government's goal of a 3.2 percent increase for the year.

headline: SALVADOR TALKS WITH REBELS CALLED AT CRISIS POINT
abstract: Representatives of the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels met here today. After the three-and-a-half-hour meeting, the head of the Government peace commission, Francisco Quinonez, said the talks had reached a crisis point and would not continue unless the left changed its position.   At the meeting, the leftists rejected the Government's proposal that they participate in elections tentatively scheduled for early next year. Instead, they offered in writing three counterproposals, including one to continue negotiations with the object of forming a new government, including the left, to oversee elections. They also called for a national debate on the Salvadoran situation and asked that the next meeting be held in El Salvador.

headline: Board Sought In Far East
abstract: The Vancouver Stock Exchange, one of the partners in the International Options Clearing Corporation, said today that negotiations were under way to add a Far East exchange to the clearing corporation.   With such an exchange, the network would provide a 24 hour-a-day market, the Vancouver board said.   The exchange, along with the Montreal exchange and the European Options Exchange, trades gold options through the clearing corporation.

headline: INTERPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STOCKS IN BEST GAIN IN NEARLY 8 MONTHS
abstract: The credit markets snapped out of the doldrums yesterday and interest rates declined sharply in early trading on hopes that the Federal Reserve Board's revised growth targets for the nation's basic money supply will allow short-term rates to remain stable or even decline slightly.   The morning enthusiasm quickly waned, however, and interest rates rose during the afternoon, ending the day only slightly lower. Since early this month, trading had been very quiet as many investors stayed on the sidelines.   Several Government securities dealers noted that anticipation of the adjustment in money supply growth targets announced yesterday by Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, was strong enough for foreign and domestic customers to start trading well before the traditional 9 A.M. opening.

headline: SWAZILAND QUEEN LOSES POWER FIGHT
abstract: A power struggle in the royal household of the independent kingdom of Swaziland led today to the deposing of the Queen Regent, known as the Ndlovukazi or ''She Elephant,'' who had ruled since the 61-year reign of King Sobhuza II ended with his death a year ago.   The ouster of Queen Dzeliwe, whom the monarch had selected from among his 70 or so wives for the sensitive task of overseeing a succession, was described in a terse announcement as being in accord with ''Swazi law and tradition.''   But some Swazis said they saw it as a violation of tradition, intended to consolidate the hold on power of the most conservative elements in the royal household. Those elements have been resisting pressure to allow a constitutional form of government to evolve with the Prime Minister and Cabinet exercising the decision-making authority that rested with the late King.

headline: Chile to Buy British Ship
abstract: The Chilean Navy is negotiating to buy the British Royal Navy's 5,440-ton destroyer Antrim, the Defense Ministry said today.

headline: BEIRUT PREMIER OFFERS TO RESIGN IN TRUCE ACCORD
abstract: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan offered his resignation today to pave the way for the formation of a new Lebanese Government made up of representatives from the leading Lebanese political and religious factions.   The Prime Minister tendered his resignation only a few hours after the cease-fire agreement announced Sunday night ended a month of steady fighting in and around Beirut.   President Amin Gemayel immediately asked Prime Minister Wazzan and his 10-member Cabinet to stay on with full powers until proposed talks on national reconciliation begin and ''our new course becomes clear,'' the state- run National News Agency reported. Cease-Fire Largely Effective    Sniping between the Lebanese army and Syrian-backed anti-Government militiamen around the front-line village of Suk al Gharb, nine miles southeast of the center of Beirut, occasionally interrupted the cease-fire that took effect at 6 A.M. today.

headline: Air 1 Cuts Fares
abstract: Air 1 said it had reduced its unrestricted fares from Newark Airport to St. Louis and between St. Louis and Washington National Airport by $20 each, to $122 and $100, respectively.

headline: West German Inflation
abstract: West Germany's Federal Statistics Office said consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July from June. Economists had expected a month-to-month rise after an increase in West Germany's value added tax to 14 percent from 13 percent took effect July 1.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND COMPANY-Shreve M. Archer Jr., director, sold 20,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 339,971 shares.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Telephone and Telegraph Co.  has named Alexander C. Stark Jr. president of the new telecommunications joint venture formed with N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken.     *  Chi Systems , Ann Arbor, Mich., has appointed Richard A. Hayden senior vice president.

headline: Castle & Cooke Shows Increase
abstract: Higher banana prices helped Castle & Cooke Inc., the processed and fresh food and real estate company based in Hawaii, to report fourthquarter net income of $15.9 million, or 51 cents a share, a sharp increase from the $1.2 million reported in the final quarter last year.   Revenue rose a little more than 2 percent for the fiscal final quarter, to $446.4 million, from $435.6 million.

headline: PUTTING THE BRAKES ON A WAR MACHINE
abstract: IT is an open secret that the Reagan Administration is not of one mind on the issue of trade with    the Communist bloc. No one questions the need to embargo technology that has obvious military applications. But there is much disagreement over the advisability of selling to Communist countries technology of more general use, particularly that needed to develop energy resources.   One school of thought, strongly represented in the Departments of Commerce and State, regards embargoes on energy equipment as not only futile but also counterproductive. It is in the interest of the West, so the argument runs, to assist the Soviet Union in developing its rich oil and gas deposits, partly to bring down international energy prices and partly to dissuade Moscow from invading the Middle East in search of needed oil. In any event, the United States is unable to stem the flow of energy equipment to the U.S.S.R. because most of it is available in Western Europe and Japan.

headline: ALLEGATIN AGAINST GREEK REBUTTED BY C.I.A.
abstract: A Greek journalist, accused by American officals in 1977 of misrepresenting his war record and of working for foreign intelligence services, has made public a new Central Intelligence Agency review of his case that refutes the allegations against him.   The charges against the journalist, Elias P. Demetracopoulos, appeared in an article in The New York Times in December 1977.   Mr. Demetracopoulos, who works for the Greek daily papers Makedonia and Thessaloniki, has made public a C.I.A. review of his case, dated Aug. 10, which asserts that despite what C.I.A. officials told The Times in 1977, there is nothing in the agency's files to support the allegations.

headline: Coleco Delays Adam Delivery
abstract: - Coleco Industries, which planned to start deliveries of its new Adam home computer by Aug. 31, said that the initial shipments would be ''a couple of days late.'' But Coleco played down the delay as insignificant.

headline: NEW ESMARK OFFER CONVINCES NORTON
abstract: Esmark sweetened its bid for Norton Simon, the company accepted the offer and David Mahoney is getting richer. The price tag is about $34 a share, or $918 million, plus Esmark gets a ''right of first refusal'' to buy any of Norton Simon's companies for one year. This will probably discourage Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts and last week's newcomer - Anderson-Clayton - from pursuing their own takeover bids.  As for Mr. Mahoney, right, his ''motivation all along has been to get the best deal for the shareholders,'' his spokesman said. And Mr.  Mahoney is no small shareholder. His 718,513 shares will be worth some $25 million under the new deal - $3.5 million more than the value under his initial $29 a share offer. Moreover, his five-year, $9 million employment contract will be honored, even though he will probably leave the company after the acquisition.   More sweeteners. Lenox finally acquiesced to a $3 a share improvement in Brown-Forman's takeover bid -$90 a share, or $408 million. The china and crystal maker was evidently uncertain about the effects of its ''poison pill'' defense and was concerned about a possible flood of lawsuits by angry shareholders. Lenox chairman John S. Chamberlain will be elected to the Brown-Forman board. Of the coming merger, W.L. Lyons Brown Jr., president of the distiller and winemaker, said, ''I suppose Bolla wine could be served in Lenox crystal.''

headline: FIGHTING IN LEBANON: BALANCE OF FORCES
abstract: American and other intelligence officers say there is evidence that the Syrians and their allies in Lebanon have been considering their military choices in the confrontation with the multinational peacekeeping force and the regular army in Lebanon.  Signal intercepts and individual reports reflect reasonable confidence, the informants said, that the current harassment of the peacekeeping force of United States marines and French, Italian and British troops can continue without punitive reaction and that the Lebanese Army will prove incapable of driving the Lebanese Moslem Druse militiamen from their present positions.   But, they said, the unknown ingredient in the situation is the role being played by Soviet advisers to the Syrian forces. According to Maj. Gen. Amir Drori of the Israeli Army, Soviet officers, nominally attached to the Syrian Army, are now involved in all field activites of the forces in Lebanon that are fighting the Lebanese and the multinational force.

headline: GROMYKO ACCUSES WEST OF BLOCKING A PACT ON MISSILES
