abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that the ''lopsided proposals'' on medium- range nuclear weapons put forward by the United States and its partners in the Western alliance can only mean that they wish to block agreement on the issue with the Soviet Union.   Although Mr. Gromyko did not mention the proposals that President Reagan announced Monday at the United Nations, the Foreign Minister's remarks appeared to be an oblique response to Mr. Reagan's initiative.   Other Moscow reaction took the form of press commentaries, including one by Tass, the Government press agency, which described the Reagan speech as ''the same propaganda game and nothing more.'' Previous commentaries based on Western press reports in advance of Mr. Reagan's speech had called his proposals a ''mockery of common sense.''

headline: LITTLE CHANCE SEEN OF CUTS IN DEFICITS
abstract: With Congress returning to work Monday, the economic outlook is still good. But the chances for shrinking the Government's record budget deficits are fading.   The curious twist is that, if the economy were getting worse, the fiscal outlook might be improving. As the situation stands now, the Government and the economy face the prospect of $200 billion annual budget deficits.

headline: NAMIBIANS ASSAIL GOVERNING SYSTEM
abstract: A Government commission says this South African territory's multilayered system of racial and ethnic governments has led to widespread mismanagement, inefficiency and corruption.   The report of the Thirion Commission, which was appointed by South Africa, was depressing news for residents who have grown increasingly cynical about prospects for independence for the territory, also known as Namibia.   The economy is in its worst depression in decades, and the report, which was issued late last month, blamed the multilayered system South Africa designed to keep tribes and racial and ethnic groups apart. Under the system there are, for example, 11 education and health departments.

headline: Economic Scene; Confrontations Over Deficits
abstract: THE Reagan Administration presides over the threat of large budget deficits into the indefinite future. Such deficits are not consistent with classical governmental financial policy and in themselves must be viewed as undesirable by sophisticated supporters of the Administration. Yet, the Administration is willing to tolerate these deficits as a weapon in a struggle to reduce the size of the Government.   The Administration began office committed to support these goals: a path of reduced Government spending, a budget that eventually will be balanced, and a program of slow and steady growth in the nation's stock of money.

headline: BANK CITES POWER UNIT FOR FRAUD
abstract: Chemical Bank, trustee for thousands of Washington Public Power Supply System bondholders, filed suit in Federal court here today charging the system and its sponsoring utilities with fraud and negligence in issuing $2.25 billion in bonds to finance two canceled nuclear power plants.   The power system, in an action that constituted the nation's largest-ever default on a municipal bond issue, acknowledged last week that it did not have the money to pay either the principal or interest on the bonds.   That action, in turn, followed a Washington Supreme Court ruling that essentially stripped the system of any source of income by nullifying guaranteed-revenue contracts with its 88 affiliated utilities.   Chemical, which brought its suit in United States District Court because it is alleging violations of both state and Federal securities laws, said its action was aimed at recovering the full $2.25 billion in principal plus interest until the debt is repaid.

headline: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLISH CRITICISM OF WALESA TAKES SARCASTIC TONE
abstract: The Polish authorities, apparently worried over underground calls for demonstrations to mark the third anniversary of the creation of Solidarity, the independent union, have begun a campaign against Lech Walesa, its founder.    For most of the week, the Government-controlled newspapers and television news programs have carried items slighting Mr. Walesa, whom the authorities previously brushed off as ''the former leader of the former Solidarity.''    In addition to concern over calls by the underground remnant of Solidarity for a two- hour transit boycott and other demonstrations on Aug. 31, the authorities appear particularly upset at remarks by Mr. Walesa that Western economic sanctions on Poland should not be eased.  Aug. 31 is the anniversary of the signing of the Government's agreements with protesting Gdansk shipyard strikers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Hospital Supply Corp. announced that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Hoffmann-La Roche Inc.'s Burdick & Jackson Laboratories Inc. subsidiary for an undisclosed price.   * DMG Inc. said it would acquire Master Shield Inc., a Weatherford, Tex., affiliate of Equity Group Holdings, a privately held firm that owns about 24.7 percent of DMG's common, in exchange for 2.4 million DMG common shares, 115,000 shares of a new series of preferred stock, and $2.5 million principal amount of 12 1/2 percent subordinated notes.   * General Instrument Corp. said it had agreed to form a joint venture with a unit of General Electric Co. P.L.C., London, to develop and sell advanced cable television and video conferencing systems.

headline: ORDERS OF DURABLE GOODS RISE
abstract: Orders to factories for durable goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, with strong gains by some industries mostly offset by a big drop for military hardware, the Commerce Department said today.   Excluding the decline for military capital goods, new orders rose 3.5 percent, the Commerce Department report said. Automobiles, primary metals and nonmilitary capital goods all showed gains.

headline: KISSINGER CALLS PRINTING OF PENTAGON PAPERS PROPER
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has stated that the press did nothing improper by publishing the Pentagon Papers in 1971 although he was ''outraged'' by their appearance in public at the time.   In an interview with American Heritage magazine, Mr. Kissinger discussed international relations, diplomacy and the secrecy required during sensitive negotiations like the ones he was then conducting to end the war in Vietnam. Mr. Kissinger was national security adviser to President Richard M. Nixon and, he said, ''most intensely concerned with controlling leaks'' that could compromise those talks.    But he says in the magazine's August-September issue: ''I do not believe that it is the press's job to discipline itself about what information it receives, or to reject information it can obtain, on the ground that it might harm a negotiation. The media are in no position to make such a judgment.''

headline: Seoul Reports Sinking North Korean Boat
abstract: South Korean patrol boats assisted by planes and shore troops sank a North Korean patrol boat cruising near a nuclear power plant on the southeast coast today, the Defense Ministry said.   A ministry spokesman said the clash took place after a guard on shore near the plant saw the North Korean patrol boat heading toward the beach in Wolsong, 187 miles southeast of Seoul.

headline: ISRAEL OPPOSING U.S. SUGGESTION ON WITHDRAWAL
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel had not abandoned its determination to see simultaneous Syrian and Israeli withdrawals from Lebanon.   Speaking on the Israeli television, Mr. Shamir said there had been some discussion among Reagan Administration officials ''on certain changes in the timetable of withdrawals.'' He added: ''We reject all changes like this. We think there is nothing to be gained from this.  We think all sides must be faithful to the principle of simultaneous withdrawal. Furthermore, there was no discussion of changing this principle.''

headline: Market Place; G.M. Dividend Interest Stirs
abstract: INVESTORS and analysts following the fortunes of the Ford Motor Company enjoyed a pleasant surprise last week when Ford's directors reinstated the 30-cent quarterly dividend that had been omitted since January 1982. Now the dividend spotlight in the automotive industry swings to the General Motors Corporation and its directors' meeting set for Aug. 1.   G.M.'s stock, meanwhile, has been a strong performer since spring in response to rebounding earnings for the nation's biggest auto maker. The stock changed hands Wednesday at 75 1/2, its highest price since 1977. In February 1982 the shares sold as low as 34. In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, G.M. eased 5/8, to 74 5/8.

headline: Unicare Bought By Extendicare
abstract: Extendicare Ltd., of Toronto, announced that it had completed the acquisition of all the outstanding and issued shares of Unicare Services Inc., a Milwaukee-based health-care company, for $142.9 million (United States).

headline: 3 Thrift Units
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had approved the merger of three Indiana savings and loan associations - First Federal of East Chicago, Gary Federal and Citizens Federal of Hammond. Before the merger, First Federal had $209.5 million in assets and five offices, Gary Federal had $15.2 million in assets and two offices, and Citizens Federal had $260 million in assets and four offices. Citizens Federal is the surviving institution.

headline: U.S. OFFERS A ROAD PLAN TO COSTA RICA
abstract: The chief of the United States Army's Southern Command in Panama, Gen. Paul Gorman, has offered to build a network of roads and bridges in Costa Rica with the help of the United States National Guard, according to American diplomats here.   General Gorman, who arrived for an unpublicized 24-hour visit on Tuesday, was said to have made his proposal to President Luis Alberto Monge and members of his Cabinet. A person present at the meeting said President Monge was ''clearly enthused'' about the idea.   Although no detailed plan was presented, according to an American diplomat, it would involve creating access to the more isolated areas of Costa Rica, but also have a strategic purpose.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.54 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer.  Aa Utility Bonds*12.63 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Trade Down
abstract: Trade between the United States and the Soviet Union fell to its lowest level in a decade in the first half of 1983, and was down 42.2 percent from the 1982 period, according to preliminary figures published today.   The figures, in the weekly Economicheskaya Gazeta, showed that the value of traded goods in the first six months of the year dropped to $1.36 billion from $2.36 billion.

headline: NATIONAL HEALTH ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SHOPPING AROUND FOR A DISCOUNT BROKER
abstract: THE continuing bull market may have made it harder to find bargains i n the stock market. But there are now enormous opportunities to get b argain-basement prices on stock brokerage services. The enthusiastice ntry of the nation's commercial banks into the discount brokerage b usiness has dramatically widened investor access to trading c ommissions that are well below those charged by traditional b rokerage firms.   In recent weeks, Citicorp, Chemical Bank, United Jersey Bank and Liberty National Bank of Kentucky have announced plans to join Security Pacific, Bank of America, and some 600 other banks in offering discount brokerage services. The New England Life Insurance Company is also planning to offer discount brokerage. And Security Pacific and other big banks are even franchising their discount brokerage packages to other banks, providing back-office services while the local banks provide the order takers.

headline: ISRAELI LABOR COALITION TO REPLACE BEGIN
abstract: A delegation from the opposition Labor Party coalition urged today that the ''historic opportunity'' created by the resignation of Prime Minister Menachem Begin be used to set up an alternative Government that will ''lift the country out of the economic, social, security and political morass.''   The call came as the group met with President Chaim Herzog, who was a Labor member of Parliament until he was elected President as a Labor alignment candidate. As head of state, he is required to be above politics. Under Israeli law, the President calls upon one of the 120 members of Parliament to try to set up a government capable of gaining the Parliament's support.

headline: Greece Says U.S. Bases Must Go After 5 Years
abstract: Greece today rejected American interpretations that the agreement initialed between the two countries Friday allowed the possibility for United States military bases to remain beyond the duration of the five-year accord.   ''The agreement initialed on the bases means that their stay in our country ends by the 30th December, 1988, at the latest,'' the Government spokesman, Dimitrios Maroudas, said.

headline: Ruling on Hydroelectic
abstract: The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision that makes it easier for municipal authorities to take over hydroelectric projects now in the hands of investor-owned utilities.   The court, by a 6-to-2 vote, thus rebuffed an effort by the Reagan Administration to prevent these projects from being acquired by public systems serving relatively few customers.   Large investor-owned utilities that have hydroelectric plants tend to spread the savings inherent in such generation to all their customers, thus keeping their average charges a bit lower than those set by utilities more dependent on oil- or gas-fueled plants.  Municipal utilities that may now buy more of the water-powered plants tend to have many fewer customers; any savings might thus benefit fewer customers.

headline: Campaigns By L'eggs And Atari
abstract: THE three-hour Emmy awards show on the NBC-TV network last night also served to introduce new ad campaigns for both Atari home computers and L'eggs Sheer Energy pantyhose, and each was a radical departure from past efforts.   Atari's ads mark the debut of the actor-director-writer Alan Alda, star of ''M*A*S*H,'' who is beginning a five-year-relationship with the Warner Communications subsidiary.

headline: Bill on Beer Distributors
abstract: Beer industry representatives today opened a new campaign before Congress for legislation that would give distributors a limited exemption from Federal antitrust laws.

headline: BEER DISTRIBUTORS SEEK ANTITRUST EXEMPTION
abstract: Opposition is mounting to a campaign by beer distributors for an antitrust exemption that would permit exclusive distribution rights in a territory.   The proponents, who also include brewers and the teamsters, began lobbying Congress last session for such a bill, following the lead of the soft drink industry, which won such an exemption in 1980 after a long fight. Initially it looked as if the beer interests might have it easier.   But last year's session ended without action, and now the industry is locked in battle with tavern and food store owners, as well as consumer groups, who contend that the bill would lead to higher prices. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission have also opposed the bill as anticompetitive.

headline: PATENTS; New Fuel Pellets For Commercial Use
abstract: A Brooklyn man has invented a process for the production of fuel pellets to be burned in commercial plants. Charles J. Reilly was granted patent 4,398,917 this week for a method of using enzymes to break down wood, municipal waste and other materials so they will flow more easily into the pelleting equipment.

headline: ARGENTINE LEADERS IN WAR WERE INEPT, MILITARY PANEL SAYS
abstract: The Argentine junta that ordered the invasion of the Falkland Islands demonstrated incompetence in virtually every aspect of the war and should be court-martialed, according to a military investigative commission report that was disclosed to the press today.   An abbreviated version of the report was published by La Voz, a newspaper run by a Peronist who opposes the Government.

headline: A Greyhound Unit Sells 3 Airliners
abstract: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation said that it had sold two 747's and one DC-8 jumbo-jet airliner to National Airlines after terminating a lease for them by mutual agreement with World Airways. Greyhound Leasing, a subsidiary of the Phoenix-based Greyhound Corporation, said World had been paying $10 million a year under a 15-year lease term expiring in 1988 and 1989.

headline: Chock Full Stake
abstract: Milton Petrie, chairman of the Petrie Stores Corporation, has purchased 4.2 percent of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, Chuck Full said. It said that Mr. Petrie had bought the stock from Lillian Schwartz Black, former wife of William Black, chairman of the company until his death last March. The company has been engaged in a running battle with Jerry Finkelstein, a dissident stockholder, who has been attempting to replace current management. Mr. Petrie could not be reached for comment.

headline: EUROPE'S GYPSIES HEAR THE CALL OF THE EVANGELICALS
abstract: The beautiful young woman, dressed all in white, with a white ribbon that cut through her black hair like a quarter- moon on a night sky, walked onto center stage. She stepped into a two-foot- tall, plastic child's wading pool. It was blue and white and decorated with clouds, colored flowers and Walt Disney caricatures of birds, fish and happy cocker spaniels.    She looked nervous, sitting there in the water. A man thrust a microphone before her and asked if she was ready to ''follow Jesus.'' She said yes, but it was barely audible even with the mike.

headline: CHILE AIDE SAYS CHANGES WILL CONTINUE
abstract: Chile's Interior Minister, Sergio Jarpa Reyes, said in an interview here today that Chile's promised political changes would continue despite the assassination Tuesday of a senior official.   Mr. Jarpa, who started the new policy after taking over as Interior Minister three weeks ago, said the assassination of Carol Urzua, the Governor of metropolitan Santiago, was ''a criminal act aimed at getting the Government to change its policies.'' But, he said, ''there will be no changes in the plan.''   Mr. Jarpa, who was previously Chile's Ambassador to Argentina, has been in Buenos Aires for several days making arrangements for the move back to Chile.

headline: Dutch Leaving Lebanon
abstract: The Netherlands plans to go ahead by Oct. 1 with previously announced plans to withdraw its 800 troops from the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said Friday night.

headline: TWO NEW POLITICAL ANTAGONISTS EMERGING IN CHILE
abstract: Chile's new Interior Minister, who is 63 years old, is locked in a political struggle with a 29-year-old labor leader who was imprisoned Friday on charges of defaming the Government.    The union leader, Rodolfo Seguel, who is head of the National Copper Workers Confederation and chairman of the National Workers Command, a labor coalition, is among the most outspoken critics of the Government. He was imprisoned after he called President Augusto Pinochet Ugarte an ''absurd and fanatical dictator.'' Mr. Seguel has vowed to continue agitating until the military regime falls.   The new Interior Minister, Sergio Onofre Jarpa, who was appointed five weeks ago, insists with equal fervor that the military will continue running the country for at least six more years. An outspoken rightist, he often says Chile faces danger from Marxist subversion. Many Chileans believe that, if General Pinochet were to be forced out of office, he would name Mr. Jarpa as his successor.

headline: People
abstract: * Peter H. Reader has joined Herman & Rosner Inc., as senior vice president/director of client services.     * Harry Kay elected a senior vice president of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising.     * Laurel Baer promoted to senior vice president of Marsteller Inc., Chicago.

headline: SENATOR TOWER BACKS U.S. MILITARY SUPPORT FOR CHAD
abstract: Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that the United States ''should provide all of the logistical support possible'' to Chad to prevent the incursion of Libyan forces into that African nation.   The Texas Republican added, however, that Chad should look to other, friendly African countries for troop support and not to the United States.   Senator Tower, speaking on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' said Chad had to be considered of ''vital interest to the United States.''   The Reagan Administration has already allocated $25 million in supplies to the Chad regime for its fight against Libyan-supported rebels under former President Goukouni Oueddei and against reported Libyan air attacks on the northern city of Faya-Largeau.

headline: REFUGEES ACCUSE SANDINISTAS OF HARASSMENT
abstract: Intimidation and harassment by Nicaraguan armed forces of the Indian and Creole population along the country's Caribbean coast has increased dramatically over the last five or six months, according to refugees who have fled to Costa Rica.   Refugees are arriving in increasing numbers in all kinds of craft from canoes to commandeered fishing boats.  They say that since late January or early February, there have been beatings and killings in Indian settlements. As many as 15,000 Indians have fled into the mountains to live off the land while trying to arm themselves against the Nicaraguan Army and the Sandinista militias, the refugees report.   About 300 people are thought to have arrived by boat in Costa Rican ports in the last few months. They join at least 4,000 documented refugees from other parts of Nicaragua who have come to Costa Rica overland or by air. There are more than 20,000 Nicaraguan refugees in Honduras.

headline: Baldwin's Rating Cut, But 3 Units Fare Better
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced a further reduction in the debt rating of the Baldwin-United Corporation and one of its affiliates, but reaffirmed its high-grade ratings on the claims-paying ability of three of Baldwin's other affiliates.   Subordinated public debt of Baldwin-United was cut to CCC, a highly specultive grade, from B, and senior debt of the D.H. Baldwin Company was cut to CCC from B+.

headline: PAY-TV LINK ACCEPTED BY U.S. AFTER CHANGES
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it would permit a merger of Showtime and The Movie Channel, the second- and third-ranking pay television companies, because the proposal no longer includes two major movie distributors as co-owners.   The department had announced in June and again in July that it objected to merger proposals on the ground that they violated antitrust laws.   But today, Assistant Attorney General William F. Baxter, who heads the antitrust division, said he no longer objected, primarily because the new proposal involved only one motion picture distributor, Warner Brothers. The earlier proposals would have included Paramount Pictures, owned by Gulf and Western Industries, and Universal City Studios Inc., which is owned by MCA Inc.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: ZIMBABWE AIRMEN CLEARED AND SEIZED ANEW
abstract: Six white Zimbabwean air force officers were found not guilty today of having aided in the sabotage of 13 warplanes, but then were detained again by the Government 40 minutes later.   The high-ranking officers were taken into custody again under Zimbabwe's emergency powers regulations, which allow indefinite detention without trial.    The six officers, including Air Vice Marshal Hugh Slatter, 43 years old, formerly the second in command of the air force, had stepped out of Zimbabwe's High Court and were embracing their wives and family members when policemen rearrested them and led them away in handcuffs. A crowd of nearly 100, who had been cheering the released officers, turned to booing and jeering the police.

headline: Arafat Criticizes West At Geneva Conference
abstract: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, criticized the United States and other Western countries today for not taking part in the United Nations conference here on Palestinian rights.   Mr. Arafat, speaking at the conference, said the nonparticipating countries had refused to ''meet their responsibilities,'' and he asked the 134 nations present to take all the action required to assure Palestinians a ''just peace and the right to live in dignity in their homeland.''   The United States and Israel are boycotting the session on the ground that its sponsors wanted it only as a platform for ''one-sided judgments'' in support of the P.L.O. The major West European powers have sent only observers.

headline: Archer Daniels Facing Redemption Challenge
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm, filed a lawsuit last Friday challenging the Archer Daniels-Midland Company's plan to redeem its 16 percent debentures due in 2011.   The suit is attracting attention because it tests the legal ability of a corporation to retire bonds or debentures issued when interest rates were much higher than they are now. Morgan Stanley says in the suit that it suffered losses when Archer Daniels announced last month that it would redeem the debentures Aug. 1 at a price of $1,173.28 for each $1,000 face amount.

headline: NEW BUSINESSES CITE LACK OF CAPITAL
abstract: Elizabeth L. Hubbard had long dreamed of owning her own business. Last March, however, the opportunity came a bit more abruptly than she expected when she was laid off by Atari Inc.   As an inexperienced and somewhat reluctant entrepreneur, Miss Hubbard, who is 31 years old, says she does not expect easy success from her new career as owner of The Good Word, a word-processing center that she opened in Sunnyvale, Calif. with $20,000 in savings.   Survival rates for new businesses, she knows, are notoriously low.  What she did not foresee, however, was how ''hard-nosed'' banks could be when she recently tried to borrow an additional $25,000 to keep her fledging business going.

headline: U.S. STEEL PURSUES TALKS ON IMPORTS
abstract: The chances of the United States Steel Corporation's reaching an agreement to import steel from Britain to its plant in Fairless, Pa., are ''less than 50-50,'' a U.S. Steel official said yesterday.   Thomas C. Graham, the company's vice chairman and head of its steel division, said it was still negotiating with the British Steel Corporation.

headline: SEOUL LIKELY TO SLOW STEPS TOWARD SOVIET TIES
abstract: In the wake of the destruction of a Korean airliner carrying 269 people last week, South Korea will pull back from recent efforts to open diplomatic channels to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries, Government officials and foreign diplomats said today.    ''After this terrible incident, there has to be some change,'' a senior Government official said.   South Korean officials stressed that in the immediate aftermath of the tragedy, long-term foreign policy was not being set, but they added that a shift was inevitable.   In its battle with North Korea to be recognized as the only legitimate representative of the Korean people, South Korea has constantly tried to gain greater international recognition. In recent years, Seoul has made particular efforts to begin to normalize relations with Peking and Moscow, hoping to soften the support for North Korea from its principal sponsors.

headline: Time Inc. Changes TV-Cable Publisher
abstract: In a surprise move yesterday Time Inc., changed the publisher of its fledgling TV-Cable Week, which is potentially its biggest magazine property.

headline: HOUSE COMPROMISE SOUGHT ON NICARAGUA
abstract: The Reagan Administration is negotiating with Republicans and Democrats in Congress to devise a compromise that would avoid a vote in the House of Representatives to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, high Administration officials said today.   Participants in the negotiations said top Administration officials met four times last week with nine key members of Congress to draft an alternative resolution that would make a cutoff of covert aid to the rebels contingent on the Nicaraguan Government's certifying that it had stopped channeling military aid to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.   Administration officials said no agreement had yet been reached on a specific proposal. But they said they were hoping that a resolution on what they call a symmetrical cutoff could eventually win the backing of the House majority leader, Jim Wright of Texas, and the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, as well as members of the House Intelligence and Foreign Affairs committees.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Lloyd's Chairman Planning to Retire    Sir Peter J. F. Green, chairman of Lloyd's of London, the world's largest insurance market, announced plans yesterday to retire at the end of the year.   Sir Peter was named chairman of Lloyd's in 1980 and served through a stormy period in which scandals shook the 20,000-member insurance society. Several moves to tighten rules have been made in the last few years, including the appointment of a new governing council mandated by Parliament.

headline: Iraq Reports Air Raid Against the Iranians
abstract: Iraqi war planes attacked Iranian troops on Saturday in a new outbreak of fighting between the two neighbors, the state-run Iraqi press agency reported.   The agency said Iraqi jets hit several Iranian emplacements, but did not identify the targets.   Clashes between the two armies were reported at several spots along the front between the two armies, the agency said without elaboration.

headline: APPEALS FOR MISSILE ACCORD CONTINUE AT THE U.N.
abstract: Despite a rejection by Moscow of President Reagan's new proposals for arms reduction in Western Europe, speakers at the General Assembly here today continued to express the hope that some settlement could be reached.   ''We do not want to be constantly exposed to the threat of Soviet intermediate-range missiles,'' said Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Foreign Minister of West Germany. ''We pin our hope on an interim agreement that would limit these missiles of the Soviet Union and the United States to the lowest possible number.''

headline: NUCLEAR HALT
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Christopher Flavin's article is full of enthusiasm for California's use of renewable sources of electricity. It does not, however, mention the costs of these sources.   Mr. Flavin cites a non-megawatt photovoltaic facility financed and built by Arco Solar, which sells electricity to Southern California Edison, as a forerunner of 100-megawatt photovoltaic or solar thermal power plants. Information on the financing has not been made available by Arco Solar, but figures for SCE's Solar One are available.

headline: PROGRESS FOR SOVIET PIPELINE
abstract: Barely 14 months after the first trench was dug in the hinterland of Siberia, welders have secured the last length of pipe along the 2,780-mile route that will carry natural gas westward to the Soviet frontier with Czechoslovakia and onward to the homes and factories of Western Europe.   The occasion has been celebrated here as a vindication of the crash program ordered by the Kremlin when the Reagan Administration began its unsuccessful campaign to halt the project.   Persevering through a six-month winter, when Siberian temperatures can snap tempered steel, construction crews have thrown the pipeline across hundreds of marshes and lakes, past major rivers such as the Volga and the Don and across the Ural Mountains.   But the accomplishment leaves much to be done by early next year.  Forty-two compressor stations to pump the gas through the 36-inch pipeline have to be installed and tested to make sure that the first deliveries flow on time.

headline: Telegram Promising Return Is Disclaimed by Mrs. Peron
abstract: Isabel Martinez de Peron, former President of Argentina, has disclaimed a telegram attributed to her that announced that she would return to Argentina this week, informants close to her said today.   Although she is expected to preside over her party's national congress in Buenos Aires on Saturday, the 53-year- old widow of President Juan Domingo Peron has yet to announce official details of her trip, they said.

headline: Northeast Utilities Begins a Financing
abstract: Northeast Utilities Inc. of Berlin, Conn., yesterday offered 3 million shares of common stock at $12.40 a share, through an underwriting group managed by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.   Proceeds will be used to repay the company's outstanding short-term borrowings and to make open-account advances and capital contributions to the company's subsidiaries, primarily the Connecticut Light and Power Company and the Western Massachusetts Electric Company.

headline: Ford to Raise '84 Prices About 2.3%
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, following the lead of the General Motors Corporation, announced that it is increasing the prices of its 1984 models an average 2.3 percent, or $254, putting the price of the average Ford auto at $11,200.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: Merck Halts Sales Of Arthritis Drug    RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 1 (Reuters) - Merck & Company said today that it had agreed to suspend temporarily sales of the measured-release formula of the anti-arthritis drug indomethacin in seven countries.   The suspension is in response to concerns about reports of adverse reactions to the drug.

headline: ALLIES PRESSING U.S. ON I.M.F. BILL
abstract: Western Europe and Japan have told the Reagan Administration that they will block a $6 billion emergency loan to the International Monetary Fund because they want to put more pressure on Congress to approve an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the I.M.F.    The Europeans and Japanese also said they were not sure the I.M.F. would need as much as $6 billion by the end of this year to keep operating even if Congress had still not approved its increase.   The European-Japanese viewpoint was discussed with the Americans Wednesday night, officials said, at a private meeting in Paris of the so- called Group of Five. Attending the meeting were senior finance officials of the United States, West Germany, France, Britain and Japan. Washington was represented by Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs.

headline: Dollar Bonds Slip in London
abstract: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were little changed this afternoon after declining early in the day by about 3/8 point, dealers said.

headline: Jello-O Plans Campaign Costing $2 Million
abstract: Jell-O, a dessert division of the General Foods Corporation, announced a $2 million print and television promotion campaign for its ''Simply Sensational'' instant winner game.   The campaign, created by Cato Johnson Inc., a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam Inc., is the largest in the gelatin maker's 86-year history. It will support the company's purchase- incentive program and instant winner game designed by Don Jagoda Associates.

headline: Report Calls for U.S. Pressure On Pakistan to Grant Rights
abstract: Two American legal groups are urging the Reagan Administration ''to exert pressure'' on Pakistan for the restoration of civil rights in that country.   In a report issued over the weekend, they said there had been a ''serious breakdown in the rule of law in Pakistan,'' with a ''devastating effect on the nation's civilian judicial system.''   The report was commissioned by the Committee on International Human Rights of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and by the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights.

headline: Thrift Unit Issue Is Oversubscribed
abstract: The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, one of the nation's largest thrift institutions, said yesterday that its initial public offering of 30,252,159 shares, priced at $11.25 a share, was sold out. Underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Patents; Tuning In To Remote Stations
abstract: WASHINGTON THE inventors of a device with the trademark of Selectastation expect that it will permit remote listening to any local radio station in any American city where one of the units has been installed. Patent 4,393,277 was granted this week to Stuart D.  Goldberg, sales manager of WRKS-FM, a New York radio station, and Peter D. Besen and Don H. Shulsinger of Arlington, Mass., engineers with degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: GREECE SAYS PACT SPELLS END TO AMERICAN BASES
abstract: The Greek Government has said the new military agreement with the United States means American bases will have to be disbanded after the accord ends in 1988.   ''Unlike all other agreements, this one specifies a beginning and an end for the bases,'' said Ioannis Kapsis, an Under Secretary at the Foreign Ministry, making public the text Friday.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Coopers & Lybrand has named David L. Millstein tax partner-incharge of the Newark office, succeeding Harry F. Immerman, who was named tax partner-in-charge of the New York office.   * Fleet National Bank, Providence, R.I., has named H. Robert Wagner Jr. a senior vice president.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, AUGUST 26, 1983    International Washington and Moscow signed a new five-year grain accord under which the U.S. will sell the Soviet Union at least nine million tons a year. In announcing the pact, which guarantees that supplies will not be interrupted, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block disavowed the partial grain embargo President Carter imposed after the Soviet move into Afghanistan in 1979. (Page A1.) In effect, the pact pledges that future Administrations won't block grain exports for foreign policy or national security reasons. (D4.)  Ford has taken over first place in European auto sales and G.M. is making rapid gains. It is the first time a U.S. auto maker has been Europe's top seller. In the first half of 1983, Ford's sales rose more than 11 percent, while G.M.'s soared nearly 25 percent. Analysts cited skillful marketing and cost-cutting. (D1.)

headline: Commodities; Integrating the Markets
abstract: WHEN the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade last week announced plans to give their members access to each other's stock index futures and options markets, it marked the next to last round in the eventual integration of the securities and futures markets.   The last step in the process will involve merging the Securities and Exchange Commission with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. A White House panel headed by Vice President Bush is now studying this possibility as part of its overall examination of regulatory agencies.   ''What the Amex-Chicago Board joint-access arrangement did was speed up an irreversible process that began with the opening of the financial futures markets in Chicago more than a decade ago,'' said Thomas A. Russo, partner in the Wall Street law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. ''That was the the first major crack in the thick walls that once separated the securities, commodities and money markets.''

headline: IN HEAT AND DIRT, CREWS FIX CABLES
abstract: All over the 12-block area of midtown affected by the Consolidated Edison blackout, workmen poked their heads out of manholes, coated with grime and grease.   The power failure Wednesday morning had been mechanical; it was men who would have to bring back the light.   From 30th to 42d Street in the garment district, hundreds of Con Edison workers fanned out yesterday to join the electrical cables that would return power to the area. Dirty, Wet and Stifling    ''It's at least 120 degrees down here,'' said Albert Tallini, stroking a soldering iron across two cables he was splicing together. ''It's dirty here. It's wet. My shirt is sticking to my skin. But this is the only way to get the power back.''

headline: Chilean Police Seize 6 In Clash With Students
abstract: The police clashed today with a group of about 150 students who marched out of memorial services for the Nobel Prize-winning poet Pablo Neruda shouting slogans against the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet.   At least six people were arrested.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Telephone and Telegraph Co.  announced that four of its digital transmission services would be marketed as Accunet Digital Services.     * Cellu-Craft Inc., New Hyde Park, L.I., said its board had approved in principle an offer of $9 a share from a private group led by management and a unit of Merrill Lynch; Merrill Lynch has also acquired an option to purchase 58 percent of the company from certain holders.

headline: Rescuer of BL Set For Computer Task
abstract: Sir Michael Edwardes, the diminutive 52-year-old former chairman of BL P.L.C. who will become chairman of International Computers Ltd., has made clear in his autobiography that the public's image of his work interests him as much as the work itself.   Sir Michael presided over BL, formerly British Leyland Ltd., during a time of severe cutbacks, and helped make the company viable again, despite the criticism that he was overly harsh with the union.   ''I know that the average worker feels I have done a reasonable job, for he tells me this quite spontaneously when I go around BL factories,'' Sir Michael said in his book, ''Back From the Brink.'' He adds, ''But it is the public image that matters when it comes to selling the company's products, and my image was magnified out of all proportion by the media as 'the man who took on the unions.' ''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Japan Machine Orders
abstract: Japanese machinery orders, excluding shipping, fell 30.2 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted $2.02 billion, from $2.89 billion in June, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

headline: NICARAGUA REBELS SAID TO STEP UP COMBAT ACTIVITY
abstract: Insurgents fighting the Nicaraguan Government have stepped up their activity in the last week, mounting at least eight attacks over a wide area of northern Nicaragua and inflicting scores of casualties, according to Government officials.    Nicaraguan officials and diplomats say they believe that as many as 2,000 insurgents have entered Nicaragua from bases in Honduras this month. The Defense Ministry issued a statement today asserting that the country was facing ''a new escalation of aggression.''   Defense Minister Humberto Ortega told reporters over the weekend that the military situation had become ''difficult.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Toyota Profit $829 Million TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP) - The   Toyota Motor Corporation,   Japan's top auto maker, said   today that it earned $829 million in its fiscal year ended   June 30 on sales of $20.14 billion.

headline: HOW TO SPOT THE TURNAROUND STOCKS
abstract: IN this age of last-minute debt rescheduling, corporate turnaround artists and Government loan guarantees, it should be no surprise that companies like Chrysler are alive - indeed, are thriving. But who would have thought that Chrysler's stock, written off by analysts as a dog in 1981 after trading as low as $3, would rise from the dead - it closed at $25.50 on Friday - and become one of Wall Street's biggest winners this year?   Or consider International Harvester, the troubled maker of farm machinery and construction equipment. In August 1981, the prognosis on Wall Street was that Harvester might not survive the year. Negotiations with lenders, however, enabled the company to carry on. Since then, its stock has risen from a low of $2.75 last year to $8.88 now.

headline: CRACKING A SWISS BANK'S CODE
abstract: The possible breaching of the venerable Swiss system of bank-account codes, apparently through the use of high-powered computers, has led to a sharp exchange between the French Government and a leading Swiss bank.   The State Secretary for the Budget, Henri Emmanuelli, hinted today that the Government had broken the coding of accounts of a major bank and had discovered the identity of thousands of French citizens who had smuggled money into Switzerland.   But a spokesman for Union des Banques Suisse, the bank involved, denied that any such breach had occurred. He suggested that the French Government was bluffing in a bid to frighten citizens into confessing to smuggling, in return for a promise of lenient treatment.

headline: Sellers and Buyers Differ on Media Time
abstract: The sellers and buyers of media time seem to be looking at entirely different pictures, according to a recent survey of 900 spot television advertisers and 100 sellers of broadcast time by Vitt Media International, a media planning and buying service.

headline: Swiss Intercept Airliner
abstract: Two Swiss Air Force planes intercepted a Bulgarian civilian airliner today that had entered Swiss airspace without notification. An air force spokesman said an F-15 jet fighter and a Mirage reconnaissance jet intercepted the Bulgarian TU-134 airliner.

headline: U.S. Steel Plans 4,000 Job Cuts
abstract: After two weeks of rumors, the United States Steel Corporation officially announced that it would dismiss 4,000, or approximately one-fourth, of its white-collar employees in steel and related jobs.    A spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based steelmaker, the nation's largest, said the ''extraordinary worldwide decline in steel markets'' was responsible for these layoffs of supervisory, professional, technical and other non-union employees.

headline: Chinese Preparing Campaign To Remove Party's 'Leftists'
abstract: The Communist Party's Central Committee will convene before Oct. 11 to begin a campaign to remove ''leftists'' who have resisted change, Hu Yaobang, the party's General Secretary, said today.   Mr. Hu told a delegation from the Socialist Party of Japan that the party would discuss the forthcoming three- year purification of the 40 million- member party and issue a public document about it.

headline: THE DIRKS RULING: INSIDERS' LICENSE?
abstract: At a track meet in 1981, Barry Switzer, the head football coach of the University of Oklahoma, overheard a conversation about the impending liquidation of Phoenix Resources, an oil and gas company. On the basis of the information, Mr. Switzer and several friends bought stock in the company - and together made a profit of $605,674 when the company actually announced its intent to liquidate.   The Securities and Exchange Commmission sued Mr. Switzer in Federal District Court in Oklahoma City last February, charging that he had violated the agency's rules against trading on the basis of insider information. The action is still pending, but Mr. Switzer has denied the charges and is defending the suit.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American States Insurance Co., Indianapolis, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lincoln National Corp., said it proposed to buy all the outstanding shares of American States Life Insurance Co.; American States Insurance currently owns 68.5 percent of American States Life.     * E. F. Hutton Group Inc.  has purchased a majority stake in the common stock of S-A-L Inc., the newly formed holding company of Summit Airlines Inc; terms were not disclosed.

headline: Data General Job
abstract: The Data General Corporation said it had been awarded an eight-year contract by the Department of Agriculture to provide a nationwide network of office automation and management systems for the department's Forest Service. During the first three years of the contract, the Forest Service has the option to purchase or lease more than 800 systems with an average hardware value of about $85,000 each. The total hardware system value of the first three years would be more than $70 million if all systems were purchased, it said.

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 3, 1983
abstract: Markets   The U.S. intervened in world currency markets for the third trading day in a row in an effort to slow the rise of the dollar. It was joined by West Germany, Japan, Switzerland and France. While the coordinated effort may cost Washington as much as $1 billion, some experts said, it could still fail to curb the dollar, which has been pushed upward mainly by rising U.S. interest rates. (Page A1.) The dollar fell slightly in foreign currency trading. Gold prices, meanwhile, rose $2 an ounce, to $414 in New York. (D5.)    Long-term interest rates stabilized as the Treasury completed the first part of a three-part, $15.75 billion financing. It sold $6.5 billion of new 11 3/8 percent, three-year notes at an average yield of 11.43 percent. The yield, the highest since August 1982, was further evidence that investors and securities dealers are concerned about the direction of interest rates. (D1.)

headline: U.S. UNIT OF VW IN BLACK
abstract: Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, reported today that its United States unit made a ''slight profit'' in the first half of 1983, and said it was under no pressure to conclude a cooperation agreement with the Chrysler Corporation.   Carl H. Hahn, VW's chairman, said at the company's annual shareholder meeting that the ailing United States unit, which lost $153 million in 1982, reached the ''profit threshold'' in this year's first six months, partly because of the strong United States dollar.

headline: Hauser to Acquire A Cable Company
abstract: Hauser Communications Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire for more than $30 million the assets of the Arlington Telecommunications Corporation, a cable communications company serving about 27,000 subscribers in Arlington, Va.   The acquisition will be made by Arlington Cable Partners, a company owned by affiliates of Hauser Communications Inc. and Odyssey Partners, a New York investment partnership composed of former principals of the brokerage operations of Oppenheimer & Company.   Hauser Communications was formed by Gustave M. Hauser, formerly chairman and chief executive of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., a joint venture of Warner Communications and the American Express Company.

headline: LE MONDE STRUGGLING TO STEM LOSSES
abstract: Le Monde, the most influential French newspaper, has started thinking about new techniques to win and hold readers after a serious drop in circulation and the largest operating loss in its history.   In a letter to the newspaper's employees last month, Andre Laurens, Le Monde's director, reported a deficit of $2.36 million in 1982 and the loss of 40,000 readers, or about 9 percent of its paid circulation. These setbacks came on top of a lesser drop in circulation in 1981.   With a further decline in revenue and a circulation loss of about 3 percent expected this year, Mr. Laurens has proposed cutbacks that he says will save about $600,000.

headline: Vatican Sets Up Phone For Kidnapper of Girl
abstract: The Vatican said tonight that it had set up a special telephone line so that a man who said he kidnapped a teen-age girl could call the Vatican's Secretary of State to arrange her release.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Common Stock   * A&M Food Services, a Tulsa, Okla., company that operates 82 Pizza Huts, made its initial public offering of 1.1 million shares at $6.50 a share, through Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood.     * Coast R.V. Inc., a wholesale distributor of recreational vehicle replacement parts, filed an initial public offering of 930,000 shares, with 230,000 to be sold by present shareholders, through First Wilshire Securities Management.     * CSX Corp.  plans to file an offering of common stock soon, with the number of shares and offering date subject to market conditions, and use the proceeds to retire part of the debt incurred in its recent acquisition of Texas Gas Resources Corp. stock.

headline: Chilean Copper Union Meets Interior Minister
abstract: Leaders of the Copper Workers Confederation, seeking the release from jail of their union's president and the rehiring of 700 strikers dismissed by the Government mining company, met today with the Interior Minister.   The 90-minute meeting between the six union directors and Interior Minister Enrique Montero Marx was the first between the Government and labor leaders since a series of strikes and protests last month against the Government of President Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Bond Rates Set By Loan Bank
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank yesterday announced the interest rates for a three-part, $1.395 billion financing.  The $550 million of bonds due July 27, 1987, are offered with a 11.35 percent yield; the $320 million due Nov. 27, 1989, yield 11.55 percent, and the $525 million due July 26, 1993, yield 11.7 percent.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBELS FAIL IN EFFORT TO SEIZE LARGE TOWN IN THE NORTH
abstract: The largest group of guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government said today that it had failed in an attempt to seize a large town in northern Nicaragua, but that it had taken three outlying areas.   Edgar Chamorro Coronel, a director of the group, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, said here that the guerrillas had been unsuccessful in their attempt to seize the town of Ocotal, but had taken the three nearby neighborhoods.   Mr. Chamorro said that the field commander in charge of the attack on Ocotal had reported that the number of Nicaraguan Government defenders was three times greater than the guerrillas had expected. He said the rebels withdrew from Ocotal to assault ''other objectives in the area'' late this morning. He also said that fighting was going on in the towns of Mozonte, Achuapa and Ciudad Antigua, all of which are in northern Nicaragua.

headline: Plessey in Deal With Mitsubishi
abstract: -The Plessey Company Ltd. said its Stromberg-Carlson Corporation subsidiary and the Mitsubishi International Corporation had agreed in principle to form a joint venture company to market cellular mobile telephone systems in the United States.   The joint venture's cellular system, named Astromet, will use Stromberg- Carlson's digital switching technology and Mitsubishi's radio frequency equipment, mobile telephone transceiver and data links. Mitsubishi International is the United States unit of the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan.

headline: Strike at Peugeot Unit
abstract: Unions halted production at Automobiles Talbot's plant west of Paris because of plans by the parent company, Peugeot S.A., to eliminate 8,000 jobs within the group. The two unions called for full strikes at Peugeot and Talbot factories on Thursday, when the group will announce details of the cutbacks.  Peugeot, which has lost $900 million in three years as a result of strikes and shrinking markets, has told unions and the Government that it wants to reduce its work force by 10 percent.

headline: Bristol-Myers Plans Big Coupon Campaign
abstract: Bristol-Myers is going to dump 43 million cents-off coupons into the homes of America on behalf of Extra Strength Datril which, if cashed, would cost it $64.5 million.   The drop will be accomplished via a full-page ad in John Blair Marketing's Sunday newspaper insert on Aug. 21.

headline: CHADIANS MOP UP AROUND 2 DESERT OUTPOSTS
abstract: The fighting in northeastern Chad has ceased, a Government spokesman said today, but ''cleanup operations'' are continuing just north of two desert outposts.    Information Minister Mahamat Soumaila repeated earlier assertions that 3,000 Libyan-backed rebels on Friday attacked Government positions near Oum Chalouba and Kalait, about 500 miles northeast of here.   He said 800 rebels had been killed and 600 taken prisoner. Among those killed or captured, he said, were a large number of Sudanese who had worked in Libya and had been recruited into Libya's Islamic Legion.

headline: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRESIDENT ACCUSES SOVIET ON '62 PACT
abstract: President Reagan contended today that the Soviet Union and Cuba had repeatedly violated a 1962 agreement that ended the Cuban missile crisis by continuing to ship ''offensive weapons'' into the American hemisphere.    ''As far as I'm concerned, that agreement has been abrogated many times by the Soviet Union and Cuba in the bringing in of what can only be considered offensive weapons, not defensive, there,'' the President said to a group of reporters.   His spokesman, Larry Speakes, later said the President was referring to violations of the ''spirit of the agreement,'' an agreement that had essentially focused on nuclear weapons. Mr. Speakes did not cite specific violations, but said that the United States has no plans to abrogate its half of the agreement, which was not to invade Cuba.   Mr. Reagan gave his interpretation of the agreement in response to a question about Soviet-Cuban activity in the hemisphere. The 1962 settlement was never agreed to in writing by President Kennedy and Prime Minister Nikita S. Khrushchev or their representatives. The absence of a document and the ambiguity of the meaning of ''offensive'' has led to continuing disputes in the United States Government and with the Soviet Union. Nevertheless, it has been generally agreed that the terms applied only to nuclear weapons or weapons with a nuclear capacity.

headline: Advertising; Equitable's Assignment For D'Arcy
abstract: AFTER an extensive search for an agency to handle its big corporate advertising campaign, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has decided on D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York. Plans call for a budget of $12 million.   The other finalist was Benton & Bowles.  Not involved in the assignment are the large insurance company's projects at Isidore & Paulson, which ''until further notice'' will remain where they are, according to Mel Gregory, senior vice president, corporate communications, of Equitable.

headline: Saudis Lower Price of Gas
abstract: Petromin, Saudi Arabia's state-run oil company, has told Japanese importers that it cut its price for liquefied petroleum gas by $10 a ton, to $270, effective Aug. 1, the Nippon Petroleum Gas Company said today.

headline: MATTEL EXPECTS TO POST LARGE LOSS
abstract: Just three years after it ventured beyond toys to compete in the promising video game and home computer markets, Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its electronics division would lead the company to a pretax loss of ''significantly more than $100 million'' for the first half of 1983.   Mattel will apparently be the third home electronics manufacturer to report second-quarter losses in excess of the worst predictions of industry analysts. On Thursday, Warner Communications reported that it had lost $283 million in the quarter because of poor performance in its Atari unit, and on Friday, Texas Instruments said it had lost $119 million in the same period.   All three companies have been caught in a spiral of price cutting and sharply diminished sales in what a year ago was a booming home entertainment market, consisting mostly of video games and lowpriced computers.

headline: BET THE PONIES: BEFORE OR AFTER THE RACE
abstract: IN the world of speculative investments, few can match the glitter - or the risk - of thoroughbred horses. ''It's a tough game, but wheni t's good there's nothing like it,'' says W. Cothran Campbell, p resident of Dogwood Farm Inc. in Atlanta.   The regal prices brought at a recent yearling sale in Keeneland, Ky., by descendants of horses that made racing the sport of kings show that it is also an expensive undertaking.   At the sale, a yearling sired by the greatest living stallion, Northern Dancer, went for $10.2 million. And the average price of all 301 yearlings sold was just over $500,000.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Fund Backs Grenada Loan    WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) - The International Monetary Fund today approved a $14.1 million loan for the leftist Government of Grenada despite vigorous opposition from the Reagan Administration.   An official announcement by the I.M.F. made no mention of the United States position, but Government sources said Washington opposed the loan to the Caribbean island-nation on economic grounds.   The United States has about 20 percent of the voting power in the fund, but does not have veto power unless other countries go along with its position.

headline: Unity Liquidation
abstract: The Unity Buying Service Company, a mail order company based in Hicksville, L.I., said that its board had adopted a plan to liquidate the company and distribute all the cash generated to its shareholders. Unity said that it intends to make a public offering of substantially all the shares of its Mail Marketing and Fulfillment subsidiary and a similar offering or a private sale of another subsidiary, Beautiful Visions Inc. It also said it would sell off its factory buying club, its distribution complex in Georgia and its remaining assets.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Ryland Acceptance Corp.  filed an offering of $250 million of G.N.M.A.- collateralized bonds, series A, due in 2013.     *  Sperry Corp.  filed a shelf registration for $250 million of debentures.     *  Tenneco Inc.  filed an offering of $300 million of debt securities.

headline: Voice of America Is Telling Russians of Plane Incident
abstract: The Voice of America is increasing broadcasts to the Soviet Union in an effort to get the story out about the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Russian warplane, a spokesman said today.   The spokesman for the United States Information Agency, which runs Voice of America, said the radio station began adding 56 transmitter hours of broadcasting daily after the crisis began.   ''The Soviets are giving their own people even less than they are giving us,'' Charles Z. Wick, the U.S.I.A. director, said.

headline: Jews Who Reject Israel Inflame Jerusalem Area
abstract: The police set up a special task force today to enforce law and order in the Mea Shearim quarter of Jerusalem, the bastion of Jewish religious militants who reject the state of Israel as a heresy.   The move followed nightly riots this week in which the police and demonstrators reportedly used tear gar.

headline: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRAZILIAN SEEKING NEW LOANS IN U.S.
abstract: The governor of the central bank of Brazil, Carlos Langoni, flew to the United States last night to seek $3.6 billion in fresh loans to help the country remain current in its debt payments, a spokesman for the central bank said yesterday.   The Brazilian Government did not say from whom it would seek the new loans. But the fact that Washington was Mr. Langoni's first stop suggested that the central bank head may seek part of the $3.6 billion from the United States Government and multilateral lending institutions before meeting with commercial bank officials in New York.   The announcement that Mr. Langoni would visit the United States came less than 24 hours after Brazil reached a tentative agreement with the International Monetary Fund on the terms of a new and tougher austerity program. That paved the way for the resumption of credit disbursements from both the I.M.F. and commercial banks.

headline: CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GRAIN SALES TO SOVIET INCREASING
abstract: The Soviet Union has bought more grain from the United States - 250,000 metric tons of wheat and 125,000 tons of corn - for delivery in 1983-84 under terms of a long-term agreement signed last month, according to the Agriculture Department.   That pushed the estimated value of Moscow's purchases since Sept. 1 - the day a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean jetliner - to more than a half billion dollars.   At current grain prices at the farm, the latest sales would be worth about $49 million. Sales so far under the new agreement are worth an estimated $575 million, according to current prevailing prices.

headline: U.S. Fighters Intercept Two Libyan MIG's
abstract: American F-14 fighters from the aircraft carrier Eisenhower intercepted two Libyan MIG-23's Wednesday when they came within 108 miles of the vessel in the Mediterranean, the Pentagon said today.   A spokesman, Henry Catto, said the interception occurred in international waters 25 miles off the Libyan coast.

headline: Paris Reports Sending More Arms to Chad
abstract: French officials said today that the Government had delivered 200 tons of military equipment to Chad since rebel forces captured a town in the north of the country last week.

headline: Hotel Check-In Computerized
abstract: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation today introduced a computer terminal that allows guests to check in and out of its hotels by using a credit card. ''Response from our guests has been very positive,'' Pat Foley, Hyatt Hotels president, told a news conference.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Two years ago, economic relations between the United States and Canada had become muddy at best and stingingly acrimonious at worst.   Americans sternly criticized the Canadian Government's nationalist moves to discriminate against foreign oil companies, tighten restrictions on foreign investment and adopt an overall industrial policy that seemed to further political aims at the expense of foreign economic interests.   For its part, Ottawa viewed these policies as something of a lastditch attempt to reverse American dominance of several of the nation's key economic sectors.   Foreigners, principally Americans, control 40 percent of Canadian mining; by contrast, foreigners control just 5 percent of mining in the United States. When the National Energy Plan was launched, foreigners controlled 65 percent of Canada's oil and gas industry as against 18 percent in the United States.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Chrysler Canada Ltd. said it had agreed to import and distribute vehicles made by Automobiles Peugeot of France, and that beginning Oct.1, it would have exclusive distribution rights.   * General Electric Co. said it had signed contracts totaling $23.6 million to supply two gas turbines and accessory equipment and services for cogeneration facilities in Norway and the Netherlands.   * General Motors of Canada said it had deferred the conversion of its Oshawa, Ontario, full-sized car assembly plant to the production of front-wheel-drive, midsize vehicles because of continuing consumer demand for full-size cars.

headline: PHILIPS CLOSE TO RAISING ITS INTEREST IN GRUNDIG
abstract: N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken, the giant Dutch electrical products group, is close to an agreement to increase its share of Grundig A.G., West Germany's largest home electronics company, officials of both companies said today.    The disclosure comes about six months after the French Government-controlled Thomson-Brandt Company acquired 75 percent of Telefunken, the home electronics unit of Germany's ailing AEG-Telefunken. A Thomson-Brandt bid for Grundig had been rejected by the Bonn antitrust office.

headline: Heller to Sell American National to First Chicago
abstract: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its American National Corporation, owner of the American National Bank and Trust Company, to the First Chicago Corporation, owner of the First National Bank of Chicago, for $275 million.   The sale would leave the Heller organization with an estimated $490 million in cash or cash equivalents but no operating companies. It would also narrow the gap between Chicago's two largest banks.

headline: Factory Orders Off 1.7% in July
abstract: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in July, only the second decline since they hit a low during the recession last October, the Commerce Department said today.   The decline, which followed a 5.1 percent surge in June, reflected a falloff in durable goods. Orders for these ''big ticket'' items fell 3.5 percent, after climbing 7.6 percent in June and 1.6 percent in May, the department added.

headline: Harris Bankcorp Seeks 4 Banks
abstract: Harris Bankcorp, involved in talks about its own acquisition by a banking company, said it had signed letters of intent to acquire four Chicago- area banks for $38.6 million.

headline: TRADERS REACT TO MONEY DATA
abstract: For several years the Federal Reserve has warned against predicting changes in Fed monetary policy on the basis of weekly money supply data, which it says ''are highly volatile and subject to revision.'' For just as many years traders, economists and investors have ignored the Fed's advice by treating each weekly money supply announcement as a major event.    The credit markets' focus on money supply data was especially evident in August when the Friday afternoon announcements were the catalyst for several major price changes.   Last Friday, for example, Treasury bond prices rose about 1 3/8 points after the Fed reported a $1.4 billion decline in the basic money supply instead of the increase of $500 million to $1 billion that had been widely forecast. On Aug. 26 bond prices fell almost a point following a less-than-expected $200 million decline in M-1, and on Aug. 19 bond prices rose almost 2 points after a suprising $500 million decline in M-1.

headline: SOME RELIEF FOR FATHER OF VICTIM
abstract: The father of Mary Jane Hendrie, the first victim of Flight 7 to be positively identified, expressed gratitude today that doubts about the 25-year-old woman's fate had been dispelled.   ''I didn't really hold much hope,'' Thomas Hendrie, chief laboratory technician at Plummer Hospital in Sault Ste.

headline: U.S. TAKES A STEP TO PROMPT POLES TO FREE PRISONERS
abstract: The United States has told Poland that it would take steps to relax some of the sanctions imposed at the time martial law was declared in 1981 if Warsaw released a significant number of political prisoners, it was reported today.   This message was conveyed to Poland's charge d'affaires, Zdzislaw Ludwiczak, by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, last week, in the most substantive meeting between the two sides in many months. The report did not originate with the Administration, but was confirmed by Administration officials today.   Hoping to lend encouragement to Polish authorities to carry out some liberalizing steps in coming weeks, the Reagan Administration told the Poles that if substantial numbers of political prisoners were released, the United States would agree to join with other Western nations, members of the so-called Paris Club, on July 29 to consider rescheduling Poland's outstanding debt to Western nations, thereby allowing Poland to be eligible again for Western loans.

headline: Grumman-Egypt
abstract: The Grumman Corporation said the Government of Egypt had signed letters of acceptance to purchase for $465 million two E-2C Hawkeye Airborne Early Warning System aircraft.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; RERUNS PAY PRODUCERS' BILLS
abstract: THIS month, the Federal Communications Commission issued   a tentative decision that will insure the ABC, CBS and NBC networks' total monopolization of the television marketplace.  Under current F.C.C. regulations, the networks are prohibited from securing any financial interest or syndication rights in programs produced by companies such as MTM Enterprises, Lorimar, Tandem and Spelling Productions. Although the networks obtain the license to air the shows twice, the production companies own them and control their use afterward.  But the F.C.C.'s so-called ''compromise'' position would give the networks the right to obtain 100 percent financial ownership and total creative control of the programs produced by independent companies. That means that once a network obtains the right to air an independently produced program, it also may obtain - without any further payment to the producer - the right to syndicate it, or sell it in the form of reruns.

headline: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A TENTATIVE ACCORD IS REPORTED AT THE EAST-WEST PARLEY IN MADRID
abstract: Delegations from East and West reportedly reached tentative agreement here today on a proposed final document for the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Diplomats said the development brought nearly three years of often-deadlocked talks on detente close to an end.   The draft reportedly would provide for both a follow-up meeting on human rights performance and a conference on European disarmament.  The Soviet Union has been urging such a disarament conference since the Madrid meetings opened in November 1980 to review compliance with the human rights and economic provisions of the accords signed by representatives of 35 Governments in Helsinki, Finland, in 1975.  Inclusion of a call in the final document for a follow-up meeting on human rights performance was insisted upon by the West.

headline: ...ON INSIDER TRADING AND THE S.E.C.; A CALL FOR STRONGER DETERRENTS
abstract: INJURY results from deception and fraud. There is no harmless d eception. Trading on material nonpublic information is both d eception and fraud. Simply put, it is stealing. The fact that it is a ccomplished in a professional environment without broken windows andp hysical abuse does not make it harmless.  Insider trading jeopardizes the integrity of our marketplace. Our capital markets are broad, efficient and liquid largely because of the precept of fairness. Investors depend upon this fairness. Without it, who is to know what savers would seek as alternative investments?

headline: Detroit's Ren Cen
abstract: To the Business Editor: Your article on the causes and effects of the Renaissance Center's failure to revive Detroit is certainly valid (''The Renaissance Center: Ford's Costly and Failing Bid to Revive Detroit,'' July 3).  But perhaps another major reason for its demise is that architecturally, in concept, the complex was ill-conceived.

headline: Chairman Reappointed By British National Oil
abstract: Lord Croham, 65, has been reappointed to a two-year term as part- time nonexecutive chairman of the state-owned British National Oil Corporation, beginning Nov. 1. He was first appointed to the post in 1982 and had previously been part-time deputy chairman since 1978, two years after the formation of the organization on Jan. 1, 1976.   Lord Croham's appointment in 1982 was in connection with the privatization of Britoil, which considerably changed the role of the British National Oil Corporation. The exploration, production and development activities were turned over to Britoil, a new company, and the British National Oil Corporation was left primarily as an oil trading organization.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Your Money; Certificates as An Alternative
abstract: SINCE the creation last December of bank money market deposit accounts, some $400 billion has flowed into these liquid short-term accounts. Billions of dollars more are invested in similar, but uninsured, money market funds offered by brokerage firms and mutual fund organizations.   Over the last year or so, though, interest rates have declined sharply. Just this week, interest rates for bank money market deposit accounts, which had been higher than money market funds, declined to the same relatively low level as the money fund rates.

headline: Nkomo Says He Plans A Return to Zimbabwe
abstract: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwe opposition leader, said today that he would fly home Monday, ending five months of self-imposed exile in Britain.   Mr. Nkomo, who said on his arrival in London in March that Prime Minister Robert Mugabe had ordered him killed, said in a press statement that he would attend a session of Parliament in Harare on Wednesday.

headline: A LIMPING WARNER AMEX
abstract: When Hurricane Alicia ripped through Houston last month, it knocked out service of the city's new cable television system for a week. That was just one of a series of devastations to the Warner Amex system and, in its customers' view, the most forgivable; the other disasters have all been man-made. ''If I were God,'' said Drew Lewis, chairman and chief executive officer of Warner Amex Cable Communications, in an interview last week, ''I wouldn't have any problems.''   As it is, however, the former Transportation Secretary has problems aplenty. And while Mr. Lewis and many analysts believe the long-term prognosis is favorable, the troubles of Warner Amex, the joint venture by Warner Communications and American Express, are immense.

headline: Advertising; 3M's Goal Of Leading In Video
abstract: WITH an eye on an exploding market and its trophy case sporting a brand-new Emmy for pioneering work in developing videotape, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company is preparing to outspend all its competition on advertising.   The goal is to establish in consumers' minds that 3M's Scotch brand is the leader in consumer video cassettes, even though current sales might not justify such a claim.   The advertising theme line will be ''The world watches Scotch.'' It was created by Grey Advertising, which in January replaced Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Minneapolis, on the account.

headline: TWO ROCKETS FIRED FROM JORDAN HIT NEAR AN ISRAELI TOWN IN GALILEE
abstract: Two rockets fired from Jordanian territory exploded in the Jordan Valley Sunday night, the Israeli Army announced today. There were no casualties and no damage.   The Soviet-built Katyusha rockets were the first to fall on Israeli territory since the initial days of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last year and the first to be fired at Israel from Jordan in two years. The announcement said the Israeli Army ''takes a very grave view of this incident of firing from Jordanian territory.''

headline: 5 Executives Sentenced In Italian Dioxin Case
abstract: A court sentenced five former chemical plant executives to prison today for their role in an explosion that released poisonous dioxin that killed thousands of animals and caused severe skin diseases in children.   Four defendants were found guilty of willful failure to prevent the explosion in Seveso on July 10, 1976, which sent a cloud of dioxin over a seven-square-mile area.

headline: CASTRO PROPOSES ACCORD TO CURB ARMS TO LATINS
abstract: Fidel Castro says Cuba will halt military aid to Nicaragua if an agreement is reached for all countries to stop sending arms and advisers to Central America.   In response to Mr. Castro's remarks, which were broadcast on American television today, President Reagan said he was willing to give Mr. Castro ''the benefit of the doubt'' in any negotiations.   But Administration officials stressed that the United States could not accept any agreement for withdrawal of foreign military forces from Central America unless the agreement was ''under fully verifiable and reciprocal conditions.'' Curb on Advisers and Arms   Mr. Castro made his remarks Thursday night in an interview with reporters. Speaking through an interpreter, he said: ''If there were to be an agreement among all the parties involved about withdrawing all the advisers, we would be willing to support such a settlement.  If an agreement were reached on the basis of the cessation of sending weapons to any state of Central America we would be willing to abide by it.''

headline: Occidental Unit
