abstract: In line with its diversification policy, the Ford Motor Company has agreed to acquire the Parker division of the Occidental Chemical Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash. The division, which manufactures metal surface treating products, has headquarters in Madison Heights, Mich., and accounted for less than 10 percent of Occidental Chemical's $2 billion in sales last year. Occidental Chemical, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, also said that George B. Berry, vice president and general manager of Occidental's plating systems division, would head a management group buying out the metal plating operation, which has headquarters at Warren, Mich.

headline: NEARLY 600 BANKS ARE IN TROUBLE OVER BAD LOANS, REGULATORS SAY
abstract: Almost 600 banks are in deep financial trouble because of bad loans in the wake of the 1981-82 recession, according to Federal bank regulators in Washington.   The number of banks on the problem list of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures deposits in commercial banks, has risen to 597, representing 4 percent of the nation's 14,835 banks.   This was the highest level ever recorded by the insurance agency, officials said, and it was far above the previous high, reached shortly after the 1973-75 recession, in November 1976. At that time, the level reached 385, or 2.6 percent of banks in the United States.

headline: E.E.C. Opens Finance Talks
abstract: The European Economic Community opened tough bargaining today on reshaping its troubled finances and on curbing expensive farm subsidies.

headline: Stocks Decline; Dow at 1,184.25, off 8.64
abstract: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday in continued slow trading, with some of the technology and retailing issues posting the largest losses.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout most of the session, closed down 8.64 points, to 1,184.25, its low for the day. The Dow was off 10.26 on Tuesday.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 1,000 to 556. Turnover on the Big Board amounted to 72.2 million shares, compared with 66.8 million shares the day before.

headline: Bank Rate Up Again
abstract: Interest rates offered by banks for money market deposit accounts rose again in the latest seven-day period, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.   The rates moved to 8.67 percent, from 8.62 percent last week and 8.58 percent the week before, The Monitor said.

headline: HIGH COST OF MILITARY PARTS
abstract: A thumb-sized plastic knob for the cockpit of the Navy's A-7 jet fighter can cost $400. A tiny machine screw for the Minuteman 2 missile can cost $36.77. A ring seal used in the engine of B-52 bombers can cost $2,020.50. And the Navy paid $435 for an ordinary hammer.    Selling spare parts to the military is a $13 billion-a-year business that Pentagon officials and defense-industry executives say is almost impossible to control. Perhaps more than in any other area of military purchasing, spare parts tend to be sold at huge markups under contracts that are signed without competitive bidding by manufacturers who are rewarded even if they deliver their products late.   But because the Defense Department buys them in small quantities and because they typically account for only a small fraction of a contractor's total sales, spare parts are rarely subject to close scrutiny. Officials say this means that rapid price increases are rarely challenged.

headline: Turkish Journalists Charged
abstract: The editor in chief and a columnist for the newspaper Turcuman were charged today with insulting the military Government and a prosecutor urged that they be jailed for up to eight years, officials said.

headline: THE TESTING OF MARTIN FELDSTEIN
abstract: WASHINGTON THE rumors began the moment Ronald Reagan won the election and they spread as the President-elect kept putting off the choice of chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers. Surely, the press and much of the academic community speculated, he would turn to Martin S. Feldstein, the 40-year-old Harvard professor who was president of the respected National Bureau of Economic Research. Mr. Feldstein was the best known of the younger generation of conservative economists that had emerged in the wake of the Democrats' failure to stem inflation or generate steady growth.   Mr. Feldstein says he had heard the rumors, but had not been approached. ''I didn't want to come,'' he recounts now. Taking the initiative, he wrote the White House asking not to be considered. But when Murray L. Weidenbaum, the man who did take the job,decided to return home to St. Louis in the summer of 1982, the White House called and Mr. Feldstein was ready - even eager.

headline: Soviet Line Status Report
abstract: Less than half the compressor stations on the Siberian-West Europe gas pipeline have been built, but the line is capable of delivering as contracted, the Minister of Oil and Gas Construction, Boris Shcherbina, said today.   He said at a news conference that the line was already capable of delivering nine billion cubic meters of gas a year whereas the contracts for deliveries to West Germany, France and other Western European customers called for only five billion cubic meters in 1984. Mr. Shcherbina said 17 out of a total of 40 compressor stations would be finished this year and the remainder in 1984.

headline: Mitsui Engine
abstract: Mitsui & Company said it had been licensed to produce and market everywhere except in North America and Western Europe a small, direct-injection diesel engine that can run on vegetable oil. Mitsui said the engine uses 25 percent less fuel than a conventional diesel engine, does not need a radiator or fan, and is suitable for use in cars and agricultural and construction machinery. It said it had acquired the license from Elko Lizenz G.m.b.H., a West German research institute.

headline: Extradition Treaty Is Signed By Officials of U.S. and Ireland
abstract: The United States and Ireland signed a treaty today to permit law enforcement authorities in each country to apprehend and extradite fugitives sought by the other country.

headline: Hitler 'Diaries' Ruling Upset
abstract: Gerd Heidemann, the journalist who sold the bogus Hitler diaries to the West German magazine Stern, was back in police custody today after the state prosecutor appealed a judge's decision Tuesday to release him. A higher court said Mr. Heidemann might tamper with evidence or leave the country.

headline: AN INDUSTRY FINDS GOLD IN GOLDFISH, AS NEW PET FOOD
abstract: They were cultivated as a science by China's Sung Dynasty. Louis XV gave them to his mistress as a love token. P. T. Barnum promoted them as freaks. And today there are more of them in the United States than there are people.   They are, of course, goldfish, those simple, slippery little orange things that have become the foundation for the nation's secretive, not-so-simple, not-so-little goldfish industry.

headline: Debt Ratings
abstract: *  Southern Corp.'s commercial paper rating has been lowered to prime-2 from prime-1 and its sinking fund debenture has been lowered to A3 from A2 by Moody's Investors Service.     *  Texaco-Cities Service Pipeline Co.'s commercial paper rating has been lowered to A1 from A1x by Standard & Poor's. The company has also been removed from Creditwatch. The reduction results from the sale of Cities Service's 50 percent ownership in the pipeline to Southland Corp., rated A-.

headline: Stocks Mixed; Metromedia Up by 30
abstract: Stock prices ended with mostly minor changes yesterday in slower trading. The main exception was Metromedia, which rebounded 30 points, to 425, after plunging 110 points earlier in the week.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, fell 1.59 points, to 1,174.39. In the previous two sessions, the key indicator rose almost 13 points after having been under heavy selling pressure in the previous two weeks because of risinginterest rates.

headline: No Headline
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: President Adds a Title In Dayton-Hudson Shift
abstract: A new chief executive was announced yesterday for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest general merchandise retailer, with 1,052 stores and sales approaching $6 billion annually.   He is Kenneth A. Macke, 44, who has been president and chief operating officer of the Minneapolis-based company. Mr. Macke, who will retain the title of president, succeeds William A. Andres, 57, who continues as chairman. Mr. Andres was elected chief executive in 1976, the first executive outside the Dayton family to head the company.   ''We have planned this transition with great care,'' Mr. Andres said in a statement. ''Our tradition at Dayton-Hudson is for the chief executive officer to step aside when the successor and management team is ready. And they are ready.''

headline: Mass Grave in Chad For 30 Soldiers Reported
abstract: Chad said today that it had found a mass grave of 30 Government soldiers who it said were put to death several days ago by rebel units acting on Libyan orders.

headline: FUEL PLANT CRITICIZED ON OUTLOOK
abstract: The General Accounting Office today reported that owners of the nation's first major synthetic fuels plant are understating their financial position.   The House subcommittee chairman who requested the report expressed concern that this was being done to win increased Government backing.   The report concluded that the parent companies that own the Great Plains coal gasification plant in North Dakota are not taking potential tax benefits into account when they say it now looks like the project will not make enough money to pay its own way in the early years.   The findings ''raise serious doubts about the extent of Great Plains' difficulties, if any at all,'' said the Congressman, Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma. His panel, the Environment, Energy and Natural Resources Subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee, is planning hearings on the matter when Congress returns from its summer recess next month.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL HEARS A TAPE IN RUSSIAN
abstract: Mrs. Kirkpatrick's speech, page A15.           UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 - A hushed and intent Security Council today heard 11 minutes of the tape-recorded voices that the United States said were those of the Soviet fighter pilots involved in the downing of a South Korean airliner with 269 on board.   On five television screens placed around the Council chamber, the Council's 15 members and dozens of other diplomats read the translation and listened to these climactic reports attributed to the Soviet fliers:   ''Now I will try a rocket,'' said the pilot of the SU-15 who United States officials say shot down the airliner.    ''Twelve to the target,'' a second pilot added.  This meant 12 kilometers, or about 7 miles.

headline: French Aerospace Unit
abstract: Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, the French state-owned aerospace company, today reported a one-third rise in sales in the first half of this year to 11.4 billion francs - about $1.42 billlion. The company also disclosed a substantial drop in its order book, which it said partly reflected the international economic recession. Orders on hand on June 30 were down 10 percent to 45 billion francs - about $5.6 billion - from a year earlier.

headline: CANADIAN BEERS MOVING SOUTH
abstract: To Americans, Canada is towering pine trees, majestic mountains and stalwart Mounties. At least that's the way Canadian beer makers see it, and they say it all adds up to big beer sales.   ''Let's face it, people drink images,'' says H. Hollis Brace, president of Molson Breweries International.   If so, Molson's image is certainly the strongest of the Canadian products. And with a flurry of award-winning radio ads and its first television campaign now in the works, that image seems likely to grow even stronger.

headline: Soviet Delegate Admits Error in Plane Incident
abstract: A Soviet delegate to an international conference here acknowledged today that Soviet pilots made a ''mistake'' in the downing of a South Korean airliner. He said they wrongly identified it as a military reconnaissance plane and wouldn't have shot it down if they had known it was a commercial flight.

headline: British Utility Proposals
abstract: The British Government is exploring several plans to inject private capital into the nation's gas and electric utilities, including a proposal to take the state-owned British Gas Corporation private, Government sources said today. The sources emphasized, however, that no detailed plans have yet been drawn up.

headline: Correction
abstract: The Personal Finance column of July 24 incorrectly stated the valuation date that may be used in calculating estate taxes. It may be any date within six months of death.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE LESS STRAIN IN SOVIET TIES
abstract: On the strength of some favorable developments in several fields of negotiation with Moscow, senior Administration officials say the decline in Soviet-American relations has stopped. But they are uncertain whether a genuinely positive trend has taken hold.   President Reagan set the mood after the announcement of a new Soviet- American grain agreement late in July when he was asked whether the accord signaled ''a thaw'' in the two countries' relations. ''I wouldn't use that word yet,'' he replied, taking a position between caution and hopefulness.

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Forms Public Relations Unit
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather, a major worldwide advertising agency that began to move aggressively into the public relations field in 1980 when O. & M. Public Relations was set up under Yustin Wallrapp, has formed a new unit to encompass all of its activities in that area and brought in a new man to run it.   Gerald T. Horton, 48, formerly senior vice president of public affairs and strategic planning of the Georgia Power Company, will be chairman of Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations Group.

headline: Bid for Northwest: No U.S. Bar Seen
abstract: The Williams Companies said the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department do not intend to block its offer for the Northwest Energy Company, a major pipeline company based in Salt Lake City.   Williams said the F.T.C. and the Justice Department had agreed to an early termination of the waiting period for the acquisition, as required under antitrust laws.

headline: NICARAGUANS REPORTED CAPTURED
abstract: Nicaraguan rebels captured 37 Government soldiers amid heav? fighting for control of a southern Nicaraguan town on Saturday and turned them over to Costa Rican authorities, a rebel spokesman said today.   The spokesman for the Revolutionary Democratic Alliance said in a state- ment issued in Costa Rica that Eden Pastora, the leader of the rebel group, led a column that captured the 37 prisoners in the Nicraguan province of Rio San Juan.

headline: Pope Makes New Appeal For Missing Girl
abstract: Pope John Paul II today made a new appeal for 15-year-old Emanuela Orlandi, the Vatican employee's daughter who disappeared last month and is believed to have been kidnapped.   After the weekly Angelus prayer, John Paul told 4,000 people at the papal summer residence in this town south of Rome, ''Once again I invite you to pray for this Emanuela Orlandi who is in the heart of all and constitutes, as in a family, our great preoccupation.''   Anonymous telephone calls from men claiming to have kidnapped Emanuela said she would be killed if Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk who wounded the Pope two years ago, was not released from jail by last Wednesday midnight. Mr. Agca was not freed and there has been no definite word on her fate.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 20, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 3 P.M. to open 38th session.

headline: Ghana Reported Ready To Reopen Togo Border
abstract: Ghana is ready to reopen its border with Togo, which was closed a year ago to prevent smuggling and currency trafficking, the Accra radio reported today.   The radio also said Togo was taking steps to reopen its side but did not make clear whether the two Governments were acting in concert nor did it give a timetable.   Ghana sealed its borders with Togo, the Ivory Coast and Upper Volta 12 months ago.

headline: Breaking Up
abstract: To the Business Editor:   We've been annoyed a long time over the A.T.& T. suit, but the self- righteous William G. McGowan has made us boil over (''Struggling to Make the Breakup Work,'' July 17). Who does he think he is, telling thousands of small shareholders of A.T.& T. that they should be ''punished'' because he happened to get a suit decided in his favor which will certainly enrich him? (    The article noted that, according to a decision issued before the A.T.& T. case was settled, A.T.& T. had violated antitrust laws. Mr. McGowan, chairman of MCI Communications, had commented, ''If you violate the law, the shareholders should be punished.''

headline: Advertising; McKesson May Drop Foremost
abstract: THE Foremost in the name of 150-year-old Foremost-McKesson Inc. was contributed by a prize bull belonging to James Cash Penney, founder of the retail chain.   Despite the romantic connection -and if the stockholders at their July 27 meeting see it the same as the management - Foremost will be forgotten, and full-page newspaper and business publication ads will proclaim the existence of the McKesson Corporation.   And that event in The Wall Street Journal, a Sunday issue of The New York Times, The San Francisco Examiner and Chronicle, Forbes and Barron's, according to Marvin L. Krasnansky, vice president, corporate relations, will mark the first real corporate advertising in the company's long, extremely colorful history. As it is, the effort will be less-than-exciting for people who like to read big numbers. The spending probably will not go over $300,000.

headline: 22 Die in Philippine Typhoon
abstract: A typhoon called Vera, which hit the Philippines after eight months of drought, left at least 22 people dead and about 24,000 homeless, relief agencies said today. The typhoon swept through the southern region of the main island of Luzon Thursday night and Friday.

headline: Car Sales Up In Model Year
abstract: Americans bought a record 2.37 million imported cars in the 1983 model year ending Friday, according to preliminary figures. Domestic auto makers also gained, with sales of 6.4 million, up more than 15 percent from 1982's depressed levels.

headline: TELEVISION'S 'BAD BOY' MAKES GOOD
abstract: ATLANTA HE is best known as ''Captain Courageous'' - the skipper of the yachts that won the 1977 America's Cup and the stormy 1979 Fastnet race, off the south of England, in which 15 other sailors drowned. At Fastnet last week, Ted Turner tried for another victory at sea. But the waters were calmer this year, and another boat came in first.   If Ted Turner thrives in stormy weather, it is not only at sea. While the rest of the cable industry is going through a shakeout, R. E. (Ted) Turner, television's bad boy, and his company, Turner Broadcasting System Inc., appear to be on the verge of turning a profit for the first time since 1978.   After losing $3.4 million last year on revenues of $165.6 million, TBS has reported a profit of $6.3 million for the first half of this year - roughly equivalent to its loss in the period a year ago - and is estimating a $20 million profit for 1983.

headline: Busy Peter Lynch
abstract: To the Business Editor: Peter Lynch (''The Man Behind the Magellan Fund,'' July 10) has a remarkable record over the past five years and he should be very proud. The record of which he should be most proud, and it should be submitted to the Guinness Book, is if he accomplishes his statement that ''I will probably visit over 400 (companies) in 1983.''

headline: Kenyans Vote For a New Parliament
abstract: Kenyans voted in general elections today to replace the Parliament dissolved by President Daniel arap Moi last June a year ahead of schedule to purge what he called disloyal elements.

headline: BARRY DILLER'S LATEST STARRING ROLE
abstract: ''IM learning new words,'' said Barry    Diller, and he listed a few: Laser   disks. Returns of books. Caps on salaries. NBA rules.   Mr. Diller, the chairman of the Paramount Pictures Corporation since 1974, is more comfortable with the peculiar vocabulary of motion pictures and television. But in the months since he became head of the newly formed leisure- time group of Gulf and Western Industries, Paramount's parent, he has been studying the lexicons of computers, publishing and sports - and of divestiture.

headline: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET IS SAID TO HAMPER SEARCH
abstract: The Defense Department's chief spokesman said today that American ships had heard signals from one of the two flight recorders on the Korean airliner shot down in the Sea of Japan but had been unable so far to recover them.   The spokesman, Benjamin Welles, also told reporters that the United States had protested to the Soviet Union that Soviet warships had harassed American ships in those waters and thus hampered the search for the flight recorders.   At the same time, the State Department spokesman, John Hughes, said the Soviet Union had promised to turn over ''objects and documents'' recovered from the airliner, which was shot down by a Soviet jet fighter on Sept. 1 with the loss of 269 lives.

headline: 5 Shot and 5 Others Hurt In Greek Political Melee
abstract: Five people were shot and five others injured with clubs and chains during political clashes in Kalamai, on the southern coast of Greece, Saturday night, the police reported today.

headline: Comsat Issuing Commercial Paper
abstract: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today that it would issue commercial paper for the first time early this month.

headline: Japanese Car Deal Possible
abstract: A high- level Japanese minister said today that the question of restraining auto exports to the United States ''is a completely clean slate,'' indicating that Japan may reconsider its decision not to renew the limits a fourth year.

headline: Toro Company Reports Profit
abstract: The Toro Company, citing the successful introduction of several new products, yesterday announced earnings of $320,000 in its fourth fiscal quarter ended July 29, in contrast to a loss of $100,000 in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The Minneapolis-based producer of lawn and maintenance, irrigation, and snow removal equipment said that sales in the latest three months rose 6.7 percent, to $54.1 million, from $50.7 million.

headline: 2 PAY-TV SERVICES MERGE
abstract: Two of the nation's leading pay- television services, Showtime and The Movie Channel, have been merged into a joint venture to be owned by Viacom International, Warner Communications and Warner Amex Cable Communications, it was announced yesterday.     The new venture is intended to offer more competition to Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, which dominates pay television. However, the partners said they intended to keep Showtime, a broad-based entertainment service, and The Movie Channel, an all-movie service, as separate entities.

headline: FOR 2 APARTHEID FOES, A SISTERHOOD OF SHARED FATE
abstract: Although they have encountered each other only once and come from political backgrounds that are now sometimes represented as being in conflict, Winnie Mandela and Mamphela Ramphele can be said to share a highly unusual kind of sisterhood.   The name of each of these two black women is inevitably mentioned in the same breath as that of a key political leader. Each of them has had to bear an almost unbearable loss. Each has been recognized as a significant political figure in her own right, not only by blacks but also by the white authorities who reserved a singular form of restriction for them, one that has left them with surprisingly similar perspectives on black politics.   That restriction was not only to silence them with what are called banning orders but also to banish them to obscure and impoverished rural communities, where they knew no one and where they would be isolated from the political milieus in which they had been effective.

headline: EUROPEAN PILOTS JOIN BAN ON MOSCOW
abstract: Thousands of commercial pilots in western Europe said today that they would join a 60-day boycott of scheduled flights to Moscow in retaliation for the Soviet Union's downing of a Korean Air Lines 747 jumbo jet.   British, Scandinavian, Dutch and French pilots heeded the call issued Tuesday by the governing board of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations that its 61,000 members join the boycott.    Federation officials in London said they had also been given assurances that Italian pilots will shortly announce their intention to join the boycott. And they said West German and Swiss pilots had expressed a desire to take part but were uncertain whether they had the legal right to refuse to fly if their governments opposed the move.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TURKEY'S GENERALS KEEP FOES OUT OF ELECTION
abstract: The military Government this week in effect barred conservative and social democratic parties from the parliamentary election Nov. 6, thereby excluding its opponents.    Only three moderate parties, led by politicians sympathetic to the military Government, had been declared eligible for the election when the deadline for approval passed on Wednesday.   Nearly three years after seizing power, the generals are preparing to return the country to civilian rule through the election, but it will apparently offer very limited choices. The conservative Nationalist Democracy Party led by Sturgut Sunalp, a retired general, received official endorsement last week with the announcement that Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu and four Cabinet ministers would run for Parliament on its ticket.

headline: Key Japanese Indicator Off
abstract: Japan's leading indicator of future economic activity fell to 66.7 in June from 79.2 in May, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, SEPT. 5, 1983
abstract: International Latin American debtor nations begin a meeting today to discuss their financial burdens, and people in the banking community see an improvement in the world debt crisis. They note lower interest rates, the imposition of harsh economic measures on debtor countries and rapid action by lending institutions. But risks remain, and economists are anxious about the next 12 months. (Page 31.)

headline: Senator Starts Fund for Kin
abstract: A $1 million fund for families of the 61 United States passengers killed in the shooting down of a Korean airliner has been started by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.Today the Senator asked the Internal Revenue Service to grant tax-exempt status to the fund so that contributions would be tax-deductible.

headline: OFFICIALS SEE LESS FRICTION WITH MEXICO
abstract: Differences between Mexico and the United States over President Reagan's Central American program are narrowing, Administration officials said today as they prepared for Mr. Reagan's visit Sunday with President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado.   Mr. Reagan intends to discuss his program of applying military and economic pressure in the region when he meets Mr. de la Madrid at La Paz in Baja California, according to senior Administration officials. The officials declined to predict whether the President would make substantial progress.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS PILOT TRANSCRIPT REVISION PROVES U.S. IS LYING
abstract: A Soviet news commentator said today that a revised transcript of exchanges between Soviet fighter pilots and their ground control ''totally shattered'' American allegations that the fighters gave no warning to a Korean Air Lines jetliner before shooting it down.   The commentary by Tass, the official press agency, said that the new tape transcript proved that as far as American efforts to lay the blame for the incident on the Soviet Union were concerned, ''All this hullabaloo, from beginning to end, is built on lies, on a crude, brazen distortion of facts.''   The commentary followed the release by the State Department on Sunday of a revised transcript that made three changes in the initial transcript of the Soviet conversations. The revised transcript included a new reference by one of the Soviet pilots to firing ''cannon bursts'' six minutes before he launched the missiles that shot the airliner down.

headline: SHULTZ SUPPORTS ISRAELI PULLBACK
abstract: Concluding three days of meetings with Israel's Foreign and Defense Ministers, Secretary of State George P.  Shultz said today that ''any notion'' that the pullback of Israeli forces in Lebanon ''is part of an effort to stay in Lebanon is totally wrong.''   Mr. Shultz, speaking to reporters outside the White House after Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Moshe Arens met with President Reagan, described the planned redeployment of Israeli forces to more secure positions in southern Lebanon as ''a step in the direction of total withdrawal.''   Mr. Shultz's comments, and those of other senior Administration officials, indicated that the United States accepts the Israeli pullback as inevitable and is abandoning its efforts to persuade Israel to reconsider or postpone the move.   President Reagan's new envoy to the Middle East, the White House deputy national security adviser Robert C. McFarlane, is to travel to the region this weekend to begin a new round of talks with Middle East leaders. Administration officials said Mr. McFarlane would probably stop in Syria as he continues the American effort to find a formula for the total withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.

headline: Tourists Leave Upper Volta
abstract: About 3,000 tourists, mostly French, were scheduled to begin leaving Ouagadougou, the capital of Upper Volta, today. A French airline official said clearance had been received for flights for the tourists, who have been stranded there since the coup Aug. 4.

headline: STATEMENT ON BEGIN
abstract: Following is the text of the Cabinet annnouncement read by Cabinet Secretary Dan Meridor today on Prime Minister Menachem Begin's intention to resign, as translated by The Associated Press:    At the Cabinet meeting held today, after a discussion of various subjects, the Prime Minister told the Cabinet of his intention to resign. Following his announcement, the ministers asked the Prime Minister to remain in his post and emphasized the state's improved political and security situation. All the ministers spoke and the meeting ended.

headline: French Chemical Gains
abstract: Output for the French chemical industry in the first half of 1983 rose 3 percent and sales increased about 12 percent, the French Chemical Industry Association said today. A survey of 22 French chemical companies showed that the rise was largely a result of exports, which increased 17.8 percent in the period.

headline: A.M.C. Loses $78.9 Million
abstract: The American Motors Corporation lost $78.9 million in the second quarter, its 13th consecutive quarterly loss, company officials said today.

headline: INDUSTRY USED 75.8% OF CAPACITY IN JULY
abstract: United States industry operated at 75.8 percent of capacity last month as manufacturers - particularly auto makers - put more of their long-idled production lines into action, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The report showed a rise of 1.2 percentage points in use of manufacturing, utility and mining facilities in July, bringing the operating rate to the highest level since the 77 percent of November 1981.   It was the eighth straight monthly advance since the operating rate hit a record low 69.6 percent last November during the trough of the recession, and the second largest of those gains. Only the advance of 1.3 percentage points in April was higher.

headline: Winter Wheat Harvest Is Seen as Near Record
abstract: The nation's winter wheat farmers, although idling nearly a fifth of their land, will harvest 1.94 billion bushels this year, the third-largest crop on record, the Agriculture Department said today.   It would be only 8 percent less than the record 2.11 billion bushels harvested last year and up 3 percent from the June forecast of 1.88 billion bushels.   The Agriculture Department's Crop Reporting Board attributed the large size of the crop to an unprecedented yield on the acreage that was planted. The average yield, estimated from July 1 field conditions, should be 40.7 bushels nationwide, 4.6 bushels higher than last year and 3.8 bushels above the 1979 record.

headline: Philadelphia Sale Of Notes Canceled
abstract: Philadelphia announced yesterday that it had canceled the sale of $150 million of temporary loan notes. It also said it was putting off a sale of $75 million of commercial paper that would have followed the note sale.

headline: REAGAN SEEKS JOINT RESEARCH
abstract: President Reagan asked Congress today to modify antitrust, patent and copyright law to encourage joint research and development ventures by corporations.   ''Cooperation is necessary if American industry is to compete internationally,'' the President declared in a message to Congress.   The proposals would protect fully disclosed joint ventures in research and development from private antitrust suits and from damage suits by the Government. Joint ventures are necessary, Administration officials contend, to conduct the immensely expensive research projects required to produce breathroughs in modern technology.

headline: Norton Simon Disclosures
abstract: Norton Simon Inc. disclosed yesterday that it had rejected a combined offer of $1.2 billion from Anderson, Clayton & Company and Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts before it accepted a $918 million takeover bid from Esmark Inc. last Thursday. It contended that the combined offer was uncertain.

headline: PATENTS; Patent Conference Set On Computerized Data
abstract: A conference with the European and Japanese Patent Offices will be held in Washington by the Patent and Trademark Office Oct. 17 to 19, according to Gerald J. Mossinghoff, a commissioner. He said the meeting would be an important step toward the goal of an international exchange of computerized data by 1990. The three agencies already have cooperative automation agreements.

headline: Start of Transition At Florida National
abstract: George C. Whitner, the president and chief executive of the Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., was named vice chairman yesterday, but he disclosed plans to retire by Jan. 1, 1985.   Mr. Whitner, who is 60 years old, gave up the post of chief executive to John D. Uible, the chairman of the bank holding company. Mr. Uible is 47.   E. Bruce Bower was named president and chief operating officer. He will continue as president and chief operating officer of the company's Florida National Bank. He is 42.

headline: South Africa Denies Fighting With Lesotho
abstract: South Africa today denied that its soldiers had taken part in fighting Sunday on the border with Lesotho.

headline: Toshiba-Korea Accord
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation has signed an agreement with the Korea Electronics Company to provide technical assistance for the production of bipolar linear integrated circuits, Toshiba said today. Toshiba owns 6.25 percent of Korea Electronics, a major South Korean producer of semiconductors. The agreement covers a line of integrated circuits designed mainly for audio and video equipment.

headline: Some Markets Closed
abstract: Stock, financial and commodity markets were closed for holidays yesterday in London and Hong Kong. As a result, tables for those markets do not appear in today's paper.

headline: Honduran Leader's Condition Is Grave After Heart Attacks
abstract: President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras had two heart attacks within 12 hours and is in ''grave'' but improving condition, doctors said today.   A group of American doctors sent by the Reagan Administration arrived today in the city of Comayagua, 60 miles northeast of Tegucigalpa, where Mr. Suazo is hospitalized, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

headline: GREENLANDERS FIND THE LIMITS OF DANES 'HOSPITALITY'
abstract: For two centuries Denmark ran its Greenland colony as a closed society. Outside of Danish fishermen, seal hunters and priests, no one was allowed into Greenland and the indigenous people were not allowed to travel beyond their Arctic land.   Thirty years ago, when it was apparent that appalling health conditions were quickly killing off the Greenlanders, the law was changed and the vast tract of frozen land was incorporated into the kingdom of Denmark.   The opening of Greenland has brought radical changes for its people, and those who have undergone the most jolting cultural shock of all have been those who have traveled 2,500 miles to settle in the mother country.

headline: Sri Lanka Accuses the Left Of Promoting Ethnic Tension
abstract: The Government, which is trying to restore order after riots last month, accused leftists today of promoting ethnic tension to unleash more violence.   Douglas Liyanage, a Government spokesman, said leftists were trying to ''keep up tension at panic level so that any single incident, or even a big rumor, can be used to unleash violence causing further damage and undermining the stability of the Government.''   He told reporters 384 people were killed in violence between Sinhalese and the minority Tamils, which began with the killing July 23 of 13 soldiers by separatist guerrillas in the northern district of Jaffna.

headline: LEBANESE PHALANGISTS URGE FORCES TO END PROTEST OVER ISRAELI MOVES
abstract: The Christian Phalangist militia called today on its supporters in southern Lebanon to end their protest against moves by the Israeli occupation forces to close Phalangist offices in the area.   Both Phalangist and Israeli officials said the situation in the south was quiet today and that Christian villagers had ended demonstrations and removed burning cars and tires used to block the entry of Israeli troops into Phalangist-dominated villages around Sidon and Nabatiye.   Negotiations to settle the dispute continued between Israeli and Phalangist representatives in Beirut.  ''Because of the positive atmosphere of the talks yesterday,'' said the spokesman of the Phalangist Lebanese Forces, Fadi Hayek, ''we have asked the population to call off the strikes and remove the roadblocks in order to prepare the atmosphere for further positive talks. We are sure we can reach an agreement which will safeguard the interests of the population in the south and the security imperatives of the Israel Defense Forces.''

headline: CYANAMID ELEVATES 3 IN RACE TO THE TOP
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company promoted three officers yesterday to the position of executive vice president, creating what analysts said amounts to a contest for the presidency. They will also be members of the executive committee, which runs Cyanamid, a leading industrial corporation. The appointments, effective tomorrow, will increase the company's top management team to six.

headline: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1983
abstract: International   Marc Rich and his partner were indicted on charges of evading a record $48 million in income taxes. They also face a charge of buying Iranian oil after trade with Iran was banned, as well as racketeering and fraud. Neither Mr. Rich nor his partner, Pincus Green, appeared in court; they were said to have fled to Switzerland. Through a spokesman, however, both men said they were innocent. (Page A1.)   Hughes Tool should be barred from selling Moscow $40 million worth of oil exploration equipment, a Federal panel urged in an apparent response to the downing of the Korean airliner. It would also place similar products under Pentagon controls. (D1.)

headline: Xerox Cuts Some Prices
abstract: The Xerox Corporation announced price reductions of 20 percent to 28 percent on three of its smaller copiers and reductions of 11.5 percent and 16.7 percent on two of its electronic typewriters.   The price of the 1020 copier, which was introduced on June 1, was reduced to $1,995, from $2,495, on June 13.

headline: INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: President Is Named By Executone Inc.
abstract: John R. Jester has been named president of Executone Inc., designers and marketers of business telephone systems, the company announced yesterday.   Mr. Jester, 42 years old, who has been executive vice president for the past year, succeeds George Zoffinger, who left recently to become president of the Coradian Corporation in Albany.

headline: Debt Meeting On DeLorean
abstract: Investors who gave more than $17 million for research on the gull-winged DeLorean sports car likely will meet Sept. 13 in New York to decide whether to pursue what happened to the money, according to an attorney for the DeLorean Motor Company.   The lawyer, Lawrence Snider of Detroit, said Tuesday that the meeting of the investors probably will come before the United States District Court in Detroit.

headline: Kaiser Steel Bid Is Withdrawn
abstract: An investors group headed by the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs has pulled out of an agreement to buy the Kaiser Steel Corporation, a Kaiser official said today.   Mr. Jacobs met with Kaiser officials in Oakland on Wednesday and told them that he was unwilling to go ahead with the deal under terms of a May 27 agreement, according to the spokesman, Montye Male.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Results Up at JWT And Interpublic
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies and JWT Group Inc., both holding companies for advertising agencies, yesterday announced improved results for the second quarter.

headline: Italy Sells Pipe to India
abstract: Italy's state-owned Siderexport has signed a $38 million contract to supply steel pipe for India's offshore gas pipeline, an Italian Embassy official said today.

headline: U.S. IS SENDING AFRICAN NATIONS MORE ARMS AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration, concerned about Soviet and Cuban involvement in Africa, has quietly doubled military aid to key countries in the region.   Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker, head of the Bureau of African Affairs and the key American policy maker for the region, said military aid now represents about 20 percent of overall American aid to sub-Saharan African countries.   The bulk of American aid, he said in an interview this week, is designed to alleviate the critical balance-of-payments deficits in most African countries, many of which are facing their worst economic crisis in 40 years. The crisis was fostered by drought, declining food production, rising birth rates and paltry foreign exchange earnings from such traditional export products as cocoa and rubber, the prices of which are depressed on the world market.

headline: TRAVEL AGENTS FACING AIRLINE COMMISSION RIFT
abstract: The airline industry is in turmoil over how much to pay travel agents and corporate travel departments. More than $2 billion a year in commissions are at stake.   On Wednesday, American Airlines notified more than 20,000 travel agents that beginning Sept. 19 it will cut commissions to 9 percent from the industry standard of 10 percent.   Almost immediately, United Airlines and Continental Air Lines said they were reviewing their commissions. A decision on whether to make a similar cut is expected today. Spokesmen for Eastern and Delta said they, too, were reviewing agency commissions.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Rise Slightly
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday for short-term and long-term securities.    While some dealers said that demand should increase after various investor committees have had time to meet, such an increase in demand was not apparent yesterday.   By late in the day, prices fell enough to reduce Treasury bill rates by one to four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Prices of Treasury issues due in 10 years or more fell as much as a quarter point, with the 12 percent bonds due in 2013 offered at 101 10/32 to yield 11.83 percent.

headline: THE SUPERSTARS
abstract: Mary E. Cunningham Vice President Joseph E. Seagram    The only businesswoman to approach the success of the corporate circuit's ''superstars,'' Miss Cunningham receives between $7,500 and $8,000 for each appearance. Publicity surrounding her Bendix years and her relationship with William Agee (another top-drawing speaker and now her husband) may have contributed to her demand on the circuit, but she refuses to include the subjects among her topics at the podium. ''What I've tried to do,'' she explained, ''is encourage people to treat me as a business speaker rather than as a celebrity.'' Indeed, audiences more often cite her ability to lecture on her forte, strategic planning. She generally accepts about two speaking engagements a month. ''Anything more frequent interferes with the amount of time I spend on the job,'' she said.  Lee A. Iacocca Chairman Chrysler Corporation

headline: Mrs. Gandhi Says India Does Not Have the Bomb
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India does not possess the atomic bomb but is going ahead with a nuclear development program for peaceful purposes.   ''I hope you are all aware that our nuclear program is prompted not by military objectives but by developmental necessity,'' Mrs. Gandhi said at the opening session of the World Energy Conference.

headline: 3 SENATORS PROPOSE 2-STEP PLAN FOR CUT IN NUCLEAR WEAPONS
abstract: A two-step reduction in nuclear weapons by the Soviet Union and the United States was urged today by three senators involved in arms control policy.    The first reduction would involve the total number of ballistic missile warheads.

headline: Oil Stockpile Contractor
abstract: The Government will likely restore soon a line of credit to the contractor that manages its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, Energy Department officials said today.   The credit, allowing Petroleum Operations and Support Services Inc. of New Orleans to draw operating expenses directly from the Treasury, was suspended last month after assertions by Government auditors of fiscal mismanagement.

headline: A TRAIL OF WESTERN TECHNOLOGY IS FOLLOWED TO THE K.G.B.'S DOOR
abstract: Every year Western high technology with military applications, worth millions of dollars, disappears beyond the borders of the Soviet Union and its allies. Sometimes the Warsaw Pact's procurement effort is so effective that the embargoed equipment is even returned to the West for secret repairs. American laws and North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreements ban the transfer of such sophisticated microelectronic and computer equipment. But the volume reaching the Eastern bloc is startling, according to Western intelligence experts.   Much of it is obtained, they say, through dummy corporations and covert suppliers who cooperate with the technology procurement campaign, which is regarded as the current primary task of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal-security agency, and the G.R.U., its military counterpart. The Case of the Man at Orly

headline: CBS REALIGNS OFFICERS IN BROADCASTING UNITS
abstract: CBS Inc. announced a realignment of the top management of its broadcasting operations yesterday, elevating the presidents of CBS News and CBS Sports to new corporate positions with expanded duties.   With these shifts, the day-to-day responsiblities for the various CBS broadcast divisions are divided among four executive vice presidents rather than the two who hold them now - forming, in effect, an office of the president.   Gene Jankowski, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said that the corporate realignment was designed to broaden the experience of the company's top broadcasting executives.

headline: French Aide, in Cuba, Discusses Latin Crisis
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France, on the second day of an official visit to Cuba, met today with Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, a specialist in international relations.   A French Embassy official declined to give details of the talks, but he said an important theme was the conflict in Central America and moves that might bring about a negotiated political settlement in the region.

headline: Marc Rich Asset Freeze Due
abstract: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would sign an order permitting the United States Attorney to freeze up to $55 million in United States assets of Marc Rich & Company A.G.    The order, which Judge Leonard B. Sand said he would sign today in Federal District Court in Manhattan, would allow restraining notices to prohibit companies and individuals from paying funds that they owe to the Swiss-based international commodities trading concern.   The order is the latest attempt by Federal prosecutors to assure payment of fines levied against Marc Rich after it refused to turn subpoenaed documents over to a Federal grand jury investigating possible tax violations by Marc Rich. Rich says the transactions being investigated were not under the jurisdiction of United States laws.     Judge Sand imposed a $50,000- a-day fine on the company on June 29 for its refusal to surrender the documents. Last Thursday, Rich paid $1.35 million in accrued fines, but the Government claims that a maximum of $27.5 million may be due if the company does not pay the fines by March 14, 1984, when the term of the grand jury expires.

headline: PREMIER OF SOVIET WARNS KOHL ON BID TO DEPLOY MISSILES
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov canceled his first meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany here today, but Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov, who took the Soviet leader's place, exchanged blunt remarks with Mr. Kohl.   In a dinner speech, the Soviet Prime Minister said that if the North Atlantic Treaty Organization went ahead with the deployment of new American missiles in Europe, ''we and our allies will respond by taking without delay additional measures to strengthen our security and develop a counterbalance to NATO's new military potential.''   The warning echoed previous threats by Moscow to station new nuclear weapons on the soil of its Warsaw Pact allies if the West goes ahead with its deployment, with the new statement that the countermeasures would come ''without delay.'' Kohl Responds to Russian   Mr. Kohl said in response that it was the Soviet Union's ''vast superiority'' in medium-range weapons that had prompted the Western alliance to take countermeasures. He insisted that his ''numerous talks'' with President Reagan had convinced him of Washington's dedication to resolving the missile dispute by negotiation.

headline: PAKISTANI DIES AS AFGHAN JETS ARE REPORTED TO RAID VILLAGE
abstract: Seven Afghan Air Force fighter-jets bombed a Pakistani border village today, killing at least one person and injuring another, the Government said.   A Government spokesman said seven Soviet-made MIG-21's attacked the village, three miles northeast of Parachinar, which is 280 miles west of Islamabad.

headline: WESTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PENTAGON REPORTS ENCOUNTER AT SEA WITH SOVIET SHIP
abstract: A Defense Department spokesman said today that a United States Navy destroyer came close to a Soviet freighter off the Pacific coast of Nicaragua on Saturday and asked the vessel's destination and cargo.   The spokesman said that as the destroyer, the Lynde McCormick, approached the merchant ship, the Aleksandr Ulyanov, at a point about 50 miles off the coast, the American captain hailed the Soviet captain on a bridge-to-bridge radio. The ships were no closer than three-quarters of a mile apart, the Pentagon said.   According to the spokesman, the American captain asked the Russian to list his cargo and destination. The Russian, he said, replied that he was carrying trucks and other general merchandise and was bound for Corinto, a port 90 miles north of the Nicaraguan capital at Managua.

headline: Market Place; Mesa's Offer To KN Energy
abstract: WHEN the Mesa Petroleum Company made a bid last week for KN Energy Inc., a lot of people thought that T. Boone Pickens was just going through one of his profitable exercises again and was not entirely serious about acquiring the company.   After all, Mr. Pickens, Mesa's chairman, has waged takeover bids that have come to naught while Mesa profited from the purchase of stock in the target before it made the bid.   Last year, Mesa acquired stakes in the Cities Service Company and the General American Oil Company of Texas before making bids for the companies. Mesa lost out in both attempts, when the companies found other buyers. But it made $31.5 million on the Cities Service deal and another goodly amount on the General American deal.

headline: Wickes Toy Sale
abstract: Wickes Companies Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif., said it has sold the assets of its Toy World division for about $5.5 million to the Kay-Bee Toy unit of the Melville Corporation.

headline: U.S. REQUEST REBUFFED ON ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL
abstract: The United States pleaded with Israel on Saturday not to go ahead with its planned withdrawal from the hills around Beirut but was rebuffed by Israeli officials, the White House said today.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other senior officials met throughout the day to discuss the Lebanese situation in the aftermath of the Israeli pullback, which occurred Saturday night and early Sunday. One State Department official, commenting on the new fighting among opposing Lebanese factions as the Israelis pulled back, said: ''It is a total disaster.'' Publicly, however, the Administration has been more optimistic.

headline: ONE VIEW OF NORTON'S CHIEF
abstract: In 1972, David J. Mahoney, the chief executive of Norton Simon Inc., declared in an interview that he planned to stay on for 8 or 10 years. ''By then, I'll either have made my pile or flopped,'' he said.   This week, some people say, the 60-year-old Mr. Mahoney has done both. Already a wealthy man, he is likely to become some $25 million richer as a result of the takeover of Norton Simon by Esmark Inc., announced by the two companies on Thursday.

headline: FRENCH VIEWS OF CHAD: PRIDE, ANGER, DOUBT
abstract: ''Some things are more important than Chad - like food.''   With that, Francis Boissard, a retired truck driver who can usually be found in Le Charlemagne in that important social interval just before lunchtime, downed his aperitif, saluted with two fingers and ambled out the door to fix a meal for himself and his wife.   It is a daily ritual that is close to his heart. And Chad, after all, is 2,000 miles away.

headline: Diamond Crystal
abstract: The Diamond Crystal Salt Company has agreed to a $32 million out-of-court settlement offered by Texaco Inc. and the Wilson Brothers Corporation stemming from a suit filed in 1980.  The suit was filed after an oil rig operated for Texaco by Wilson Brothers broke through the roof of a Diamond Crystal salt mine in Louisiana. Diamond Crystal, based in St. Clair, Mich., said it would repay its insurance carriers $3.5 million of $10 million it previously received from them in settlement in insurance claims.

headline: Interest Rates Move Lower; 6-Month Bill Falls to 9.31%
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday and wiped out almost all of the increases that occurred in last Friday's trading.   Government securities dealers said there was a modest amount of investor buying of long-term bonds, especially early in the day. They added that much of the strength in prices was due to buying by speculators who had been sellers last week.   By late in the day, rates for Treasury bills outstanding had fallen about one-tenth of 1 percentage point, with three- and six-month issues bid at 9.08 percent and 9.26 percent, respectively. Among longer-term issues, the new 10 5/8 percent Treasury notes due in two years rose almost 1/4 point, to 99 7/8, to yield 10.7 percent, and the 10 1/8 percent notes due in 1993 rose a point, to an offered price of 92 18/32, to yield 11.39 percent.

headline: Tennessee Bank Fails
abstract: The Warren County Bank was declared insolvent and closed Friday because of excessive loan losses, marking the 12th failure of of a financial institution in Tennessee this year, officials said.

headline: SOVIET COOL TO ARAFAT IN HIS DISPUTE WITH SYRIANS
abstract: In meetings this week with a high official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko appears to have refused to throw the Kremlin's weight behind Yasir Arafat, head of the guerrilla movement.   A report in the Soviet press today about Mr. Gromyko's meeting with Farouk Kaddoumi, the foreign affairs specialist in the P.L.O.'s Executive Committee, made no mention of Mr. Arafat, even though there had been reports that Mr. Kaddoumi had come to Moscow to prepare a visit by Mr. Arafat.   Instead, the statement contained a Soviet demand that the P.L.O.  put its house in order and ''strengthen cooperation'' with ''progressive Arab countries,'' an apparent allusion to Syria.

headline: Poles Begin Their Holy Trek
abstract: Tens of thousands of Poles set out today on treks from all directions to the shrine of the Black Madonna in Czestochowa. Lines of men, women and children stretched more than four miles on the highway south of Warsaw. People were taking part in similar marches from other cities.

headline: Lockheed Sets New Jet Deals
abstract: The Lockheed Corporation will probably dispose of its remaining inventory of five L-1011 wide-body jets, valued at about $300 million, through lease-financing deals, James West, president of the Lockheed Finance Corporation, said.   ''I think we will put them out on seven- or ten-year leases,'' Mr.  West said.

headline: Purse Strings
abstract: To the Business Editor:   I enjoy reading the Personal Finance column.

headline: MITTERRAND VIEWS PEACE IN CHAD AS AIM BUT COMBAT AS POSSIBILITY
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand said today that French troops had been sent to Chad to ''bring peace,'' but he warned that, if threatened by Libyan-backed rebels, they could go on the offensive.    The President's statements, his first full exposition of policy since fighting flared in the Central African nation two months ago, appeared as a question- and-answer interview in Le Monde. The questions were not submitted in advance, but the text was personally reviewed by the President before its publication this afternoon.   The interview came amid a growing public debate over France's military buildup in Chad. It also came as Paris pressed a diplomatic effort designed to avoid a clash with Libya. The commitment by France is rapidly becoming larger than any in Africa since the Algerian war two decades ago.

headline: Signal Stock Sale
abstract: The Signal Companies said it had agreed to sell all of its Diamond Shamrock Inc. common stock in a public offering that will result in proceeds of $164 million.

headline: Consolidated-Bathurst
abstract: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. said today that it would close two of its newsprint machines Sept.15 because they cannot be modernized. The machines account for 55,000 metric tons of the company's annual one-million-ton production capacity.

headline: Reactor Leaks Tritium At a Station in Canada
abstract: A nuclear reactor in Pickering, Ontario, leaked a small amount of radioactive tritium after an accident that began Monday, the Canadian authorities announced yesterday, prompting officials in Ontario and in New York State to step up air sampling.   The Ministry of Labor for the province of Ontario notified the New York State Health Department by telephone yesterday morning that the reactor, which is east of Toronto, on Lake Ontario, had leaked about 16 curies of tritium, which the ministry said ''slightly exceeded one percent of the release limit'' set by the authorities.

headline: Air Force Awards
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation received a $552.3 million Air Force contract for production through 1985 of 480 F-16 fighter aircraft, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said that the United Technologies Corporation had got a $94.6 million Air Force award for TF30, TF33 and J57 engine spare parts, and that the Northrop Corporation received a $46.5 million contract from the Air Force for full-scale engineering development of the MX missile inertial measurement unit.

headline: U.S. VETOES A U.N. CENSURE OF ISRAELIS OVER SETTLEMENTS
abstract: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that said Israel's settlement policies in the occupied Arab lands ''have no legal validity'' and ''constitute a major and serious obstruction'' to peace.   The latest Council meeting was touched off by the killing of three students at the Islamic College of Hebron on the West Bank last week, an act that Arab diplomats here say was perpetrated by Israeli settlers.   Abdalla S. al-Ashtal of Yemen requested the meeting and called on the Council to ''take immediate practical steps'' to halt Israel's settlement policies and ''put an end to Israel's flouting of the Council's resolutions.''

headline: FORBES'S LIST OF THE RICHEST
abstract: Gordon Peter Getty got there the classic way. He had wealthy parents. Sam M. Walton did it by selling things cheap. J.R. Simplot did it with potatoes, Robert Vesco fled with millions.    All did what most Americans only dream about doing - they struck it rich - and they all show up on the second annual Forbes 400 list, a gossipy and not scrupulously precise ranking of the richest people in the country compiled for the latest issue of Forbes magazine.

headline: U.S. PLANNING TO VETO GUYANA DEVELOPMENT LOAN
abstract: The United States has decided to veto a $40 million loan to Guyana that is under consideration by the Inter-American Development Bank.   The decision was transmitted July 27 in a document given to Foreign Minister Rashleigh E. Jackson, by Gerald E. Thomas, the United States Ambassador in Georgetown, the capital.   The document, a copy of which was made available here, objected to Guyana's economic policies and said that, unless changes were made, the United States ''does not feel that the loan's objective of increased production will be possible.'' The loan is for a water project intended to stimulate rice production along the Abary River, near the coast southeast of Georgetown.

headline: Real EstateAnthony DePalma Tower Rises on 5th Avenue
abstract: WHILE the Fifth Avenue of high fashion and fanciful prices does not reach down to 47th Street any more, the developers of a new combination office and retail building on the site of the old Korvettes department store at 575 Fifth Avenue hope to re-create something of its atmosphere there.   The developers, led by Fred Wilpon, the president and part owner of the New York Mets, are building a 27- story tower encased in flame-finished pink granite that stands atop a wider and longer eight-story base built around the steel shell of the former store.   The new building, designed by Emory Roth & Sons of Manhattan, has 35 floors but is actually 40 stories high. The difference is taken up by a four-story atrium that will hold 55,000 square feet of retail space, hanging gardens and a waterfall.

headline: AMERICAN IS FREED WITH HELP OF SYRIA
abstract: David S. Dodge, the acting president of American University in Beirut, who was abducted last year, has been freed with the help of Syrian leaders, the White House said today.   The officials declined to give details, but Administration officials said Mr. Dodge had been held for at least the last six months in Iran.   He was seized in Beirut on July 19, 1982, evidently by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems. It is believed he was taken first to Syria and then to Iran.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Pervious   Year

headline: Dissident Jailed in Soviet
abstract: Galina Barats, wife of Vasily Barats, an imprisoned human-rights and religious activist, has been sentenced to six years in a labor camp for anti-Soviet agitation, dissident sources said today.

headline: Head of Puget Power Fights Nuclear Losses
abstract: John W. Ellis, the president and chairman of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, concedes that he is participating in a high-stakes battle to protect the utility from big losses on its investments in nuclear power.   This week, Puget Power and three other private utilities said they were calling it quits on $400 million they had invested in twin nuclear reactors in Washington State. Ground had never been broken.

headline: Needham, Harper Wins Ramada Hotel Account
abstract: Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, has emerged triumphant in the struggle for the advertising account of the Ramada Hotel Group, which spent $7 million last year.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: 200 Units, and Counting, For Restaurant Family     It only seems as though the Riese brothers own all the restaurants in New York. Actually they have a mere 200.   That figure will be growing, though. Earlier this month the Riese brothers, Murray and Irving, agreed to take over the operation of 17 Chock Full o'Nuts restaurants in New York City. They also have plans to open at least 25 Godfather's Pizza units in the city, with an option for at least 50 more in the metropolitan area.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: For years, the Kemper family has dominated banking in Kansas City, Mo. No foreign entanglements for them. Commerce Bancshares - with James M. Kemper Jr. as chairman and his son, David W. Kemper, as president - has a total overseas exposure of just $3 million.

headline: American Doused With Blood By a West German Activist
abstract: Gen. Paul Williams of the United States Army was doused with human blood today by a member of West Germany's Green Party as a protest against American policies.

headline: Zimbabwe Finds Two Bodies, Believed Those of Hostages
abstract: Government security forces believe they have found the bodies of two white farmers kidnapped by insurgents in Matabeleland province in the past year, the national press agency reported today.   It quoted Emmerson Munangagwa, Zimbabwe's Security Minister, as saying captured rebels pointed out the bodies, believed to be those of Robert Dyer-Smith and David Belang.

headline: SIGNING A CONTRACT BEFORE MARRIAGE
abstract: WHEN the head of a large public company recently separated from his wife, the man's lawyer, Roy M. Cohn, was relieved, but not because the marriage was over. Two years earlier, at Mr. Cohn's insistence, the couple had signed a prenuptial contract. Now, instead of a divorce settlement that would make headlines, the woman would quietly receive a small, lump sum settlement. Mr. Cohn, a New York lawyer whose practice includes many wealthy individuals, says 90 percent of his clients who get married now have prenuptial contracts.   But such arrangements are not just for the rich. They are increasingly also for those with family businesses, those marrying for the second time and even those marrying for the first who are worried about giving up in a divorce some day, their right to a rent-controlled apartment or other valuable asset. ''Premarital agreements should be as obligatory as blood tests,'' says Raoul Lionel Felder, a New York divorce lawyer.

headline: Economic Scene; Back to Basics On Budgets
abstract: THE collaspe of faith in the Phillips curve-the purported trade-off between inflation and unemployment that was generally accepted in the 1960's - has led to a renaissance of the classical doctrine about Government finance, both among economists and statesmen. But evidently, the doctrine has not yet decisively influenced the United States Government.   In classical economic doctrine, the case for balancing a government's budget is based on the notion that a government should finance itself like a private firm or individual. The idea is that in a competitive economy, good results are promoted when the government commits itself to compete for loans on an equal footing with private parties.

headline: Georgia-Pacific Net Off
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the country's largest domestic producer of plywood, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter fell 21.1 percent, to $56 million, or 52 cents a share, from $71 million, or 68 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: The martial law administrator, Lieut. Gen. Hussain Ershad, announced today that a general election would be held by March 1985, three years after he seized power in a military coup.   In a broadcast speech, General Ershad also said that lower-level elections would be held this December and next February and March.  ''We have fulfilled our promise to the nation to return to democracy,'' General Ershad said.

headline: Ex-Marketer of Perrier To Sell French Wines
abstract: Bruce S. Nevins thinks Americans like to drink French. He brought Perrier, the effervescent mineral water, to the United States in the 1970's, and now he has moved on to something a bit harder: French wine.   Mr. Nevins sold his minority interest in Perrier and was president of the United States marketing subsidiary when he left in 1980. His new company, Premium Wine Imports, which he founded in 1981, is aiming at the same health market.

headline: Hydro Lets Bonds Run for 15 Years
abstract: A $250 million issue of British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority bonds due in 2013 was offered at a price of 98.654 to yield 12.675 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: U.S. Voices Certainty On Lebanon Pullouts
abstract: The White House emphasized its confidence today that planned redeployments of Israeli troops in Lebanon will eventually lead to a total withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign troops from the country.   ''Lebanon will soon face an opportunity to restore stability and extend the process of reconstruction and consensus building,'' the White House said in a statement that hailed what it termed the ''solid foundation of support'' in both Israel and the Arab world for eventual withdrawal of all foreign troops.

headline: Business and the Law
abstract: THE returns are in on the fight over the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 - and both sides are claiming victory.   Almost since the bankruptcy code was enacted, the consumer credit industry has been arguing that it made personal bankruptcy too attractive and encouraged abuse of the bankruptcy process by people who had the means to pay their debts.   Blaming overly liberal bankruptcy laws at least in part for the dramatic rise in personal bankruptcies over the last few years, the creditors have mounted a strong legislative push to tighten the law.   In particular, they say, too many debtors are filing for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 - which provides for the liquidation of assets and discharge of debt - when they are financially solid enough to manage Chapter 13 bankruptcy, which involves a stretched-out repayment plan.

headline: Racal Electronics Picks Deputy Chief Executive
abstract: David C. Elsbury has been appointed to the newly created position of deputy chief executive of Racal Electronics P.L.C., a company that has been one of Britain's industrial success stories.   Sir Ernest Harrison, who as Racal's chairman and chief executive is ranked among Britain's top managers, said in a statement that Mr.  Elsbury would be in charge of Racal's data comunications group.   Michael Sperring, an electronics analyst with Scrimgeour, Kemp-Gee in London, said that ''Mr. Elsbury is a very, very dynamic man, very ambitious. He has emerged as Harrison's successor and will be making the decisions when he's not around.''

headline: MAJOR CORPORATIONS ASK WORKERS TO PAY MORE OF HEALTH COST
abstract: Some of the nation's largest corporations are asking their employees to pay a bigger portion of their health-care bills than in the past. If adopted nationwide, the practice would mark a reversal of one of the most widespread and generous employee benefits in America.   This summer five large companies - A.T.& T., Ford, Chrysler, W. R. Grace and Citibank - have asked their employees to pay an increased share of their health costs.   Ford, Citibank and Grace in effect dictated this policy to their white-collar, nonunion employees. At A.T.& T. and Chrysler, both bargaining with unions, the request that workers shoulder more of their health costs met bitter resentment. Union representatives negotiating contracts with the two companies flatly rejected the idea, and the companies dropped it, at least temporarily.

headline: Occidental Loan
abstract: The Bank of China is considering a loan to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of the United States, which plans to develop an open-cast coal mine in China, a bank official said.

headline: MARINE ROLE IN LEBANON: NEW OPTIONS AND RISKS
abstract: Military Analysis    American and other military sources say the military options of the United States marines and other contingents in the multinational force in Lebanon have increased along with the resources required to carry them out.  But, they say, the hazards of individual or collective operations against the Lebanese Druse militias have also grown.  The Syrian position, the informants said, appears to be hardening. They noted that the Syrian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Farouk al-Share, had said that Syria would defend its position and continue its help to Lebanese national forces, meaning units arrayed against the Government of President Amin Gemayel.   His statement, the sources said, is not to be taken lightly. They cited Israel's high estimate of the Syrian Army and said that military supplies of all kinds were flowing to the anti-Government forces from Syrian depots and that Syrian officers and noncommissioned officers were advising and sometimes directing operations.

headline: 7 Pakistani Politicians Reported Arrested
abstract: The police arrested seven members of the banned Pakistan People's Party today when they returned to Pakistan to lead a campaign for democracy in their native Punjab Province, airport sources said.   Passengers on the Pakistan International Airlines flight from London told reporters 15 to 18 policemen carrying rifles were waiting for the plane and led the seven away to waiting police vans.   The group, the first of what party officials in London have said are up to 300 Punjabis ready to return, ended self- exile in Britain and West Germany to join protests led by the opposition Movement for the Restoration of Democracy.

headline: Racal-China Pact
abstract: A British company, Racal Survey Ltd., signed contracts establishing two joint ventures in China to support offshore oil exploration and production, China's official New China News Agency said.

headline: I.B.M. EARNINGS UP 24.1% IN QUARTER
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, citing a sharp rise in computer equipment sales and continuing improvement in operating margins, reported yesterday that earnings for the second quarter soared 24.1 percent, to $1.34 billion, one of its largest quarterly profits ever.   The profit, amounting to $2.22 a share, was better than many analysts had expected, and some said it was indicative of a record year for the huge company.   In last year's second quarter the world's largest maker of computers and information-processing equipment and systems earned $1.08 billion, or $1.81 a share. Revenue of the Armonk, N.Y., company in the latest three months climbed 19.1 percent, to $9.59 billion, from $8.05 billion.

headline: Ozark-Caledonian
abstract: British Caledonian Airways and Ozark Air Lines today announced an agreement under which British Caledonian would resume nonstop flights from St. Louis to London.

headline: Chrysler Increase
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation will increase prices of its 1984 model cars by an average 2 percent, company sources said.

headline: Thailand Standby Loan
abstract: Thailand has accepted an offer from 12 banks for a $200 million standby credit at three-eighths of a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate, a senior official of the Bank of Thailand said today.

headline: Missiles Protested in Sicily
abstract: About 350 demonstrators protesting plans to locate United States cruise missiles in Italy blocked the gates today to an airfield where the missiles are to be housed, a spokesman for the protesters said. He said the 11-hour blockade was peaceful.

headline: Continental Illinois Stock
abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation's 1,750,000 shares of adjustable-rate preferred stock are being offered at $50 a share, with an initial dividend yield of 11.25 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering was increased from 1,250,000 shares. After Dec. 31, the dividend on the stock, which is rated A-3/BBBx, will change quarterly at one percentage point below the higher of the bond equivalent yield for 3-month bills, the yield for 10-year Treasury notes or the yield for 20-year Treasury bonds.

headline: NEW RULES ON HOLDERS' PROPOSALS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a hotly debated proposal that will make it more difficult for activist shareholders to put social and other issues to a vote at corporate annual meetings.   By a 3-1 vote, the commission decided to require that those proposing resolutions hold at least $1,000 worth of a company's stock for a minimum of one year and to require that a losing resolution obtain at least 5 percent of the vote for it to qualify for resubmission the following year. Currently a proposal can be repeated if sponsors achieve 3 percent.   In addition, the commission's new rules will allow a company to omit from the proxy material a proposal if it deals with substantially the same subject matter as a proposal in the previous year.

headline: TESTING TIME IN LEBANON
abstract: Military   Analysis    The military situation for all of the forces in Lebanon is likely to change profoundly in the next week as a result of three factors, in the view of American and other NATO intelligence officers familiar with the region.  Two of these factors, they said, are positive: the sending of 2,000 marines to a position off Beirut this week, where they can support the 1,200-man force already ashore, and the visible improvement last week, at least in street fighting abilities against Moslem militiamen, of the Lebanese Army.   The negative factor, the officers said, is the withdrawal of the Israeli Army, the most experienced force in Lebanon, to new positions that they said would open the way for what one officer called ''seepage'' by Moslem militia forces into the vacated areas.   The intelligence officers noted that Israeli guns would still command the army's old positions after the Israeli forces completed their pullback from the Beirut area south to the Awali River on Sunday. But they said the possibility that the Moslem militiamen would be able to infiltrate at night into the area southeast of Beirut's international airport, which is held by the marines, was a matter of concern.

headline: SELLING COMPUTERS LIKE SOAP
