abstract: After years of analyzing and satisfying consumer tastes for soap, soda pop and cigarettes, professional marketers are being recruited into the top ranks of the microcomputer industry, to sell personal computers and video games.   The fact that packaged-goods marketers are moving into high technology is a measure of the changes occurring within the computer industry, according to computer manufacturers, as well as executive recruiters and management experts. With manufacturers jostling for market share, they are giving marketing precedence over technology.   And as the personal computer evolves into a familiar household appliance, its producers are increasingly relying on techniques that have worked for more expendable goods.

headline: Ex-Im Bank
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Doug Bandow's statement that the Administration is requesting ''even more subsidized financing'' for the Export-Import Bank is, at best, misleading (''Another Handout for Big Business,'' Aug. 21).   What the Administration has proposed is a modest increase in Ex-Im Bank lending authority only if the bank determines that such an increase is needed in fiscal year 1984 to meet renewed demand for United States exports.

headline: BALDWIN SELLS 5 LOAN UNITS TO HUTTON
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which averted bankruptcy last week and is now trying to raise cash, yesterday announced the sale of its five mortgage banking subsidiaries to E.F. Hutton & Company.   Baldwin-United, which said it would get $100 million in cash from the sale, also said it had received $77.5 million as prepayment of a promissory note from Daniel K. Ludwig, the entrepreneur and industrialist.   Victor H. Palmieri, who joined Baldwin-United in May as president and chief executive officer, said in a statement that the two transactions ''are part of our program to dispose of selected subsidiary companies and related financial assets.''   Mr. Palmieri, who was invited to head Baldwin because of his reputation for resuscitating ailing companies, has said he wants to generate $500 million this year plus $200 million over the next two years through the sale of some of its 250 subsidiaries.

headline: RUSSIAN REACTION: OLD FEARS REVIVED
abstract: NewsAnalysis    MOSCOW, Sept. 5 - In a country where secrecy, insecurity and suspicion of the outside world permeate all aspects of life, the explanations offered by the Kremlin about the South Korean jetliner seem certain of widespread acceptance.  Although Russians reacted with incredulity and dismay on hearing that a civilian jetliner had been downed, the measured doses of official explanation - branding the plane a hostile intruder, attributing its fate to American anti- Soviet aggression and mentioning challenges to Soviet sovereignty and prestige - have played to some of the strongest instincts nurtured by the Soviet state. In a land where foreigners are viewed with deep distrust, where state frontiers are regarded as the front lines in an ideological death struggle and where secretiveness pervades all levels of life, the notion that any plane straying into Soviet airspace is probably hostile would be common.   The Soviet explanations steered the public away from the United States report that a Soviet pilot had shot down a civilian jumbo jetliner carrying 269 people - facts that have yet to be explicitly acknowledged by Moscow - and to the familiar patterns of Soviet- American rivalry.

headline: Quaker City Filing
abstract: Quaker City Industries said it had filed a voluntary petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey. The company makes steel utility buildings.

headline: Quebec Offers 2 Issues Totaling $200 Million
abstract: A two-part bond financing by the Province of Quebec totaling $200 million was announced yesterday by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds had not been scheduled for sale this week, but a registration statement had been filed previously with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: BATTLE OF RETAILERS IN DALLAS
abstract: Five miles from the mirrored-glass glitter of downtown Dallas, four lavish shopping malls are drawing the country's major luxury retailers to battle for a share of this city's $21 billion annual retail market.   In the last year Tiffany and Saks Fifth Avenue from New York, Gumps from San Francisco, Marshall Field's from Chicago and a dozen others have opened in the vast, five-level Galleria mall, which anchors the North Dallas area proudly called ''the Golden Corridor'' by business executives.   And within two miles of the Galleria sit the Prestonwood, North Park and Valley View malls, each with its own healthy complement of what the industry calls ''high end'' retailers. Bloomingdale's is scheduled to open at Valley View, for example, in October. And Macy's is negotiating for a site in the Galleria.

headline: Atlanta Transit Bonds To Yield Up to 10.43%
abstract: A $175 million bond issue of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, known as Marta, was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of about 10.43 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2004. Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers offered other bonds with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1986 to 10.25 percent in 2003, with a 7 percent issue due in 2011 offered at a price of 71 1/4 to yield 10.10 percent.

headline: CANADIAN OLYMPIC SITE RUNS INTO PROBLEMS
abstract: In January 1982 local promotors convinced the International Olympic Committee to hold the 1988 Winter Olympics in and around Calgary. It was Canada's first successful bid for the Winter Games in seven tries. In retrospect, that seems like the easy part.

headline: Baldwin Unit In Kroco Sale
abstract: Baldwin-United said that its National Investors Insurance Company unit had agreed to sell for $60.9 million cash its interest in Kroco Inc. to the Kroger Company, a joint owner. The sale is subject to approval of the Arkansas insurance commissioner.

headline: U.S. Telephone Chief Resigns
abstract: U.S. Telephone Inc. said today that James Devlin, its chairman, president and chief executive officer, had resigned for personal reasons.

headline: Jesuit Meeting Opens With Warning by Pope
abstract: Pope John Paul II opened the general congregation of the Jesuits here today with a call to the order to leave to laymen those aspects of the world's struggle for justice that promote mainly material well-being.

headline: MUGABE HAS A HELPING OF GEORGIA HOSPITALITY
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, in a stopover here this weekend, was served a large helping of Georgia hospitality.   Mr. Mubabe met with local business leaders to discuss foreign-investment possibilties in Zimbabwe, was given an honorary degree by a local college and was taken on a tour of the grave and memorial of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by the civil rights leader's widow, Coretta Scott King.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JULY 6, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stock prices declined sharply as investors reacted to a $600 million increase in the money supply and reports that the Federal Reserve is thinking of raising the discount rate. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.73 points, to 1,208.53. Volume on the Big Board edged up to 67.3 million shares from Friday's preholiday turnover of 65.1 million shares. (Page D1.)   Interest rates rose sharply and prices fell. The rate on the sixmonth Treasury bill climbed to 9.20 percent from 9.14 percent at the weekly auction, And the sale, delayed a day by the holiday, produced an average discount rate of 9.10 percent on the 90-day bills, up from 9.09 percent last week. (D1.)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH SAYS NET TRIPLED IN 2D QUARTER
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, benefiting from a surge in trading commissions and underwriting fees, yesterday reported that second-quarter net income more than tripled, to $112 million, compared with the $36 million it earned in the similar period last year.   Merrill Lynch's earnings, however, declined from the first quarter of 1983, when it reported net income of $126.9 million. On a per share basis, second-quarter earnings were up almost threefold, to $1.32 a share, from 45 cents, in 1982's second quarter. The results were adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split that took effect on June 27.

headline: Turks Report Pipeline Fire
abstract: A fire broke out Friday in a pipeline from Iraq to the Turkish Mediterranean coast, halting the flow of oil through the line, the Turkish press agency Akajans reported.

headline: Soya-Upjohn Deal
abstract: The Central Soya Company said it had agreed to sell the 2,778,628 shares it owns in the O's Gold Seed Company to the Upjohn Company for $6 a share. It said the transaction involved 60 percent of the O's Gold shares outstanding. Upjohn, based in Kalmazoo, Mich., said it planned to make a tender for the remaining shares at the same price.

headline: PUROLATOR UNIT NAMES WELLS, RICH, GREENE
abstract: Wells, Rich, Greene on Friday was named agency for Purolator Courier and thus enters its creative talents into battle for dominance of the sky by the nation's air express companies.   It is a war in which good creative advertising appears to be reflected in market share - if the position of Federal Express can be equated with the awards its advertising by Ally & Gargano has been winning.

headline: Reagan Asks Increase In Arms Office Budget
abstract: President Reagan asked Congress today to increase the budget for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency by $2 million, about 10 percent more than the $21.4 million previously approved.   The President will also ask that the agency be allowed to hire 25 new staff members over a two-year period.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: A reported $2 billion drop in the money supply delighted the credit markets late last week; bond prices soared and interest rates plunged almost a third of a percentage point. Most market participants had expected a jump in the money supply of as much as $1 billion. The drop in M-1 - currency in circulation plus all check-like deposits - placed money growth within the Fed's current target range. It seemed to allay fears that the central bank would have to tighten credit and boded well for those looking for lower interest rates. ''This is the best money-supply picture we've had in the last 12 months; everything is on target,'' was the reaction of one market analyst.   The stock market also put in a positive week, approaching its record highs. Despite fairly quiet trading, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up more than 24 points, to 1,240.04.

headline: Gold Traders Check Files
abstract: The Alderdice brothers have been allowed out of their jail cells to begin poring over the financial records of their bankrupt gold and silver trading company in an effort to clear themselves of fraud charges.   ''We're here to fight back with the truth,'' said William Alderdice, the 39-year-old president of the International Gold Bullion Exchange.

headline: WEINBERGER TO VISIT 3 LATIN NATIONS NEXT MONTH
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he would visit Central America soon, and he defended the dispatch of Awacs radar planes to help Chad.   Mr. Weinberger said at a news conference that he planned to visit Panama, El Salvador and Honduras in early September to watch United States troop maneuvers and to confer with defense ministers in the region. Denies U.S. Acted Alone    Mr. Weinberger also said France had considered deploying warplanes to Chad and had asked the United States to dispatch Awacs radar planes to provide intelligence support. He denied that the United States had acted without consulting France.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Triangle Industries announced that it would file later this month for an offering of subordinated debentures, and warrants to purchase common stock, but no further details were available. Common Stock   * AIA Industries, parent company of American International Airways, said its initial public offering of 2.2 million shares was priced at $10 a share, through Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc.   * Allied Capital Corp. filed for an offering of one million shares, through Shearson/American Express Inc.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has elected to its board Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State.   * American Express Co.  has named Joan E. Spero senior vice president- international corporate affairs.

headline: The U.N. Today; July 29, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on occupied Arab territories. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: Northrop Turnaround
abstract: The Northrop Corporation yesterday reported net income of $27.5 million, or $1.81 a share, for the second quarter, in contrast to a net loss of $1.6 million for the period a year before. Sales were up 42.3 percent, to $804.1 million, from $565 million.

headline: REAGAN REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR U.N.
abstract: President Reagan, in an effort to clarify American intentions, has decided to ''reaffirm strongly the U.S. support for the United Nations.'' But he will also criticize the way the organization functions when he visits New York on Sunday and Monday, a senior Administration official said today.   In a briefing for reporters on Mr. Reagan's plans, which include a speech on world affairs and arms control to the General Assembly on Monday, the official sought to reconcile the often contradictory signals from the Administration in the past week about its United Nations policy.   Mr. Reagan's first appointment on Sunday will be a luncheon he will give for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, and the official said Mr. Reagan would express the United States' continuing ''strong support'' for the United Nations.

headline: Pearle Health Registers Initial Offering of Shares
abstract: Pearle Health Services of Dallas said yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial public offering of 6.6 million common shares through a syndicate of underwriters managed by William Blair & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering price is estimated at $18 to $21 a share, Pearle said.   Pearle, formerly the Searle Optical Group of G.D. Searle & Company, is the largest retailer of prescription eye-care products in the United States.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.60    An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*13.00    Salomon Brothers' estimate for new   long-term issues.

headline: CURBS NOW PUT IN LEGAL CODE
abstract: The Polish Government announced today the longawaited, formal lifting of martial law.  But the end of 19 months of military rule is expected to make little difference in everyday life. Many of the controls under martial law, imposed to break the independent trade union Solidarity, have been institutionalized in the legal code. And today, Parliament enacted a series of temporary regulations to insure a continued tight grip on political and economic life. Today Is a National Holiday   The significance of the announcement that martial law will end on Friday, the anniversary of the establishment of Communist rule in 1944, lay in the hope of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's Government that Western nations would now be encouraged to ease sanctions squeezing the already weakened economy. (President Reagan said at a news conference that he would look for ''deeds, not words'' before deciding whether to ease sanctions. Page A6.)

headline: MGIC IS MORTGAGE PIONEER
abstract: The MGIC Investment Corporation has had a rough year, but the company has long been a leader in the home mortgage insurance business.   Founded in 1956 by Max H. Karl, MGIC's main business has been the sale of mortgage insurance policies to banks and thrift institutions. The policies guarantee repayment of home mortgage loans.

headline: Danes Buying U.S. Missiles
abstract: The Pentagon told Congress today that it intends to sell Denmark 33 antiship Harpoon missiles for $37 million.

headline: INDEPENDANCE OF CLARENDON AT CENTER OF INQUIRY
abstract: A key issue in the investigations surrounding Marc Rich & Company A.G., one of the world's largest commodity traders, has been the independence of a company that at one time was a subsidiary operating in the United States.   The Marc Rich empire encompasses dozens of corporations in numerous countries. The companies are closely held and information about them is difficult to obtain, but they operate under the umbrella of two parent companies: Marc Rich & Company A.G., a Swiss corporation, and Richco N.V., a Netherlands Antilles corporation.  'Substantially' Same Shareholders    The parent corporations are owned by ''substantially'' the same group of shareholders, according to Peter F. Ryan, the chief financial officer of Clarendon Ltd.

headline: CITICORP'S NET INCOME RISES 53.3%
abstract: Citicorp reported yesterday that the sharply increased profitability of its consumer business pushed up its second-quarter net income by 53.3 percent, to $210 million, from $137 million in the same period of last year. Per share earnings rose 50 percent, to $1.59, from $1.06.   Earnings by the company's so-called Individual Bank, the consumer division, soared to $56 million in the latest quarter, from $4 million. This was a major breakthrough in Citicorp's efforts to make a significant profit from consumer banking.

headline: Judge Clears Way For Weirton Vote
abstract: A judge has rejected two lawsuits seeking the release of more information on plans for an employee takeover of Weirton Steel, clearing the way for Friday's vote on the proposal.   United States District Judge Robert Maxwell denied a request to order the release of part of a consultant's report detailing reasons for an employee wage and benefit cut.

headline: IN A JAPAN TOWN, NOT ALL HAIL 'NO SMOKING' DAYS
abstract: By latest count, there are 7,370 people in this town, and while no one knows how many of them smoke, it can safely be said that a few are not happy these days.   Even less happy are the merchants who sell them their cigarettes.   Waki has taken a radical step by declaring three ''no smoking'' days a month in a campaign that began in June. Tobacco is not prohibited outright, but its use and sale are strongly discouraged. Posters warn of a terrible future for those who persist in their cigarette habit.

headline: SOUTHLAND OFFICIAL IN BRIBE PLEA
abstract: A vice president of the Southland Corporation, which runs the nationwide 7-Eleven convenience-store chain, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the chain.    No official has been charged with receiving a bribe in the scheme.   At the plea proceeding in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, it was also indicated that the company official, Eugene De Falco, had testified Monday before a grand jury known to be investigating whether other top Southland officials were also involved in the scheme.   According to one court document in the case - a letter that a prosecutor sent to an attorney for Southland in June - ''the co-conspirators known to the Government at this time include John Thompson.'' John P. Thompson is chairman and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based Southland, which says it is the 11th-largest retailer in the country.

headline: ADVANCE REPORTED BY CHADIAN REBELS
abstract: New gains by insurgent forces were reported today in eastern Chad, about 400 miles from here, adding to fears that another battle for this capital may be approaching.   Three times in the last four years, there has been fighting in Ndjamena, as the bombed-out buildings and bullet-riddled walls along Avenue Mobutu, Avenue Charles de Gaulle and other streets attest.   Alarm has been growing here since last month, when rebels led by former President Goukouni Oueddei and backed by Libya wrested control of Largeau, a northern garrison town, from troops of President Hissen Habre and pressed southeastward toward the oasis of Oum Chalouba.   Chad's Information Minister, Mahamat Soumalia, said today that Government troops were still resisting in the Oum Chalouba area but would probably have to withdraw again, this time to what he described as a strong line of defense at Biltine, about 100 miles farther south.

headline: Advertising; Providing Creativity For P.& G.
abstract: PROCTER & GAMBLE is the country's largest national advertiser, and it probably has the most stable agency relationships on record. Despite these two winning characteristics, Roy Grace, executive creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach's domestic operation, was relieved when the Cincinnati giant announced it was splitting with the agency last Nov. 16, ostensibly because of a product conflict in Europe.   ''I was pushing very, very strongly for us to resign the business,'' said the 46-year-old one-time art director, who became chairman of D.D.B./U.S. a month later.   Until it terminated with Doyle Dane, Procter & Gamble in all of its years had never completely left an economically healthy agency or one that planned to continue operating. D.D.B. had been one of its agencies for a decade. Of Procter & Gamble's estimated $671.8 million in billings in 1981, Doyle Dane had $20 million.

headline: 'MR. INSIDE' GOES SOLO AT LEHMAN
abstract: WITH his rumpled appearance and quiet demeanor, Lewis L. Glucksman h ardly looks like the kind of man to have ascended to the top of one o f Wall Street's most prestigious investment houses. And, Mr.  G lucksman, by his own admission, is a private person - a loner whose p assions in life are boating and carpentry and who feels u ncomfortable in the public eye.   Yet this reticent executive - whose office is plastered with sailing charts and pictures of clipper ships and who spends his free time reading books about naval warfare - will become the new chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., replacing one of Wall Street's best-known figures, Peter G. Peterson, Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration, who resigned 10 years to the day of coming to Lehman.   Not surprisingly, Mr. Glucksman's dramatic ascendancy to this top spot after a Lehman board meeting last week has been a topic of Wall Street speculation. In public statements issued by the two men, it was clear that Mr. Glucksman, who had for years been the No. 2 executive at Lehman, wanted to run the firm alone. While both he and Mr. Peterson said that the latter's departure was voluntary - Mr.  Peterson will leave to go into venture capital - the transition could not have taken place without Mr. Glucksman having been fully confident of the support of key Lehman partners as he pursued his ambitions.

headline: SEAS OFF JAPAN YIELDING GRIM FLIGHT 7 DEBRIS
abstract: After a week of reluctance, the seas north of Japan have finally begun to give up the remains of Korean Air Lines Flight 7.   One grim bit at a time this weekend, debris from the downed airplane, and possibly parts of bodies of some passengers as well, have washed ashore from the Sea of Okhotsk along the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.   One chunk of metal has been positively identified by airline officials as a section of the plane's vertical tail.  Another metal piece was pierced with some sort of bullet holes, which would be consistent with the ''cannon bursts'' that United States and Japanese Government officials said today had been fired at the jet before it was destroyed.

headline: MCCANN-ERICKSON ACTS TO UNIFY ITS OPERATIONS
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide, an advertising agency that is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, yesterday announced top management changes to help unify domestic and international operations.    McCann-Erickson is the fifth-largest ad agency in the world, and it has more gross income overseas than any other American agency.   Eugene H. Kummel, 61 years old, will step down as chairman of the company to become chairman of the executive committee.

headline: CEASE-FIRE ACCORD GAINED IN LEBANON WITH SAUDIS' HELP
abstract: The United States said yesterday that it regarded the announcement of a cease-fire in Lebanon as only ''a first step'' toward the more difficult goals of bringing about a strong central government in that country and the withdrawal of all Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces.   In New York, speaking to reporters at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel after the cease-fire announcement in Damascus, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he and President Reagan viewed the expected halt in the fighting as the start ''of an important process.''   He said the objectives of President Reagan and President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon ''remain unchanged, in wanting to see the removal of all foreign forces from Lebanon, the emergence of a strong central government of Lebanon, based of course on national reconciliation.'' In addition, he said the United States remained committed to insuring that any final settlement in Lebanon provides ''appropriate security arrangements'' along Israel's northern borders. Role of Marines Unchanged    As to the 1,600 American marines in Lebanon, Mr. Shultz indicated no change in their disposition at this time. He said their mission ''remains important and remains unchanged.'' He added, ''I think, however, they'll be a little more comfortable in carrying that mission out because they won't be subject to the crossfire that they have been in.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Chicago, has promoted Dale A. Holmer to vice president.     * The Futures Industry Association has elected Raymond A. Worseck president for the 1983-84 term.

headline: Argentine Party Invites Mrs. Peron to Congress
abstract: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron's political party has invited her to return from self-exile in Spain to preside over the party's congress next month.   Deolindo Bittel, first vice president of the Peronist party, said a letter inviting Mrs. Peron had been mailed on Saturday.

headline: Advertising; Watchdog Division's Director
abstract: love just out of college was advertising, has returned to it at age 47 richer by one husband, two children, a Ph.D. in education and a successful career in a seemingly unrelated field.   She is the new director of the Children's Advertising Review Unit of the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, whose self-policing function will probably be forced into a more important role since the Government-requested shelving of the National Association of Broadcasters Television Code.    And how can the advertising industry possibly fault a person who lives in Westport, Conn., and can say, ''My friends who are in advertising are the smartest, funniest and hardest working people I know.'' Obviously a woman with her head on straight, especially when she adds, ''I don't think we are adversaries.''

headline: Dunlop Holdings
abstract: Guaranty Nominees, a wholly owned nominee company of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, said it had increased to 17.44 percent, from 12.2 percent, its stake in Dunlop Holdings P.L.C. ordinary shares, held in the form of American Depositary Receipts. It now holds 25.1 million ordinary shares, up from 17.5 million, on behalf of a large number of individuals.

headline: BRITISH AIRWAYS RETIRES 70 OF ITS TOP EXECUTIVES
abstract: British Airways, the Government-owned carrier, announced today that 70 top executives were being retired early - 20 percent of its senior management.   The airline, which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wants to sell to private enterprise, said the move was aimed at increasing profitability.   The airline has reduced its manpower to 37,000, from a peak of 58,000 five years ago, and has said it wants to lay off another 2,000 more people in coming months.

headline: TEXT OF TASS STATEMENT ON DOWNING OF AIRLINER
abstract: Following is the text of a Soviet statement, issued today by the English-language service of Tass, the official press agency, about the Korean Air Lines plane:    As it has already been reported, on the night from August 31 to September 1 this year, an unidentified plane had rudely violated the Soviet state border and intruded deep into the Soviet Union's airspace. The intruder plane had deviated from the existing international route in the direction of the Soviet Union's territory by up to 500 kilometers and spent more than two hours over the Kamchatka Peninsula, the area of the Sea of Okhotsk and the island of Sakhalin.   In violation of international regulations the plane flew without navigation lights, did not react to radio signals of the Soviet dispatcher services and made no attempts to establish such communications contact.   It was natural that during the time the unidentified intruder plane was in the U.S.S.R. airspace Soviet antiair defense aircraft were ordered aloft, which repeatedly tried to establish contacts with the plane using generally accepted signals and to take it to the nearest airfield in the territory of the Soviet Union. The intruder plane, however, ignored all this. Over the Sakhalin island, a Soviet aircraft fired warning shots and tracer shells along the flying route of the plane.

headline: ALUMINUM'S MODEST UPTURN
abstract: In the 1850's, when aluminum sold for $545 a pound, Napoleon III used it to serve royalty at state dinners, relegating lesser guests to gold and silver. Later in the century, after two young men hit upon a process for producing the metal in quantity, the price plummeted to 57 cents a pound - a level that made aluminum better suited to soda cans than dinner service.   While far less dramatic than a century ago, sharp price fluctuations are still the bane of aluminum manufacturers. Now, as the industry enjoys a sharp upturn after its deepest recession in more than three decades, company executives and industry analysts say that maintaining stable, relatively high prices is crucial to sustain the industry's recovery.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Arltru Sought By Hartford    The Hartford National Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Arltru Bancorporation, a Massachusetts bank holding company, in an exchange of stock valued at $50 million.   Arltru, based in Lawrence, Mass., is the holding company for the Arlington Trust Company, an 18-branch bank with assets of $782 million as of June 30.

headline: CHAD SAYS PRISONER IS PROOF OF LIBYA LINK TO REBELS
abstract: The Chadian Government publicly displayed a prisoner identified as a Libyan soldier today and said his capture was ''physical proof'' of Libya's role in the conflict between proand anti-Government forces.   The Government paraded the soldier in front of 400 Government and party leaders as well as foreign reporters in the auditorium of the Foreign Ministry, where troops carrying automatic weapons stood guard.

headline: 30,000 MARCH
abstract: An estimated 30,000 marchers in a southern city today demanded the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila pleaded with him to accept a compromise aimed at averting ''a bloody revolution.''   The rally in the opposition-governed city of Cagayan, 500 miles south of Manila, was held a day after riot squads in the capital broke up protests with tear gas, clubs and guns, wounding 14 people and jailing 53. The Government said those arrested had been charged with sedition and rebellion.

headline: Sweden Hunting Submarine
abstract: The Swedish Navy dropped depth charges after spotting what was believed to be a foreign submarine stalking naval maneuvers near the Karlskrona naval base Tuesday night, the Defense Staff said today.

headline: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GUATEMALAN'S SISTER KIDNAPPED
abstract: Four armed men kidnapped the pregnant sister of President Efrain Rios Montt last week, officials said today.   The victim, Marta Elena Carlota Rios de Rivas, 36 years old, was abducted June 29 from a drugstore near the primary school where she worked as a teacher, said Rafael Escobar Arguello, deputy presidential press secretary.

headline: FIDELITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORAN GUERRILLAS ATTACK NATION'S THIRD LARGEST CITY
abstract: In some of the heaviest fighting since the start of the three-year-old civil war, rebel forces attacked the third largest city in El Salvador during the night.    Guerrilla radio broadcasts said that more than 300 Government soldiers had been killed or wounded in the fighting in the eastern city of San Miguel, which has a population of more than 150,000, and that the rebels had destroyed two bridges, two coffee warehouses and three gasoline stations.   The press office of the Salvadoran armed forces said 10 soldiers had been killed and 35 wounded in the battle.  There were no reports on guerrilla casualties.

headline: ISRAELIS APPROVE OUSTER OF MAYOR IN WEST BANK CITY
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet today endorsed a decision to dismiss the Arab Mayor of the occupied West Bank city of Hebron.  Cabinet officials said after the meeting that the Government would go ahead with a decision to restore the old Jewish quarter of that city despite local Arab resistance.   Meeting in its regular weekly session, the Cabinet also warned Jewish settlers in the Hebron region against taking the law into their own hands in punishing attacks by Arabs on Jews. After the meeting, Dan Meridor, the Cabinet Secretary, quoted Prime Minister Menachem Begin as having said, ''The security forces will protect the lives of the Jews all through Eretz Israel and will not allow anyone to act at his own discretion.'' Eretz Israel is Hebrew for ''Land of Israel.''

headline: 2 Bus Crashes in North India Kill 56 and Leave 50 Missing
abstract: At least 56 people were killed in two bus crashes in northern India last night and about 50 others were believed to be missing, the Press Trust of India reported today.   The news agency said rescue workers recovered the bodies of 50 passengers who were traveling in a bus swept away by a river swollen with monsoon rains near Gwalior, some 180 miles south of New Delhi.

headline: PRUDENTIAL IS CUTTING 1,700 JOBS
abstract: The Prudential Insurance Company said yesterday that it would shift 800 jobs out of northern New Jersey and eliminate a total of 1,700 jobs nationally as part of a consolidation program that would save $50 million a year.   Individual insurance administrative work now done in South Plainfield and Woodbridge, N.J., by 800 employees will be transferred to Fort Washington, Pa., near Philadelphia, over the next year and a half. While some of the 800 New Jersey workers will be offered transfers to the Philadelphia area, Joseph A. Vecchione, a spokesman for Prudential, said it was too soon to predict how many would move.

headline: Ryder Truck Account Is Going to Thompson
abstract: J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. has won the Ryder Truck Rental account.

headline: THREE INDICTED IN DRYSDALE COLLASPE
abstract: In the first criminal prosecutions stemming from the collapse of the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation last year, two of the company's top officials and a former senior partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company were indicted yesterday.    They were charged with defrauding the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of $290 million. In essence, they were accused of misrepresenting the worth of Drysdale Government Securities.   Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said the firm ''was insolvent the day it opened its doors.'' Its listed assets were transferred back to the company from which it was formed, Mr.  Morgenthau said.

headline: Afghan Rebels Kill 1,500 Foes, Leader Says
abstract: An Afghan guerrilla leader said today that Moslem rebels killed 1,500 Soviet and Afghan Government troops in July.   Abdul Rasool Sayaf, head of the Mujahedeen guerrillas, said the rebels shot down three MIG-23's with antiaircraft guns taken from captured Soviet tanks and destroyed 40 tanks in fighting northwest of the capital, Kabul.

headline: LAKER BLOCKED ON FILING SUIT IN U.S.
abstract: Liquidators of the bankrupt Laker Airways cannot sue British Airways or British Caledonian Airways in United States courts on charges of antitrust activity, a British appeals court ruled today.   Christopher Morris, an accountant with Touche Ross & Company who has overseen liquidation of the airline portion of Sir Freddie Laker's travel operations, filed a suit last November in the United States District Court in Washington, D.C., charging eight airlines with conspiring to drive the carrier out of business. Mr. Morris, who is seeking triple damages amounting to more than $1 billion, is expected to challenge today's ruling in the House of Lords, Britain's final court of appeal.   The ruling could make it impossible for Laker to enforce in Britain any judgment it might win in the Washington litigation against the British airlines or other defendants.

headline: Washington WatchKenneth B. Noble Proxy Rules For Activists
abstract: THE Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to change its shareholder-voting rules this week, which may make it harder for small shareholders and social activists to advance their causes at corporate meetings.   The commission will vote on whether to tighten or - less likely - to liberalize its rules allowing shareholders to include proposals in proxy materials. In the past, such proposals have included attempts to curtail business in South Africa, have questioned the morality of producing napalm and have pressed for bans on nuclear power.   The proposed changes reflect concern among some agency officials that activists and corporate gadflies have used existing rules to turn annual meetings and proxy votes into public spectacles. Currently a person holding one share of stock may offer proposals for voting.

headline: SHULTZ TELLS SENATE REPRISALS AGAINST SOVIET WOULD REQUIRE SUPPORT
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the Senate today that the United States would not invoke sanctions against the Soviet Union unless it received the international support needed to make the sanctions effective, according to senators who attended a closed, two-hour session.   Mr. Shultz reportedly told the senators that the Soviet Union had violated an international code of conduct when it destroyed Korean Air Lines Flight 7, and that reprisals should come not merely from the United States, but also from the rest of the world.   Defying the Administration's position, a group of conservative senators, meanwhile, moved to gain Congressional support for specific diplomatic and trade sanctions, in retaliation for the Soviet destruction of the plane.   The conservatives' proposal was introduced over the objections of the Senate leadership of both parties as an amendment to a resolution condemning the Soviet action. The Senate is scheduled to vote on the measure Wednesday, and leaders have predicted it will be adopted unanimously.

headline: AMEX CARVING A NEW NICHE
abstract: In the mid-1960's, the American Stock Exchange was the place to go for market action. At one point, trading got so heated that the president of the exchange issued a statement warning against excessive speculation in Amex stocks.   The late 1970's sparked investor interest in the the exchange, too. The focus then was on the Amex's energy stocks, which helped push the exchange's index to new highs.   Today, however, the Amex has lost some of its momentum. While the index again registered strong gains in the past year's bull market, the number of listed companies has steadily slipped. The volume of stock trading has also failed to grow as rapidly as that of its two main competitors, the New York Stock Exchange, which has started a push for the growth companies traditionally attracted to the Amex, and the over-the- counter market, whose sophisticated electronic trading systems are becoming more popular.

headline: Hearst Picks A Publisher
abstract: Charles J. Kennedy, whose resignation as publisher of Newsweek ''to try to run something himself'' was announced earlier this month, has been appointed publisher of Town & Country. Mr. Kennedy, 48 years old, succeeds David A. McCann, 54, who has been named publisher of Connoisseur magazine, another Hearst publication. Both appointments are effective Sept. 5.

headline: Rise in Jobs Off the Books
abstract: Workers in undeclared jobs are increasing in most Western countries and now represent about 10 percent of the total workforce, the International Labor Organization said today.   Italy, with 10 percent to 35 percent of the workforce classed as ''black economy'' labor, and the United States, with 23 percent, have the highest proportions, the organization said in a report.   Such labor was estimated at 8 to 12 percent in West Germany, 14 percent in Sweden, 10 percent in Britain and 3 to 5 percent in France.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: It has become increasingly clear since Syria expelled Yasir Arafat a week ago that the rebellion among his Fatah guerrillas in Lebanon is another variation of the long-running power struggle between the P.L.O. chairman and President Hafez al-Assad.   The rebels may have acted independently when they began their revolt, but their ability to expand the area under their control and repeatedly attack Arafat loyalists in Lebanon could have been done only with Syrian approval, and, at this stage, can be stopped only by Syrian decree.   Not surprisingly, the mediation team formed by the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis today will concentrate its efforts as much on patching up the Assad-Arafat rift as on dealing with the rebels and their demands.   Not only has the P.L.O. decided to focus on the Syrian-Arafat dispute, but so too have the would-be Arab mediators. Saudi Arabia and Algeria each sent envoys to Damascus today with an offer to convene a meeting in Saudi Arabia between Syrian and Arafat representatives to talk out their differences.

headline: CHRYSLER SAYS TALKS CONTINUE
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and Volkswagen of West Germany are still discussing cooperative operations, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said today.    ''I have been talking to Dr. Hahn and we will be meeting again in a couple of weeks,'' Mr. Iacocca said, referring to Karl H. Hahn, the chairman of Volkswagenwerk A.G. He said the most immediate prospect of cooperative efforts between the companies would be purchases of components from each other. Auto companies frequently buy from competitors parts they cannot make in economical quantities.

headline: POPE SAID TO PLAN VIENNA CALL FOR CHURCH FREEDOM
abstract: Two days before Pope John Paul II begins a four-day visit to Austria, his host, Franz Cardinal K"onig of Vienna, said the Pope would deliver a call from the Austrian capital to the neighboring Communist countries calling for religious freedom and a role for the Roman Catholic Church in promoting unity between Europe's East and West.   The head of the Austrian Roman Catholic Church is known to be close to the Pope and was one of the principal gatherers of votes in support of John Paul's election in the conclave nearly five years ago. His comments and their broadcast by the Vatican radio today were assumed to reflect the Pope's views of the purpose of the 20th foreign trip of his papacy.   ''John Paul II is going to speak in Vienna, the capital of neutral Austria, on the borderline of the two opposing power blocs, East and West,'' Cardinal K"onig told a Vatican radio interviewer.

headline: LIBYAN PLANES ARE REPORTED TO BOMB CHAD TOWN
abstract: Libyan warplanes bombed the Government outpost of Oum Chalouba in northeastern Chad today, a Government official said.    The attack, by Soviet-made MIG and Sukhoi fighter-bombers, lasted 90 minutes, according to Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia. There was no immediate report on casualties.

headline: SALVADORAN MILITARY IS SAID TO REGAIN MOMENTUM
abstract: Salvadoran and American officials say the Salvadoran military appears to have regained the momentum in the civil war with an offensive that began a month ago in several provinces.   American advisers acknowledge that the soldiers have met little resistance, and they say that if the army retreats to the barracks, as it has done repeatedly in the past, the guerrillas could regain a stronger position.   Moreover, the guerrillas were inactive during last year's rainy season, between May and September, but returned with renewed force in October. Despite these reservations, there is a new enthusiasm among Salvadoran officers and the American advisers, who have been among the most pessimistic about El Salvador's military abilities.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Federated Department Stores, Cincinnati, has named Clinton A.  Clark president and chief executive officer of its Children's Place division.

headline: REBEL CRITICIZES HOUSE VOTE
abstract: A leader of the anti-Sandinista guerrilla movement said Thursday night that the vote by the House of Representatives to cut off aid to his organization ended the possibility that the war in Nicaragua would end quickly.   ''The problem will not go away,'' said Edgar Chamorro Coronel, a director of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force.  ''Eventually the United States will have to get involved in the fighting,'' Mr. Chamorro said, ''because sooner or later the United States will have to intervene directly.''

headline: B.A.T's Profit Climbs by 27%
abstract: B.A.T Industries P.L.C., a retailer and tobacco producer, said today that lower taxes helped it increase profit 27 percent in the first six months of the year from the same 1982 period. Net income for the first half was $:189 million - about $283.5 million at current exchange rates - compared with $:184 million in the first half of 1982, the company said.

headline: Mitsubishi's 128K Chip
abstract: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it had started to ship samples of three models of a new high-capacity chip used to store information for computers. The 128K chips are erasable and reprogrammable, and can store about 131,000 characters, or enough to fill three standard-size newspaper pages, the company said. Production at a rate of 50,000 a month is to start in August.

headline: MERITS OF HARRIS TIE TO LANIER DEBATED
abstract: Can the Harris Corporation, marketer of sophisticated computers for the professional, find happiness with Lanier Business Products Inc., purveyor of copiers and a catalogue of relatively unsophisticated office equipment?   Officials at the two companies, understandably, believe that the pending acquisition of Lanier by Harris is a good one.   But the stock market appears relatively unimpressed with the deal. Harris shares, which traded at $48.50 just before the the transaction was announced on July 22, have dropped more than 10 points, closing today at $37.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. And some Securities analysts are concerned that the product lines of the two companies are a mismatch and that their sales forces may not be able to cope with the differences.

headline: P.L.O. Central Council Rallies Behind Arafat
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization's central council, rallying behind Yasir Arafat, the group's chairman, expressed ''regret and great pain'' today over his expulsion from Syria in June.   In a communique issued after a three-day meeting, the council also called for ''immediate dialogue'' to rebuild Palestinian-Syrian relations.

headline: DOW DECLINES 3.21 IN LIGHT TRADING
abstract: Stock prices eased yesterday on uncertainty over the course of interest rates. Trading also decreased.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was about level at noon, repeated its recent pattern of late declines. It finished 3.21 points lower, at 1,207.23. Retreating stocks outnumbered those that advanced by 941 to 630, and volume receded to 66.5 million, from 97.1 million the day before.

headline: Tampa Bank Indictments
abstract: Two executives have been indicted on charges that they tried to gain control of the Metropolitan Bank and Trust Company by secretly using loans from it to buy up its own stock shortly before it collapsed last year.   A Federal grand jury returned a 15- count indictment Monday against Donald A. Regar, 46 years old, a former president of the bank, and Allen Z. Wolfson, 36, a land developer.

headline: 21 Bodies Recovered In Colombian Mudslide
abstract: Rescue workers found 21 bodies today at a hydroelectric project where officials said 120 people died in a mudslide.

headline: Colt Industries Shows Profit
abstract: Colt Industries yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $26.2 million, or $1.06 a share, in contrast to a net loss of $164.8 million a year earlier, which included a provision of $193 million for the disposition of its steelmaking facility in Midland, Pa.   Sales declined 5.3 percent, to $401.6 million, from $424.1 million.

headline: President Adds Job Of Chief at Viacom
abstract: Terrence A. Elkes, president of Viacom International Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief executive, the company said yesterday.   Mr. Elkes, 49, succeeds Ralph M. Baruch, 60, who remains as chairman. Both men will continue to occupy the company's office of the chief executive.

headline: SOVIET BROADENS ARMS PROPOSALS, RAISING U.S. HOPE
abstract: The Soviet Union has both broadened and slightly moderated its strategic arms proposals, causing the White House to voice hope today that Moscow intends now ''to move the negotiations forward.''   Well-placed officials said Soviet negotiators in Geneva last week spelled out new details of Moscow's position. They proposed to limit each side to a total of 1,200 land- and submarine-based multiplewarhead missiles and strategic bombers armed with cruise missiles. Single-warhead missiles were not covered by this limit.

headline: President Leaving Dome Petroleum
abstract: William E. Richards resigned yesterday as president and director of Dome Petroleum Ltd. and its associated companies. The step clears the way for the new chairman and chief executive, 55-year-old J. Howard Macdonald, to stamp his own management style on the financially troubled group, which is based in Calgary, Alberta.   The resignation is effective Oct. 1, the day Mr. Macdonald, who is currently group treasurer of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, takes over the top job.

headline: G.M. Changes In Steel Orders
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will reduce its steel purchases from the Republic Steel Corporation in the 1984 car-model year, starting this October, according to G.M.  sources.   They declined to specify the level of order reduction.  G.M. had decided in the past month that it would order steel in 1984 from the same 12 steel suppliers as the year before.

headline: Sperry to Market Ericsson System
abstract: The Sperry Corporation, a New York- based computer and electronics company, has agreed to market the Ericsson 2100 Branch Automation System to financial institutions in Europe and Southeast Asia, Ericsson Information Systems said.

headline: Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer An Economist Changes Sides WASHINGTONTHE Reagan Administration, which was famous for the infighting over economic policy
abstract: between the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget, has accomplished one of the more interesting trades of this or any other season.   Lawrence A. Kudlow, who was one of the sharpest infighters for the O.M.B. team before leaving this spring, is being replaced as associate director for economic policy at the budget office by a Treasury Department economist and tax specialist. He is J. Gregory Ballentine, currently deputy assistant secretary for tax analysis. He will have to bone up on his budget economics and forecasting, but both O.M.B. and the Treasury are happy with the move.

headline: U.S. Calls for Meeting Of the Security Council
abstract: uf813    UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 - The United States called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to consider the downing of the Korean Air Lines passenger jet. The Council is expected to begin debate on Friday.

headline: Development Loans
abstract: Multilateral development banks are providing more contingency and local financing to developing countries in the face of growing economic and political uncertainties, an energy adviser to the Asian Development Bank said today. The adviser, Jayanta Madhab, said the viability of development projects was increasingly unpredictable because of changes in the world economic environment, lower oil prices and inflation.

headline: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Milwaukee Road Takeover Studied
abstract: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, a freight and commuter service, announced that it intends to acquire the Milwaukee Road rail system.

headline: ENDORSING A COMPUTER MONOPOLY
abstract: The Apple-Franklin litigation has been the subject of much notoriety and controversy. It has broadened beyond a dispute between two parties and has raised questions involving the rights of computer manufacturers, software companies, and, most importantly, consumers.   Franklin is of course sympathetic to the needs of the software industry to enjoy protection for their original works of authorship. This issue was never a question. Our dispute with Apple involves a substantially different matter. Namely, whether the copyright laws can be stretched so far as to afford protection in areas for which they were never intended.

headline: HUSBAND OF JET'S PASSENGER SUES SOVIET UNION AND AIRLINE
abstract: A bereaved husband filed a $52 million federal suit against Korean Air Lines and the Soviet Union today, saying wanton negligence caused his wife to die when a South Korean jetliner was downed Thursday.   Melvin Belli, an attorney, filed the suit in United States District Court in San Francisco for Michael Kole, 47, of Loudenville, N.Y., whose wife, Muriel, 40 years old, is presumed dead after the jet went down Thursday.

headline: A BID TO TAKE BIG OIL'S STATIONS AWAY
abstract: With profit margins perilously thin at the pump and hundreds of stations being forced out of business each month, a high-stakes battle is being waged between the major oil companies and the thousands of small businessmen who operate - and generally own - independent service stations.   But the battleground is now being expanded beyond the pumps: It has reached the legislative chambers of statehouses around the country.   The independents, who buy their gasoline from the oil companies and label it as such, are increasingly complaining of price gauging. In almost every state, the independents have charged the oil companies with supplying gasoline to their own company- operated stations at steep discounts. Many are now urging new laws that would create ''retail divorcement,'' or prohibit large oil companies from operating their own retail outlets.

headline: ABC Up 8.9% In 2d Quarter
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies reported yesterday the best single quarter in its history, with contributions coming from television, radio and publishing, but not from cable.   Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman, reported that second-quarter income rose 8.9 percent, to $64.6 million, or $2.20 a share, from $59.3 million, or $2.06 a share, in the comparable quarter last year.

headline: Stone Asks Nicaragua Talks
abstract: Richard B. Stone, the United States special envoy, said today that Nicaragua should open talks with its opponents and ''fulfill the promises'' it made when the Sandinistas took power in 1979. Mr. Stone, on the ninth day of a visit to the region, also said United States ships now off Nicaragua may ''decrease the risks'' of fighting in Central America. He arrived in Colombia from San Jose, Costa Rica.

headline: THE NATION'S PRISONERS JOIN THE LABOR FORCE
abstract: LEAVENWORTH, Kan.    PENOLIA GARLINGTON rolls out of bed at 5:30 A.M. here, long before an intense sun begins to bake the undulating fields of brown grass. Every weekday, she catches the 7:15 bus to work, where for eight hours she operates a punch press in a small metal-working factory.   What distinguishes her from other blue-collar employees in this state though, is that when she returns home at night, the bus drops her off at the Kansas Correctional Institution in Lansing.   Mrs. Garlington is serving 10 years to life for second-degree murder.

headline: A MODERN CONDOMINIUM AMID WEST SIDE SOLIDARITY
abstract: A certain drab solidity prevails along 79th Street west of Columbus Avenue. Most of the boxlike brick buildings, 15 stories tall, date from the period of heavy construction between the two world wars. It is an environment unaccustomed in recent years to new construction.    That changed last March when the owners of the Park West Memorial Chapel decided to sell. Their building occupied a 13,000-square-foot site on the northwest corner of Columbus and 79th, opposite Theodore Roosevelt Park behind the Museum of Natural History.

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS LOST $119.2 MILLION IN QUARTER
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said late last night that it lost $119.2 million in the second quarter, a deficit it attributed to a sudden plunge in sales of home computers and software. In a separate announcement, it said that the executive in charge of the home computer business, William J. Turner, had resigned.   Mr. Turner, who had been president of the Consumer Group, accepted a position as the president of the Banking Services Group at Automatic Data Processing Inc., a computer services company in Clifton, N.J.   Texas Instruments' loss was the second huge one announced by a home computer company this week. On Thursday, Warner Communications announced a surprisingly large $283.4 million loss because of problems at its video game and computer subsidiary, Atari Inc., which had a $310.5 million operating loss. Texas Instruments, Warner and Mattel, which lost $20.4 million, had a combined deficit of $423 million in the quarter, a testament to severe price cutting and oversupply in the home computer and video game businesses.

headline: 3 SOLIDARITY FUGITIVES SURRENDER
abstract: Three fugitive officials of the banned Solidarity union have emerged from hiding and been granted amnesty under arrangements aimed at ending underground opposition.   Television showed the three men after they had surrendered and met with Justice Minister Sylwester Zawadzki.

headline: Assault on Rebels Reported in Chad
abstract: Government forces counterattacked rebel positions today in the second day of fighting at an oasis crossroads in northeastern Chad, officials in Ndjamena, the capital, reported.   About 1,500 soldiers have been deployed on both sides at Oum Chalouba, where Libyan-backed insurgents, in a five-hour battle Tuesday, renewed their month-long offensive against forces loyal to President Hissen Habre.

headline: Peking Criticizes U.S.On Taiwan Arms Sale
abstract: China criticized the Reagan Administration today for plans to sell Taiwan $530 million worth of arms, saying the package showed the United States Government ''wants to continue the arms sale to Taiwan on a large scale.''   The official New China News Agency said the package is ''one of the largest sales of the kind ever made by the U.S. Government.''

headline: ISRAELIS FLEXIBLE ON PULLOUT, ARENS HINTS
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Arens today redefined Israel's conditions for withdrawing from Lebanon, saying that even if Syrian troops remained, the Israelis might leave the western and central sectors once the Lebanese Army or local militias could police the territory.   However, he said, Israel will not leave the eastern sector, facing the Syrians in the Bekaa Valley, if the Syrians do not withdraw and the Lebanese Army is not deployed there.   The Defense Minister, looking tired, explained the evolving Israeli position during an hourlong interview in his office. His remarks came two days after Israel's withdrawal from the Shuf Mountains, overlooking Beirut, to the Awali River, just north of Sidon.

headline: CHIEF IS REPLACED AT TROUBLED ATARI
abstract: Raymond E. Kassar, the mercurial executive who led Atari Inc.  through a period of breakneck growth and sudden collapse, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday.   Warner Communications Inc., Atari's parent company, said James J.  Morgan, 41-year-old executive vice president of marketing for the United States cigarette operations of Philip Morris Inc., would succeed him on Sept. 6.   Mr. Morgan will face the task of rebuilding a company that has been shaken by huge losses in its core home video game and computer businesses and by widespread turmoil in management ranks.   His appointment underscores a trend in the home computer industry toward hiring marketing expertise over engineering knowledge. Mr.  Morgan, who says he owns a video game machine but is not familiar with computers, will become one of several Atari executives with experience in consumer marketing but not in electronics.

headline: RATES RISE A BIT IN QUIET DAY
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Analysts said there was no change in the economic or financial outlook to account for the negligible rise in rates.   By late in the day, rates for Treasury bills ranged from unchanged to higher by four basis points in the case of one-year bills. Their rate rose to 9.47 percent from 9.43 percent. Among recently sold Treasury notes and bonds, prices fell no more than a quarter of a point, with most issues falling an eighth of a point or less. The 12 percent bonds due in 2013, for example, fell 2/32 and were offered at 102 14/32 to yield 11.69 percent.

headline: WAR POWERS BILL WINS INITIAL APPROVAL
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a compromise today that would continue the deployment of American troops in Lebanon for an additional 18 months.    The vote was 30 to 6, with four Democrats and two Republicans opposing a measure that has the backing of the White House and most Congressional leaders of both parties.   But even many lawmakers who voted in favor of the resolution expressed growing alarm about events in the Middle East and uncertainty over the long-term implications of the bill.   Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, a senior Democrat on the committee, said the vote ''does not reflect the closeness of the issue.'' But he predicted that the resolution would eventually go through Congress because members would come to see it as ''the least bad alternative.''

headline: REAGAN URGES THE HOUSE TO BACK I.M.F. INCREASE
abstract: Although it was unclear whether proponents had the votes to win, the Reagan Administration today urged the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives to hold a scheduled vote Thursday on the $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund.   All sides acknowledged this evening that they lacked the committed votes for passage.  The bill has been approved in the Senate but is opposed by many members of both parties in the House.  Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan met with House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts and the majority leader, Jim Wright of Texas, and asked them not to delay the scheduled vote, according to Treasury and House staff members. Earlier in the day, Congressmen and staff members said the vote was being delayed because approval was in doubt.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * AIG Capital Funding, a unit of American International Group, will issue $150 million of commercial paper, through Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc.   * Dayton-Hudson Corp. filed a shelf registration for $200 million of debt securities.

headline: Ford Unit's Shelf Filing
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company said today that it had filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering up to $500 million of medium-term notes.

headline: AMNESTY FOR SOLIDARITY FIGURE WHO GAVE UP
abstract: The Polish Government granted an unconditional amnesty today to Wladyslaw Hardek, a senior leader of the Solidarity union who surrendered to the police and who urged other fugitives to do the same.   In Cracow, where Mr. Hardek was questioned by the military prosecutor, an editor at P.A.P., the official press agency, said the underground union leader was released this afternoon.   Mr. Hardek's surrender, and his televised appeal to others to turn themselves in, shocked supporters of the banned labor federation.

headline: Oil Demand Rise Seen
abstract: United States petroleum demand has bottomed out and will rise through the first half of 1984, the Energy Information Administration said today. Demand is projected to rise to 15.7 million barrels daily in the first half of 1984, after reaching a low of 14.8 million barrels a day in the first half of 1983, the administration said. As consumption picks up in the second half of this year, it added, demand for 1983 as a whole is expected to rise to an average of 15.1 million barrels a day, compared with 15.3 million in 1982.

headline: CO-OP PLAN AVERTS FALTBUSH HOUSING ABANDONMENT
abstract: Housing abandonment mostly affects poor people, but it does not hurt poor neighborhoods exclusively. It also occurs in middle-class areas.   A case in point is Brooklyn's Flatbush section, a sprawling neighborhood where a large stock of middle-income housing has been imperiled by the decay and abandonment of low-income housing.   So it was with a sense of excitement that officials from city agencies, community housing, legal, and social service groups and a Citicorp subsidiary gathered recently in the lobby of the 79-unit apartment building at 2215 Newkirk Avenue in Flatbush.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.568 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.542 percent at last week's auction.   * Diagnostic Retrieval Systems Inc. filed an offering of $25 million of subordinated debentures due in 1998 and convertible into the company's class B common, through Drexel Burnham Lambert.   * Swift Energy Co. filed an offering of $30 million of limited partnership interests in Swift Energy Income Partners 1983-84, under which a series of limited partnerships are to be formed to purchase and operate oil and gas properties in the continental U.S. Common Stock   * Conifer-Essex Group filed an offering of 400,000 shares, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; DON'T PUNISH THE RICH: THEY MAKE JOBS
abstract: WHERE do jobs come from?  We answered last week that they come simply from those who hire - from bosses. We also considered society's attitude toward bosses; and because bosses who succeed tend to do well financially, this includes society's attitude toward the rich.  One of the clearest signals the rich receive about society's attitude toward them comes quietly but forcefully in the tax laws. Our existing tax system is based on a progressive scale. The more money you make, the higher your percentage of tax. The individual who earns twice as much as another pays more than twice as much tax. The principal rationale for this is a platitude that is on the tongues of all politicians and many citizens: ''The rich have a greater ability to pay.''  It sounds good: Let the wealthy fund the Government, for the most part. But one of the verities of life is that for every benefit, there is a cost.

headline: NAMIBIA TALKS SNAGGED OVER U.N. ROLE
abstract: -West Africa, Aug. 25 - One of the longest-standing issues of the negotiations over independence for this disputed territory came up again today, only a day after South Africa told the Secretary General of the United Nations that it could be considered settled.    The Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, scheduled a round of talks with an array of political parties, ethnic fronts, factions and splinter groups in an effort to demonstrate the United Nations' impartiality toward all the groups that could participate in an election it is supposed to supervise.   South African reservations about such impartiality has been a major issue in the efforts to turn the territory into the independent nation of Namibia. But Wednesday, at the conclusion of talks in Cape Town with Mr. Perez de Cuellar, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha declared it to be ''no longer an issue'' as far as his Government was concerned.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Aug. 1, 1983 SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on the Occupied Arab Territories at 3:30 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Investor Program Curbed by Court
abstract: A New Hampshire man has been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with fraudulently offering to investors promissory notes paying a minimum of 50 percent interest per year.   Judge Martin F. Loughlin of the Federal District Court here has issued a temporary restraining order against Richard J. Greenlaw of Henniker, N.H., and plans an initial hearing Oct. 4.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Beatrice Foods Co.  has named Warren Lewis president of its refrigerated warehouse division and I. Donald Rosuck president of its newly formed home products division.     * Biogen Inc., Geneva, has appointed Paul J. Appermont vice president- trade and licensing.

headline: Corporate Spies
abstract: To the Business Editor:   ''Boom Days for Political Risk Consultants'' (Aug. 7) did a disservice to many of us in the field of political risk consulting. Its subtitle, ''C.I.A. alumni have flocked to the profession,'' and concentration upon that segment of our profession failed to do justice to what is a far more diverse pool of skilled individuals.    In my own experience, political risk consultants are an eclectic group; for every Central Intelligence Agency alumnus or alumna that I have met, I can name several political risk consultants with backgrounds in academia, private business or branches of government other than the intelligence agencies.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied Corp.'s Bendix unit announced that it would establish a major manufacturing and assembly facility in Bessemer City, N.C., to produce a complete line of factory automation systems.   * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Yegen Associates Inc., a Paramus, N.J., consumer loan production company, in a transaction valued at more than $15 million.    * Bunker Ramo Information Systems, a subsidiary of Allied Corp., said it would provide electronic systems to the new financial services centers being established in Sears, Roebuck & Co. stores by Sears' Dean Witter Reynolds subsidiary.

headline: BOC Selling Stake In Medical Unit
abstract: The BOC Group P.L.C. of London announced that it would sell its 52 percent stake in Mountain Medical Equipment Inc., a producer of oxygen concentrators for home health care, and said it expected the sale to be made either to a corporate buyer, or through a secondary public offering of stock. The sale is to be made through BOC's United States subsidiaries, Airco Industries and Glasrock Medical Services, each of which hold 26 percent.

headline: Nicaraguan Says U.S.  Ships Honduras Arms
abstract: Interior Minister Tomas Borge Martinez has charged that the United States is shipping the Honduran Army weapons and equipment to wage war on Nicaragua.   Mr. Borge told reporters Saturday that an arms shipment consisting of 12 jet fighters, four bombers, 20 M-79 tanks, 60 armored tanks and 10 155-millimeter cannon was due in Honduras within weeks.   Mr. Borge also said President Reagan had ordered two detachments of American soldiers of Hispanic origin to assimilate into the Honduran forces to participate in plans to assassinate Nicaraguan leaders.

headline: Japanese Sale in Turkey
abstract: A Japanese consortium has won a $75.7 million order for hydroelectric power plant equipment from Turkey, the Nissho Iwai Corporation said today. Its partners are Hitachi Ltd., the Toshiba Corporation, the Fuji Electric Company and the NPC Engineering Corporation.

headline: Manville Hearing Set
abstract: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge in New York has scheduled a Sept. 13 hearing on the Manville Corporation's proposed sale of Johns-Manville Canada Inc. for $117 million, the corporation has announced. The Denver-based asbestos and building supply manufacturer said on Friday that the bankruptcy judge first must approve the sale of the company, which owns the Jeffrey asbestos mine in Asbestos, Quebec.

headline: Revlon Hires TV Star To Promote a Perfume
abstract: In the minds of Revlon top brass, the role of Alexis Carrington played in the TV series ''Dynasty'' by Joan Collins is that of a scoundrel.

headline: Marc Rich Assets May Be Frozen; Sale of U.S.  Unit Is Cited
abstract: A Federal judge in New York has given the United States Attorney's office permission to freeze some of the assets of Marc Rich & Company A.G., one of the world's biggest commodities traders, in order to collect $1 million in fines for contempt of court.   The authorization, at a hearing Friday by Judge Leonard B. Sand, followed the disclosure in court that the Swiss company, based in Zug, Switzerland, had sold its American subsidiary, Marc Rich & Company International Ltd., to Clarendon A.G. Ltd., a new concern led by some of the principals of Marc Rich A.G.   The United States Attorney's Office called the American subsidiary Rich's ''only real asset in the United States.'' Restraining Notices   After the hearing, Morris Weinberg, the Assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case, served restraining notices on the Chase Manhattan Bank, the principal American bank of Rich, and others connected with the company.   A telephone call yesterday to the Rich office at 650 Third Avenue in New York was answered by the operator with the word ''Clarendon.'' She said the only person who could provide any information was Peter Ryan, who was not further identified and who did not return two calls.

headline: Brown's Lenox Bid
abstract: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, which is to acquire Lenox Inc. for about $426 million, began accepting Lenox shares at midnight Friday and will begin payment tomorrow. Lenox shareholders will receive $45 a share for their shares after the effect of a 100 percent stock dividend.

headline: RISE IN RATES HURTS DEVELOPING NATIONS
abstract: After an eight-month respite, one of the main culprits in the international debt crisis - interest rates - are on the rise again.  Since late May, the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, which determines the size of interest payments on at least two-thirds of the $600 billion debt owed by developing countries to foreign creditors, has risen about a percentage point, to the 10.3 percent level. Morgan Guaranty put the rate as high as 10.5 percent on Friday.   With so much debt tied to fluctuations in that short-term rate, the increase that has occurred in the last six weeks would, if sustained over the course of a year, add $4 billion or more to the interest payments of debtor nations, according to financial experts.

headline: People
abstract: * George S. Fabian promoted to executive vice president at SSC&B.   * Richard M. Ruud named senior vice president and West Coast manager of W.B. Doner & Company, Los Angeles.

headline: THE EMPIRE AND EGO OF DONALD TRUMP
abstract: HE made his presence known on the island of Manhattan in the mid 70's, a brash Adonis from the outer boroughs bent on placing his imprint on the golden rock. Donald John Trump exhibited a flair for self-promotion, grandiose schemes - and, perhaps not surprisingly, for provoking fury along the way.   Senior realty titans scoffed, believing that braggadocio was the sum and substance of the blond, blue-eyed, six-footer who wore maroon suits and matching loafers, frequented Elaine's and Regine's in the company of fashion models, and was not abashed to take his armed bodyguard-chauffeur into a meeting with an investment banker.   The essence of entrepreneurial capitalism, real estate is a business with a tradition of high-rolling megalomania, of master builders striving to erect monuments to their visions. It is also typically dynastic, with businesses being transmitted from fathers to sons and grandsons, and carried on by siblings. In New York, the names of Tishman, Lefrak, Rudin, Fisher, Zeckendorf come to mind.

headline: OSBORNE'S COLLAPSE SOBERS THE INDUSTRY
abstract: With orders evaporating , creditors knocking at its doors and $45 million in debt, the Osborne Computer Company sought shelter by filing for corporate reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. The development was just another in a woeful string of losses and dismissals that had sobered the high- flying personal computer industry in recent months. Osborne was once a golden boy of the industry. Founded by a brash British entrepreneur, Adam Osborne, the company pioneered the low-cost portable computer and packaged software. But competition from other portable computer makers plus ill-timed product announcements this year left Osborne with almost no cash flow. As a competitor said, ''One of the big hitters just hit the dust.''   Another Adam was having his troubles. Coleco's much-touted Adam Computer has been awaiting approval by the F.C.C. for weeks, but delays continue. Agency officials said the company had failed to provide the software to run the computer's printer and thus it had suspended testing. Shipment delays will be at least a month now, and could cost Coleco substantial fall sales.

headline: Market Place; Cash Strategy In Bull Market
abstract: INTEREST rates have moved higher since the middle of May and stock prices have edged lower since the middle of June, proving again that rates often call the tune in advance for the equity markets. But money keeps pouring into the coffers of investment advisers. What stocks have they been buying lately?   Interviews with money managers yield two common themes to their current investment strategies: on the one hand, there is no rush to build up cash reserves but, on the other, they are generally conservative - in view of the large gains registered by a bull market now in its 12th month - in putting fresh cash to work.

headline: CHINA SAYS VIETNAM GROWS OPIUM TO EARN FUNDS
abstract: China has accused Vietnam of having grown opium since 1981 to earn foreign exchange for its hard-pressed economy.  Its charge was made in the current issue of the monthly Liaowang.  The magazine is published by the official New China News Agency, which also circulated some details in an earlier news dispatch.   The magazine printed a picture of a document in Vietnamese that it said was issued last October by the Dong Van district in Vietnam's Ha Tuyen Province outlining preparations for opium poppy production in 1982 and 1983. The Chinese authorities said they had been given the document by a Vietnamese refugee who crossed into China.
