headline: DEATH TOLL CLIMBS TO 6 IN ORLY BOMBING
abstract: The death toll in the bomb attack at Orly Airport rose to six today with the death of a French boy, and the police announced that one of those killed was a Greek-American who was about to leave on a flight to Istanbul with his Turkish fiancee.   Officials said 48 people remained hospitalized for injuries suffered when a bomb exploded in a suitcase Friday at a Turkish Airlines check-in counter. A total of 56 were injured, and many of those still hospitalized were reported today to be in serious or critical condition. The Interior Minister, Gaston Defferre, said in a television interview that he feared more would die.

headline: U.S. DEFICIT WORRIES MRS. THATCHER
abstract: Amid mutual declarations of friendship, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain met with President Reagan today but came away ''not assured at all'' that Mr. Reagan planned any new actions to reduce the United States deficit.   Mrs. Thatcher said at a news conference here that the Administration appeared to have ''a different view'' about the effects of the deficit than she did. She said she had made it clear she felt the high deficit was keeping interest rates up and hampering economic growth.   The Prime Minister held a full day of meetings with Mr. Reagan, senior Administration officials, members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Paul A. Volcker, Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: MONTEDISON: SHIFT IN STRATEGY
abstract: Although Montedison, the giant Italian chemicals company, appears to be drowning in red ink, its stock is soaring, and so is morale at company headquarters here.   The reason is that Montedison is seen by industry analysts, and apparently many of its own employees, as a company not only on the way up but also leading the way among Europe's chemicals companies.   After spending a decade as one of Italy's bloated, loss-producing, Government-controlled companies, Montedison started a new life in June 1981, when a group of leading businessmen bought a controlling interest. Since then, the company, which had sales of $6.6 billion last year, has acquired a new management team and ruthlessly trimmed its operations at a cost of more than 10,000 jobs.

headline: Chrysler Warrants
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation Loan Guarantee Board will consider the auto maker's request that the board delay selling the 14.4 million Chrysler stock warrants it holds, a spokesman for the panel said today.

headline: New Magazine Aimed At Women Physicians
abstract: The medical profession is inundated with publications aimed at doctors, and most live well on advertising revenues from the bigspending pharmaceuticals industry. And the consumer publishing field is inundated with publications for women because, in a majority of households, they make the most frequent buying decisions.   Allison Newberry, 30-year-old former media director of the Smith Kline & French pharmaceutical company, will, in a way, be bringing the two together in Medica magazine, which will be subtitled Women Practicing Medicine. The magazine's first issue is due in September; after one other issue this year, it will begin six-times-a-year publication in 1984.

headline: Malta Leaves U.N. Meeting In Dispute Over Arab Boycott
abstract: Malta stunned the United Nations Conference on the Palestinians here tonight by walking out in a dispute over the Arab boycott of a Maltese company.   Malta's permanent United Nations ambassador in New York, Victor Gauci, who had been elected the official recorder of conference proceedings, was greeted by silence when he announced Malta would withdraw over the boycott of the company for trading with Israel.

headline: ANOTHER O'NEIL AT RKO
abstract: Shane O'Neil, a member of the family that founded the General Tire and Rubber Company, has been named president and chief operating officer of its big RKO General Inc. subsidiary.   Mr. O'Neil, 36, has been with RKO for 13 years. He succeeds Hubert J. DeLynn, 62, as chief operating officer and Frank Shakespeare, 58, as president.

headline: BLAST IN LEBANON KILLS FRENCHMAN
abstract: A French soldier died in an accidental explosion today that destroyed a French ammunition truck in West Beirut. A short while later a bomb ripped through the Air France offices in East Beirut, wounding three Lebanese, the authorities said.   Maj. Alain de Lestrade, spokesman for the French contingent in the multinational force, said a fire accidentally blew up crates of ammunition loaded into a truck outside a building used by the French forces, killing the French soldier and injuring eight others.

headline: BONN LEADER OFF TO MOSCOW TODAY FOR VITAL TALKS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl travels to Moscow Monday on an official visit that is expected to highlight how the Soviet leaders plan to approach East-West relations as the deadline nears for the deployment of American missiles in Europe.   As the first head of government of a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to meet with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, the West German Chancellor has repeatedly made it clear that he will express unflinching support for the deployment of mediumrange missiles in December in the absence of a Soviet-United States arms accord.   But he has also suggested that he will seek areas of accommodation between West Germany and the Soviet Union.

headline: SEOUL'S EFFORT TO INDUSTRIALIZE
abstract: Despite its progress in developing heavy industry, South Korea is still straining to become an industrial nation.    While its path to prosperity appears the same as Japan's two decades earlier - sending a flood of manufactured goods into foreign markets - the business practices of its East Asian neighbor may hinder its development.    In any case, in today's world of slower economic growth, increased trade barriers and accelerated technological change, the ascent is expected to be far more difficult for South Korea than it was for Japan.    ''It's been said that the world was fooled once - by Japan,'' said Chung Mong-Joon, president of Hyundai Heavy Industries, a major shipbuilder that is part of Korea's largest industrial group. ''It isn't going to happen again. Climbing up the ladder to become an industrialized nation by exporting manufactured goods will be far more difficult for South Korea.''

headline: Japanese to Buy Planes
abstract: Japan Air Lines, 37.7 percent Government-owned, wants to buy about 10 new aircraft to replace its DC-8s and has asked three aircraft manufacturers to suggest suitable replacements, Yasumoto Takagi,president, said today. He told reporters the airline approached Boeing and McDonnell Douglas of the United States and Airbus Industrie of France.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; WHY THE EXPERIMENTS HAVEN'T WORKED
abstract: THE trading systems of the future   will emerge not from experiments designed or fostered by government but from the forces of competition, technology and investor needs.  Merrill Lynch recently decided to discontinue its participation in two trading experiments - the so-called 19c-3 experiment fostered by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which tested market making in certain listed stocks outside the normal auction process of the New York Stock Exchange, and the National Securities Trading System of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange.  Unfortunately, the computerized methods involved in these experiments aroused more interest than the benefits each might have brought to the marketplace. This focus may actually have doomed the experiments by clouding and to an extent blunting the broader goals that the S.E.C., Merrill Lynch and other industry stakeholders had in mind.

headline: Danish Unemployment
abstract: Unemployment in Denmark fell in May, for the first time this year, to 10.7 percent from April's 10.8 percent, the Government said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Columbia Chase Corp., Braintree, Mass., said it signed an agreement with Fuel Tech Inc. to provide commercial and industrial fuel suppliers a system for making their fuel more economical and less polluting.     * Crown Zellerbach Corp., San Francisco, said it would invest more than $30 million to build a wood products plant near McComb, Miss. The plant, scheduled to begin operation in late 1984, will produce 100 million board feet a year of lumber for residential construction.

headline: Brazil Seeking Funds for 1983
abstract: Brazil plans to press its private creditors at a meeting in New York Friday for quick release of $1.7 billion of the $4.4 billion loan package that commercial banks put together last autumn, Brazilian finance officials said here today.   Brazil is also expected to ask that $3 billion of a proposed $6.5 billion increase in commercial bank lending for 1983-84 be provided this year.

headline: Two Join Antarctic Pact
abstract: Brazil and India were admitted as members of the Antarctic Treaty today and will join the 14 other member countries on Tuesday for two weeks of talks on the future of the continent. A special meeting of the treaty consultative group accepted the two countries, which have both sent scientific expeditions to the continent and intend to set up research stations, its chairman, John Rowland, said here.

headline: Economic Scene; U.S. Gains In Technology
abstract: TALK has it that the United States is losing ground in the race to develop the fast-growth, high-technology industries critical to economic success. But the evidence mustered by economists tends to support the opposite thesis: That we have a longstanding comparative advantage in what ought to be called ''high-creativity'' industries.   These are industries like medical diagnostic equipment, satellite communications, computer- aided industrial design, fiber optics, lasers and biotechnology that marry computers with something else. And they include computer hardware and software producers themselves.

headline: 1,200 Italian Prisoners Declare Hunger Strike
abstract: More than 1,200 prisoners in four Italian jails went on a hunger strike today to demand penal reforms, especially a reduction in pretrial detention, according to the prisoners.   More than 800 prisoners at Ucciardone jail in Palermo, Sicily, said they were beginning an indefinite strike and would take only water.

headline: New Hampshire Ratings Lowered
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating of the New Hampshire Municipal Bond Bank's state-guaranteed bonds to AA-minus from AA, and it downgraded the bank's moral obligation bonds to Aminus from A.   The action reflects the state's continuing fiscal imbalance, Standard & Poor's said. New Hampshire plans to sell $17.7 million in new bonds today.

headline: TRADING HEAVY
abstract: Stock prices fell yesterday in heavy trading after an explosive early rally based on hopes of lower interest rates evaporated. Traders cited rumors, later denied, about errors in Friday's money supply figures, as well as underlying caution.   At the conclusion of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 10.67 points, to 1,229.07, after having been ahead almost 18 points in the first half-hour of trading.   At that time, it exceeded the record close in the key barometer of 1,248.30, set on June 6, by almost 9 points. The Dow ended at 1,239.74 on Friday.

headline: MANUFACTURING IN U.S. CALLED SOUND BY A STUDY
abstract: Is America's industrial base deteriorating?    Proponents of industrial policy, who would like the Government to develop policies to help specific industries, say yes. They contend that, without such a policy, American manufacturers cannot hold their own against foreign competitors that are aided, or propped up, by their governments.   But a recent study that is attracting attention in economic and business circles concludes that manufacturing in the United States is basically sound. The study, by Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, will be expanded upon in a book, ''Can America Compete?'' It is to be published early next year by Brookings, a research group in Washington.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Avis Rent A Car System Inc., Garden City, L.I., has appointed Robert J. McKenna senior vice president and general manager.     * Dominion Bankshares Corp., Roanoke, Va., has named Lacy L. Edwards senior vice president.

headline: SEMICONDUCTOR RISE HELPS INTEL SURGE
abstract: The Intel Corporation reported yesterday that a general turnaround in the semiconductor industry helped its earnings nearly triple in the second quarter while revenues grew 20 percent.   The manufacturer of microprocessor components and systems, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said its net income in the three months ended June 30 soared to $24.3 million, or 22 cents a share, from $8.2 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. The per-share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on June 30.

headline: BUSH PRAISES HUNGARY ON RIGHTS
abstract: Vice President Bush praised Budapest's human rights record today and said the United States wanted better relations with all East European countries.   But Mr. Bush also stressed that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, while seeking a ''fair agreement'' on arms control, would respond to Soviet threats to military stability in Europe.   In Rumania, before flying to Hungary, he said that even though Washington was willing to prolong the United States-Soviet arms control talks in Geneva beyond the November cut- off date, new United States Pershing 2 and cruise nuclear missiles would be deployed in Europe in December if no agreement was reached by then.

headline: Your Money; Tax Planning For Year-End
abstract: MANY individuals delay the start of their year-end tax planning until there are just a few weeks or days remaining in the year. But by that time, it may be too late to prepare the strategic moves that must be undertaken in 1983 to help save money when filing Federal income tax forms next April.   So with about three months to go in 1983, you might consider looking over your tax situation now for steps that can be taken to reduce your potential tax burden. Such actions can be either in response to actions that have already occurred or in anticipation of those to come.

headline: U.S. Aide Gets Pepsico Post
abstract: Max L. Friedersdorf, the 54-year-old United States Consul General in Bermuda, has been named vice president for public affairs of Pepsico Inc., effective Monday. He will deal with government relations and corporate public relations.

headline: People
abstract: Theodore A. Bell, Daniel S. Reid, and Robert J. Taylor elected senior vice presidents at Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago.     *Toni Meyer to join McCann-Erickson Worldwide as senior vice president, director of communications.

headline: Chrysler Plea Said to Fail
abstract: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board does not plan to reconsider selling warrants for Chrysler Corporation stock and will tell the company that in a letter, probably late this week, a Government source said yesterday.   Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of Chrysler, last week wrote the board asking that it postpone its sale of the 14.4 million warrants until a Congressional hearing on the matter is held.

headline: MONSANTO CHOOSES CHIEF AND CHAIRMAN
abstract: When Richard J. Mahoney responded to a help wanted advertisement run by the Monsanto Company in 1962, he was a traveling salesman for another, and smaller, chemical company. ''I was afraid the people I was working for would find out and I'd be out of work altogether,'' he recalls with a chuckle.

headline: Coast Hotel Sold
abstract: The British-owned Sir Francis Drake Hotel in San Francisco has been sold to a hotel-owning group in California for $25 million, Lonrho P.L.C. announced in London. The company, while not disclosing the name of the buyer, said that the sale had been made by its Princess Properties Interational, Ltd. (Bermuda) subsidiary because it did not fit into the category of conference and resort hotels in which the subsidiary specializes in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: PARIS SAYS SUSPECT CONFESSES ATTACK
abstract: The French Government said today that a 29-yearold Syrian national of Armenian extraction had confessed to planting the bomb at Orly Airport that killed six people and wounded 56 others on Friday.   The Armenian, Varadjian Garbidjian, was charged with assassination, attempted assassination and a variety of other crimes.  According to a statement by the Government spokesman, Max Gallo, Mr. Garbidjian said he was the head of the French branch of a group calling itself the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia.

headline: U.S. DELEGATE IN TASHKENT ACCUSES MOSCOW
abstract: The chief United States delegate to an international communications conference in the Soviet Union said today that the United States cannot excuse the Soviet downing of a Korean passenger plane. The Soviet delegate called the remark inappropriate.

headline: Bancal Tristate Signs Merger Pact
abstract: The Bancal Tristate Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement covering its previously announced acquisition by Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. of Japan.

headline: SUBSTANTIAL RATE DROP DOUBTED BY ECONOMISTS
abstract: Security prices surged early this week as traders speculated about the possibility of an ''easing'' in Federal Reserve policy and lower interest rates. But interviews with market participants have disclosed uncertainty about whether a drop in the cost of credit can be sustained, and, if rates go back up again, whether the economy will continue to expand.  Interest rate forecasts by Wall Street economists seem to be geared to the weekly gyrations of the nation's money supply - a big increase is often interpreted as implying higher rates, and a big decline the reverse.  Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has been making speeches suggesting that interest rates would drop if only the nation's bankers were willing to credit the Administration with getting inflation under control. But this view has not attracted much of a following in either Washington or Wall Street.

headline: HABIB FLIES TO BEIRUT AGAIN FOR PULLOUT TALKS
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy for the Middle East, returned here from Israel today and met with Foreign Minister Elie Salem on Israel's latest position in troop withdrawal talks.   Government sources said Mr. Habib had conveyed Israel's position on a possible withdrawal of its troops to new lines in southern Lebanon.

headline: FRIDAY, SEPT. 9, 1983
abstract: The Economy   The volume of financing, mostly through borrowing, soared to a record level in the second quarter, according to the Federal Reserve's latest study. If it continues, the rising demand for credit could push up interest rates and threaten recovery. Almost all of the increase came from individuals and state and local governments. Interest rates are unlikely to rise sharply, analysts say, until nonfinancial corporations start to demand substantial credit. (Page D1.)    Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said banks and other members of the financial community are maintaining a higher- than-necessary level of interest rates. In renewing a complaint voiced earlier this year, he was reflecting Administration concern that continuing high interest rates could weaken the recovery next year. The Secretary's basic argument was that interest rates should be lower now that the inflation rate is lower. (D1.)

headline: HARD-HIT SONY GIRDS FOR A FIGHT IN THE AMERICAN ELECTRONICS MARKET
abstract: TOKYO NOT long ago, the Sony Corporation seemed the ultimate consumer electronics company and the darling of Wall Street, and its pioneering Betamax video cassette recorder promised to lead the industry's glamorous new video sector.    But a bad economy, tough competition on its home turf and a misreading of the video cassette market has changed all that. Today the company, armed with a host of new products and an expanded research and development budget, is fighting hard to regain its corporate confidence - and its American market share.   It will not be a battle easily won. Sony reported that profits in the first half ended April 30 plunged 66 percent from a year earlier, to $45 million. The drop was due mostly to severe price-cutting and sagging sales overseas, particularly in the United States, which accounts for more than 25 percent of Sony's total revenues. The disappointing showing followed an even steeper decline in net income in the last quarter of 1982.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: uf1 People     *  William Green has joined Carrafiello-Diehl & Associates, Irvington-on- Hudson, N.Y., as a senior vice president.

headline: SCOTT MAKES UP LOST GROUND
abstract: The Scott Paper Company's decision last week to sell three profitable assets - its foam division, its Brown Jordan furniture division and 240,000 acres of Northwest timberland - was viewed by some as mainly an attempt to frustrate Scott's major shareholder, Brascan Ltd., which has said it wants to increase its stake in Scott.   But the move was also rooted in perhaps Scott's most bruising marketing battle to date, a fight, more than a decade ago, with its chief rival, the Procter & Gamble Company, and others, for a bigger share of the paper towel, toilet paper and tissue markets.  Scott is the world's largest producer of what the industry calls personal paper products. And it is still fiercely competitive with P. & G., since both hold roughly a 25 percent share of the national toilet paper and paper towel market. In facial tissues, however, it has about 10 percent of the market, compared with nearly 50 percent for the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which makes Kleenex.

headline: THE GIANT AND ITS NEW PEANUT
abstract: The Peanut is coming, and the home computer industry is preparing for yet another shock.   The Peanut is the long-awaited entry into the home computer market by the International Business Machines Corporation. And many say that its introduction - probably by October - will be as important an event in the volatile industry as the huge, unexpected losses earlier this year at Warner Communications' Atari unit and at Texas Instruments.   ''I.B.M. is about to redefine the home market for computers,'' said David Lawrence, an analyst for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, echoing a common view. ''They won't be able to make them fast enough.''

headline: Spectra-Physics Loss of $10 Million
abstract: Spectra-Physics Inc., a laser development and manufacturing company, said that it had lost $10 million through a series of unauthorized foreign exchange transactions.   The discovery Friday of extensive, illicit currency trading in the past two to three months by one employee makes it ''highly likely'' the company would post a loss for its fiscal year 1982 ending Sept. 30, according to the senior vice president, Michael R. Gaulke.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fund's Success Spurs Growth
abstract: PETER LYNCH, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund, retains his big bet on Chrysler, the fund's spectacular winner last year, and he has also been building portfolio positions in Ford and General Motors, along with certain chemical stocks. Currently, he is very keen, too, on regional banks and savings and loan associations.   In a telephone interview yesterday, the 39-year- old Mr. Lynch discussed the strategies behind his giant Boston-based fund, which owns more than 700 stocks. His views are of more than passing interest to investors, thanks to Magellan's record. For the year ended June 30, the fund's total return - market appreciation plus dividends and capital gains reinvested - more than doubled.

headline: ANDROPOV URGES TOP PARTY AIDES TO SPUR ECONOMY
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov pressed his campaign to overhaul the economy today by summoning senior Communist Party officials to a meeting and telling them that the ''half-measures'' adopted in the past were not enough.   Two weeks after the Government announced a package of experimental measures intended to ease central control of some industries, Mr. Andropov in effect appealed for the support of the party bureaucracy that has played a large part in thwarting previous attempts to modernize the cumbersome economic system. Loss of Jobs Feared    Such resistance has resulted partly from the party establishment's suspicion of anything that weakens centralized direction of the nation's affairs. Partly, too, it has come from the fact that a large number of jobs would be in jeopardy if decision-making powers were taken away from senior officials on a wide scale and given to plant managers and others more directly involved in production.

headline: NIGERIA VOTING IS CALM BUY MARRED BY DELAYS
abstract: Millions of Nigerians voted today in the second presidential election held here since military rule ended four years ago. Despite widespread fears of violence, the voting appeared to be proceeding peacefully.   President Shehu Shagari deployed armed troops to ''assist the police'' at checkpoints along roads and outside some government buildings. In the absence of serious clashes, the biggest problem appeared to be disorganization and confusion on the part of Fedeco, the independent federal commission in charge of conducting the elections.

headline: Soviet Jails Antiwar Activist
abstract: A member of an unofficial Soviet antiwar group has been jailed for 15 days for the second time this year, his wife said today. The activist, Vladimir Fleishgakker, was seized at his home here Tuesday, taken to court and convicted on charges that his wife, Maria, said were ill-defined. The couple are members of the self-styled Committee to Establish Trust Between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.

headline: New President Named For Environmental Air
abstract: Richard V. Dempster, a longtime executive at the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, has been named president of Environmental Air Control Inc., a Hagerstown, Md., company that produces contamination control systems - ''clean rooms'' - for industry and medicine.   Mr. Dempster, 55, started at Black & Decker, which is also based in Maryland, in 1951 as a service repairman.

headline: Psychiatric Group's Chief To Seek East-West Unity
abstract: The World Psychiatric Association's new president promised today to smooth an East-West dispute in the organization.

headline: Brazil's Industrial Center Faces Strike Shutdown
abstract: Sao Paulo, the largest industrial center in South America, faced a virtual shutdown today after transport workers voted to back a 24-hour strike called by other unions to protest the military Government's economic policies.

headline: CHURCH DENIES IT HAS POLITICAL GOALS IN GUATEMALA
abstract: Officials of a California church that counts among its followers the deposed President of Guatemala, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, deny having political ambitions and disagree with those who say their sect and other Protestant churches are being manipulated by conservative forces in Latin America.    Resentment about General Rios Montt's outspoken advocacy of a fundamentalist Protestant theology in a traditionally Roman Catholic country is widely believed to have been a factor in Monday's coup led by the Defense Minister, Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.   Along with several officials he had appointed to high posts, General Rios Montt belongs to the Christian Church of the Word, one of more than 45 congregations in seven countries affiliated with Gospel Outreach, an evangelical Pentecostal church with headquarters in this logging and fishing town of 24,000 people 270 miles northwest of San Francisco.   That the fundamentalist church, which occupies a few modest buildings and is best known for giving refuge to runaways, former drug addicts and other troubled ''street people'' in an abandoned Coast Guard lighthouse, has figured prominently in such an event has surprised many people here.

headline: Key Banks Inc.  To Buy Units
abstract: The Bank of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 29 of its upstate branches to Key Banks Inc. of Albany, which has been aggressively expanding in New York and New England.   Neither company would disclose the purchase price of the branches, which have $540 million in deposits, but banking sources put the figure at about $25 million.

headline: REAGAN UPGRADING LEBANON PRESENCE
abstract: President Reagan has authorized ''aggressive self-defense'' tactics to protect the Marines in Lebanon and is consulting with Congress on a resolution to approve a continuing American military presence there, Administration officials said today.   The officials said ''aggressive tactics'' meant the use of naval planes and guns, if necessary, to protect the Marine force that has been under fire at Beirut's International Airport.   In the consultations with Congress, James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, met today with the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., to marshal support for a resolution. Mr. Baker was told the President should seek formal backing for American military involvement in Lebanon under the War Powers Resolution of 1973. O'Neill Warns the Syrians    ''We want to work together with the White House,'' Speaker O'Neill said later. ''If Syria thinks America is divided and it can wait around until we pull out, they are wrong.''

headline: Michigan Yields Are at 6 1/4% to 9 7/8%
abstract: A $135 million issue of Michigan highway revenue bonds is being offered with yields ranging from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9 percent in 1993 and 9 7/8 percent in 1999, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.   The rating on the bonds, backed by motor fuel taxes and vehicle registration fees, were recently downgraded to A from A-1 by Moody's Investors Service; they are rated AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Proceeds of the issue will be used to rehabilitate highways in the state.

headline: Advertising; Phase 3 Of Wild Dior Antics
abstract: ONE OF THE most talked-about campaigns of the last year has to be the Christian Dior print advertising. To which the people at Lansdowne Advertising say, ''Thank goodness.''   The ads, featuring the somehow related, sometimes wild but totally fictitious Dior family, were created with the idea of raising sales of the products of 32 licensees of the Dior name through raising awareness by raising eyebrows.   Other big-name designers are always getting their names in gossip columns, and that is beneficial to their licensees. But Christian Dior has been dead since 1957, and this advertising is intended to make the news he can no longer make himself. It is also the first umbrella Dior advertising to benefit franchises, just like Century 21 or Burger King.

headline: Advertising; New TV Tactics for Broadway
abstract: WHO'S more likely to squeeze the most promotion potential out of television advertising on behalf of a Broadway show than a showman who is also a former adman.   Mitch Leigh is the name. Music is the game. From jingles to ''Man of La Mancha,'' he's done it all.

headline: MGM Suing Taurus-Film
abstract: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has filed a $960 million lawsuit that accuses a major European film distribution company of price-fixing and restraint of trade.   The suit, filed Friday in the United States District Court here, accuses the Taurus-Film Company, of Munich, West Germany, its chief executive, Leo Kirch, and its American business agent, Milton A. Rudin, a Los Angeles attorney, of conspiring to restrain trade and fix prices in the distribution of American films to television stations in German-speaking areas of Europe.

headline: 10% OF BALDWIN ASSETS IS CARRIED AS GOOD WILL
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation disclosed last night that 10 percent of its assets, nearly $1 billion, are carried as good will, an intangible asset that Baldwin might be forced to write off as its financial problems eat away at its reputation.   Baldwin, a financial services conglomerate that deals mostly in insurance, also reported that the Securities and Exchange Commission had authorized a formal investigation into possible violations of securities laws.   The new details became available in the company's 10-Q report filed shortly before the S.E.C. office in Washington closed at 5:30 P.M.  The report is a quarterly statement detailing the financial condition of a publicly held company. Analysts Express Surprise   Analysts expressed surprise that Baldwin still lists so much in good will, which is the monetary value that a company places on its public reputation. If Baldwin were forced to write off that much, their creditors might be inclined to force them into bankruptcy, analysts said. The creditors have postponed debt payments as part of an effort to help revive Baldwin.

headline: Merger Talks At Harris Bank
abstract: The Harris Bank corporation, owner of Chicago's third-largest bank, said yesterday that merger talks with a group it identified only as a major international bank were continuing ''on an intensive basis.'' It said it would be ''inappropriate'' to give details until an agreement was reached.

headline: PATENTS ; Helping Computers Understand Speech
abstract: Because of variations in sound combinations, it has been technologically difficult for a computer to understand human speech, particularly continuous speech.

headline: Advertising; 'Peanut' Campaign Awaited
abstract: IF anyone's heart leapt with anticipation of revelation at the sight of   International Business Machines and Lord Geller Federico Einstein listed together in a program for an advertising workshop yesterday, he was disappointed.   The agency's representatives had nothing to say to the magazine crowd or their supporters about the mysterious ''Peanut'' computer that everyone is convinced will soon be coming from their client.   Not that I.B.M. has ever said it had such a product or that it was assigning its advertising to the same agency that does its corporate print advertising or the campaign for its existing personal computer. People just ''know,'' that's all.

headline: ACCOUNTANT IS CHOSEN FOR STANDARDS BOARD
abstract: Colleagues describe Raymond C. Lauver, who has been appointed to the Financial Accounting Standards Board, as an outstanding technician who likes to get his mind around problems, be they accounting or bridge.   The board, which was established 10 years ago, sets standards for the accounting profession. Each of its seven members earn $185,000 a year. Mr. Lauver, vacationing at the New Jersey shore, could not be reached for comment about his appointment, which is effective Jan. 1.

headline: Douglas to End Its DC-10 Line
abstract: Production of the DC-10 airliner, plagued by financial losses, tragedy and a virtual collapse of orders, is ending, the Douglas Aircraft Company announced.   Officials of Douglas, a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which is based in St. Louis, said they no longer were marketing or building the wide-body, three-engine jet first produced in 1969 and they did not expect any new orders that could revive production.

headline: U.S. ACTION CALLED PROVOCATIVE
abstract: The Foreign Ministry claimed today that the United States Navy frigate Clifton Sprague was less than 15 miles off Nicaragua's Pacific coast in ''an attitude that is clearly provocative and offensive to the national sovereignty.''   A ministry statement also said an unidentified plane fired three rockets at El Cardon island Thursday night and fled in the direction of Honduras.

headline: Polish Debt Negotiations
abstract: Talks under way between Western bankers and Polish officials on a rescheduling of Poland's commercial debts may be extended for a third day, a banking source said today. The negotiations, which started Tuesday, were to have ended today. The banks have proposed that 95 percent of the $1.5 billion of commercial debt that is due this year be rescheduled over 10 years, and that 60 percent of $1.1 billion in interest due this year be converted into short-term credits.

headline: POLICE IN PAKISTAN FIRE ON PROTESTERS, KILLING ONE
abstract: The police fired on a crowd of anti-Government demonstrators in Sind Province in southern Pakistan today, and official sources said one protester was killed and another was wounded.   Opposition sources said the shooting occurred after the crowd, which they estimated at up to 50,000 people, followed the son of a local religious leader on a rampage through two towns in central Sind.   Officials said the crowd fired on the police, but the opposition sources said the police opened fire first.

headline: S.E.C. Accord With McGoff
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has settled charges against John McGoff, a newspaper publisher accused of trying to buy American newspapers with secret funds from South Africa.   Mr. McGoff did not admit or deny the charges but agreed Wednesday to a court order barring any future violation of securities laws.

headline: NON-TREASURY OFFERING PACE IS SLOW
abstract: While many corporations and local governments are finding interest rates uncomfortably high and thus are not selling new debt issues, large Federal deficits mean that the United States Treasury has no choice but to continue borrowing, no matter how high rates are.   This week the Treasury will hold its regular weekly aucion of three- and six-month bills on Monday and its regular monthly sale of two-year notes on Wednesday. After repaying maturing securities, these financings will raise about $3.6 billion of new money for the Government.   In advance of the $12.4 billion bill sale, outstanding three- and six-month issues were bid late Friday at rates of 9.12 percent and 9.34 percent, respectively. Dealers in Government securities offered the new two-year notes to large investors late Friday on a whenissued basis with a yield of 10.85 percent.

headline: Gas Plant Costs
abstract: The Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company said it cut the cost estimate for its proposed natural gas processing plant, to be built on Alaska's North Slope, by $900 million, to $3 billion, by incorporating a process designed by BASF A.G., of West Germany. Northwest Alaskan, a subsidiary of the Northwest Energy Company, is leading a consortium planning a 4,800-mile gas pipeline from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay oil and gas fields to the lower 48 states.

headline: Spectra-Physics
abstract: Spectra-Physics Inc. said its loss from previously reported unauthorized foreign exchange transactions would be $9.4 million for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

headline: LEBANON'S TROOPS BATTLE THE SHIITES IN A BEIRUT SUBURB
abstract: The Lebanese Army, backed by tanks and heavy artillery, fought a daylong street battle with Shiite Moslem militiamen in a crowded Beirut suburb today as the focus of the Lebanese conflict shifted to the capital.   A United States Marine Sea Knight transport helicopter ferrying supplies to a Marine outpost near the street fighting in Beirut's southern suburbs was fired on by unidentified gunmen and retaliated with several bursts from its .50-caliber machine guns, according to witnesses and a Marine spokesman, Warrant Officer Charles Rowe.   Hours later another Marine spokesman, Maj. Robert Jordan, denied that the American helicopter had fired and said that what the witnesses had seen, and what the Marines earlier confirmed, was ''sunlight flashing off the barrels.'' Second Copter Involvement    The helicopter, which was on its way to one of the United States Navy supply ships off Beirut, was not hit by the ground fire. It was only the second time American helicopters had become involved in the fighting. The first was on Aug. 29, when a Cobra helicopter gunship fired a rocket at unidentified gunmen firing on Marine positions south of the Beirut airport.

headline: GARN SUPPORTS BANK DEREGULATION IDEA
abstract: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that he favored early enactment of legislation that would allow banks to enter real estate and insurance brokerage, and some securities activites. Mr. Garn said he expected Congress to pass a bill before the end of the year.   But at a committee hearing on the broad issue of giving banks more regulatory freedom, with Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan seated at the witness table, Mr. Garn, a Utah Republican, said he had some reservations about a new Administration proposal that would let banks engage in a full array of nonbanking activities.   ''While supporting some of the bill's provisions, I want to know about others,'' Mr. Garn said. He did not specify what he objected to in the Administration's bill that would speed the pace of deregulation.

headline: Stone May Hold Talks With Salvador Rebels
abstract: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America said today that he might meet with Salvadoran rebel leaders on his current visit to the area, but he declined to give any details, saying ''publicity, though interesting, kills opportunities.''   The envoy, Richard B. Stone, met with President Belisario Betancur of Colombia, who arrived in El Salvador this morning.

headline: Advertising; Ohlmeyer's Special Skills
abstract: IF there really is a move back to TV programming control by advertisers, then there will be a new agency in town that is prepared to ride the new wave.   Ohlmeyer Communications Advertising becomes an official entity on Monday at 9 West 57th Street, and unlike most agencies around it will have a distinct reason why an advertiser should join its client roster.   That reason would be the knowledge and skill to produce sports and other entertainment programming for television or cable television. It is the world that the chairman, Donald W. Ohlmeyer, 38 years old, and the president and chief executive, Philip Howort, 40, are part of.

headline: Texaco to Lay Off 400 at Refinery
abstract: Texaco Inc. said that about 400 workers at its Port Arthur refinery would lose their jobs in a series of layoffs to begin Aug. 19.   Charles Rentz, a spokesman for the oil company, said the jobs are being eliminated because Texaco is phasing out its grease making, packaging and shipping and lube oil blending operations at the Port Arthur refinery. He said the operations would be transferred to plants in North Carolina and California to put the products ''closer to the markets where they are sold.''

headline: National Can To Buy 4 Plants
abstract: The National Can Corporation of Chicago announced that it had agreed in principle to buy four manufacturing plants from the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation for $55 million in cash. National said the acquisition of the plants, which primarily manufacture beer bottles, would broaden the market coverage of its glass business.

headline: INFORMERS AIDING SALVADOR REBELS
abstract: Attacks by rebels in the eastern part of El Salvador in the last two days indicate they used information obtained from informers within the Salvadoran Army, a Western official here said today.    ''Boy, have they got an intelligence system,'' the official said. ''It is significantly better than what the Government troops have.''   The official, who refused to allow himself to be identified any further, said that the guerrillas' ''amazing'' intelligence ability had been demonstrated clearly in the fighting in the provinces of Morazan and San Miguel.

headline: Salvador Official Seized By Rightist Death Squad
abstract: A right- wing death squad said in a communique today that it was responsible for the kidnapping Tuesday of the director of economic affairs for the Foreign Ministry.

headline: FARMERS WARY ON EXPORT OUTLOOK
abstract: The new farm trade agreements with the Soviet Union and China have improved prospects for United States agriculture exports, but American farmers are not cheering yet.   True, the Soviet Union agreed to a new five-year grain agreement with the United States on July 28 that increases the minimum purchase by 50 percent. And China has returned to United States markets after the settlement of a textile trade dispute between the two countries, ending a boycott of American farm products that dragged on for most of this year.   In addition, trade skirmishes with the European Economic Community that threatened to erupt into a full- scale agricultural trade war have just about ceased.

headline: Plan to Save Transturk
abstract: Four private Turkish banks have agreed to a plan to help save from collapse Transturk Holdings, one of Turkey's biggest industrial groups, banking sources said today.

headline: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Louisiana Bonds Yielding Up to 9%
abstract: A $100.2 million issue of Aa-rated Louisiana general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent in 1984 to 7.9 percent in 1993 and 9 percent in 2002-03, through underwriters led by Citibank.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: American Business Products, Atlanta, has appointed C. H. Jones president of its Curtis 1000 Inc. unit.     * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, has appointed Lee G. Weeks chief financial officer.

headline: SEIZURE OF BISCAYNE THRIFT UNIT UPSET
abstract: Federal regulators acted improperly in seizing the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association in April and must return it to stockholders, a Federal District Court judge ruled here today.   The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, by conducting ''negotiations wrapped in a shroud of deception,'' blocked the owners' attempts to rescue Biscayne, Judge Eugene P. Spellman said.   The bank board, which regulates savings and loan associations, was instructed to meet with the stockholders within 30 days to devise a plan for restoring Miami-based Biscayne to its former owners. Meanwhile, the bank board will continue to own and operate the institution, a situation that could go on during an appeal.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: American involvement in the Lebanese crisis took a significant new turn today when the United States Navy began firing its guns not to defend American soldiers under attack but to support the operations of a Lebanese Army unit.  Today's naval bombardment by two American ships in support of Lebanese soldiers trying to hold onto their positions in the mountaintop village of Suk al Gharb marked the first time American forces had acted under the new rules of engagement given them by President Reagan last Tuesday.     The President granted the Marines in Beirut the right to order air and sea strikes to defend the four-nation peacekeeping force and Lebanese Army troops. In elaborating on these rules of engagement, the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said at the time, ''If the marines are in danger because the Lebanese Army is in difficulty, the marines are authorized to defend themselves.''   As for the marines' being in any direct danger as a result of today's fighting, the Marine spokesman, Maj.  Robert Jordan, stated unequivocally, ''There was no direct threat.''

headline: PRETORIA SHELVES UNIVERSITY QUOTAS
abstract: The Government has decided to shelve, for the time being at least, a system of racial quotas on university admissions that aroused strong campus protests when it was enacted into law by the white Parliament only two months ago.    A statement this week by the Minister of National Education, Gerrit Viljoen, said he had decided not to fix quotas on the admission of nonwhites to the nine predominantly white universities because he was convinced there was ''unlikely to be a substantial change in the composition in their student bodies'' in the immediate future.   However, he indicated that the law would be held in reserve and the situation reviewed annually to keep nonwhite enrollment on these campuses from rising to a level that the Government deems unacceptable.   The Government has never said what that level is, but it appears to be determined to keep any of the predominantly white universities from becoming predominantly nonwhite. That possibility is more than theoretical in a society in which whites account for only 16 percent of the population, but it is also fairly remote.

headline: Economic Scene; Briefing Book For Volcker
abstract: TOMORROW Paul A. Volcker goes before the Senate Banking Committee to testify on his renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. What sort of briefing material has been prepared for him as he girds his loins for his debate with such Republican conservatives as Jake Garn of Utah, the chairman; John G. Tower of Texas and William L. Armstrong of Colorado, and such Democratic liberals as William Proxmire of Wisconsin, Alan Cranston of California and Donald W.  Riegle Jr. of Michigan?   Since security at the Fed has always been a lot tighter than security around the White House or the National Security Council, as the current excitement over the Reagan campaign's obtaining President Carter's briefing papers has again demonstrated, no copy of the Fed's briefing book for Mr. Volcker has leaked or been purloined. But one can well imagine that it would say something like this:

headline: Radio Paging Experts Off on Cellular Venture
abstract: The Oleck brothers, having made their fortune in radio paging when they sold their company to Metromedia, decided not to sit on the beach and are busy developing a new company.   ''My wife didn't want me home for lunch,'' said Theodore S. Oleck, who has been in partnership with his brother, Lawrence, in the New York area for 40 years. ''I tried sitting home for about two weeks and I just couldn't do it.''

headline: Weinberger Says Koch Issued False Transcript
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger issued a statement today criticizing Mayor Koch for making public what Mr. Weinberger called ''a very crude attempt at disinformation.''   The statement was in response to a letter from the Mayor referring to a reputed transcript of a meeting between Mr. Weinberger and the Defense Minister of Saudi Arabia in Paris in May.

headline: DOW RISES BY 3.30, TO 1,225.26 CLOSE
abstract: The stock market rose again yesterday in light pre-holiday trading, recovering from its plunge earlier in the week.  The Dow Jones industrial average - ahead 1.60 points at 3 P.M. - showed little movement until the final hour of trading, when it rose to close ahead 3.30 points, at 1,225.26, cutting its loss for the week to 16.43 points. The Dow advanced 8.12 points on Thursday.

headline: SNAGS CITED IN NAMIBIA TALKS
abstract: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, arrived here today for the opening Monday of a 10-day conference on Palestinian rights. He was to spend the weekend drafting a report for the Security Council on his unsuccessful talks in southern Africa on the deadlock over independence for South-West Africa.   On a flight to Geneva from Angola, United Nations sources said Mr. Perez de Cuellar felt his five-day mission ''had not been a success'' but he had managed to ''generate confidence'' among South African officials about United Nations mediation on Namibia, as the territory is also known.

headline: ON THE SEA OF JAPAN, 20 SHIPS COMB FOR THE WRECKAGE
abstract: Off the coast of this port, strong with the smell of the sea and the fish-packing plants, a race is on for who can unlock some of the mysteries of Korean Air Lines Flight 007.   So far, the race does not seem to have a leader, although no one can be sure.   What is clear is that, within sight of each other, American and Soviet ships are busy in the northern waters of the Sea of Japan, looking for the recording system of the South Korean airliner shot down on Sept. 1 with 269 people aboard. This ''black box,'' containing flight data and cockpit voice recordings, might answer lingering questions, especially about why the plane strayed into Soviet airspace.

headline: U.S. Fights Manville Suit
abstract: The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to dismiss a lawsuit by the Manville Corporation seeking to recover money from the Government for $1 million in payments to 50 asbestos workers.   In legal papers filed in the United States Court of Claims, the Government charged that the company, and not the United States Treasury, was responsible for any claims from workers who became ill and now say that asbestos caused their illnesses.

headline: NEW DOUBT CAST ON REAGAN PLAN TO VISIT MANILA
abstract: The scheduling of a visit to China by President Reagan for April has raised new questions about whether Mr. Reagan should go ahead with his visit to the Philippines in November, a senior Administration official said today.   The official said Mr. Reagan's two-week Asian itinerary later this fall could be shortened, and that the stops in the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand could be added to the China trip next year.   This evening, however, a White House official reported that both William P. Clark, the national security adviser, and Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of the White House staff, had told colleagues that the November trip was still scheduled to take place in its entirety.   Mr. Reagan also plans to visit South Korea and Japan this fall.

headline: AS A COMPUTER MARKET FRAYS
abstract: The declaration of bankruptcy by the Osborne Computer Corporation was the first spectacular failure in a shakeout in the personal computer industry that is bound to hit many others, according to analysts and executives.   The same problems that hit the home computer industry - oversupply and severe price competition - are starting to affect the market for more expensive personal computers, which are used largely in business.   By some estimates, there are more than 150 companies trying to compete on the periphery of a business that is increasingly dominated by the International Business Machines Corporation. In such a crowded environment, and one in which technology is changing so quickly, one can go from riches to rags almost overnight.

headline: U.N. Conference Assails South Africa and Israel
abstract: The United Nations World Conference to Combat Racism ended today with a call for stronger sanctions against South Africa and criticism of Israel's policies in the territories it occupies.   Most Western delegations, while condemning South Africa's policy of racial separation, abstained or voted against the measures.

headline: Egyptian Official Calls Ties With Israelis a 'Cold Peace'
abstract: Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, described relations with Israel as ''cold peace'' today and said that no Egyptian minister would visit Israel in the near future.   Mr. Ghali said at a news conference he did not believe any ministers would reciprocate visits paid last month by Israel's Energy Minister, Yitzhak Modai, or former Defense Minister Ezer Weizman.

headline: German Yard Gets QE2 Job
abstract: The Cunard Steam-Ship Company drew harsh protests today for its announcement that its flagship, the Queen Elizabeth 2, will go to a West German shipyard for its annual refitting this fall.   British ship repair yards and unions, reeling from the loss of work in recent years despite heavy Government subsidies, protested the decision, which will send the QE2 to the Hapag-Lloyd Yard in Bremerhaven in November for work estimated to be half of the total $6.75 million refitting.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Family Circle will introduce new graphics and an 8 percent advertising rate increase with its Oct.4 issue.

headline: Scali Gets Don Q Rum
abstract: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which in early July won the Harvey Bristol Cream Sherry business from the Heublein bundle that had been resigned by D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/ New York, has been tapped for Don Q Puerto Rican Rum. It will do the English-language advertising for Don Q, which had also been in the bundle. Leading National Advertisers, which measures advertiser media spending, could only find less than $1 million spent on Don Q last year.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE PROFIT OFF
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income dropped 12.7 percent, to $96.4 million, or $1.09 a share, from $110.4 million, or $1.28 a share, a year before.  Sales fell 3.2 percent in the latest quarter, to $2.39 billion, from $2.47 billion.

headline: SOME MARINES 'FEEL HELPLESS'
abstract: At 3:15 P.M. today, the call went out that no marine on the base here likes to hear. ''Into the bunkers!'' shouted a marine to his comrades. ''Condition One!''    A siren sounded to signal the danger - Condition One heralds the most serious of threats - and troops scrambled into holes in the ground covered over with metal, the walls reinforced by wood and steel and the entire shelter surrounded by sandbags.

headline: U.S. WARNS IRAN ON BLOCKING OIL FLOW IN GULF
abstract: The State Department warned today that the United States would use military force if necessary to counter any Iranian attempt to shut down all oil shipments through the Persian Gulf.   The United States Navy's newest aircraft carrier, the nuclearpowered Carl Vinson, with nearly 100 aircraft aboard, is in the Indian Ocean along with a cruiser, a destroyer and several frigates, a spokesman for the Defense Department said.   The State Department warning is a response to a sequence of recent developments in the war between Iran and Iraq. This exchange appears to have begun with a threat by Iraq to attack Iranian oilfields and installations, according to a broadcast from Teheran today.

headline: DRUSE TAKE KEY MOUNTAIN TOWN AFTER HEAVY FIGHTING IN LEBANON
abstract: Syrian- backed Druse militiamen captured a key mountain town 10 miles east of here from Christian Phalangists after heavy fighting Tuesday.    Early today, Beirut radio broadcasts reported that some Lebanese Army positions were coming under shell fire and that Beirut International Airport was also being hit by shells.   On Tuesday, Druse groups clashed with Lebanese Army soldiers south of the capital through the early morning and much of the day.   Two United States marines were killed and three wounded at dawn when rockets, mortars and artillery shells landed in and around the Marine base at Beirut International Airport. Shells also struck the area of the Italian contingent of the multinational peace- keeping force, slightly wounding six soldiers.

headline: Mickleberry Profit Up 27.9% in Quarter
abstract: The Mickelberry Corporation, a holding company of ad agencies including Cunningham & Walsh; Laurence, Charles & Free, and Nadler & Larimer, announced its second-quarter results yesterday: They were up.

headline: Peoria Newspaper Sold to Employees
abstract: The Peoria Journal Star, the largest Illinois daily outside Chicago, will be sold to its employees, the president, Henry P. Slane, said.   A trust will be established under Federal law that will hold the company's stock for the employees' benefit.

headline: KOREAN AIRLINER CARRIED EXTRA NAVIGATION AIDS
abstract: The South Korean airliner that the United States says was shot down by a Soviet fighter was equipped not only with three computerized navigation systems but with radar that enables pilots to follow coastlines and other terrain features.    Furthermore, the crew would normally have been able to verify the proper functioning of the navigation systems perhaps two hours after takeoff when their Boeing 747 jumbo jet flew past a powerful radio fix at the end of the Aleutian Island chain.   The availability of such electronic aids only magnified the puzzlement among safety experts as to why the South Korean crew deviated from course and strayed deep into Soviet territory.   Some experts asked whether there might have been a major malfunction that could have knocked out or distorted the readings of these electronic aids. If so, why then would the crew not have reported trouble when making radio reports to air-traffic-control facilities?

headline: I.M.F. Help For Morocco
abstract: The International Monetary Fund agreed tentatively to provide about $300 million of assistance to Morocco, monetary sources said today.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN TELEPHONE MARKETING; PROFITS IN CUTTING THE CORD
abstract: Cutting the phone cord is proving to be a successful marketing tactic this year. In fact, cordless telephones - hybrids of radio and telephone technology - are the fastest-growing segment of the telephone industry.   ''Cordless phones are needed products, not something silly,'' said Carl Korn, president of the Dynascan Corporation, which supplies Cobra phone products. ''We're reaching a far greater audience than that which just sits around swimming pools talking to friends.''

headline: Mexican Rise In Oil Income
abstract: Mexico's oil revenues will exceed targets by 3 to 4 percent this year, Eliseo Mendoza Berrueto, the nation's Under Secretary of Energy, said here today.

headline: 15,000 RALLY IN SAN SALVADOR IN SUPPORT OF LAND PROGRAM
abstract: About 15,000 farm workers and their supporters from the moderate Christian Democratic Party held a march and rally today in support of the country's land redistribution program.   The Constituent Assembly plans to debate three draft articles of the new constitution that refer to land redistribution next week, and the farm workers made it clear today that they want changes in the draft articles.   As written, Articles 103, 104 and 105 could seriously set back the country's land redistribution program, according to labor leaders, some politicians and independent lawyers. The vaguely worded articles could restrict farmers' cooperatives in their choice of crops and could permit large landowners to split their holdings among family members, reducing the size of each plot to less than the minimum for redistribution.

headline: SENATE UNIT BACKS LEBANON MEASURE
abstract: After a sharp debate over the Reagan Administration's policy in the Middle East, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted along party lines today to approve a resolution that would authorize United States Marines to remain in Lebanon for another 18 months.   In most of the key votes, nine Republicans supported the compromise measure, drafted this week by White House and Congressional negotiators, and eight Democrats opposed it. But several of the Republicans echoed Democratic concerns that the President Reagan was taking the country on a dangerous and uncertain course in Lebanon.   ''I don't think any of us know where this is leading,'' said Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee. ''It could lead to direct conflict with Syria or direct conflict with the Soviet Union.''

headline: Warning on Tariffs
abstract: Tariffs and quotas pose ''a serious threat to the health and stability of U.S.-Japan economic relations'' and most should be eliminated, according to a report by a group of business leaders from the two nations. The recommendation came in a 109-page report by the Japan-U.S. Businessmen's Conference, a panel of more than 100 heads of corporations. The report was released Thursday as the group opened a two-day meeting here.

headline: Middle East Air In Lloyd's Accord
abstract: Middle East Airlines has reached a compromise with Lloyd's of London to preserve the war-risk insurance of Lebanon's national air carrier.   Insurance on seven planes that serve this war-torn nation was due to run out at midnight today, Lebanon time, but Lloyd's agreed to continue the insurance, provided three Middle East Air Boeing 747 jumbo jets will not remain at Beirut International Airport at night, Beirut newspapers reported today.

headline: Marsh Unit Appointment
abstract: Robert J. Newhouse Jr. has been named chairman of Marsh & McLennan Inc., the risk management and insurance brokerage subsidiary of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, effective Dec. 1, the New York-based company announced yesterday. Mr. Newhouse, 58, succeeds Alessandro C. di Montezemolo, who is retiring at 65. Mr. Newhouse has been vice chairman of the parent company. Robert Clements, 50, another vice chairman of the parent company, was named chairman of a newly formed executive committee of Marsh & McLennan Inc.

headline: GIBSON GREETING CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MUNICIPAL UTILITIES FACE RISING RATES
abstract: Municipally owned electric utilities are faced with higher interest rates on their new bond issues as a result of the default of the Washington Public Power Supply System on $2.25 billion of bonds.   Nevertheless, the tax-exempt municipal bond market in general has weathered the long-expected default without losing the confidence of the individual investor, the mainstay of the market.   ''There has not been much change'' in the public's willingness to buy most kinds of municipal bonds, said Steven J. Heuglin, executive vice president at Gabriele, Hueglin & Cashman Inc., a municipal bond firm. Although prices have fallen and yields have risen on municipal bonds since default by the supply system became imminent in June, the problem has been greatest for bond issues backed by revenues from the sale of electricity, and for borrowers in the Northwest.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Big Bite Inc., Columbus, Ohio, has appointed Charles L. Rioux as chief executive officer and operating officer and Richard A. Stimmel as chairman, following the resignation of Nicholas C. Maraitis as chairman and chief executive officer.     * Champion Products Inc., Rochester, has elected Gerard F. Norton Jr. as general counsel and secretary.     * Conquest Exploration, Houston, has elected to its board William B. Breed Jr., president of the Madison Fund, and Robert F. Vagt, president of Madison Resources and a vice president of the Madison Fund.

headline: FLIGHT 7'S FINAL MOMENTS: DID IT SURVIVE 12 MINUTES?
abstract: A Japanese news agency quoted unidentified military officials Monday as having said that the South Korean airliner struck by a Soviet missile had fallen in ''vast spirals'' until it reached 2,000 feet and then plunged vertically into the water 12 minutes after the attack.   The Soviet missile did not destroy all four of the aircraft's jet engines, the officials reportedly said, and so the plane managed to stay aloft with what remained of its wing. There was no indication whether any of the 240 passengers and 29 crew members were still alive as the airliner went down.   Meanwhile, Japan, unhappy with Moscow's response to the tragedy, increased sanctions against the Soviet airline Aeroflot. A Cabinet task force headed by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone approved an order today to suspend the airline's flights into Japan for two weeks.

headline: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS FEAR RESULTS OF DEFEAT IN SHUF
abstract: The three men gathered on the patio of the Lagon Yacht Club were the picture of prosperity and contentment.   But the talk at this table in the heart of the Lebanese Christian stronghold north of Beirut was not of boating or stock prices. The three men spoke instead of the possiblility of losing the good life in Lebanon.   ''The Christians are very pessimistic,'' said one man, who asked to be identified only by his first name, Joseph. ''Many of them are trying to go away, to friends in the United States, to France. It's the shock from the defeat in the mountains.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: To the Business Editor:   ''Summer Jobs: A Lesson in Economics I'' seems to me very clear evidence that we should not hasten to prolong the school year as the Commission on Excellence in Education advocates. Learning never has and never should be confined to the school room.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp.  said it had received a Navy contract with a potential value of $67.5 million to supply automated data processing support services to the Naval Weapons Center at China Lake, Calif.     * Consolidated Natural Gas Co.  said it had made a ''significant'' discovery with a wildcat well in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Market Place; Coca-Cola Without Wine
abstract: SEVERAL analysts have been recommending the purchase of Coca-Cola shares recently, but some do so with reservations. ''It's a current purchase recommendation,'' said Anton J. Brenner of Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., ''but not what you would call a table-thumping purchase recommendation.''   The company's plan, announced on Monday, to sell its wine operations is ''a major positive,'' according to another analyst, Roy Burry of Kidder, Peabody & Company.   There is little argument about that on Wall Street. The domestic wine business is viewed as a high capital enterprise where it is difficult to make a decent rate of return.

headline: Talking Business with James Akins, oil consultant; Nervousness Over Mideast
abstract: In the six months since OPEC decided to lower its oil prices and limit output, the international market has stabilized. But many American oil executives have become increasingly worried about political tensions in the Middle East.   These concerns have been aggravated by Menachem Begin's plans to resign as Prime Minister of Israel and the spreading civil war in Lebanon. Oil executives also maintain that the three-year war between Iran and Iraq, both members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, could engulf other oil producers in the region.

headline: 37 Flee Belgian Jail
abstract: Thirty-seven prisoners escaped from Tournai Jail here during the night while guards were on strike, the police said today. The strike was part of a national stoppage by public service workers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Consolidated Foods Corp., Chicago, announced the sale of L'erin Cosmetics to Andrea Products Corp.; terms were not disclosed.     * E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.  said it would begin construction in November on a multimillion dollar project at its Corpus Christi, Tex., plant to provide for the production of chloroform and carbon tetrachloride.     * Exxon Corp.  has increased the prices for some of its residual fuels by 50 cents a barrel as of last Saturday; the new prices range from $27.62 a barrel for 2.9 percent residual fuel to $28.95 a barrel for 2 percent residual fuel.

headline: MARC RICH MAY FACE NEW CHARGES
abstract: Marc Rich and Pincus Green, the multimillionaire commodity traders indicted Monday for evading a record $48 million in taxes, may face additional charges of tax evasion and obstruction of justice as the grand jury investigation of their dealings continues, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.   Meanwhile, an official of Switzerland, where the two are believed to be hiding, said that his Government had begun to explore ways it might extradite Mr. Rich and Mr. Green to the United States.   Tax evasion is not a crime in Switzerland and would not be grounds for extradition, but the official said the indicted businessmen might be turned over to United States authorities if it could be proved they committed fraud or forgery for a crime other than tax evasion.   ''It is not our intent to protect a criminal,'' said Juerg Leutert, the legal attache to the Swiss Embassy, at a news conference in New York. ''And we certainly do not wish to frustrate the order of a United States court.''

headline: Technology
abstract: ONE day recently, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided that five nuclear power plants were potentially dangerous and ordered them shut down. Then, on the very next day, the commission reversed itself. Such is the tenuous position of the regulator.   Indeed, the job of any regulator - whether dealing with the environment, occupational safety or technologies such as nuclear reactors - is an exercise in uncertainty. Too little regulation may expose people to danger; too much may be costly and unnecessary. And even when moved to action, the regulator often cannot readily justify it. The benefit - usually a vague commodity, like ''safety'' - may not be universally apparent, while the cost may be more easily measured and is often sizable.

headline: White-Collar Wage Gains Decline
abstract: Lawyers, engineers, secretaries and other white-collar workers averaged smaller raises last year than in the previous two years, the Government has reported.   However, the prices Americans paid for most items also rose less last year, so the workers' standards of living were not necessarily hurt.

headline: DELTA, CONTINENTAL AIR SHOW LOSS IN QUARTER
abstract: For the first time in 36 years, Delta Air Lines Inc. reported a loss for its fiscal year, which ended June 30. Robert Oppenlander, senior vice president-finance, said yesterday that the prevalance of discount fares had put a ceiling on revenues and higher expenses had depressed earnings.

headline: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT ON RELATIONS WITH U.S.
abstract: Following is a statement yesterday by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:    The Soviet leadership deems it necessary to make known to the Soviet people, to other peoples and all those who are responsible for shaping the policy of states its assessment of the course pursued in international affairs by the present United States Administration.   Briefly, it is a militarist course that poses a grave threat to peace. Its essence is to try and assure for the United States a dominant position in the world without reckoning with the interests of other states and peoples.   Precisely these aims are served by the unprecedented buildup of the United States' military potential, large-scale programs of manufacturing weapons of all types - nuclear, chemical and conventional. Now it plans to spread the unrestricted arms race into outer space as well.

headline: ELMHURST ATTACHED HOUSES TO HAVE GARAGES IN REAR
abstract: The plot of land was deep enough and the builder was willing, so the new attached houses that the Overlook Construction Corporation is building in the Elmhurst section of Queens will have their garages in the rear, under the structure.   To say that this placement is ''revolutionary'' would be an exaggeration. Garages at the rear, entered from a single long driveway, were typical in Queens residential construction years ago. The cars used a single entrance to the driveway from the street, at the end of the strip of houses.

headline: American Solar King Puts Banker in No. 2 Job
abstract: The American Solar King Corporation of Waco, Tex., a manufacturer of solar-heated hot-water systems, yesterday named Daryl S. Kirkham president and a director, effective Sept. 20.   Mr. Kirkham, 34, had been executive vice president of the First National Bank of Waco since November 1982.

headline: LENDING RESTRICTIONS IN I.M.F. LEGISLATION
abstract: Following are some of the restrictions on the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks in the House-passed bill authorizing an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the fund. The fund restrictions are directives to the United States executive director to oppose loans under certain circumstances. It is not clear, however, that a ''no'' vote by the United States would block I.M.F. action in all cases.

headline: Norton Simon Shares Tendered
abstract: Esmark Inc. said it had received 22.2 million shares, or 89.4 percent, of Norton Simon Inc.'s outstanding common by the expiration of the tender offer Monday.

headline: Talking Business with Britain's Sir Michael Havers; Legal Discord With an Ally
abstract: The normally cordial relationship between the United States and Britain has been strained by two legal events: the sanctions President Reagan imposed in June 1982 on foreign companies aiding the construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline, and the Federal grand jury investigation of the role of British Airways and British Caledonian Airways in the collapse of Laker Airways.   Although the pipeline sanctions were lifted last November, the Laker investigation continues. There is now a trans-Atlantic legal battle over whether Laker's liquidator is able to bring a triple- damage antitrust suit against the two British airlines in a United States court. The British have invoked their Protection of Trading Interests Act of 1980 against the grand jury action.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's repeated references in his news conference Tuesday to the Soviet Union and Cuba as key sources of unrest in Central America reflected growing frustration over the reaction to his policy at home. As the White House sees it, the public, Congress and the press have failed to appreciate the serious threat posed by Soviet and Cuban interference in the region.   It was no accident, Administration officials said today, that Mr.  Reagan returned several times at the news conference to the theme.  At one point, he ascribed the trouble in Central America to ''revolution exported from the Soviet Union and from Cuba and from others of their allies.'' Later he said, ''If you go to the source'' of violence in the region, ''I think you're talking about the Soviet Union.''   But many legislators continued to express confusion and dissent today over the President's stated policy.  The House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., was sharply critical of Mr. Reagan's defense of his policy at the news conference, calling the President's performance inept and ill-informed.

headline: 16.05 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 1,206.50
abstract: Encouraging economic news and a stronger bond market helped stock prices rise sharply yesterday in heavier trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, gained 16.05 points to end the day at 1,206.50. It was the first time that the key barometer has closed above 1,200 since July 28, when it closed at 1,216.35.   In the overall market, stocks that rose on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that fell by 1,046 to 576. Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 87.8 million shares from 71.8 million shares on Tuesday, as institutional interest increased.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.59    An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.75    Salomon Brothers' estimate for new   long-term issues.

headline: POLAND ACCUSES 6 IN DEATH OF YOUTH
abstract: Two Polish policemen and two ambulance drivers have been charged with beating to death a youth in their custody, officials said today.   The youth, Grzegorz Przemyk, 19 years old, was detained in May as he celebrated finishing his high school examinations. His funeral turned into a political demonstration, with some 20,000 people rallying for the cause of the the outlawed Solidarity trade union.

headline: Advertising; A Lehman Brothers Campaign
abstract: WHEN all around you people are talking about one great financial caper or another, but they are not giving the proper investment banker credit for pulling them off, because they don't know who the banker is - and it's your bank - the time has definitely come for a corporate advertising campaign.   So Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb will embark on just such an educational adventure next Tuesday, with full-page ads in the national editions of both The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. It will mark the first time the investment banking firm has had a sustained corporate effort, and it is the biggest thing its agency, Albert Frank-Guenther Law, has done for it since its return from a multiyear embrace uptown by Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: SPINNING MINIS AND NEW SALES
