abstract: Back in the days when Elvis was king, records were sold as either singles or albums. But with rising costs sending the list price of singles up to $1.98 and albums as high as $9.98, the industry has come up with an intermediate-sized entity that is priced accordingly. Enter the mini-LP.

headline: FLORIDA'S GLOBAL-BASED TAX PROTESTED
abstract: Companies in Florida used to complain that the state's poor education system hindered business growth. But three weeks ago Florida acted to raise more money for education by taxing overseas corporate income, and major companies have been objecting bitterly ever since.   The storm of protest is buffeting the state's carefully cultivated pro-business image and might lead to a legislative about-face.   At issue is worldwide unitary taxation, which permits states to tax the worldwide income of multinational corporations on the basis of their presence there. On June 27 the United States Supreme Court ruled that unitary taxes are constitutional. It upheld a California law that had been challenged by the Container Corporation of America, a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Apeco Corp.  said it had discontinued the operations of its copier supplies group and intends to focus its efforts on its recreational vehicle and manufactured housing operations while continuing to pursue acquisition opportunities.     * Browning-Ferris Industries said Adams County, Colo., commissioners had given approval for its Highway 36 Land Development Co. unit to locate a $15 million hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility in the county.

headline: War Worrying Oil Experts
abstract: International oil experts have grown increasingly worried that the war between Iran and Iraq, a border dispute now in its third year, could escalate rapidly because of the introduction of advanced fighter planes capable of firing missiles at oil tankers and storage facilities. The aircraft, five French- built Super Entendard planes, are scheduled for delivery to Iraq before the end of summer.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In only five days in office, Guatemala's new chief of state, Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, has moved the country's foreign policy decidedly closer to Washington's view of the causes and cures of the region's problems.  General Mejia Victores, who took power in a coup on Monday, has abandoned the inward-looking and relatively neutral stance of his predecessor, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.   He has replaced it with a vocal hard line against the left in the region and attitudes that are certain to change substantially the dynamics of regional peace efforts.   General Mejia Victores's first Cabinet change was to dismiss Foreign Minister Eduardo Castillo Arriola. The General has already taken public aim at Nicaragua's Sandinista Government, calling it ''not only a threat to Guatemala but to the whole continent.''

headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks' Growth Seen
abstract: PLUMMETING interest rates last summer touched off a dramatic increase in stock prices and a corresponding expansion in priceearnings ratios. But now, with interest rates apparently stabilizing, the consensus on Wall Street is that the continued rise of most stock groups henceforth must depend upon higher profits, rather than the willingness of investors to push up multiples.   Banks, however, offer a notable exception to this situation, in the opinion of Thomas H. Hanley, who heads bank stock research at Salomon Brothers. ''We believe multiple enrichment is inevitable for bank stocks,'' he stated.

headline: China Alters Banking Role
abstract: China announced a shake-up of its banking system today, saying a commercial bank would be established to take over the commercial role of the People's Bank.

headline: PATENTS; New Chip Design
abstract: A new design for an integrated circuit chip has been invented for use in telephone switching centers. The new chip converts analog telephone signals, which resemble waving lines, into digital signals, or strings of pulses. The inventor, M. R. Dwarakanath, assigned patent 4,404,544 to Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

headline: A Drive Against Thai Pirates Is Paying Off, U.N. Aide Says
abstract: A campaign in the waters off Thailand against pirates who prey on refugee boats fleeing from Vietnam is meeting with some success, a United Nations official said today.   Poul Hartling, High Commissioner for Refugees, who is on a four-day official visit to Japan, said, ''We have been able to cut down the number of attacks, even though they are still going on.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: President Resigns At Cities Service    After a year as an employee of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Robert H. Chitwood, president and chief operating officer of the Cities Service Company, has submitted his resignation.   Cities Service, which was acquired by Occidental last September, acknowledged yesterday that the 52- year-old executive planned to depart, but declined to elaborate on his reasons or his plans for the future.

headline: THE LESSONS OF A BOND FAILURE
abstract: IN March 1977, brokers across the nation began hawking bonds to build two nuclear power plants in the    State of Washington. The initial issue of $145 million, like most ''munis,'' sold well because of its tax-free interest income and its presumed safety.   This ritual was re-enacted 13 more times, and by the spring of 1981, the Washington Public Power Supply System had sold $2.25 billion in bonds for the two plants. Major Wall Street investment houses, in the time-honored tradition of underwriting, bought the bonds and resold them at a profit, frequently to small investors who were saving for retirement and considered the paper gilt-edged.   While the bond sales were taking place, however, basic questions were being raised about the economic viability of the power plants. One warning, in fact, was sounded by the Seattle City Council before the first bond was ever sold, when it decided not to be a customer for the electricity that the two nuclear plants were to produce. The decision was based on a detailed study that said demand for electricity in the Northwest could be met through conservation and simpler power plants.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allen Group Inc.  said it sold assets of its Cal Chrome Division in Long Beach, Calif., to Mike Wilkinson, a California investor. The new company will be called Cal Chrome Inc. and will continue as a manufacturer and marketer of chrome-plated and painted steel wheels and off-road accessories for the automotive aftermarket.     * Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., said it acquired the health care operation of Catered Living Inc. for approximately $24.5 million.

headline: A.M.C. Sales
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it expects its domestic sales to rise to 350,000 units next year, from an estimated 250,000 in 1983. Dale Dawkins, a vice president at A.M.C., said at a news conference held to introduce the company's 1984 models: ''We see a healthier industry next year and we expect to increase our penetration.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Iraq to Seek Oil in Jordan BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 24   (Reuters) - Iraq will soon   start exploring for oil in Jordan   under an agreement between   the two countries, the official   Iraqi press agency said today. It quoted Issam al-Chalabi,   head of the Iraqi national oil   company, who returned from a   visit to Jordan on Tuesday, as   saying the Jordanians would   prepare technical studies   ahead of the exploration work.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; INDUSTRIAL POLICY AND EAST COAST MYOPIA
abstract: SUNSET, like the TV evening   news, comes three hours later  to us on the West Coast. Perhaps that is why the concern over ''sunrise'' and ''sunset'' industries, which occupies such an important place in the East Coast debate on industrial policy, hasn't captured our attention in the West.  East Coast economic strategists have proposed a national industrial policy to shift resources, workers and America's future out of the sunset, heavy industries that they feel can no longer compete, such as textiles, garments, steel, machinery (the list has no boundary) and into high-technology sunrise industries such as microelectronics, computers and biotechnology, that they've seen on their visits to Silicon Valley.  Such a policy makes no sense politically. It pits the few folks working in ''officially'' designated, high-technology sectors against the battalions of auto workers, steelworkers, textile workers - in fact, almost everyone - and tells that vast majority to organize its own demise.

headline: MARC RICH PAPERS SEIZED AT AIRPORT
abstract: Acting on a late-night tip, United States agents rushed to Kennedy International Airport Monday night, halted a jet about to depart for Switzerland and seized two steamer trunks that the Government said were packed with documents subpoenaed more than a year ago from a commodity trader, Marc Rich & Company International Ltd.   Federal agents sealed the trunks and brought them to the United States Courthouse in lower Manhattan, where they were placed under the protection of United States marshals.   Then, at a court hearing yesterday morning, Federal Judge Leonard B. Sand ordered the firm that recently acquired Marc Rich International, Clarendon Ltd., to turn over by noon today subpoenaed documents that have not yet been delivered.   Visibly angered, Judge Sand told lawyers for Clarendon:   ''Within 24 hours from noon today, every single piece of paper in control of Clarendon from outside the United States is to be sent to the custody of this court. Failure to comply with that will be a violation of this court's order and will bring further actions.''

headline: Michigan General Acquisition Plan
abstract: The Michigan General Corporation said today that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the retail lumber and building products division of Diamond International Inc. for $120 million in cash, stock and notes.   Michigan General said the Diamond unit, which includes 97 homebuilding centers and lumber yards in 15 states, had revenues of $207 million last year. It said all the purchase price, except for common stock to be issued, would be refinanced.

headline: Bush, in Algiers, Says U.S. Respects True Nonalignment
abstract: Vice President Bush said today that the United States respected genuine nonalignment but rejected the idea of a ''natural alliance'' between nations that espouse nonalignment and the Eastern bloc.   Mr. Bush, who arrived here Tuesday on the second leg of a tour of three North African countries, was speaking to students of the National School of Administration after several hours of talks with President Chadli Bendjedid.

headline: Times Co. Payout
abstract: Directors of The New York Times Company increased the dividend on the company's class A and class B common stock yesterday to an annual rate of $1.40 a share, from $1.22 a share.

headline: FOR RUSSIANS, BREZHNEV IS A FADING MEMORY
abstract: The bronze plaque on the wall above the sidewalk at 26 Kutuzovsky Prospekt is of a size and style that the Soviet system reserves for its most honored citizens.    The inscription, beside a bas-relief sculpture, reads:   ''In this building, from 1952 to 1982, lived the outstanding leader of the Communist Party and Soviet Government, of the international Communist and working class movement, four times Hero of the Soviet Union and Hero of Socialist Labor, Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev.''   Beneath, on a brass shelf, is a cellophane-wrapped bouquet of gladioli, badly wilted, and a potted plant that looks as if it could use some water.   A K.G.B. guard with a poorly concealed walkie-talkie stands a few feet away, on duty to protect other Soviet leaders who live in the building. But people pass by on the sidewalk with barely a glance at the memorial to the man who, until nine months ago, was the country's supreme leader.

headline: 4 WESTERN NATIONS CONFER ON BEIRUT
abstract: The United States and the three other Western countries with soldiers in Lebanon met yesterday for the first time since the cease-fire and agreed on the need to keep their troops there to support the Lebanese Government, an American spokesman said.   In addition, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the foreign ministers of Britain, France and Italy discussed the establishment of a 600-man observer corps, to be somehow affiliated with the United Nations, to police the cease-fire, a senior American official said. The cease-fire agreement, made public in Beirut on Monday, said only that ''the truce will be policed by neutral observers'' without specifying who they should be.   The official said that Syria, whose support is needed for the cease-fire to work, has so far not been in favor of the United Nations being involved, and has said it would prefer to invite certain nations individually to send observers.

headline: Reagan's Conference With Reporters Is Off
abstract: President Reagan will not hold a news conference this week, a White House spokesman said today.   White House aides had indicated earlier that Mr. Reagan would meet formally with reporters Wednesday, after a two-month lapse.

headline: COAL-SLURRY BILL LOSES IN HOUSE
abstract: The House of Representatives, by a surprisingly large 53-vote margin, defeated a bill today that would have cleared the way for construction of underground pipelines to transport coal.   The vote, a major victory for railroads, which were joined by farmers and environmentalists, was regarded as ending any chance that coal-slurry legislation will be enacted before 1985 at the earliest. Nine pipelines now on sponsors' drawing boards to carry coal from mines to electric utility plants are unlikely to be built without the emiment domain authority contained in the bill.   That authority would let the slurry companies lay their pipelines on private property without the consent of the owners provided the companies paid fair compensation to the property owners.

headline: Dow Up 7.22; Bond Strength Cited
abstract: After two days of decline, stock prices rose yesterday in moderate trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had fallen 2.41 points on Monday and 12.02 on Friday, closed 7.22 higher yesterday, at 1,197.12, and the New York Stock Exchange index closed at 95.48, up 0.52. Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was 0.88 higher, to 164.83. Advancing stocks led declines, with 946 issues higher and 653 issues lower on volume of 74 million shares, up from 69.1 million.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: Assets of money market funds fell $527 million, to $164.8 billion, in the seven-day period that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The drop was the second consecutive one.

headline: West Germans Demonstrate Against NATO Nuclear Plans
abstract: About 200 antinuclear demonstrators were carried off by the police today after they broke through a cordon and tried to hold a sitdown blockade at the United States' Bitburg Air Base.   It was the first clash in what some fear will be a ''hot autumn'' of demonstrations against North Atlantic Treaty Organization plans to deploy new nuclear missiles in Europe this winter if arms talks between the Russians and the Americans fail.   Parliamentary deputies of the antinuclear Green Party were among those temporarily detained in a two-hour police action to clear the entrance of the camp in southwest Germany.

headline: Prices Up in O.E.C.D.
abstract: Consumer prices in the 24 nations that make up the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose four- tenths of 1 percent in July after an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the O.E.C.D. said today.

headline: Colombia Rebels Abduct An American Rancher
abstract: Leftist rebels abducted an American rancher tonight as he got off a private airplane at an airport near his hacienda, the police said. It was the third kidnapping this year of a United States citizen in Colombia.

headline: British Unemployment
abstract: The British unemployment rate was 12.4 percent in June, unchanged from a month earlier, the Government said today.

headline: OUSTED ONCE, ALIENS YIELD AGIAN TO LURE OF LAGOS
abstract: When he graduated from a Presbyterian secondary school in Accra two years ago, Michael Addo, then 24 years old, hoped to go into business. But given the sickly state of the Ghanaian economy, even the best job he was offered would have paid him in a month only enough to buy food for about a week.   So like many young Ghanaians at that time Mr. Addo came to the Nigerian capital. He found work as an apartment house guard, and on his salary he was able to afford food, shelter, new clothes and such small luxuries as a portable radio. There was even a little money left over to send home to his family occasionally.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * American Continental Corp. filed for an offering of $100 million principal amount of senior notes, plus about 1.1 million common shares and warrants to purchase about 500,000 shares, through Drexel Burnham Lambert. The offering will be preceded by a 400-for-1 common stock split, which will increase the company's pre-offering fully diluted common shares outstanding to 12.7 million.   * Dana Corp. filed a shelf registration statement for up to $100 million of debt securities, with terms to be set later.

headline: ALLEGHANY VALUES I.D.S. AT 827 MILLION
abstract: The Alleghany Corporation, which agreed on Monday to sell Investors Diversified Services to the American Express Company for $773 million, said yesterday that it would actually realize $827.5 million for its big mutual fund and insurance complex.   Wall Street analysts indicated that Alleghany and American Express, conscious of the collapse of an earlier deal between them, were both trying to present the new deal in the most favorable light.   American Express had originally agreed that, to get I.D.S., it would buy substantially all of Alleghany's assets for stock then valued at about $1 billion. This would have included a small steel company, MSL Industries, that American Express really did not want to buy. American Express backed out of that deal last month, saying the price was too high.

headline: Metzdorf Acquired
abstract: Marschalk, another of the Interpublic operations, last week acquired the Metzdorf Advertising Agency in Houston, which is 15 years old and billing $25 million. Marschalk had a four-person agency office in Houston, opened two years ago to service the Coca-Cola Foods account. It will be absorbed into the new big Marschalk office, of which Lyle Metzdorf will be chairman and chief executive.

headline: DeLorean Funds Frozen
abstract: A Federal Bankrupcty Court judge ordered today that proceeds from the sale of a company owned by John Z.  DeLorean be put in an escrow account.   Mr. DeLorean, on the basis of the pending sale, had pledged to put up at least $5 million for reorganization of his defunct DeLorean Motor Company, which produced sports cars in Northern Ireland for export to the United States.

headline: PENTAGON SAYS SOVIET STRESSES ARMS BUILDUP
abstract: The Defense Intelligence Agency has reported to Congress that Soviet military spending, while not increasing as fast as it did several years ago, is still growing more rapidly than the Soviet economy.   The Pentagon's agency told the Joint Economic Committee that the annual growth rate of military outlays, when measured in what they would be in dollar costs, slowed from 4 percent a year in the early 1970's to 2 percent in the early 1980's.   The conclusion reflects a compromise by the Defense Intelligence Agency after a debate with the Central Intelligence Agency. Until last winter the Pentagon agency contended that military spending was continuing to rise at 4 percent a year. C.I.A. analysts said it had fallen to 2 percent.

headline: Mortgage Rates At 12.21% in June
abstract: The average contract interest rate on conventional home mortgages arranged in early June was 12.21 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The rate was compiled from major lenders that arranged financing for purchases of previously occupied homes.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Trout & Ries Selected    Trout & Ries Advertising has been named agency for the United Jersey Banks, a holding company based in Princeton.

headline: LEBANON'S JETS ATTACK MILITIA NEAR KEY TOWN
abstract: American and Saudi mediators shuttled between Beirut, Damascus and Cyprus today, trying to arrange a cease-fire between the Lebanese Army and Syrian-backed Druse militiamen. But Lebanese officials said obstacles to a final agreement remained.   Military action during the day was relatively light, with Lebanese Army units in Suk al Gharb, a hilltop village overlooking the capital, exchanging artillery and machine-gun fire with Druse militiamen. Similar exchanges were reported around Khalde, which controls the coastal highway leading out of Beirut toward southern Lebanon.

headline: People
abstract: * Bernard Ryan Jr. coming to the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the new position of vice president, public affairs.   * Michael Ryan joining Needham, Harper & Steers/USA, Chicago, as senior vice president, director of media resources on July 25.

headline: Senior Cuban Official Said to Defect to U.S.
abstract: A Spanish-language radio station in Miami has reported that a senior Cuban Government official defected to the United States last week. A State Department spokesman refused today to confirm or deny the report and declined to say whether the agency had received a request for political asylum for the official, who was identified by the station Friday as Jesus Raul Perez Mendez.

headline: Correction
abstract: A report in the Prospects column last Sunday misidentified Ellen S. Levin.

headline: Talks Set on Baltic Dispute
abstract: Sweden and Denmark will hold formal talks over a disputed zone of the Baltic Sea where the Danes are drilling for oil, the Swedish Foreign Ministry announced today. It said the two countries had agreed not to sink any new test wells during the talks and that Sweden had accepted provisions under which current prospecting by a Danish company could continue in an area 15 miles north of the Danish island of Hesselo.

headline: ANDROPOV APPEALS TO BONN LEGISLATION ON MISSILES
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov appealed to West German legislators today to resist the deployment of new American medium-range missiles.   The Soviet leader's statement was couched in a reply to a group of 57 Social Democrats who had urged both the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet legislature, and the United States Congress to curtail the arms race.   Since the German letter was sent July 11, more than two months ago, Western diplomats viewed Mr. Andropov's reply at this time as a bid to assert his image as a peacemaker, untarnished by the furor over the downing of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1.   The question of whether he was involved in the decision to shoot down the plane or whether he took part in drafting the subsequent Soviet explanations has been a subject of speculation.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AT THE F.D.A.; DOSE OF DATA FOR PATIENTS
abstract: The F.D.A. is expected to come under increasing pressure to require that prescription drugs come packaged with Government-approved leaflets telling about the drugs and any potentially harmful side effects.  While the American Medical Association is now distributing leaflets for physicians to give to their patients on a voluntary basis, a recent Lou Harris survey conducted for the F.D.A. indicates that many doctors, wishing to be the sole source of information for their patients, prefer not to dispense the leaflets.  Heavy opposition from pharmacy and drugstore interests, coupled with an emphasis on deregulation, led the F.D.A. to abandon a Carter Administration plan to require mandatory distribution of approved leaflets for 10 classes of widely prescribed drugs.

headline: Wheat Pact Renewal
abstract: President Reagan asked the Senate today to ratify a three-year extension of the International Wheat Agreement. It sets grain trading rules.

headline: Anti-Chile Protests in Spain
abstract: About 20 people forced their way into the Chilean Consulate here and vowed to occupy the offices for 24 hours to show their opposition to Chile's military Government. In Madrid, 40 people protested in front of Chile's Consulate with placards attacking the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Imagic Layoffs
abstract: Imagic Inc., a once fast-growing maker of video game software, has laid off 40 of its 170 employees and said it expected more layoffs next week. The company, which is privately held, is being hurt by the shakeout in the video game and home computer business. Margaret Davis, a company spokesman, said Imagic is reaching agreements to sell off its excess inventory to raise cash, but said the company is not filing for bankruptcy protection.

headline: 100 Are Believed Dead In Rioting in Sri Lanka
abstract: More than 100 people are believed dead in rioting in Sri Lanka, according to a survey of police stations and other sources. Meantime, arson and looting lessened today in Colombo as troops and police officers patrolled the capital.

headline: White House Tax Comment
abstract: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today that the President had no plan to tax fringe benefits such as free airline tickets, discounts on clothes and use of company cars.   But a staff aide to Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, chief sponsor of a bill calling for taxes on some such benefits, said the California Democrat was expected to go ahead with the legislation.   The White House has reportedly told the Treasury Department not to support the bill.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Centex Acceptance Corp., a unit of Centex Corp., filed for an offering of $100 million of Government National Mortgage Association collateralized bonds, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.   * Texas International Co.'s offering of 100,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of 13 1/8 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1993, plus 19 common shares and nine common stock purchase warrants, was priced at $999.16, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   * The World Bank's 100 million issue of 11 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1988 was priced at 99.5, to yield 10.96 percent, through Baring Brothers & Co. Ltd.

headline: U.S. Said to Protest To Greece on Missiles
abstract: Western diplomats said today that the United States had protested to Greece over its proposal that the Common Market support a six-month postponement in the scheduled deployment of American missiles in Europe.   They said Richard Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, raised the issue last week with the Greek Ambassador to Washington, Nicholas Karandreas.

headline: 60 Pages of Ads Sold For Olympics Program
abstract: The Olympic Games are a multimedia event, although print has a more modest share. Sports Illustrated, which is producing and distributing the official souvenir program for the Los Angeles games, has already sold more than 60 pages at almost $2 million to advertisers, including a number of Olympic sponsors.   The program, with a guaranteed circulation of a million, will be between 240 and 400 pages, half of it advertising.

headline: More Mexican Oil for Japan
abstract: Japanese oil officials expect to raise imports of Mexican crude oil to 160,000 barrels a day, the contracted volume under the present long-term deal, from the current 110,000 barrels, according to a spokesman for Japan's Mexican Petroleum Import Company.   He said on Friday that a final decision about the increase, which would take effect Oct. 1, would be made at the company's board meeting on Monday.

headline: SOUTH KOREA'S AIRLINE AND ITS PILOTS HAVE REPUTATION OF BEING AGGRESSIVE
abstract: Korean Air Lines, whose off-course 747 carrying 269 people was shot down by the Soviet Union, has a mixed reputation among aviation officials, industry executives and pilots.   But all seem to agree that the Korean flag carrier is ''extremely aggressive'' in its quest for rapid growth, its bargain-basement pricing of tickets and its willingness to assume huge debts to finance its ambitious plans.   According to some airline officials and pilots, the corporate inclination toward aggressiveness is seen in the flying practices of Korean Air Lines pilots, nearly all of whom are alumni of the South Korean Air Force.   For example, there is a practice some pilots use to land their plane before others. Since ground control radar can reach only about 200 miles, a pilot will give a false position to the control tower from outside its tracking range, indicating that the plane is closer or better positioned for landing than it is.

headline: BUSH HOPEFUL ON ARMS TALKS
abstract: Vice President Bush said today that a breakthrough was possible this summer in the Geneva nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union, according to Danish officials.   Mr. Bush's assessment of the American-Soviet negotiations came in talks with Prime Minister Poul Schluter in Copenhagen.

headline: Growth Seen In Third World
abstract: Economic growth in most developing countries should accelerate during the next decade, but the pace of the expansion will depend on the strength of recovery in industrialized nations, the World Bank said today.   The bank's 1983 world development report projected economic growth of 4.4 percent a year in the developing world from 1982 to 1985 and 5.5 percent a year for 1985 to 1995.

headline: HOUSE VOTE ON I.M.F. DELAYED
abstract: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he would delay a vote on President Reagan's plan for an $8.4 billion increase in United States support for the International Monetary Fund until the Administration lines up enough Republican votes to pass the measure.   ''I don't see the sense of bringing it up if the votes are not there,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''It is up to them to do the work.'' A vote had been set tentatively for Thursday after Administration officials assured Mr. O'Neill that they had enough support for the legislation. The Massachusetts Democrat, however, disagreed with their assessment.

headline: NEW YORK PANEL SEEKS FASTER CHECK CLEARANCE
abstract: In an effort to speed clearance of checks through the banking system, the New York State Banking Department recommended yesterday that maximum check-clearing times be established for all banks operating in the state. The times would range from two to eight business days.   But because of exceptions to these maximums, 80 percent of the checks could be available to depositors in just one day, according to the recommendations. For example, one-day availability was urged for all checks under $100 and for many Federal Government checks.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF RADIO TALK OF SOVIET PILOTS INVOLVED IN DOWNING AIRLINER
abstract: Following is a transcript of the conversations of Soviet pilots involved in the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7, as made public in translation by the White House today. The United States also showed a video tape to the United Nations Security Council in which the Russian-language conversations were on the audio portion and English and Russian transcriptions were on the video part.    Times are in Greenwich mean time. The numbers 121, 163, 731 and 805 identify the pilots of the Soviet fighters who are speaking. The White House identified 805 as the pilot of the SU-15 that shot down the Korean Air Lines flight, and 163 was identified as the pilot of a MIG-23. The statements of the ground stations - Karnaval, Deputat and Trikotazh - were not included.     1756:58 *** - Roger, course 70 (degrees).

headline: No Headline
abstract: People     *  C. Ray Freeman named president and chief operating officer of Muir Cornelius Moore.     *  Kenneth A. Ash named vice president, marketing for the Satellite Television Corporation, Washington, D.C.

headline: MARCOS SHUTS PAPER FOR HINT THAT MILITARY HELPED KILL FOE
abstract: Government security men tonight raided and padlocked the office of a Manila newspaper that has suggested in recent issues that the military was involved in the assassination last month of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief opponent, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.   The officers seized newspapers, films, typewriters and other documents of The Philippine Times, a weekly tabloid whose circulation is reported lately to have jumped into the hundreds of thousands.   The army officer who led the raid, Lieut. Col. Berlin A. Castillo, carried a search warrant issued today by a civilian judge in nearby Quezon City. The warrant said there were reasons to believe the newspaper's editor had committed ''the crime of inciting to sedition.''

headline: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BankAmerica Is Fined
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation has agreed without admitting any wrongdoing to pay a $108,000 fine arising out of charges that it violated Federal regulations prohibiting aid to the Arab boycott of Israel, the Commerce Department announced today. It was the largest fine ever imposed on a United States bank and the ninth penalty imposed for the offense in the last 10 months.

headline: Broken Hill Offer
abstract: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd., Australia's largest company, said it had recommended that its shareholders reject the share exchange bid from Wigmores Ltd., a subsidiary of Robert Holmes A'Court's Bell Group Ltd. Broken Hill said it would give its reasons for the recommendation in formal documents responding to the Wigmores offer, which was valued at $3.5 billion at current exchange rates.

headline: U.S. PRESSES FOR INCREASED RELIEF AID FOR FAMINE-STRICKEN ETHIOPIA
abstract: The Reagan Administration has decided to press for increased relief assistance for Ethiopia, where drought and famine now threaten hundreds of thousands, according to officials of the Agency for International Development.   The United States effort, which represents a shift in policy, is being pursued partly through the United Nations. But officials of A.I.D., at a meeting in New York Monday, also invited all major private American aid agencies to become involved in improving food distribution in the area and asked them to formulate plans.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Belgian Aide Arrested As an Economic Spy    BRUSSELS, Aug. 20 (Reuters) - Belgium has arrested a senior Foreign Ministry official and ordered several foreign diplomats it would not identify to leave the country for economic espionage, Foreign Minister Leo Tindemans announced today.   Mr. Tindemans, in a radio interview, said the arrested official was Eugene Michiels, 60 years old, of the foreign trade division, who had been responsible for relations with East European countries.

headline: Keller Haver Sets Test Of French Lemon Juice
abstract: Next month in one small Southern town and one Northeastern city, the Keller Haver agency will be testing which advertising assertion - all natural or ''The Gourmet Lemon Juice from France'' - will work best for a product they are introducing in this country for the first time.

headline: MOSCOW ISSUES PROTEST OVER TEEN-AGER
abstract: Andrei V. Berezhkov, the 16-year-old son of a Soviet diplomat who touched off a dispute over whether or not he wanted to leave the United States, returned here today.    Barely an hour later, the Soviet Government issued a formal protest describing the Reagan Administration's actions in a weeklong tug-of-war over the youth as ''disgraceful and inhuman'' and a breach of an international diplomatic conventions.   The protest said the United States had ''grossly violated'' the Vienna convention governing diplomatic immunity by barring the youth from leaving the United States for six days.   In a possible allusion to United States diplomats in the Soviet Union, it added that ''those who resort to violations of international commitments as regards others should not think that other standards will be applied to them.''

headline: Advertising; S.I.'s Big Olympics Preview
abstract: WHEN Sports Illustrated celebrates its 30th anniversary next year, its publisher should be Robert L. Miller, at 34 years old the 10th and youngest the magazine has had.   He is also distinguished by the fact that he entered the mighty Time Inc. organization on the financial side, not in advertising sales or circulation as, historicaly, most of the corporation's publishers have done.   And certainly the high point of the anniversary year will be the Olympics, an event made to order for this magazine's editorial department and one that the advertising department will certainly make hay with. As a matter of fact, it will make more hay than it has ever made on a single issue.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE THIS WEEK
abstract: Treasury auctions of notes and bonds totaling $14.25 billion dominate this week's calendar of debt financings.   In last week's marketing effort, government securities dealers reported little investor demand for the new Treasury issues, but they said activity should increase sharply this week. One reason investors have been biding their time is the variety of interest rate forecasts circulating through the market.

headline: PARTS OF I.M.F. BILL ASSAILED
abstract: Some executives of major banks criticized yesterday amendments to a House bill that restrict bank lending as a quid pro quo for House approval of an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund.   Bank officials, in interviews, expressed satisfaction that the House of Representatives had finally passed the quota increase. But they criticized amendments that require banks to increase loss reserves for foreign loans and to restrict lending for foreign business projects that might compete with American companies.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'SSTATEMENT ON AIRLINER
abstract: Following is a transcript of a statement by President Reagan at Point Mugu, Calif., yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:    First let me just say that Nancy and I were deeply saddened last night to learn of the death of Senator Henry Jackson. He was a friend, a colleague, a true patriot and a devoted servant of the people. He will be sorely missed and we both extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

headline: EARLY DATA SHOW ECONOMIC GROWTH REMAINS VIGOROUS
abstract: The nation's resurgent economy is still growing vigorously, the Government reported today, and for the moment, inflation remains in check.   The Commerce Department issued a ''flash'' estimate for the still-unfinished July-to-September period that put economic growth at a 7 percent annual rate.   The pace is a little slower than that of 9.7 percent set in the spring, but the deceleration cheered the Reagan Administration and private economists who had worried that the recovery might overheat and fuel inflation.  'Steady Expansion'    Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said of the new figure, ''We want solid and steady economic expansion, and now we are getting it.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation's announcement that it will repay within weeks the remaining $800 million of Government-guaranteed loans that saved it from bankruptcy just a few years ago is a dramatic indication, as it was intended to be, of the sharp reversal of the company's fortunes.   It is hard to overstate the magnitude of the turnaround. As recently as 1980, Chrysler lost $1.7 billion and, at times, was just hours from failure. Now it has $1.5 billion in cash on hand and is expected to earn a profit of about $900 million this year.

headline: Michigan Agency Prices AAA Issue
abstract: A $130 million bond issue of the Michigan State Housing Development Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9 7/8 percent for interest-paying bonds due in 2008 and 10 percent for zero-coupon (noninterest-paying) bonds due in 2008, according to underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.   The bonds, which are AAA-rated by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are backed by an insurance policy issued by the General Electric Mortgage Insurance Company, based in Raleigh, N.C.   In March the Michigan agency became the first state housing authority to offer triple-A bonds when it sold a similar issue backed by the G.E. subsidiary, which does not insure the bonds directly but provides 100 percent coverage on the home mortgages that are behind the bonds.   Such insurance differs from that of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association or the American Municipal Bond Assurance Corporation, which insure the principal and interest of municipal bonds themselves, entitling them to S.& P.'s top rating of AAA.

headline: USA Today Names Its Third President
abstract: Cathleen Black, the 39-year-old publisher of New York magazine, yesterday was named president of USA Today, the nationally circulated newspaper, its third president in little more than a year.   The Gannett Company, which inaugurated the newspaper last September, also said in Rosslyn, Va., that Miss Black would become a member of Gannett's corporate management committee. Her appointment date was left open, according to a Gannett spokesman, who said ''it could be from a day to a month from now.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Hercules Chairman Agrees to Stay On    In the six years he has been chairman and chief executive officer of Hercules Inc., Alexander F. Giacco has moved the company from a troubled line of commodity chemicals into the aerospace and specialty chemicals business. Along the way, he has gained a reputation as one of the nation's hardest-working chief executives.   Analysts who follow the company became increasingly curious about whether Mr. Giacco would adhere to a longstanding company policy of retiring at 65, an age he will reach next August. Yesterday, Hercules said Mr. Giacco would extend his tenure until January 1987.

headline: B.P. Resources
abstract: B.P. Resources Canada Ltd., which is 64.4 percent owned by the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., said it planned to acquire British Petroleum's Selco Inc. subsidiary for $50 million. The price is based on Selco's being free of debt before its acquisition and is subject to adjustment for metal price variations over the next five years, B.P. Resources said. Selco operates a copper, gold and silver mine in Quebec and a lime and limestone plant in British Columbia.

headline: Mesa in a Bid To KN Energy
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company announced that it had bought, in a private transaction, 3.9 percent of the shares of Denver-based KN Energy Inc., and had offered to acquire all the rest of KN's outstanding common through a tax-free exchange that would give KN holders 3.5 Mesa shares for each KN share.   At yesterday's closing price for Mesa, $15.375, the offer comes to $53.81 a share, or about $460 million.

headline: Texas Air Order
abstract: The Texas Air Corporation, the holding company for New York Air and Continental Airlines, said it would purchase 11 new DC-9/Super 80 aircraft from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a $250 million deal. The planes, which have a range of up to 2,300 miles and carry between 135 and 170 passengers, are to be delivered in 1984 and 1985, a spokesman said.

headline: Washington WatchRobert D. Hershey Jr. G.M. and Ford Fuel Standards
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Transportation Department is looking   hard for ways to allow the General Motors   Corporation and the Ford Motor Company to avoid heavy fines for violating the Government's fuel economy standards.   The two auto makers have said they will probably not be able to meet the requirements this year and in the next few years because their bigger models are selling unexpectedly well. Thus, the companies seem to face a choice of either restricting sales of their most profitable models or paying millions of dollars in fines.   One idea under study at the Transportation Department is to permit the companies - G.M.'s situation is considered much worse than Ford's - to include high-mileage light trucks when calculating their status under the corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, rules. Another idea is to allow the auto makers to borrow against future credits. There is more flexibility than generally acknowledged in administering the standards, one official insists.

headline: HOUSE CONSTRUCTION DOWN 0.6% IN JULY
abstract: New housing construction fell a slight six-tenths of 1 percent in July, to an annual rate of 1.74 million, easing for a second month from its 3 1/2-year peak, the Commerce Department reported today.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the housing revival may well continue to weaken in the months ahead, ''especially in view of the recent climb in interest rates.''   The report said a sharp increase in multiple-family buildings almost made up for a 11.9 percent drop in work started on single-family homes.

headline: FIREWORKS FLARE FOR BASTILLE DAY
abstract: As France celebrated the anniversary of its revolution with street dancing, fireworks and a display of military power down the Champs-Elysees, President Francois Mitterrand reiterated his commitment to a tough military posture but came close to ruling out intervention in the war in Chad.   For France's leaders, it was a day for symbols and words. It was a chance for the Socialist Government to underscore its belief in a strong military and for Mr. Mitterrand to speak soothingly to a nation discouraged by economic difficulties and largely unhappy with the way his Government has handled them. Mr. Mitterrand promised that things would ''become plainly better.''   For many of France's citizens, however, the celebration of the fall of the Bastille to revolutionaries 194 years ago was a chance to celebrate.  In cities and villages throughout France the revelry began in the streets on Wednesday night and will continue tonight and into the early morning.

headline: Reports Warn of Dangers of U.S. Oil Policy
abstract: The United States is likely to rely increasingly on oil from the Persian Gulf region in the 1980's, and the Reagan Administration's relaxation of precautions could seriously damage the economy in another embargo, a report to Congress said today.   A separate report said that 10 states participating in a two-month test concluded that the Administration's free-market approach to the oil problem would turn an oil shortage into an economic disaster that would send oil prices to $98 a barrel.   Assistant Energy Secretary William A. Vaughn said, however, that that test, coordinated by the International Energy Agency, showed that letting the free market determine the price of oil in a crisis would reduce consumer demand enough to curb the need for Government action on price or allocation.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Sri Lanka Death Toll Now Put at 200    COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 31 (Reuters) - The Government estimated today that more than 200 people died in rioting across the country last week, at least 80 more than previously acknowledged.   A spokesman, Douglas Liyanage, said the figure represented deaths up until Friday.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Citicorp said an average rate of 9.628 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.459 percent at last week's auction.     *  Intel Corp.  filed a bond offering of a $80 million in Puerto Rico industrial medical and environmental pollution control industrial revenue bonds 1983, through L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.     *  Long Term Credit Bank of Japan Finance N.V.  is issuing $85 million of seven-year bonds, through Salomon Brothers International.

headline: Bloedel Newsprint Price Incentive
abstract: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a major newsprint supplier, introduced a 5 percent newsprint ''incentive allowance'' retroactive to July 1 for United States West Coast customers who purchase 100 percent of their annual contract tonnage.   MacMillan said the 5 percent price reduction, applies to the list price of $468.50 a metric ton and will be credited quarterly.

headline: SOVIET VIEWED AS INTENT ON JUSTIFICATION AT HOME
abstract: The Soviet Union's refusal to accept blame for downing the Korean airliner has not only angered Administration officials but persuaded analysts here that the Kremlin cares more about justifying the actions of its armed forces to its own people and allies than about its credibility and image abroad.   From the standpoint of Soviet foreign policy, American specialists reason, shooting down an unarmed commercial plane and then saying it was on a spying mission makes little sense because it fuels confrontation with the West and undercuts the peace offensive of the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, especially in Western Europe.   Officials here regard the extraordinary news conference Friday of Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, as evidence Moscow has been stung by Western charges and is concerned it has so far come off poorly in the struggle for world opinion, but not enough to admit responsibility.   A week ago the Soviet press was implying that a Soviet fighter pilot had mistaken the Korean civilian Boeing 747 for an RC-135, an American military reconnaissance plane. But within 48 hours the Soviet line hardened and on Friday Marshal Ogarkov said the decision to shoot down the plane was ''not an accident or an error.''

headline: China Reports Progress In Atom Talks With U.S.
abstract: Progress has been made in Chinese-American talks on nuclear energy, and the two sides have agreed to hold more talks soon, the New China News Agency said today.

headline: CRANSTON ASSERTS U.S. IS VIOLATING O.A.S. CHARTER BY AIDING REBELS
abstract: In a broad attack on Reagan Administration policy in Latin America, Senator Alan Cranston accused the Administration yesterday of violating the charter of the Organization of American States by providing funds for the ''covert war'' in Nicaragua.   ''United States policy toward Nicaragua stands in direct contravention of the Organization of American States charter, which prohibits nations from intervening in the affairs of other signatories,'' the California Democrat told some 75 members of the Council on Foreign Relations at Pratt House, 58 E. 68th St., in the first of two New York appearances last evening.   The Senator, a Presidential aspirant, called for an end to United States financing of anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua, the withdrawal of United States naval forces from the area and the curtailment of United States maneuvers in neighboring Honduras.   After his speech, which was billed by aides as a major foreign policy address, Senator Cranston drove to White Plains for the third of seven Democratic Presidential forums sponsored by the New York State Democratic Committee.

headline: EUROPEANS SEEM RESIGNED TO LOSSES IN BEIRUT
abstract: France's Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, said today that despite the deaths of French members of the multinational force in Lebanon, there was ''no question'' of withdrawing or reducing France's 2,000- member contingent.    The Government, like the opposition parties, news organizations and public opinion in general, appears to accept these losses as one of the risks the country took on when it agreed to contribute to the force in Beirut.   In Britain and in Italy, the two other European countries that have sent troops to Beirut, the French and American losses have also been accepted with resignation.

headline: Inouye to Kissinger Panel
abstract: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, has been named an adviser to President Reagan's commission on Central America, which is led by Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State.

headline: MARINES ARE NEITHER COMBATANTS NOR TARGETS IN BEIRUT, U.S. INSISTS
abstract: Text of Shultz statement, page A8.           WASHINGTON, Aug. 31- The Reagan Administration reiterated today that there was no reason to say the marines in Lebanon were the targets of Moslem militia units or that they were engaged in hostilities. It was the third such statement in as many days.    With pressure mounting on Capitol Hill for the Administration either to invoke that part of the War Powers Resolution that acknowledges that hostilities are imminent or to pull the troops out of Lebanon now that they have been fired upon, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said the situation could not yet be classified as hostilities involving the marines. Rather, he said, the marines were caught in the midst of widespread violence not necessarily directed at them.

headline: A SIBERIAN SOJOURN ENDS WELL FOR FOES OF WHALING
abstract: For seven antiwhaling activists released at sea by the Soviet Union after five days in custody, the worst moment in their ordeal came Thursday night, when their ship failed to keep a rendezvous to pick them up.   ''I was a little bit embarrassed,'' said Chris Cook, 30 years old, in an interview Saturday that began in Nome, where the vessel took them, and continued through a plane flight here.   ''We didn't want to make the Soviets spend money waiting around like that,'' he said. ''It was pretty hard to go back. We were pretty low.''

headline: New HMW Offer
abstract: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, specialists in leveraged buyouts, announced that it had raised the terms of its offer for 1.6 million shares of HMW Industries to $44 a share, from $40.

headline: Savings Bank Mergers
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had approved the acquisitions of two savings and loan associations in Florida and two in Virginia by the Metropolitan Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

headline: Record Deficit For Australia
abstract: The Australian Government expects a record budget deficit of $8.36 billion (Australian) for the fiscal year 1984, which began July 1, compared with a deficit of $4.47 billion in the year before, the Treasurer, Paul Keating, told Parliament today.   In Introducing the Hawke Labor Government's first budget, Mr. Keating said that outlays were expected to rise to $56.7 billion from $48.98 billion and receipts to $48.34 billion from $44.51 billion.   ''There can be no doubt that this budget, with a deficit increasing to an estimated 4.7 percent of gross domestic product from 2.8 percent last year, will prove to be highly expansionary,'' he said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Alaska Housing Finance Corp.  said a $100 million bond sale scheduled for Oct. 19 hads been postponed because of declining demand for loans.     * Allied Corp.  concluded a $275 million limited-recourse Eurodollar financing, maturing June 30, 1991, with an international syndicate of 22 banks, through the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.     *  Burlington Industries filed an offering of $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures due Sept. 15, 2008, through Kidder, Peabody & Co.     * Ford Motor Co's Ford Motor Credit Co. subsidiary filed an offering of $100 million of five-year extendable notes, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ZENITH ALSO CLIMBS
abstract: Strong sales of a staid old product, color television sets, helped the RCA Corporation to post higher profits and the Zenith Radio Corporation to rebound sharply in the second quarter from a year earlier.   Meanwhile, Coleco Industries, which has been a high flier in the more glamorous video game business, reported earnings growth that was not as substantial as analysts had expected.   Last year, the markets for televisions and video cassette recorders were extremely weak because of the economy and excess inventories that drove down prices. This year, the economy has improved and prices have stabilized somewhat, and both RCA and Zenith reported record sales of color television sets.

headline: FRENCH CONSULATE BOMBED IN BERLIN
abstract: A bomb shattered the French consulate building in West Berlin today, killing one person and injuring 23 others, the police said.   The bomb apparently detonated in the fifth floor of the six-story building, the police said, and caused extensive damage on the floor below, in which the consulate offices and a visitor's lounge were situated.

headline: MESA POSTS PROFIT ON STOCK SALE
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stake in the Superior Oil Company back to Superior. The deal marks the third time in the last year and a half that Mesa has come away from a takeover opportunity without an acquisition but with a substantial profit.    Mesa acquired about four million shares, or 3 percent of Superior, at an average cost of $34 a share earlier this year. Superior said it would buy the shares back at a price of $42 a share, yielding an indicated profit for Mesa of $32 million.

headline: Advertising; Eye Patch Lives On at Hathaway
abstract: WHEN the creative people at the Silverman Mower agency in Syracuse were studying the possible directions they could take their new Hathaway shirt account, they thought of the time-tested testimonial approach. But consumer research told them the man with the eye patch still had a ''residual equity.'' What to do?   Why put eye patches on celebrities, of course.

headline: Economic Scene; Recovery, But No Boom
abstract: ECONOMISTS see through a glass darkly when they try to measure the current pace of the recovery. The Commerce Department's ''flash'' report Wednesday for the current quarter showed real gross national product - the total output of goods and services, adjusted for inflation - growing at an annual rate of 7 percent. But the department cautions that, when later revisions are made, the rate may turn out to have been as low as 4.5 percent or as high as 12.5 percent.   Imagine for a moment that the moving object was not G.N.P. but a car, and a traffic cop said: ''I think you were doing 70 miles an hour, but it could have been 45 miles an hour or maybe 125 miles an hour. Anyhow, I'm giving you a ticket.''

headline: INVESTORS' SUIT ACCUSES SON OF ASHLAND EX-CHIEF
abstract: John J. McMullen, the owner of the Houston Astros baseball team, has filed a lawsuit charging that Charles A. Atkins, the son of the former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc., was the central figure in a $25 million fraudulent scheme to loot the assets of several partnerships.   The suit was filed in the Federal District Court in Manhattan last week by Mr. McMullen and the Bayshore Group, another group of investors.   It asserts that Mr. Atkins and several other defendants shifted the assets of numerous interlocking partnerships, valued at $84 million, to ''enrich themselves'' and in the process reduced the value of the partnerships to a ''mere shell.'' 'No Justification'    Mr. Atkins's attorney, John E. Jenkins of Huntington, W. Va., said his client was in Alaska and unavailable. Mr. Jenkins, however, added that he had read the lawsuit and believed there was ''no justification for the charges in the complaint based on the information I have.''

headline: BILL WOULD CURB PHONE RATES
abstract: The chairmen of the House and Senate commerce committees today introduced legislation intended to block increases in local telephone rates that would occur as a result of the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.   Their proposal would reverse a decision last December by the Federal Communications Commission intended to raise local phone rates by about $2 a month per household, starting Jan. 1, 1984. The charge would cover some of the costs for access to the long-distance networks that the local phone companies will need.

headline: Alexander Trading Halted
abstract: Trading in the shares of Alexander & Alexander Inc. was halted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at the company's request amid rumors of a possible takeover of the troubled insurance broker, one of the last remaining independent brokers.   Speculation centered on a possible takeover by the Sedgwick Group Inc., a London-based insurance company.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET OFFICIALS SPAR IN MADRID
abstract: The United States strongly accused the Soviet Union and its allies today of continuing violations of human rights; the delegate from Moscow forcefully rejected the charges.   The clash came during a session of the East-West conference. It was the sharpest in months, despite an agreement announced Friday on a broad compromise to end the nearly three-year-old conference on East-West relations in Europe.   The exchange was touched off by a speech of the chief American representative, Max M. Kampelman, to the 34 other delegations in the meeting, which was closed.

headline: New Ad Day Begins For Florist Transworld
abstract: Despite a single 30-second TV spot that appeared during ''60 Minutes'' on the CBS-TV Network Sept. 4, the people at Florist Transworld Delivery, or F.T.D., consider that their newest advertising effort really got started yesterday morning with commercials appearing during each of the three early morning network news shows.   Those spots brought with them Merlin Olsen, the chearful, bearded, bear of a man, who is trying to inject the same warmth that he delivers in ''Little House on the Prairie'' and ''Father Murphy'' to the promotion of flowers as gifts.

headline: West German Uptrend Seen
abstract: The West German economy will expand by nearly 1 percent this year and grow more rapidly in 1984, a Government economist said today.   Otto Schlecht, the Economics Ministry's chief economist, said that the nation's gross national product rose at an annual rate of nearly 2.5 percent in the first half of this year.

headline: Challenge to P. & G. Ad Leads to Modification
abstract: The question of whether a can of Duncan Hines Creamy Frosting contained enough icing to cover the cake that appeared with it in a Compton print ad was but one of the weighty matters resolved in August by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.   It was resolved when Procter & Gamble, the advertiser, agreed to modify the ad after being assured that the case was not a precedent.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Accounts     * Frequent Flyer magazine to Kornhauser & Calene Inc.     * Fidelity Group of Boston to the Bloom Agency, Dallas, for its new service center, Fidelity/Southwest.

headline: Court Approves Numex Unit Plan
abstract: The Numex Corporation, Hartford, announced that its United States Machine Tools Inc. subsidiary's plan of reorganization had been approved by bankruptcy court officials in Connecticut. The subsidiary, Numex's only operating unit, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1982.

headline: Pratt & Whitney
abstract: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group said it would invest $1.5 billion over the next eight years to modernize its four Connecticut jet engine manufacturing plants. The announcement reduced fears that the company was planning to move out of the state. The company has trimmed its work force from 47,500 in 1968 to 26,000.

headline: Dollar Bonds Show Firmness
abstract: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were firmer today in late trading after a morning during which price levels were little changed, dealers said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anschutz Corp., has acquired 2,646,301 shares, or 17.2 percent, of the common stock of Ideal Basic Industries Inc., for approximately $42.5 million.     * Bechtel International Corp.  and A.S.C. International, a subsidiary of Americn Surgery Centers Corp., are jointly seeking a turnkey services contract at a value exceeding $240 million, for three hospitals in the Middle East, the companies announced.     * Burroughs Corp., Detroit, said a unit of its subsidiary, System Development Corp., has been awarded a $60 million contract by the United States Navy for the supply of data processing systems.

headline: Thrift Unit Acquisition By a Bank
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board, declaring an ''emergency'' situation, yesterday approved the acquisition of the Perpetual Savings and Loan Association in High Point, N.C., by the Old Stone Corporation, a Providence, R.I., bank holding company.   This marked only the second time that the Federal Reserve has permitted a commercial bank to acquire a savings institution in another state.   Commercial bank holding companies have traditionally been barred from crossing state lines to link up with savings institutions. But last September, the Federal Reserve Board approved Citicorp's acquisition of the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, the first time a commercial bank was permitted to cross state lines to take over a thrift institution. There have been a number of instances, though, in which banks were allowed to merge with thrift units in their own states.

headline: American Can Reduces Stake
abstract: The American Can Company sold 340,000 shares of Paine Webber for prices ranging from $55 to $59.25, along with $2.6 million of Paine Webber convertible debentures, in July, according to its filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Kuwaiti Acts on Market
abstract: A special session of the National Assembly has been called by Kuwait's Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to try to resolve the crisis at the country's unofficial stock market, the Souq al-Manakh, which crashed last year. Numerous bankruptcies are feared.

headline: China Considers Joining World Nuclear Agency
abstract: China said today that it was considering applying soon to join the International Atomic Energy Agency, after a visit to Peking by the agency's Director General, Hans Blix.   A Foreign Ministry spokesman said Mr. Blix's discussions with Deputy Foreign Minister Qian Qichen last week on China's possible membership had been fruitful.

headline: Seoul Gas Import Delay
abstract: South Korea's plan to import one million tons of liquefied natural gas annually beginning in 1989 will be delayed, probably until the middle of the 1990's, the Resources Ministry said today.

headline: CHINA LISTS 3 OBSTACLES TO CLOSER SOVIET RELATIONS
abstract: China's Foreign Minister indicated today after a week of talks with the Soviet Union that Soviet military forces on China's frontiers were still ''subjects of major disagreement.''    The Foreign Minster, Wu Xueqian, also said he was planning to meet in New York with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union during the session of the United Nations General Assembly. Mr. Wu, who spoke before it was announced that Mr. Gromyko would not go to New York, will himself be leaving for the United Nations on Tuesday. He is scheduled to meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

headline: A Nominee for F.T.C.
abstract: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Terry Calvani, 36, a Vanderbilt University law professor, to a seven-year term on the Federal Trade Commission, replacing David Clanton, a Republican.

headline: PINOCHET ADDING CIVILIANS TO CHILEAN CABINET
abstract: Bending to public pressure, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean leader, shuffled his Cabinet today to include a majority of civilians in what officials called a step toward the restoration of democracy.   ''We believe that the Government should have a civilian base and that we military should have a symbolic presence in the Cabinet,'' said Gen. Fernando Matthei, commander of the air force and member of the junta.

headline: SANTA FE MERGER EXPECTED
abstract: Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Company, owners of two of the largest railroads serving the Western half of the nation, asked that trading in their stock be halted yesterday, amid widespread expectation that they would announce a newly negotiated merger.   Spokesmen for the two companies declined comment. Al Bradshaw, a spokesman for Southern Pacific, which is based in San Francisco, said he expected the company to make an announcement today. A spokesman for Santa Fe, Robert Gehrt, said his company's board was meeting this morning in Tulsa, Okla., and any announcement would probably be made then.

headline: Technology; Laser Surgery: A Repair Tool
abstract: LASERS are being used by eye surgeons to reconnect blood vessels and restore vision. They are being used by throat surgeons to remove tumors from vocal cords so that people who might have lost their voices can speak. And gynecologists use these powerful beams of intense light to remove obstructions from Fallopian tubes so that otherwise childless women may become pregnant.   These are only a few of the established medical applications - many of them for conditions that are otherwise inoperable - of this versatile and sophisticated tool. And its potential for further innovation is great.

headline: IN PEKING, NEW TALKS ON HONG KONG
abstract: China and Britain opened a fresh round of confidential talks today concerning the future of Hong Kong after the British lease over most of the colony expires in 1997.   The discussions, which will last only two days, were described earlier this month as the second phase of a process that began after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited China in September.  Consultations on the issue have been carried on by the two countries through their respective embassies.   The talks started about 9 A.M. at a state guesthouse in the old legation quarter of central Peking and lasted for several hours.  Afterward, British Embassy officials refused to give any details or even to characterize the atmosphere of the confidential talks. A joint statement is expected after the second meeting Wednesday.

headline: National Gypsum
abstract: The National Gypsum Company of Dallas has agreed to acquire the Austin Company, a building and engineering concern based in Cleveland, through an exchange of stock valued at about $34 million, the companies said. The transaction is being structured as a tax-free merger.

headline: Coleco Test Delay
abstract: Testing on Coleco Industries' new Adam home computer printer has been delayed until today or early next week, the Federal Communications Commission said.

headline: Jim Walter's Founder Gives Up Chief's Title
abstract: James W. Walter, who founded what is now the Jim Walter Corporation in 1946 as a maker of shell homes, has relinquished the chief executive title. He remains chairman.

headline: U.S. Investing Abroad Dips
abstract: Direct investment abroad by American corporations and individuals fell by 2.2 percent last year, the first decline since 1946, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Patents; Improving On Electric Motor Unit
abstract: WASHINGTON AN electrical device patented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has money-saving potential for private users. The unit, an improved power factor controller, senses the current and voltage of an operating electric motor and reduces the power input to what is actually needed to run it.

headline: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 272 COMPANIES
abstract: Revenues   Net Income

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 10, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Drafting a Convention Against the Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Meeting on Emergency Assistance to Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Aug. 23, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Nippon Steel Off 39% in Year
abstract: The Nippon Steel Corporation, citing depressed worldwide demand for steel products, said today that its annual profit fell 39 percent, to the equivalent of $148 million, from $244 million in the previous year.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Highwire Magazine Gets a New Name
abstract: Highwire magazine, which got its name from the idea that teenagers are walking a tightrope between adolescence and adulthood, will change the name to Teenage with its October issue.   The subtitle, The National Student Magazine, will remain the same, but the frequency will be increased to nine times a year from four.

headline: RIVAL OF TRUDEAU GAINING IN CANADA
abstract: Promising to build ''a brand new Canada,'' Brian Mulroney moved a big step toward his goal of becoming this nation's next Prime Minister by winning a landslide victory Monday in his first bid for a seat in Parliament.    The Progressive Conservative Party leader defeated his Liberal Party opponent, Alvin Sinclair, by a 2-to-1 margin in a Nova Scotia legislative district. Mr. Mulroney, a former businessman, told supporters that the victory represented ''a massive repudiation of the Liberal Party,'' adding:    ''There is no longer any such thing as a safe Liberal seat in Canada.''    The Conservatives were further encouraged when their candidate, Gerry St. Germain, easily defeated his New Democratic Party opponent in a British Columbia district. Mr. St. Germain won by more than 3,000 votes, after losing by 4,500 in the last election in 1980.   55 Percent Voter Support    The victories come while the Progressive Conservative Party is riding high, with 55 percent voter support in the most recent Gallup poll, compared with 27 percent for the Liberals and 16 percent for the New Democrats.

headline: Northwest Down 97.7% in 2d Quarter
abstract: Northwest Industries, citing continuing losses at its Lone Star Steel subsidiary, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plunged 97.7 percent, while sales declined 25.3 percent.   Northwest said that net income in the the latest three months plummeted to $1.8 million, from $76.7 million in the second quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped to $501.3 million, from $671.5 million.   The Chicago-based company said that the timing of a recovery at Lone Star Steel would depend upon domestic drilling activity, the rate at which the overhanging inventories of oil country goods in the hands of distributors and end users are consumed, and a reduction of current price discounting.

headline: REAGAN PROMISES HE WILL CONSULT ON MARINES' ROLE
abstract: President Reagan promised today that he would ''seek Congressional authorization'' for any ''substantial expansion'' in the size or mission of the Marine contingent in Lebanon.   In a letter to Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, Mr. Reagan also said that if he felt the Marines were still needed in Lebanon 18 months from now he would ''work together with Congress'' to find ''mutually acceptable terms'' for continuing the deployment.   With the letter, the President was trying to put out a brush fire of criticism that was set last week when Secretary of State George P. Shultz testified on legislation now before Congress to put the War Powers Resolution into effect in Lebanon and authorize the Marine presence for an additional 18 months. Under repeated questioning, Mr. Shultz said the President would not acknowledge the right of Congress under the war powers legislation to limit his powers as Commander in Chief.

headline: Heritage Shifts Ad Plan Again
abstract: Well, it seemed like a good idea at the time.  American Heritage magazine, from its very beginnings an advertising-free publication, decided in 1982 that it would change its ways and engage in commerce with its August/September issue.

headline: Nicaraguan Rebels Say They Got Heavy Arms
abstract: Nicaraguan rebels based in Costa Rica said today that they had added mortars, heavy machine guns, bazookas and rocket-propelled grenades to their arsenal.

headline: POLISH PRELATE SAYS SOLIDARITY ISN'T DEAD
abstract: A Polish archbishop said on arrival here today that the outlawed Solidarity movement ''is not finished.'' This statement, made to reporters by Archbishop Henryk Gulbinowicz of Wroclaw, came at a time when unconfirmed reports were circulating that Pope John Paul II had reached an understanding with the Government of Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski during the recent papal tour of Poland and counseled Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, to leave public life.   Asked about a rumor that a new Solidarity union was to be organized by the Roman Catholic Church with someone other than Mr. Walesa at its head, the Archbishop replied: ''I believe that it is pointless at this time to speak of a new union, because the other is not finished. So why a new one?''

headline: I.M.F.-Lisbon Debt Parley
abstract: Representatives of the International Monetary Fund are due here next week for talks on medium-term financial assistance for Portugal, official sources said today.   A Portuguese delegation visited the I.M.F. in Washington for preliminary talks last week, but the sources said the amount of aid had not been decided.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Spending Up Sharply For Newspaper Ads
abstract: Spending on ads in daily newspapers climbed 23.7 percent in June from June of last year, to $1.8 billion, according to preliminary estimates of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

headline: Humana Offering To Yield 13.927%
abstract: A $100 million issue of Humana Inc. 13 3/4 percent debentures due in 2013 is being offered at a price of 98 3/4, to yield 13.927 percent, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

headline: ARGENTINES REPORTED TO HAVE SEIZED 200 IN 70'S WAR CRIMES
abstract: The Interior Minister has told political leaders that the military Government has secretly detained 200 members of its own security forces on suspicion of committing internal war crimes during the crackdown on leftist guerrillas, a Government spokesman said today.   ''That is what the Interior Minister said,'' the spokesman said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week.  Monday   Treasury StatementAug.Tuesday   NoneWednesday   Merchandise Trade BalanceAug.Thursday   NoneFriday   Leading IndicatorsAug.    Farm PricesSept.    New-Home SalesAug.

headline: AMERICAN BRANDS, PHILIP MORRIS RISE
abstract: Two of the nation's three largest tobacco companies yesterday reported improved second-quarter earnings, while the third posted a decline.   Philip Morris Inc. reported a 16.3 percent gain in earnings, while American Brands Inc. had a 1.1 percent gain. R.J. Reynolds Industries' profit fell 19.2 percent.   According to analysts, all three companies benefited from increased prices and a return to a more normal pricing and distribution pattern following the doubling of the Federal excise tax on cigarettes, to 16 cents a pack, in January. Even though cigarette consumption has fallen slightly, John C. Maxwell Jr., first vice president of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. said he expected the industry to continue to improve. ''The second half will be substantially better than the first,'' he said.

headline: Western Airlines
abstract: Financially troubled Western Airlines is offering its employees up to 27 percent of the company's stock and 20 percent of its profits in exchange for pay cuts that could save the carrier more than $40 million. Western has lost about $190 million since 1980.

headline: U.S. STATEMENT ON COMMENTS BY ANDROPOV
abstract: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department in response to a statement by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader:    The world will be deeply disappointed with the Andropov statement.
