He has for the first time associated the highest levels of the Soviet Government with the pathetic charge that the Soviet shoot-down of a civilian aircraft was the result of ''a sophisticated provocation organized by the U.S. special services.''

headline: INTERNATIONAL PILOTS' GROUP ASKS 60-DAY BAN ON FLIGHTS TO MOSCOW
abstract: Leaders of a professional organization representing most of the world's commercial airline pilots called on their 57,000 members today to join a 60-day ban on flights to Moscow in protest over the shooting down of a South Korean airliner by Soviet jets.    The call by the governing board of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations could bring about ''the complete civil aviation isolation of Moscow'' by airlines operating in the non-Communist world, said Capt. John LeRoy, an American who is deputy president of the organization.   The ban was called after the board held a six-hour emergency session in London today to discuss responses to last week's downing of the Korean Air Lines 747. Captain LeRoy said the board's recommendation was expected to have the complete backing of member pilots who fly for the 17 airlines that provide commercial service to Moscow from non-Communist lands.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority's $200 million issue of 11.75 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 was priced at par, through Deutsche Bank A.G.     * Britoil Finance B.V.'s $100 million issue of 11.88 percent Euronotes due in 1990 was priced at par, through Goldman Sachs International Corp. The issue is guaranteed by the parent company, Britoil P.L.C.     * Comsat International N.V., the financing unit of Communications Satellite Corp., said it would issue $100 million of convertible Eurobonds due in 1998, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds are expected to carry a coupon of 7.75 percent to 8 percent, but final terms are to be set today.     * Denmark is issuing $500 million of floating rate notes due in 1990, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Group. Semiannual interest on the notes is fixed at 18.75 basis points above the London interbank offered rate for six-month dollar deposits.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: G.E. to Purchase Comsat Section
abstract: The General Electric Company said it had reached an agreement with the Communications Satellite Corporation to purchase the digital electronics portion of Comsat's computer-aided engineering software subsidiary, called CGIS.   Under the agreement in principle, General Electric will purchase all of GCIS common stock for about $14 million in cash. Comsat will retain the microwave division of CGIS, but will rename it Compact Software Inc.

headline: AN AMERICAN ALIEN IN JAPAN FEELS 'LIKE A CRIMINAL'
abstract: In a tiny courtroom devoid of adornment, testimony has droned on for months in the trial of an American woman whose offense was to refuse to press her left index finger on an ink pad.   Court sessions are held only sporadically and the case has not drawn great public attention. Perhaps a dozen spectators show up, some drifting off to sleep in the thick air of the Yokohama District Court.   Despite the lack of high drama, those in the courtroom are witnessing a major challenge, one of the few so far, to a law that requires foreigners living in Japan to report to the authorities and submit to fingerprinting every few years.

headline: FROM VIETNAM, ROAD TO WEST OFTEN ENDS IN CHINA
abstract: Some were expelled from Vietnam with little more than the clothes on their backs. Others paid out their meager savings to be smuggled across the border rather than face military service in Cambodia or exile to an inhospitable new economic zone.   The flow of refugees from Indochina, most of them ethnic Chinese, has slowed to a trickle from the torrent with which it began in 1978, yet it continues.   Six refugees have found their way so far this year to one of China's refugee processing centers in Ningming, 40 miles from the frontier with Vietnam. Officials say they expect farm work will found for them somewhere in the Guangxi@ Zhuang Autonomous Region, in which Ningming is situated.

headline: POPE AGAIN EXHORTS U.S. ON SEXUAL MORALITY
abstract: For the third time this month, Pope John Paul II made a major statement today condemning those who disobey the Roman Catholic Church's teaching on marriage and the family.    Significantly, it was the second time this month that the Pope addressed such statements directly at the United States.   As he had on Sept. 5, he chose a group of visiting American bishops to reiterate his opposition to what he is thought to view as a decline in morality in the United States.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Comerica Inc.  filed an offering of up to $125 million of debt and warrants to purchase debt, through First Boston Corp.     * Consul Corp.  filed an offering of $20 million of 20-year convertible subordinated debentures, through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Debt Ratings   * Central Illinois Light Co.'s outstanding publicly rated first mortgage bonds and collateralized pollution control revenue bonds were raised to AA from AA- by Standard & Poor's, which also raised the company's preferred stock to AA- from Ax.     * PPG Industries' senior long-term debt was raised to AA- from Ax by Standard & Poor's, which also raised the company's commercial paper rating to A1x from A1.

headline: SOVIET CITES ROLE OF U.S. SATELLITE
abstract: The Soviet press said today that the route of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on Sept. 1 was ''strictly synchronized'' with passes of an American reconnaissance satellite.   Tass, the Soviet press agency, said this offered additional proof that the airliner had been on a spy mission when Soviet jet fighters shot it down.   According to an article that Tass said would appear in tomorrow's issue of Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, the military satellite, identified as Ferret D, made passes every 96 minutes over Far Eastern Siberia on the night the South Korean plane strayed into Soviet airspace. Two of the passes, Tass said, coincided with the passage of the airliner over the Kamchatka Peninsula and over Sakhalin Island, where the plane was shot down.

headline: Single-Family Home Values
abstract: The value of the typical single-family home built since 1970 climbed to $70,900 in 1981, the Government said today.   The median value of homes built in the last 13 years went up $3,600 from 1980 to 1981, according to a joint report from the Census Bureau and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

headline: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS: NOT VERY MUCH U.S. CAN BORROW
abstract: Japanese schools are so closely tied to the culture and economy they serve that the question of what American educators might borrow is complex.   ''Japanese schools cannot be a model for American schools,'' observed Lou-Anne Wesler, an American who recently spent two years teaching in Japanese schools. ''But both countries certainly can learn from each other.''   Certain obvious strengths of Japanese schools clearly could be incorporated into the American system, beginning with the priority that education receives. The Japanese spend more of their national income than Americans do on education, give it a larger share of the national budget and reward their teachers, who work year-round, with higher salaries and more social status. Teachers are seen as performing a valued service to their country.

headline: Martin Marietta
abstract: The aerospace subsidiary of the Martin Marietta Corporation said it had received a $505 million contract from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to build fuel tanks for the space shuttle program. As a result of the contract, the company said it could hire an additional 400 employees for the 4,500-member work force at its aerospace operations. The subsidiary said the contract covers 26 fuel tanks and raw materials for 21 additional tanks.

headline: FIXED-RATE MORTGAGES RALLY
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages, which forced some thrift institutions to the brink of insolvency and hurt many others a few years ago when interest paid to depositors soared, have made a comeback. But the recent upward trend in interest rates threatens to again reduce their numbers.    When interest rates are relatively low, as they were during the first half of 1983, consumers want fixed-rate mortgages to lock up favorable monthly payments for the duration of the loan. Lenders, who attracted billions of dollars from depositors with their new money market deposit accounts, gave the customers what they wanted.

headline: Police in Pakistan Break up An Anti-Government Protest
abstract: Policemen today used tear gas and truncheons and arrested about 60 demonstrators in breaking up an anti- Government rally by several thousand people in the southern Pakistan town of Hyderabad, opposition sources said.   An official spokesman put the number of arrests in the Hyderabad region at 33. The opposition sources said 35 people were hurt during the rally.

headline: REAGAN SAYS U.S. IS WILLINGTO CUT BACK ON WARHEADS IT WANTS TO BASE IN EUROPE
abstract: President Reagan, calling on the Soviet Union ''to reduce the tensions it has heaped on the world in the past few weeks,'' today offered what he described as concessions aimed at advancing the deadlocked Soviet-American talks on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.   Speaking to a packed General Assembly chamber at the opening of debate in this year's session, Mr. Reagan charged that the Russians had violated arms and other agreements in the past, but declared that the United States was prepared ''to be flexible in our approach, indeed, willing to compromise,'' to win weapons agreements now. 'Door to Agreement Is Open'    ''The door to an agreement is open,'' the President told the delegates, speaking of the medium-range missile talks. ''It is time for the Soviet Union to walk through it.''

headline: WEDNESDAY, JULY 20, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Construction of new housing fell 2.9 percent during June, the Commerce Department reported. The new-housing starts had surged 19.5 percent in May, to the highest level in three-and-a-half years.  Analysts predicted further retrenchment if mortgage rates, which have climbed to 14 percent, do not recede. (Page D1.)   Senate-House conferees failed to agree on a bill repealing tax withholding on interest and dividend income. In another action, however, the committee approved - as part of President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative - a bill providing duty-free access to the U.S. for some of the region's products. (D6.)

headline: Marcos Pledges Code For Philippine Elections
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos pledged today that an impartial election code would be enacted to give his political opponents an equal chance in parliamentary elections scheduled to be held in 1984.   In a speech to the National Assembly, Mr. Marcos asked his New Society Party to pass a new code ''giving everybody an equal chance to be elected in the coming elections.''

headline: Economic Scene; The Questions For Politicians
abstract: THE most important factor affecting the state of the economy now and for the next few years is probably the 1984 Presidential election. Conversely, the most important factor affecting the election is the economy. Modifying John Keats's famous equation of beauty and truth, one might even say: Politics is economics, economics politics, that is all ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.   That may be a vast oversimplification, as some critics said of Keats's formula, but it is no mere truism. Those Presidents, such as Herbert C. Hoover, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, who allowed the economy to languish during an election year never returned to tell the tale. Those who insured economic advance and falling unemployment in election years, such as Franklin D. Roosevelt and Richard M. Nixon in 1972, triumphed.

headline: Ponderosa Casa Lupita Added by Avrett, Free
abstract: Ponderosa Inc., a chain of 600 steakhouses based in Dayton, Ohio, decided slilghtly more than a year ago to join the Mexican food revolution that is taking place in the West and is inching east. So it acquired the rights to the concept and trademark of Casa Lupita, which had three restaurants in Seattle catering to more affluent diners than one would find in fast-food operations.

headline: BIG STEEL'S PUZZLING STRATEGY
abstract: THE harsh glare of the television lights filled the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing room as a senator shot questions at David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation. The audience was spellbound and two other chairmen of major steel companies listened from front row seats. In a voice that cut through the hushed chamber, Mr. Roderick took to the defense - explaining why his company made the controversial decision to import steel slabs from Britain instead of making them here.   Once again, David Roderick was in the hot seat.  Last year, the 58-year old chief executive stunned the world by paying $6 billion for the Marathon Oil Company - an audacious move for someone who had just lobbied in Washington for corporate tax breaks to free up money for steel and other outmoded basic industries. This left many politicans feeling taken - ''We go out on a limb in Congress and we feel they should be putting it in steel,'' complained Arlen Specter, a Republican Senator from Pennsylvania - and raised questions about the company's long-range committment to steel.

headline: Brazil Repayment Plan
abstract: Brazil is seeking to delay repayment of principal on loans from commercial banks falling due in 1984, a spokesman for the Finance Ministry said today.   Earlier, Finance Minister Ernane Galveas told Brazilian journalists that Brazil hoped to transfer the $5.1 billion in repayments due next year into new eight-year loans with a two- and-a-half to three-year grace period.

headline: U.S. DENIES ATTACHE WAS IN COUP
abstract: The State Department said today that a deputy military attache from the United States Embassy in Guatemala was inside the national palace with a walkie-talkie during Monday's coup, but was not involved.   John Hughes, department spokesman, said the United States ''had no prior knowledge'' of the coup, in which Brig. Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores seized power from Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., will launch the first in a new series of advanced communications satellites called Telstar 3 today from Cape Canaveral, Fla.   * Ametek Inc., Paoli, Pa., said it had completed a previously announced agreement to buy the Microfoam plastic packaging materials product line from the Du Pont Co. for more than $11 million. Included in the acquisition are related Du Pont manufacturing facilities in Wurtland, Ky.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 12, 1983
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on Chad's complaint against Libya at 10:30 A.M. and 4 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Drafting a Convention Against the Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: THE PLATINUM ROLLER COASTER
abstract: After a three-year period of rapidly fluctuating prices spurred by inflation, most of the world's metals markets have settled back into something like their normal cycles of ups and downs. But not platinum.   Once one of the steadiest of traded metals, platinum now ranks among the most volatile. The main reason is that industrial demand is expanding for the dull gray ''noble'' metal - so called because it belongs in the highest-priced family of metals.

headline: Alaska Housing Bonds Offered
abstract: A $75 million issue of double- A-rated Alaska Housing Finance Corporation 12 7/8 percent bonds due in 1993 is being offered at 99.35 to yield 13 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Interest on the bonds is taxable.

headline: Penthouse Cuts Back Its Rate Base by 15%
abstract: Judging from what has been happening to the circulations of Playboy and Penthouse magazines, the economy has had a negative impact on hedonism, or at least reading about it.   Penthouse announced yesterday that with its October issue, it would cut back its rate base 15 percent, to 3.4 million, from 4 million, while increasing its advertising cost per thousand rate by 8 percent.

headline: OFFICIALS BLAME SEPARATIST GROUPS FOR SERIES OF BOMBINGS IN CORSICA
abstract: A police patrol boat was sunk, a police station was bombed and then sprayed with machine-gun fire and about 20 cars were destroyed in attacks during the night on Corsica.   Officials said they believed that groups seeking Corsican independence from France were responsible for the attacks. But Agence France-Presse reported today that the main separatist group, the Corsican National Liberation Front, had issued a statement denying participation in some the attacks, while remaining silent on other incidents.

headline: NEW ISSUE IN ULSTER: INFORMERS
abstract: For weeks, two ''supergrasses,'' as the police here call informers, have been testifying in separate Belfast courtrooms against former friends and allies inside outlawed republican ranks.   ''Supergrasses'' - the word is believed to stem from the phrase ''snake in the grass'' - have been used by Ulster security forces with devastating effect against paramilitary groups like the Provisional Irish Republican Army and the Irish National Liberation Army.   Hundreds of members of these groups, along with dozens from Protestant paramilitary organizations, have been rounded up by the police and held for trials in which they face conviction on evidence supplied by informers.   Officials and police sources here say the practice has been largely responsible for a notable drop in bombings and other terrorist attacks. So far this year there have been 138 bombings in Northern Ireland compared with 1,495 in the peak year of 1972. With three months remaining in 1983, the terrorist murder toll is about half the total of 97 recorded in 1982.

headline: 3 States Hold Bank Talks
abstract: The Governors of Georgia, Florida and North Carolina are engaged in preliminary discussions that could lead to reciprocal banking agreements between the three states, according to Southeastern banking executives meeting yesterday in Atlanta to confer on interstate banking.   On two separate occasions during the last month, Gov. Bob Graham of Florida has talked with Gov. Joe Frank Harris of Georgia and Gov. James Hunt of North Carolina about a reciprocal banking arrangement.

headline: U.S. BLAMES SALVADOR REBELS FOR FAILURE OF TALKS
abstract: A demand by Salvadoran rebel leaders that Costa Rica's President be a witness to talks with President Reagan's special envoy was an obstacle that prevented the talks from getting under way, United States officials said today.   The envoy, Richard B. Stone, returned early today from El Salvador and Costa Rica, where he had been scheduled to hold his first meeting with Salvadoran rebel leaders over the weekend. Mr. Stone briefed Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other top officials on the effort, which collapsed just as the talks were scheduled to begin.   Mr. Stone avoided reporters today and a State Department spokesman declined to discuss any details of the effort. But other officials said the rebels had raised several conditions, including one demand that the Costa Rican President, Luis Alberto Monge, be present as a witness to the talks.

headline: ALCOA DOUBLES NET; DISTILLERS DOWN
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America, citing increased aluminum shipments, said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than doubled from a year earlier while revenues edged up 1.6 percent. The profitable quarter followed three consecutive periods of losses.   The Pittsburgh-based Alcoa, the country's leading producer of aluminum, said profits jumped to $34.6 million, or 43 cents a share, from $15.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.26 billion from $1.24 billion.

headline: G.M. President Sees Good 1984
abstract: The president of the General Motors Corporation, F. James McDonald, predicted today that 1984 would be a good year for the auto industry and said that more laid-off workers could be recalled.   After a four-year slump in sales, the auto industry began a reversal at the end of last year.

headline: Statue of Pontius Pilate Is Blown Up in Lourdes
abstract: A group that is opposed to the commercialization of Lourdes blew up a religious statue here today and threatened to disrupt Pope John Paul II's pilgrimage to the Roman Catholic holy city in the Pyrenees this weekend.   A large bronze statue of Pontius Pilate was shattered by a charge of dynamite at 2 A.M. Fragments of the figure, which weighed half a ton, were hurled 200 yards.

headline: No Headline
abstract: C.A.B. to Seek Airline Data    WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) - The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it planned to order the five major airline marketers of travel agency computer reservation systems to submit detailed information on the workings of their systems.   UAL Inc.'s United Air Lines, the AMR Corporation's American Airlines, the Trans World Corporation's Trans World Airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc. and Eastern Air Lines Inc. must comply within 30 days of receiving the order, which is expected to be issued shortly, a C.A.B. spokesman said.

headline: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: $#D  Tax-Exempt Bonds*   9.42

headline: Lucas Accord With Car Maker
abstract: Lucas Industries P.L.C. will soon complete a licensing agreement with a major United States automotive company to use a Lucas process that enables the use of lighter steels in vehicle components, a Lucas spokesman said.

headline: Rates Up At Banks
abstract: Interest rates for bank money market deposit accounts increased five one-hundreths of a point, to 8.49 percent, in the seven-day period ended yesterday, the Bank Rate Monitor reported.   Last week, for the first time since the bank money market deposit accounts were created last December, the Monitor's average of 8.44 percent matched the Donoghue's Money Fund average, widely used to measure rates offered by money market mutual funds.

headline: Vauxhall Prices to Rise
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's British subsidiary, Vauxhall Motors Ltd., said today that it was raising prices by an average 4.6 percent on six car models, with optional equipment going up 4 percent. The increases for 1983-84 models cover improved specifications and the effect of inflation, it said.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Arizona Public Service Co.'s $100 million issue of 12 3/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2013 was priced at 99 1/4, to yield slightly less than 12.85 percent, through Kidder, Peabody & Company.  The bonds are rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service, and A by Standard & Poor's Corp. Common Stock   * Bindley Western Industries, a drug wholesaler, filed for an initial offering of 1.1 million shares - 500,000 shares to be sold by a current shareholder -through E.F. Hutton & Company.

headline: U.S. AND LEBANON TO SEEK FORMULA ON SYRIA PULLOUT
abstract: Senior Administration officials said today that they hoped to work out with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon this week a new formula toward ending the impasse with Syria over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.   But Lebanese and United States officials offered differing evaluations of the likelihood of any early movement toward a solution of the problem.   Foreign Minister Elie Salem of Lebanon, who is in Washington in advance of Mr. Gemayel's arrival on Wednesday, expressed optimism today that Syria's adamant refusal so far to negotiate a withdrawal was only a temporary, tactical move. No Fear of Partition   Mr. Salem also said he had no fear that either Israel or Syria had plans for any permanent partition of his country.  ''I am confident that we will break the stalemate and then we will have progress and phases that will show encouragement and then we can regain a momentum that I think we have lost in the past two months,'' Mr. Salem said.

headline: MISSING IN GUATEMALA: THE CASE OF ONE STATISTIC
abstract: On June 6 Lucrecia Orellana Stormont left her office at Guatemala's University of San Carlos to attend a meeting in a downtown hotel. Her family has not seen her since.   Miss Orellana, a 32-year-old lecturer in psychology, is now part of the shadowy world that so many Latin Americans have come to know as ''the disappeared.''   Her case reflects the many complicated and sometimes confusing facets of life in a society where violence always seems to be lurking just below the surface and where, in the absence of strong judicial and civic institutions, rumor and fear run free.   Miss Orellana is one of 34 people missing from the University of San Carlos, Guatemala's most distinguished center of learning.  Perhaps 10 times that number are now known to be missing from the society at large.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Banks Hold Their Own   In past economic upturns, the commercial paper market, which lends to large corporations, has made sharp gains in market share at the expense of the commercial banks. But this time around, the banks may come out ahead and wrest some of the corporate loan business back.   According to Jay N. Woodworth, a vice president and economist at the Bankers Trust Company, the volume of commercial paper outstanding over the last three months has declined at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 22.1 percent, while domestic corporate loans made by banks declined at a rate of only 5 percent.   He attributes the differential to a drop in the supply of money available for loans in the commercial paper market and a relative increase in funds available through banks. He cites the shift of billions of dollars from money market mutual funds, which operate outside the banking system, into high-yielding money market accounts, which banks began offering last December. Money market mutual funds have been the chief source of money for the commercial paper market.

headline: Walesa Returns to Work; May See Old Comrades
abstract: Lech Walesa ended a monthlong vacation from the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk today and renewed his pledge to meet with the underground leaders of the Solidarity union, which he founded.   But he declined to reveal Solidarity's strategy now that martial law has been formally lifted, or to say how the outlawed union plans to mark the third anniversary of its birth, on Aug. 31.

headline: People
abstract: * Brian J. Dillon named a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.   * Peter R. Wells named a senior vice president at Muir Cornelius Moore.

headline: Iran Lifts Oil Price 20 Cents, to $27.10 TEHERAN, Iran, July 31 (Reuters) - Iran is raising the price of its heavy crude oil by 20 cents a barrel, to $27.10, according to the national press agency, IRNA.
abstract: The agency said Saturday that Deputy Oil Minister Abbas Honardoust had confirmed the increase, which will take effect Aug. 20.

headline: People
abstract: * Venetia Hands joining D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York on Aug. 15 as senior vice president, director of research.     * Jerry Cammisa has joined Foote, Cone & Belding/New York as senijor vice president, director of TV/radio production.     * William P. Croasdale , a senior vice president, named director of network television and programming, at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

headline: Syria Claims Israeli Drone
abstract: Syrian troops shot down a pilotless Israeli reconnaissance plane today in Lebanon's eastern Bekaa region, the Damascus radio reported. Israel said the Syrians had fired antiaircraft missiles but no planes had been lost.

headline: SHAMIR SAYS HE'LL OFFER ROLE TO LABOR PARTY
abstract: Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud bloc's nominee for Prime Minister, said Saturday that he would try to bring the opposition Labor Party into a government of national unity.   But his efforts centered today on building the same coalition that has governed under Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who presided over today's weekly Cabinet meeting. Mr. Begin announced last week that he would resign. Mr. Shamir, the Foreign Minister, was elected leader of the Herut Party, the dominant party in Likud, and won the backing of the other factions in the bloc.   Meanwhile, Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, invited leaders of the National Religious Party and the Tami Party for talks this week about switching sides and joining Labor in the ''broadest coalition possible'' under Mr. Peres's leadership. Leaders of the National Religious Party and Tami said they would tell Mr. Peres that they were now committed to first give Mr. Shamir a chance.

headline: PATENTS; Structures for Bay Of a Space Shuttle
abstract: Spacecraft structures intended for installation in the bay of a space shuttle have been invented by Eugene R. Ganssle and Nelson F.  Samhammer, staff members at RCA Astro-Electronics in Princeton, N.J.  The truss-shaped structures are to hold electronic equipment, thrusters, fuel tanks and other equipment.

headline: PACKAGERS SUCCEED IN BICYCLE TOURISM
abstract: It was 11 years ago, on a weekend bicycle trip with three colleagues from Middlebury College, that John S. Freidin came up with the notion that vacationers might enjoy bicycling from country inn to country inn in Vermont.   Today, the 42-year-old former professor of American history is the owner and director of Vermont Bicycle Touring, the first and largest business of its kind in the nation.   From modest beginnings in 1972, when 75 people tried out what was then a novel concept in tourism, the business has grown to the point where this year more than 5,000 vacationers will spend a total of 15,000 days on Vermont roads - and, of course, 15,000 nights in Vermont inns.   Over the years, Mr. Freidin's success has generated a host of imitators. Just in Vermont, for example, operators have arranged inn-to-inn tours by way of canoe, horseback and hiking trail, not to mention establishing several new bicycling businesses. And in the winter, hardy souls can ski cross-country from inn to inn as well.

headline: Panel Rejects Build U.S.' Bill
abstract: The House Ways and Means Committee, questioning whether the reviving auto industry needs a ''build American'' bill, rejected legislation today that would require large amounts of United States-made parts in imported cars. Despite the vote, the plan - the latest in a series of so-called domestic content bills introduced in Congress - could still reach the floor.

headline: MARCOS WARNING ON PROTESTS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that his Government and military forces would allow no more unauthorized demonstrations.   The President, in a speech on television, warned that his orders to the military would apply to businessmen and Roman Catholics as well as to Communists and radicals.

headline: DETROIT'S CHALLENGE: CALIFORNIA
abstract: Carroll Shelby, the one-time racing driver turned auto designer, put his cowboy boots up on the desk at the Chrysler Shelby Performance Center here and analyzed what went wrong for the American auto industry in California.   ''People in Detroit think they're all a bunch of kooks out here,'' he said. ''But what the average Joe in California is looking for is practical transportation. Detroit was still trying to sell big boats that got eight miles per gallon when the imports came in here with well-built, well-finished cars that got 30 miles to the gallon. And then they were surprised at what happened.''

headline: C.& N.W. Repairs
abstract: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company said it had begun a $50 million, two-year program to repair the main line of the former Rock Island Railroad between Minneapolis and Kansas City, Mo. C.& N.W., which bought the line from the Rock Island's bankruptcy trustee in June, said it would initially spend about $15 million to install ties and surface about 500 miles of track to allow the railroad to increase its speeds. The additional $35 million will be spent later to allow further increases in speeds.

headline: POLL REVEALS FEAR OF EL SALVADOR AS A NEW VIETNAM
abstract: A majority of Americans questioned by Gallup pollsters say they continue to think the United States will become involved in El Salvador as it was in Vietnam, and nearly half disapprove of President's Reagan's policies in Central America.   According to the poll, released Thursday, 71 percent of the people familiar with the situation in El Salvador felt that it was at least ''fairly likely'' that the United States would become more deeply involved.   By contrast, 19 percent thought this was ''not very likely'' and 5 percent said this was ''not at all likely.'' These results mirrored those obtained by Gallup in March.

headline: F.A.A. CHIEF SAYS JET WAS BEYOND U.S. RADAR
abstract: Government officials said yesterday that United States military radar could track airliners flying from Alaska to Japan and Korea for a much greater distance than civilian radar, but they said that the South Korean jumbo jet shot down by a Soviet fighter Sept. 1 had gone beyond the range of United States military radar a good way before it strayed over Soviet territory.   They said military radar along the route could track aircraft targets to a distance at least 50 percent greater than civilian radar, which has a range of about 165 nautical miles. They noted too that military sites were situated farther along the route from Alaska to Japan.   This was the furthest the Government has gone in detailing the added abilities of military radar in the weeks since the South Korean Boeing 747 was shot down off the tip of Sakhalin Island. All 269 people on board are presumed dead.

headline: Indonesia's 5-Year Plan
abstract: The Indonesian economy will be projected to grow at 5 percent a year in the new five-year plan that begins next April, President Suharto said in a speech at the state opening of Parliament.

headline: French Jobs Program
abstract: France's Socialist Government today announced plans to hold unemployment to its current level of about two million. Max Gallo, a Government spokesman, said Cabinet ministers discussed a four-part plan to shorten the workweek from 39 hours to an eventual 35 hours, create jobs, improve services for job seekers and increase youth training programs.
